DOC.HEAD: Iraq to Get Jan. 15 Deadline in U.N. Resolution, China Balks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with China saying will not vote for U.N. resolution, details, edits to conform. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Iraq will have until Jan. 15 to withdraw its troops from Kuwait before it faces the prospect of U.N.-authorized military action, the Soviet U.N. ambassador said Tuesday. ``Yes, it's going to be the 15th,'' Ambassador Yuli M. Vorontsov replied when asked if there was a consensus among the five permanent members of the Security Council on a resolution. But Wednesday in Beijing, Foreign Minister Qian Qichen said China will not vote for the U.N. resolution. Qian, however, refused to say whether China will veto the resolution, expected to come to a vote on Thursday, or abstain. As one of the permanent members of the U.N. Security Council, China has veto power over any resolution. It has voted for all 10 previous resolutions that seek to pressure Iraq to end its nearly 4-month-old occupation of Kuwait, but has said it does not want force used. ``It has always been the position of China to call for a peaceful settlement,'' Qian told reporters at the Beijing airport while preparing to leave for the United States to cast China's vote. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze fixed the deadline in the last 24 hours, said Western diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity. The measure will authorize ``all necessary means'' to get Iraq out of Kuwait after that deadline. The date after which a military strike could begin had been the only unresolved issue in the draft measure. The United States had already secured agreement on the overall measure from the Soviets, French, British and - it was thought - the Chinese. The draft resolution has more than enough pledges of positive votes to pass when it comes before the full council. Most Security Council members are expected to be represented by their foreign ministers at Thursday's meeting, with Baker presiding. A resolution requires at least nine votes to pass, so long as none of the permanent members vetoes it. The measure is supported by at least six of the non-permanent council members: Canada, Finland, Romania, Ivory Coast, Zaire, Ethiopia. Initially, the United States had pressed for a Jan. 1 deadline, but the Soviets wanted it set at Jan. 31 to allow more time for diplomatic maneuvers. U.S. reinforcements on their way to the Persian Gulf will not be ready for a military strike before late January or February in any case, diplomats said. The measure would call on Iraq to release all foreign hostages, withdraw its troops and restore Kuwait's government by Jan. 15. If Iraq fails to comply, it would authorize ``member states cooperating with the government of Kuwait ... to use all necessary means to uphold and implement the Security Council resolutions passed in response to Iraq's invasion and occupation of Kuwait, and to restore international peace and security.'' The resolution cites Chapter 7 of the U.N. Charter, which authorizes the use of military force to counter aggression if sanctions and other steps fail. The only other time military force was sanctioned by the United Nations to counter aggression was in 1950, during the Korean conflict. Cuban Ambassador Ricardo Alarcon said his country could not support it. Yemen, the council's only Arab member, is believed likely to abstain or vote against it. Malaysia and Colombia's votes are uncertain. Colombia's foreign minister said Tuesday his government was still undecided.

DOC.HEAD: Beijing Prepares for Exercise in Socialist Democracy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The campaign season for local government offices in Beijing opened with plenty of hoopla. The city Communist Party chief shook hands at the main department store. A brass band played. Vans with loudspeakers cruised city streets and, the official Xinhua News Agency reported, volunteers gave out 1 million pamphlets. Only the candidates were missing. They are chosen weeks later, but there is no suspense for voters. Only members or supporters of the ruling party are nominated. Incumbents who supported last year's pro-democracy movement already have been purged. ``It's like taking part in a play ... performed for the Communist Party,'' a woman voter said, on condition of anonymity. ``We don't put much value on our voting rights.'' For the Communists, the elections are a deadly serious play, the basis of their claim to be the people's choice. All other officials are appointed in some fashion, so China's assertion of democracy rests entirely upon popular elections held every three years for the lowest-level representative bodies: district people's congresses in urban areas and county people's congresses in the countryside. The congresses make no laws and function mainly as conduits for passing citizen complaints and ideas to higher levels. Beijing has 18 such congresses with a total of 17,000 delegates. Other parts of the country held elections in the spring, but balloting in Beijing was delayed until Dec. 26. The reason given was that everyone was too busy getting ready for the Asian Games, held in September. Officials also may have wanted to keep the elections from coinciding with the anniversary of Beijing's massive pro-democracy demonstrations, which the army crushed in June 1989. Among other things, the marchers wanted more say in picking government officials. Voters say they have little part even in choosing the local congresses. ``God knows how the candidates are chosen,'' the woman said. After the single burst of citywide publicity that opened the election season in late October, preparations reverted to closed-door committees that take nominations from such official groups as the Communist Youth League and All-China Women's Association. A group of at least 10 voters can put a candidate forward, but few do. The candidate would be unable to organize publicity activities and would have little chance of success. The law allows two candidates for each seat, but voters say there usually is just one. Because there are no competing parties, television ads or debates, campaigns are placid events. It is not mandatory to vote, but failure to do so is frowned upon and would be noticed. Chinese officials insist the system is more democratic than multiparty elections in the West, which they say keeps power in the hands of the rich. ``Our election rights may not be the same as in the West, but equality is a basic principle,'' Xu Jingyu, chairman of the election commission in Beijing's Chaoyang District, said in an interview. He acknowleged not everyone can run for office, only those with correct ideological views, but said this was in keeping with the constitution. ``Delegates have to be able to represent the views of the masses,'' he said. ``How can someone who opposes the (party's) four basic principles do that?'' The emphasis on ideological correctness is especially strong this year, in keeping with the country's conservative turn after the democracy movement was crushed. A public notice addressed to ``comrade voters'' in the Chaoyang District called for vigilence against ``bourgeois liberals'' who might seek to sabotage the election. There have been no reports of any such plots. ``Bourgeois liberals'' are people who favor Western-style democracy with more than one party. Xu was unable to explain why some people accused of being bourgeois liberals were elected to past people's congresses. The most prominent example is astrophysicist Fang Lizhi's wife, Li Shuxian, a physics teacher at Beijing University who shares her husband's dissident views and was elected in 1987. She was expelled from the Haidian District People's Congress in 1989, soon after police accused her and Fang of counterrevolutionary crimes. They since have been allowed to go to the West. ``People change,'' Xu said. ``Maybe when she was elected, she didn't have this problem.''

DOC.HEAD: Freebie Flights Could Hurt Ailing Airlines If They Don't Show Restraint
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report; version also in financial report.
DOC.TEXT: Airlines offering two tickets for the price of one may be setting the stage for what could escalate into a damaging fare war. But analysts say the carriers can minimize risks if they limit freebie flights. ``Things like this tend to spread like wildfire,'' said Raymond E. Neidl, an airline analyst with Dillon Read & Co. Inc. ``If they can control the number of seats with black-out periods, then the damage can be controlled.'' The latest gimmick for filling seats comes as airlines have been hit hard by rising fuel costs brought on by the Persian Gulf crisis and a downturn in the economy that has kept demand for air travel sluggish. After Iraq invaded Kuwait in August and oil prices spiraled upward, airlines initiated three sets of fare increases that totaled about 15 percent. But now, most if not all of the airlines are fighting for passengers through limited promotions that offer two seats for the price of one for some flights. Tickets must be purchased by Friday, although many are good for trips through the end of February. Travel agents caution that the free flights are hard to get and blackout periods are in effect during the holidays' heaviest travel days. Travelers should be extremely flexible about arrival and departure dates if they want to get the fares. ``They're few and far between,'' said William Cooper, president of Adventure Travels in Pompano Beach, Fla. ``You're talking about coming into the Christmas season. If you're going out of here on December 21st, it's almost impossible to get a seat.'' For example, someone wanting to get the bargain rates around Christmas might end up flying at an odd hour on Christmas Day itself, he said. Cooper pointed out that the freebies weren't offered until many travelers had already booked their holiday trips. Anyone who already has tickets would have to determine whether it would be worth taking a penalty by changing reservations and going for the free flights, he said. The freebies have caused some confusion among travelers who often get the false impression that lots of seats are available under any airline promotion. Cooper said one of his agents spent three to four hours trying to get a customer a cheap seat last week, to no avail. Two of the larger, healthier carriers, American and United, fired some of the early rounds in the battle, which could eventually hurt the weaker carriers if things get out of control, analysts said. In the early stages of the promotion, airlines were offering $25 tickets for companions of people who flew at full price. It soon became a free companion ticket. As an example of how quickly airlines respond to cheaper fares offered by a competitor, Continental had separate advertisements appearing in two New York City newspapers one day last week, with one offering a companion ticket for $25 and the other offering it for free. The airline's cheap-fare strategy had been shifted too quickly for the outdated ad to be replaced by the new one, a spokesman said. An all-out fare war could prompt more restructuring in the industry like the job cuts and asset sales that have followed the recent runup in fuel costs. In one of the most dramatic moves so far, Pan Am Corp. agreed to sell United Airlines five prized London routes for $400 million. ``The stronger guys have more staying power,'' Neidl said. Thomas Canning, an airline analyst with Standard & Poor's, does not foresee the cheap seats having any major impact on the industry. ``As in all of these things, the seats are limited,'' he said. ``It's going to have some effect. I don't think it will be disastrous.''

DOC.HEAD: Israelis Feel Borders Closing in on Them
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A series of bloody border incidents has given Israelis a feeling that their frontiers are closing in on them. In the latest attack, a gunman crossed the Egyptian border north of the Red Sea port of Eilat on Sunday and killed four Israelis on a desert road. It shocked Israelis, who have grown used to the 11-year-old formal peace on the Egyptian front. On the Jordan border, where an unofficial peace has reigned since 1971, guerrillas have killed two Israeli soldiers this month. The raids have raised concerns here that King Hussein of Jordan is losing control of the extremists in his midst. On Saturday night, an Israeli gunboat sank a dinghy which the army said was ferrying gunmen from Lebanon to Israel. Hours later, the army said, a woman with explosives strapped to her body blew herself up next to an Israeli army patrol in south Lebanon, wounding two soldiers. The Lebanon front has long been Israel's most troublesome border. But now that Syria controls Lebanon, Israel worries about losing its self-declared security strip in southern Lebanon. At Massua, an Israeli farming settlement in the occupied West Bank 15 miles north of Jericho, the tension is inescapable. Two miles from here, a Jordanian teen-ager crept across the Jordan River one November night, shot dead the Israeli guarding a forward emplacement and would have killed more soldiers had one not clubbed him into submission. The Israelis' obvious state of unreadiness reflected how much Israel has come to take the peace on this border for granted. It has since moved in better-trained forces, but ``we definitely expect more of the same,'' says Yossi Olmert, director of the Government Press Office. ``This past summer things have gotten worse and worse. It makes us very uncomfortable,'' a Massua woman said last week as she wrapped bunches of hothouse roses for export to Europe. She spoke on condition of anonymity. That morning the settlement kept its gates shut until 9 a.m. because a Jordanian soldier was thought to have infiltrated across the Jordan River during the night. The claustrophobic atmosphere is not restricted to existing frontiers. A wave of knife attacks on Jews led authorities to seal off the occupied territories for four days last month, in a sense resurrecting the pre-1967 war border between Israel and the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Tension is running particularly high in Jerusalem, Israel's largest concentration of Jews and Arabs. It worsened dramatically after Oct. 8, when police fired on rioting Palestinians outside their main mosque, killing at least 17 people. On Friday, a satirical TV sketch featured a young Israeli with a rucksack telling his parents he was off on an adventure. South America? Nepal? No, Jerusalem, he replies, whereupon his mother bursts into tears and begs him to reconsider. Israelis have grown used to daily Arab violence during the three years of the Palestinian intefadeh, or uprising. But now the tension has reached places that were supposed to be immune, such as Eilat, the resort town 15 miles from the scene of Sunday's shootings. ``We try to sell Eilat as a secure and comfortable place,'' said Shalom Doron, an assistant hotel manager. Now he worries that ``Israelis may become as frightened to come here as they are to come to Jerusalem.'' Most disconcerting for Israelis is their belief that the latest attacks are not the work of their old enemy, the PLO, but of Islamic fundamentalists. They see a direct link between the rise of Moslem militancy in Jordan and the raids across the Jordan River. ``The propaganda and the agitation of the Islamic forces in Jordan has reached very dangerous proportions,'' Olmert said. ``One can see why there are those repeated attempts to infiltrate into Israel from Jordan, attempts that we have no reason to think are approved of or initiated by the regime.'' The same goes for Egypt, he said. Despite the Cairo government's strong commitment to the 11-year-old peace treaty, ``there is an infrastructure of strong anti-Israeli feeling in Egypt, basically fueled by Islamic fundamentalists.'' The fundamentalist factor was always present, he said, but has been accelerated by the Persian Gulf crisis, which is forcing Arabs to take sides for or against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein.
