DOC.HEAD: Equal Rights - or Non-Rights - For Rug-Wearers in Prison
DOC.TEXT: Score one more victory for equal rights: no longer do federal prisons discriminate gainst men in deciding whether prisoners may wear wigs. Under a Bureau of Prisons regulation that took effect Nov. 1, inmates of both sexes are banned from donning hairpieces unless they get medical authorization from the warden. It was one of countless changes that have been made in federal laws and regulations to bring about equal treatment of the sexes or to eliminate what is perceived as sexist language. Bureau officials say hairpieces are outlawed to prevent their use as disguises or to conceal contraband. The previous regulation read: ``551.3 Hairpieces. ``(a) A female inmate may wear a wig or hairpiece. ``(b) A male inmate may not wear an artificial hairpiece.'' In its notice printing the new regulation in the Federal Register, the bureau said the change was intended ``to provide for the security, good order, and discipline of the institution, and to apply this provision equally to male and female inmates.'' Occasionally, as in the wig rule, such changes do away with discrimination against men. For the most part, however, they are designed to assure equal rights for women. For instance, old rules of the Veterans' Administration, now the Department of Veterans' Affairs, presumed that a female veteran could be the dependent of a male veteran, but not the other way around. VA spokesman Don Smith said this has been changed as part of an effort that ``goes way back.'' ``For the most part, VA considers that in the last decade or decade and a half it has eliminated just about everything that would suggest that there is a difference in benefits or services depending on sex,'' Smith said. Some distinctions remain, in law if not in federal regulations and practice. There is, for example, a law still on the books that calls for the Bureau of Indian Affairs to train Indian boys as farmers and industrial workers, and Indian girls as assistant matrons. Indian Affairs spokesman Tommy Garrett, however, said that this and similar distinctions ``have been removed in an administrative sense over the years'' or superseded by later laws. Phineas Indritz, a Washington lawyer who has filed briefs with the Supreme Court in landmark sex discrimination cases, said, ``There have been a large number of substantive changes eliminating distinctions in law, but there are still a goodly number left.'' The law on training of Indian children was one of many that would have been repealed by legislation introduced in the last session of Congress, but not acted on. Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, a sponsor of the legislation, said some of the laws were archaic or obsolete and others had already been negated by agency action or court decisions. ``A number of these laws, however, are of continuing applicability,'' Hatch said. One that is of continuing applicability bars women from combat roles in the military. Another requires young men, but not young women, to register under Selective Service. Hatch and Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., steered clear of such controversial issues in their bill. There also are continuing efforts to eliminate language that suggests sexual discrimination, even though it may not exist. A case in point is the office of chief judge of the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. The incumbent is named Judith Rogers, but the D.C. code refers to the chief judge as ``he'' and ``him.'' The Judicial Conference of the United States recently went through the codes of practice governing federal courts to do away with several hundred of such gender pronouns. ``The last time I looked at them, there was only one reference to a gender basis,'' Indritz said. The code still spoke of a ship as `her.''
Here are excerpts from the opening statement of Edwin J. Gray, former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, at Monday's session of the Senate Ethics Committee.

Near the beginning of this drama, in March of 1984, Charles Keating's American Continental Corp. bought Lincoln Savings, a California state-chartered S&L. California law then permitted direct equity investments. Mr. Keating's S&L could buy companies and stocks, participate in leveraged buyouts, build and run hotels, and own and operate real estate development ventures of all types. Mr. Keating could easily raise the funds he needed to do such things, because Lincoln Savings, with its federally insured deposits, was a cash cow, well able to finance these endeavors. In 1984, Mr. Keating, in order to gain permission to acquire Lincoln, had assured state regulators and us that he would continue to operate the institution as primarily a home mortgage lender. Despite these assurances, he soon began using California's liberal thrift laws to their fullest. One month after Mr. Keating acquired Lincoln, the Bank Board asked Congress to roll back state thrift powers to the boundaries set by the Garn-St. Germain Act for federally chartered thrifts. That's something Congress had done for federally chartered thrifts. This move would have severely curtailed direct investment authority for California thrifts, but the bank board's request went nowhere. The Board began trying, through administrative rule-making, to limit the investment authority granted by California law. And Mr. Keating enlisted the first wave of paid apologists, dedicated to preventing us from doing so. All of this occurred before I had even heard of Charles Keating. The Bank Board adopted its first directed - direct investment regulation on January 30 of 1985. It limited the amount of a thrift's assets that could go into direct equity investment to 10 percent of assets, unless regulators permitted exceptions and - to be granted only under specific conditions. By the time of our rule-making, Mr. Keating had apparently been lobbying heavily to try to insure that the rule wouldn't be applied against Lincoln, or that it would be scuttled by a powerful show of force in Congress. Largely as a result of the Keating effort, more than half the members of the House signed a resolution intended to cause me and my colleagues to back down in the face of this demonstration of power. We didn't, and the direct investment regulation stood. Mr. Keating next sought to deal with this problem by hiring me out of my job as his chief regulator. He did so in a personal meeting with my chief of staff, who on my prior instructions rejected his proposal. In 1986, it became clear that Mr. Keating was conducting a campaign through its employees, agents and sympathizers to create the impression with the media, and with other influence molders, that I was feuding with him. Actually I've never met him, or even seen him in person. But we began hearing and then reading that I was somehow conducting a vendetta against Lincoln. A Gray-Keating feud story ran on the front page of The Washington Post on September 20th, 1986, in which it also was falsely alleged that I was harassing Lincoln. From that time forward, my senior staff and I believe that the alleged Gray vendetta was intended to be used by Keating as a basis for fighting thrift regulators in the future. Vendetta accusations were not the only pressure tactics I saw in operation that year. It was, we now know, not an accident that opposition to my efforts to warn about growing S&L problems coincided with the appearance of critical news stories about certain of the bank board's practices. When I arrived at the agency, these practices had been in place for over a decade. The regional banks would routinely pay part of the expenses incurred by Bank Board officials, including myself, when we attended out-of-town conferences of the regional banks. These practices had been approved by Bank Board counsel on more than one occasion, and were known to the Congress. Despite this history, and whatever may have been the source or motivation of the news stories, I concluded that the questions raised in the news stories were not unreasonable, and that the public perceptions created by the news stories were not only hurting me, but would, even if I survived in office, destroy any chance I might have at reforming the thrift system. I therefore reviewed these practices, revised them, and without being required or asked to do so, paid back certain challenged expenses. I also reimbursed the cost of airplane charter arranged for me by regional bank officials on the occasion of a severe medical emergency in my family. The total amount of the reimbursements were approximately $27,000. This matter was thoroughly investigated by the Office of Government Ethics, the Department of Justice, and the Bank Board's Inspector General, none of whom recommended any remedial action against me. These attacks were part of a pattern of pressures meant to discredit and - to discredit me, and derail the effort to achieve S&L reform and protect the American taxpayers. Senator Cranston's opening statement signaled that some would like this issue to play the same role at these hearings. I hope it will not. In mid-1986 the terms of my two Bank Board colleagues, Mary Grigsby and Donald Hovde were due to expire. News reports speculated as early as August 1986 that two Keating associates, Professor George Benston of the University of Rochester, a paid consultant to Lincoln since 1984, and Lee Henkel, a Keating lawyer and close associate who also was a major borrower of Lincoln's, were being seriously considered by the White House under the leadership of Donald Regan to fill the Grigsby and Hovde seats on the Bank Board.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: bank board.
DOC.TEXT: Henkel was indeed given a recess appointment for the Republican slot on the bank board in late October of 1986. This sent a very strong signal to me and the bank board staff that Mr. Keating had especially heavy political clout and that he intended to use it. The pressures during those years came from the Hill as well as the Executive Branch and the media - and the congressional pressures were the heaviest of all. Beginning in 1985 I'd been asking Congress for a major recapitalization of the FSLIC (the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp.) - that was in October of 1985. Finally, in the fall of 1986 we had a recapitalization bill moving through Congress, inadequate as it was, but suddenly it stopped. Incoming Speaker (James) Wright had been told that our regulators were being too tough on Texas S&Ls owned by his constituents and contributors, and he personally was putting a hold on the bill until he could get some satisfaction. The delay was critical. It also impressed on all of us at the bank board if we had not known it before, that congressional consent was the key to stopping the hemorrhage, the losses to the taxpayers. Board member Henkel in his first open meeting of the bank board proposed an alternative regulation for our direct investment rule, which was due to expire. His version would have forgiven thrifts for certain massive violations of the grandfathering clause of the extant direct investment regulation. We believed then, and I believe today, that Mr. Henkel's regulation was specifically intended to benefit Lincoln and only Lincoln Savings. Newly appointed board member Larry White and I voted against Henkel's regulation and for renewing our direct investment rule. Later, at the end of February of 1987 Mr. White and I voted to strengthen the direct investment regulation very substantially by tying a thrift's ability to make some equity investments to the level of tangible net worth on the books of the institution. Lincoln Savings thereupon sued the bank board on the grounds that we had exceeded our statutory authority. On April 2nd, 1987, this issue of the direct investment rule came up in my meeting with Senators DeConcini, McCain, Cranston and Glenn, as to which I've already testified in my deposition. Today, as we look back, it is clear many times over that the lion's share of the staggering losses that taxpayers will have to pay are the result of overly rapid deposit growth, fueled in large part by money brokers, which went into equity investments, particularly those involving speculative real estate projects. Charles Keating's losses from direct investments and high-risk land loans demonstrate beyond doubt that our regulatory concerns, our warnings, and our actions were correct. Charles Keating's purpose for Lincoln Savings was to use the institution as a source of funds for enterprises that had nothing to do with making home mortgages available to those seeking the American Dream. But there were many other thrift managements which, to a lesser or greater extent, were operating their thrifts for similar ends. Lincoln was not at all unique. These people played their political cards like masters in order to keep the regulators at bay. All the time, the stakes for the taxpayers continued to go up and up and up. The technique did not intimidate me or my regulators, I'm proud to say, but it visited a crushing burden on both the taxpayers and those depositors and bond holders who had placed their trust in our regulatory system. I hope this account makes clear that when I met, in 1987, with the five senators now before this committee, we were not discussing a normal regulatory issue to be addressed through the normal kinds of pressure, negotiation and compromise. This was a matter of clear and present danger to the nation, and demanded a more sober treatment. We have heard a lot in these hearings about the responsibility of senators to represent constituent interests, but I've always assumed that we also send our senators to Washington because we think they will have the sense to know when narrow constituent demands must take a back seat to the safety of their constituents as a whole. I hope this recounting of events also makes clear that when I met with the five senators, it was not in the midst of a normal political climate. These meetings capped years of private threats and public vilification, designed not just to change particular decisions by the bank board, but to render us unable to carry out our central responsibilities to protect the financial system and the taxpayers from loss. No one in Washington with the slightest knowledge of this issue can have been ignorant of this situation or the effect that it would have on the way regulators received and interpreted messages from senators and congressmen. Finally, I hope my experience makes clear that the savings and loan problem was not merely a problem of personal ethics among five senators. There were hundreds of players in this political drama, each of whom had some sort of interest in preserving the existing system rather than changing it and reforming it, and making it safer and more sound. This is the classic problem of a democracy. The private interests fit together so closely and operate so powerfully that the public interest - the broad public interest - the ordinary folks out there - their interest never gets served. Perhaps this crisis will encourage all of us to build more safeguards against that danger in the future. Thank you.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Legion At Home In Desert, Ready For War
With PM-Gulf-UN, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: HAFR AL-BATIN, Saudi Arabia (AP) - Around the dinner table under a Bedouin tent, the Foreign Legionnaires sang of their love for the desert and readiness to die for France. ``The desert's for us, as for sailors the sea,'' they roared. ``Let the sun bronze our corpses.'' The 1,100 men of the 2nd Infantry Regiment deployed in the northeastern Saudi Arabian desert come from 46 countries. Some joined to flee legal problems or broken love affairs, and nearly two-thirds use an assumed name. ``We never ask them why they joined the Foreign Legion,'' said Lt. Col. Antoine Lecerf, 40. ``Their past is their property. Maybe they're looking for adventure. Maybe they want to forget something in their own life. We don't mind.'' Americans may complain of harsh conditions waiting out Saddam Hussein in the desert, but that's not something that's heard at the Legion camp 65 miles south of the border with Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. ``The legion was almost born in the desert,'' said Cpl. Martin Meyer, 28, of Chicago. ``We love it out here.'' The 2nd Infantry is part of the France's 4,000-man Rapid Action Force, deployed alongside Arab troops in the face-off with Saddam. The legionnaires have seen action in Lebanon, Chad, Gabon and other hotspots where they were sent to advance France's foreign policy. Far from shunning a fight, the legionnaires look forward to it. ``Five years without seeing combat, and I'm still a virgin,'' said Meyer, who joined after serving in the U.S. Air Force. ``That's what I signed up for. That's what everyone signed up for.'' He said he preferred the legion to the U.S. military because ``It's a lot more liberal. Hey, I got my corporal's stripes because I was thrown in the nick (jail). They don't like wimps.'' As they wait for action, the legionnaires live with Gallic savoir-faire. They have bought large Bedouin tents and Arab carpets to lay on the sand, they drink from glasses decorated with the regimental crest and the food is a far cry from the American MREs, or ``meals ready to eat,'' that the GIs complain about. In the event of hostilities, they have packaged ready-to-warm rations but those, too, are a lot different from American army chow. One such ration includes ``lamb with beans, mushroom soup, beef conserve, tunnyfish in oil, candy, caramels'' and a variety of other goodies. The desert is their home. ``It's very beautiful,'' Lecerf said. ``You can have a constant communion with nature. I love the desert because it's a demanding environment that imposes a special effort from everyone.'' Cut off from their backgrounds, the legionnaires can find a new life among their comrades with no questions asked. ``Most of my friends are in jail or dead, so it was a good move'' to sign up, said Pvt. John Garcia, 20, of the Bronx, New York. He stressed it was his real name and that ``I'm no criminal.'' Asked whether he was hoping for war, he answered in his newly learned French: ``Yes. Of course. Everyone here is.'' The legionnaires have strips of Velcro on their uniforms for name tags, but none of the men of the 2nd Infantry wore the tags. Many refused to be photographed or to give their names - even aliases. These days many of the new recruits come from Eastern Europe. The legion predicts that Eastern Europeans will form the largest minority within two years. It ethos hasn't changed much since the 1939 movie ``Beau Geste'' starring Gary Cooper told the story of three well-born brothers who join the legion to escape disgrace. Capt. Hans Eberle, a 25-year-old legion veteran, said ``legionnaires are like modeling clay. They have to adapt.'' Speaking French in an accent tinged with his native German and the lilting southern accent of the legion's home base, Nimes, Eberle acknowledged he misses his wife and three children. ``But in our noble profession, there are so many rewards,'' said the 44-year-old captain, who has made hundreds of parachute jumps with a full combat load. The legionnaires spend up to 300 days a year away from home base in a totally masculine world, and they shudder at the thought that women could ever be recruited. ``I love women too much to accept that they be in the legion,'' said Eberle. ``I've seen the corpses of women. It's not a pretty sight.'' As reporters left the Legion camp, Eberle said: ``Goodbye. See you in Baghdad.''

DOC.HEAD: South African Author Wins Britain's Richest Fiction Prize
DOC.TEXT: South African author J.M. Coetzee has won Britain's richest fiction prize, the $39,000 Sunday Express Book of the Year award, for his novel ``Age of Iron.'' It is the first book in four years from Coetzee, who won acclaim for his earlier novels, ``Waiting for the Barbarians'' and ``Life and Times of Michael K.'' ``Age of Iron'' was chosen from a short list of six. Others were ``Brazzaville Beach'' by William Boyd, ``Temples of Delight'' by Barbara Trapido, Barbara Vine's ``Gallowglass'' and two novels shortlisted for this year's Booker prize, ``Gate of Angels'' by Penelope Fitzgerald and Brian Moore's ``Lies of Silence.'' ``It was a close run thing but `Age of Iron' is a story about the triumph of the human spirit and the quality of the language made it a winner,'' said novelist Andrea Newman, one of the five judges. South African actress Janet Suzman received the award on Coetzee's behalf Monday at a special literary luncheon at London's Cafe Royal restaurant. The Sunday Express newspaper presents the award annually for ``the most enjoyable and compulsively readable book published in Britain.'' Written in the first person, ``Age of Iron'' takes the form of a letter from Elizabeth Curren, a white South African, to her daughter. A retired classics teacher, Elizabeth lives alone: her daughter has lived in America since 1976, and her husband is dead. In a series of monologues Elizabeth considers her childhood, her guilt over apartheid - a ``gathering feeling of walking over black faces'' - and the growing turmoil of racially segregated South Africa. ``a bad-tempered old hound snoozing in the doorway, taking its time to die.'' She wants very much to be a mother figure to those around her, but the people with whom she becomes involved, including a vagrant who starts to share her home and two black teen-agers - both later killed during a school boycott - all prove to be well beyond her emotional reach.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 10 a.m. EST; time set by source
Nation in a Recession, 75 Percent of Forecasters Say
DOC.TEXT: Seventy-five percent of the nation's top economic forecasters contend the nation has sunk into a recession, although two-thirds expect it to be mild and end by April, according to a survey released today. ``Recession is here,'' the National Association of Business Economists said in a report on its canvass of 51 professional forecasters. The finding was a dramatic switch from an NABE survey just a year ago, when 62 percent of the forecasters said the economy would escape a recession through 1992. Just after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August, 45 percent of the forecasters said a recession either had begun or was imminent. Some economists on the current panel who say the downturn has not yet begun predicted a recession would begin early next year. Only 15 percent of the panel continue to hold to the ``no recession'' scenario. The NABE survey mirrored an earlier survey this month by Blue Chip Economic Indicators. Eighty percent of the 52 prominent economists participating in that study said a recession will begin before year's end. Another five percent said it would begin in 1991. Virtually all of the NABE forecasters who contend the economy is in recession say it began either in the third or the current quarter. ``The recession is also expected to be mild in historical terms, with the trough occurring in the first quarter of 1991,'' the NABE report said. It projected economic growth to decline 1.0 percent in the current quarter and 0.8 percent in the next. A recession generally is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative growth. ``If the current expansion is dead, it lived a long and prosperous life of 93 months (assuming an August peak) and was just a year short of the longest postwar business expansion of 1961-1969,'' the report said. The forecasters project the economy will expand just 1 percent for all of 1990 and 0.8 percent next year. That includes inching up 0.6 percent in the second quarter and growth of 2 percent in the third and 2.5 percent in the fourth. The economy grew 2.5 percent in 1989 and 4.5 percent in 1988. The survey also found the forecasters believe unemployment will rise from 5.5 percent this year to 6.1 percent in 1991. The jobless rate in October was 5.7 percent, up from 5.2 percent in June. At the same time, inflation as measured by the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index will drop from 5.5 percent in 1990 to 5.2 percent in 1991. The 1990 rate forecast in the latest survey is up from 5.3 percent in the previous survey because of higher oil prices following the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the report said. Corporate profits are projected to decline 4 percent this year and 1.3 percent in 1991. That's down from the previous survey that forecast a 2.7 percent decline in 1990 and a 3 percent gain in 1991. The forecasters said the federal budget deficit will rise from $220.4 billion in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30 to $258 billion in fiscal 1991 and $240 billion in fiscal 1992. The projections include the cost of the savings and loan bailout. Excluding those costs, the deficit would be $198 billion in the current year and $180 billion in fiscal 1992. The other deficit - merchandise trade - is forecast to drop to $100 billion this year and $93 billion in 1991. The trade deficit, which totaled $108.99 billion in 1989, has not been below $100 billion since 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Officials Dunked During Bridge Inauguration Collapse, 30 Hurt
DOC.TEXT: About 100 people, including a number of dignitaries, fell into a small river in Veracruz state when the hanging bridge they were inaugurating collapsed, the independent news agency Excelsior reported. About 30 people were injured, including nine who had to be hospitalized, in Monday's accident in the eastern state, the news agency said. The bridge across the La Antigua River, near the Gulf of Mexico port of Veracruz, collapsed during the late afternoon ceremony, said Ismael Bravo Vela, the judicial official at the village of La Posta, the news agency reported. The bridge was built to link La Posta with the village of La Antigua, across the river. Officials in both towns blamed deficiencies in construction materials for the collapse of the span, Excelsior said.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Husband Freed in Murder Case After Second Hung Jury
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of shooting his ex-wife in the head and murdering her lover was set free after two trials in which the defense argued the woman's memory was faulty because of her head wound. George Gurney, who had spent 17 months in jail, became a free man Monday after his second trial in five months ended in a hung jury. The prosecution decided against a third trial, citing the health of Gurney's former wife, Miriam Stoltz-Gurney. She spent four months recovering from the February 1989 attack before identifying Gurney as the assailant. ``Bringing her back, getting her ready for trial and actually subjecting her to having to testify again not only is not helping her rehabilitation process, it's inhibiting that process,'' said Assistant Attorney General Michael Ramsdell. The defense had hammered at the reliability of Stoltz-Gurney's memory, calling a Harvard University psychologist who testified that people with her type of head injury sometimes create memories to fill in gaps in their recall. Defense attorneys also stressed that there was no physical evidence linking Gurney, 54, to the crime scene. Gurney, who did not testify, had no comment Monday. Stoltz-Gurney, 49, was not present for the dismissal of the case. The jury deadlocked last week after deliberating about 14 hours. According to one juror who spoke on condition of anonymity, the dissenting juror doubted Stoltz-Gurney's testimony. The first trial ended in a 6-6 deadlock in June. Gurney was charged with murder, attempted murder and kidnapping in the attack that left Stoltz-Gurney in a weeklong coma and her lover, Roger Whittemore, dead. Gurney, a newspaper advertising salesman, had faced life in prison without parole. Stoltz-Gurney, who now lives at a Boston rehabilitation center, had stunned doctors with her recovery. In walking to the stand, she needed the help of a cane. At times her voice was barely audible and she admitted her memory was spotty. David Davidoff, a psychologist who interviewed Stoltz-Gurney, told the jury that she made up things to ``feel a sense of mastery and completeness.'' He testified ``the few things she does recall are likely to be distorted.'' The prosecution had portrayed Gurney as a scorned lover who was insanely jealous of Whittemore. Stoltz-Gurney, who had maintained a relationship with her ex-husband since their divorce in 1986, testified that he called the night of the murder and asked to come over. She said she told him he couldn't because Whittemore was there. The next thing she remembered, she testified, was Gurney storming into her room wearing camouflage fatigues and army boots. She said Gurney tied a pillowcase over Whittemore's head and bound his hands. ``George took a fire iron and whacked Roger with it. Roger was screaming, `I have four children and I want to do more for them!' '' she said. ``I was on the staircase cowering. I was really scared about the whole thing.'' Gurney then told her that they were going for a ride, she said. She testified she did not remember being shot. Whittemore, 52, of Swampscott, Mass, was found dead and Stoltz-Gurney was found unconscious in nearby woods.

DOC.HEAD: Disease-Fighting Fungus Approved for Commercial Use in Greenhouses
DOC.TEXT: A beneficial natural fungus that attacks two costly plant diseases has been approved by the government for commercial use in greenhouses. The Agriculture Department said the fungus, a strain of Gliocladium virens, has been approved by the Environmental Protection Agency as a greenhouse biological control of two harmful fungi that cause ``damping off'' diseases. According to the department's Agricultural Research Service, it is the first time in the United States a biocontrol fungus has been approved for use against a plant disease. Damping-off diseases cause rotting of seeds, seedlings and cuttings. Losses are estimated at more than $1 billion a year. The research service said its scientists invented and patented the technology for formulating the good fungus - Gliocladium - into easily applied pellets. W.R. Grace & Co. was granted an exclusive license for its use. Grace developed the technology further and hopes to have a product on the market in two years. Eventually, the company said it may seek EPA approval for using the pellets outdoors, as markets develop. The research service said Monday that damping-off fungi are attacked by the pellets - Rhizoctonia solani and Pythium ultimum. The diseases can destroy 10 percent to 30 percent of a crop. Among damping-off's victims are geraniums, snapdragons, chrysanthemums, celosia, poinsettias, cotton, corn, beans and soybeans. Tests performed by USDA plant pathologists Robert D. Lumsden and James C. Locke show plant losses caused by damping-off were reduced by 80 percent to 95 percent, which are similar to results gained from the use of chemical fungicides. The agency said further improvements are being sought to reduce losses 95 percent or even 100 percent. Approval by EPA allows Gliocladium's use on any plants grown in a greenhouse, including ornamentals and edibles such as tomatoes, cabbage or broccoli. The pellets resemble granular fertilizer and are made of dormant fungi spores, wheat bran and alginate, a natural gel-like material that binds the particle together. When the pellets are moistened, the spores germinate, and the fungus multiplies and controls the disease, the agency said. Gliocladium was described as ``a naturally occurring organism'' that was isolated from Maryland soil in the early 1980s at the agency's Biocontrol of Plant Diseases Laboratory in Beltsville, Md. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Agriculture Department has concluded a national hearing on possible changes in the pricing procedures under the nation's 42 federal milk marketing orders. But department officials say it will be well into next year before a final proposal can be drawn up for public comment. More than 10,000 pages of comments were taken from 195 witnesses during the 43 days of testimony that began Sept. 5 in Eau Claire, Wis., and concluded Nov. 20 in Irving, Texas. The department sid Monday a complete transcript of the hearing is being compiled. Copies are expected to be available by mid-December for public inspection at the 16 federal milk marketing order offices across the country. Briefs based on the hearing record will be allowed to be filed with USDA's hearing clerk no later than April 13, 1991. Replies will be accepted by April 27. After April 27, the department will evaluate the evidence and briefs, prepare a ``recommended decision'' on the proposals, which will be open for public comment. After that, a ``final rule'' will be prepared. ``Any changes that rule might propose would be contingent on referendums in each milk marketing area a proposal would affect,'' the department said. The procedure involves the milk pricing provisions used in all federal milk marketing orders, the system used to set minimum prices for milk that wholesalers must pay producers. Although the marketing orders do not set retail milk prices, the minimums specified at the farm level are felt through the marketing chain. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - This year's Agriculture Department yearbook tells about farmers and others who feed and clothe the American people. The 200-page book, ``Americans in Agriculture: Portraits of Diversity,'' is about ``the people of American agriculture, their jobs, their lives, their goals and their families,'' said editor Deborah Takiff Smith. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter added Monday in the book's foreword: ``The initiative and creativity and plain hard work of these millions of people are the key to our efficiency and our ability to compete in the world marketplace.'' As a special focus, the 1990 yearbook observes the centennial of the ``1890 institutions,'' the historically black land-grant colleges and universities. The book includes a history of these schools and a number of profiles of scientists, farmers, teachers and students connected with the schools. The USDA yearbook officially began in 1894, although annual volumes of reports were issued in the 1840s, when federal agriculture was under the commissioner of patents. Annual reports were continued after USDA was created in 1862. Copies of the reports were distributed to Congress, a practice that continues. Each senator will be getting 350 books and each member of the House about 300. Some are also provided to committees and other Capitol Hill offices. Free copies are available to constituents. Or the books can be ordered for $10 each from the Superintendent of Documents, Washington, D.C. 20402. The yearbooks also will be sold at government bookstores in many cities.

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Says Voters Don't Like Extreme Environmentalists
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter says many critics underestimate the government's ability to accommodate both the environment and the timber industry. ``I don't see those as nearly as incompatible as some have suggested so far,'' he told reporters Monday. Yeutter said the defeat of environmental initiatives containing ``extreme positions'' in the Nov. 6 elections shows voters want common sense approaches to the environment, including protection of the northern spotted owl. The secretary criticized views of extremists on both sides of the fight over the threatened owl's habitat, which is primarily in the centuries-old forests of the Pacific Northwest. He also said he expects the Forest Service's Northwest logging plans to survive most legal challenges. The Forest Service, acting under the Agriculture Department, has been forced to alter its logging plans since the Fish and Wildlife Service declared the owl to be a threatened species in June. A panel of government scientists led by Forest Service biologist Jack Ward Thomas said in April that logging must halt on 3 million acres of Northwest federal forests to save the owl. But timber industry leaders say that would cost tens of thousands of timber jobs by the end of the decade. ``It certainly has been politically difficult to strike a reasonable balance in many of these areas of conflict, not just the spotted owl, but a good number of others as well,'' Yeutter said. ``That is due to radical or extreme positions being held by a number of folks in the environmental community on the one side and sometimes equally radical or extreme positions being held by folks on the other side,'' he said. Yeutter said the defeat of several environmental ballot issues, such as California's Big Green, should provide encouragement to policymakers at all levels of government. ``The voters opted for reasoned and good judgment and common sense and they rejected a lot of proposals in early November that would have, in my judgment, gone off into extreme positions,'' he said. ``That is an encouraging illustration of democracy in action and a sound, solid, middle-of-the-road approach emerging as a result of the election process,'' the secretary said.

DOC.HEAD: Cigarette Company's Bill of Rights Display Leads to Counter-Display
DOC.TEXT: When Philip Morris spent millions on a high-tech, 50-state exhibition of the Bill of Rights, cynics complained the cigarette company wanted to convey a not-so-subtle message: One of our inalienable rights is the right to smoke. Now the American Lung Association of Connecticut is delivering its own message with a no-tech, low-budget counter-exhibition of the revered document. ``It's not an established right for someone to blow smoke in my face,'' said John E. Zinn, the lung association's executive director in Connecticut. ``What they're trying to do is perpetuate this myth where smoking is a right and polluting other people's air is a right.'' Philip Morris Cos. borrowed Virginia's copy of the Bill of Rights for a 16-month tour that began Oct. 10 to commemorate the 200th anniversary of the signing of the document. When the lung association heard the tour was coming to New Haven earlier this month, members quickly arranged their own exhibit, moving Connecticut's copy from the Connecticut State Library to the Old State House in Hartford. Connecticut's copy is one of 13 given to the original states after the Bill of Rights was ratified in 1791. The federal government also has a copy, on display in Washington. Costs for the Philip Morris tour, including advertising and security, are expected to top $60 million. The lung association's month-long exhibition, which opened Friday, cost $300. The Philip Morris exhibition uses blue lights and loud music to show off the Bill of Rights in an elaborate multi-media show. The document is transported around the country in an armored car, accompanied by a caravan of six trucks, four vans and two buses. Wilson H. Faude, executive director of the Old State House, used his 1983 Nissan to transport the Bill of Rights for the lung association's exhibition from its home at the state library. The document is displayed in a simple glass case. ``There's a certain dignity surrounding the Bill of Rights,'' Zinn said. ``We'll leave the splashy demonstration to them.'' Philip Morris, a conglomerate that also owns Kraft General Foods and Miller Brewing Co., denied it wanted to make a statement about smoking. ``There's absolutely nothing in the tour that promotes any of our products, nothing whatsoever, and how touring the Bill of Rights is going to fight smoking restrictions is beyond me,'' said the company's Mary Taylor. Anti-smoking groups or gay activists angered by the company's support of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., have protested the Philip Morris tour at stops in Barre, Vt.; West Warwick, R.I.; Augusta, Maine; New Haven; Albany, N.Y., and Boston. Visitors at the lung association's exhibition on Monday were divided over the Philip Morris tour. ``I'm against smoking, but the fact is, nobody's asking people to smoke just because they come see this,'' said Peter Ottaviano, a Hartford insurance agent. ``It's their right to sponsor it, but I think their motives are questionable,'' said Val Pajer of Durham. ``Something like this, something that's part of our heritage, should not be connected with a profit-making motive.'' Faude said the controversy probably has helped boost attendance at the Connecticut exhibit. In three days, it has drawn 8,000 people. ``This debate is good,'' he said. ``I think all this means is that the Bill of Rights is very healthy.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-Hearings Bjt
Bush Administration Urging Dismissal of War Powers Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is urging dismissal of a lawsuit by 45 House Democrats who say the president must get congressional approval before launching any U.S. attack on Iraqi forces. The Justice Department said Monday night the courts should not decide the case because there is no imminent threat of hostilities and, in any case, the issue is political and cannot be decided on legal principles. The ``ultimate check'' on presidential power to deploy military force is congressional control of the federal purse strings and not the courts, the department said in legal papers filed with U.S. District Judge Harold Greene. Those filing suit must show that they have suffered some injury as a result of illegal conduct, the department said. The congressmen ``have not alleged that such an attack is imminent, or even probable, but merely that there is a `realistic threat' of one,'' the department said. ``The fact that a threat may be `realistic,' however, does not mean that it is likely to be carried out.'' The suit seeks a preliminary injunction restraining President Bush from launching an offensive against Iraqi troops without congressional approval. Granting such relief ``would involve the court in the kind of diplomatic and military judgments'' which are the province of Congress and the executive branch, the Justice Department said. ``The courts have traditionally remained aloof from such issues,'' it added. It urged the judge to ``refrain from intervening in this ongoing political process'' and to dismiss the case. The papers filed by assistant attorney general Stuart Gerson called it premature to bring such a lawsuit because it is based on the premise of hypothetical future events. The department also noted that Bush ``has never said that he will not seek Congressional authorization prior to the use of force'' against Iraqi troops, who invaded Kuwait in August. ``In the absence of some actual clash'' between Congress and the executive branch, considering the lawsuit would only interject the court unnecessarily into a political process, it added. The Constitution states that ``Congress shall have power ... to declare war, grant letters of marque and reprisal and make rules concerning captures on land and water.'' Bush and others in the administration have said they have would consult with Congress before using offensive force against Iraq. Secretary of State James Baker has expressed reservations about the notion that Bush would need congressional approval if the use of force went beyond the defense of Saudi Arabia. Earlier Monday, 11 law professors supported the lawsuit in a brief filed with the court. The Constitution requires that ``the President meaningfully consult with Congress and receive its affirmative authorization - not merely present it with faits accomplis - before engaging in war,'' the professors said. Among them was Erwin Griswold, who was U.S. solicitor general during the Johnson and Nixon administrations. Congressional approval must come through ``formal action, not legislative silence, stray remarks of individual members or ... activity that the president or a court might construe to constitute `acquiescence,''' they said.

DOC.HEAD: Polluter Gets Five Years' Probation, Ordered Out of Business
DOC.TEXT: The iron-fisted matriarch of a family empire of sludge barges and tugboats was given five years' probation and sent into retirement for fouling New York Harbor. Superior Court Judge Anthony J. Iuliani said Monday only Evelyn Berman Frank's age and ill health kept him from sentencing the 75-year-old ``Dragon Lady'' of the harbor to up to 10 years behind bars. Mrs. Frank has skin cancer, high blood pressure and other medical problems. The judge also ordered Mrs. Frank to perform 2,500 hours of community service and cut all ties to her business. Her family's General Marine Transport Inc. presented a check at Monday's hearing for $500,000, half the fine levied on the company under a plea bargain. For more than 40 years Mrs. Frank had controlled a marine empire of more than 45 interlocking companies operating tank cleaners, barges and tugboats. She gained a reputation on the waterfront for barking out orders to her barge and boat employees over shortwave radio from her Fifth Avenue apartment in Manhattan or the basement of her Staten Island home. Competitors and employees dubbed her the ``Dragon Lady.'' Mrs. Frank in turn christened one of her tugboats The Dragon Lady. In July, she pleaded guilty to unlawful abandonment and release of sewage sludge - some of it toxic - in New York Harbor in 1987 and 1988. The family's environmental violations date to at least 1970 but drew little attention until September, when an illegally operated barge dumped waste oil into the harbor. In October, New York state closed the family's barge business. Lawsuits have been filed against the family and its businesses in New York and New Jersey, the city and state of New York are trying to collect more than $1 million in back taxes, and one family company has filed for bankruptcy.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Denied Committing 11-Year-old Murder Confesses in Court
DOC.TEXT: A former school administrator who had maintained he was being framed for an 11-year-old slaying led authorities to the body of his ex-girlfriend, confessed to the crime and drew five years in prison. Francis W. Malinosky, 45, was sentenced Monday under a plea bargain approved by District Judge Frank Mahady. He will be eligible for parole in a little more than three years. ``I am ashamed of myself right down to the very center of my being,'' Malinosky told the judge in confessing to the crime. Last week the former assistant director of special education for Burlington schools led authorities to the body of Judith Leo-Coneys. ``I loved Judy and (her son) Shamus and I thought we were going to be a family,'' Malinosky said. The boy, 3 when his mother died, has been raised by her parents. After his arrest in April, Malinosky said he was the victim of a small-town witch hunt and vowed to prove his innocence. Authorities said Malinosky killed the 32-year-old special education teacher in 1979 after she broke off their 2-year-old relationship. ``I'm still angry that someone can kill somebody with two bullets in the back of the head and throw her body in a plastic bag ... and only get three years,'' said Leo-Coney's mother, Patricia Leo. ``It's just not right.'' The judge and State's Attorney William Sorrell agreed the punishment was not strict enough. But they said Malinosky was allowed to plead guilty to voluntary manslaughter because a murder case against him could have been lost. Although Malinosky had long been a suspect, authorities could not find Leo-Coney's body until he led them to her shallow grave off a mountain road last week. She had vanished after going to Malinosky's home to pick up her belongings. Malinosky disappeared a short time later, and wasn't found until April, when he was arrested at a Los Angeles motel. Police tracked him down after Sorrell reopened the case last year. ``I was convinced when I looked at the file that he had murdered her,'' Sorrell said. ``It bothered me that this guy was getting away with murder.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Moves Higher, Stocks Fall
DOC.TEXT: The dollar moved higher against the yen in Tokyo Tuesday, while share prices fell moderately. The dollar finished at 128.95 yen, up 1.00 yen from Monday's close of 127.95 yen. After opening at 129.10 yen, the currency ranged between 128.55 yen and 129.10 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues shed 139.35, or 0.59 percent, closing at 23,623.51. The index had gained 362.58 points Monday. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds slipped to 86.31, down from Monday's close of 86.56. Their yield rose to 7.420 percent from 7.365 percent. Currency traders said the dollar started higher, nearly matching levels set in New York, because of continuing tensions in the Persian Gulf. The dollar closed at 129.05 yen in New York. The dollar tends to rise in times of international tension because it is seen as a safe investment, while reports of a possible gulf war usually weaken the yen because Japan depends on the Middle East for about 70 percent of its oil supply. The dollar later moved to lose some of its early gains, with bearish sentiment toward the currency prevailing in the market, traders said. ``The dollar was edging lower as it faced selling pressure above the 129 yen,'' said Shoken Sakamoto, an exchange dealer with New Japan Securities Co. On the stock market, the Nikkei index fell back on small-lot selling in trading discouraged by weakening yen and bond prices as well as higher oil prices, securities dealers said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Cuba Consult on Persian Gulf in Rare High-Level Meeting
DOC.TEXT:
U.S. concern over the Persian Gulf crisis has produced the highest-level meeting between the United States and Cuba since the two countries opened diplomatic offices in each other's capitals 13 years ago. Under Secretary of State Robert Kimmitt, the third-ranking official at the State Department, met Sunday with the chief of Cuba's diplomatic mission here, Jose Arbesu. Previously, the most senior U.S. official to meet with Cuba's chief diplomat here has been the assistant secretary for Latin American affairs. A spokesman at the Cuban mission said Monday that the Sunday meeting was limited to a discussion of the consultations on the gulf at the U.N. Security Council, of which Cuba occupies one of the 10 non-permanent seats.
---
DOC.HEAD: Cavazos: College Is Still Affordable
DOC.TEXT:
Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos is calling on colleges and universities to make ``tough choices'' to cut costs. Cavazos insisted Monday that colleges still are affordable, although tuition increases during the 1980s averaged about 8 percent a year. Average tuition and fees for fall 1990 ranged from $884 at two-year public colleges to $9,391 at four-year private colleges. Escalating costs of higher education have some analysts predicting that ``four years of college early in the next century may cost several hundred thousand dollars,'' said Cavazos. Cavazos stressed that the predictions are based on ``misperceptions about both the true cost of college and the availability of student financial aid.'' Yet he released a handbook, entitled ``Tough Choices,'' to help colleges examine institutional goals and priorities and make decisions to control spending. ``If we are to keep higher education affordable, colleges and universities are going to have to make serious efforts to control costs,'' he told reporters. ``Each institution must identify its central mission and focus, and then allocate resources accordingly, with the understanding that no single institution can do everything well.'' For example, Cavazos said colleges should consider merging duplicative services or programs and possibly eliminating programs, including certain athletic or sports programs. Institutions also might consider coordinating services with nearby schools, he said.
---
DOC.HEAD: American University President Wants to Remain on Faculty
DOC.TEXT: Former American University prssident Richard Berendzen, who resigned after being charged with making obscene telephone calls, says he wants to remain on the faculty. Berendzen said Monday the controversy over a reported $1 million buyout of his contract as president and as a tenured professor of physics has caused him ``great anguish.'' ``I am seeing the fabric of this family torn by rumor and innuendo,'' Berendzen said in a statement issued through his attorney. ``I have initiated steps that I hope will bring harmony to the university I love so dearly.'' He pleaded guilty in May to two charges of making obscene phone calls in Fairfax County, Va., and received two 30-day jail sentences, which were suspended on the condition that he remain in psychiatric treatment. Berendzen said he was hopeful the board of trustees will approve his return to teaching ``after an appropriate period of leave.'' Last week, acting president Milton Greenberg asked the trustees to rescind the buyout offer. He cited ``serious rifts'' which the arrangement had caused between the trustees and the rest of the university.

DOC.HEAD: Say, What COULD You See by the Dawn's Early Light?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16th graf pvs, `Despite denials ...' to CORRECT date to 1791.
DOC.TEXT: Did Thomas Jefferson father a child by one of his slaves? Did Old Hickory's wife already have an old man? And, say, what COULD you see by the dawn's early light? Historians - professional know-it-alls who usually save questions for students - admit to a few intriguing doubts of their own in the December issue of American Heritage. The magazine asked American historians to name the one mystery in U.S. history each would like solved. Responses ranged from ``Were Sacco and Vanzetti guilty?'' to ``Who invented the hamburger?'' Walter Lord wonders what Francis Scott Key saw the morning he wrote ``The Star-Spangled Banner'' during the War of 1812. Key was forced to observe the British bombardment of Fort McHenry in Baltimore Harbor from a flag-of-truce boat eight miles away. He later said he composed the song's lyrics at dawn, when the sight of the flag assured him the attack had been repelled. But that was unlikely, Lord suggests. Although the fort's regular flag might have been visible from eight miles, the night's rain would have forced the use of a lighter, smaller ``storm flag'' that probably could not have been seen through smoke and rain in early light. Lord argues that it's more likely Key saw an ensign flag raised by the victorious Americans over the fort's guns - a flag that a British officer saw raised around 9 a.m., not dawn. Key however, ``knew that dawn is a more magic hour than 9 a.m.,'' Lord writes. ``It was time to resort to a little poetic license.'' Another historian, Charles O'Neill, wonders if the space shuttle Challenger was sent aloft despite less than optimal temperatures because the White House wanted a dramatic background for President Reagan's 1986 State of the Union address, originally scheduled for the night of the launch. He writes: ``By examination of White House logs or otherwise, I'd like it clearly proven or disproven whether word ... went to (NASA officials), bidding those in charge not to be too finicky - given the upcoming address - about getting the Challenger into the air, cold weather or no cold weather.'' Columbia University historian Henry Graff wonders why former President James Monroe repeatedly sued the government for expenses after leaving office. He suspects Monroe was ashamed of ``the substantial charges ... that he misapplied public money while in official posts (even that he had personally profited from his refurbishing of the White House after its torching by the British).'' Several historians - uncomfortable, perhaps, with the mantle of ignorance - suggest solutions to their own mysteries. Thomas Fleming believes that Jefferson did not father the mulatto boy who looked like him. The slave woman, Sally Hemmings, was the illegitimate daughter of Jefferson's father-in-law, and her children probably were fathered by Jefferson's nephew, he says. Fleming suspects Jefferson never denied the charge publicly to protect his family. Despite denials by Andrew Jackson's supporters, biographer Robert Remini says it appears Jackson and his wife, Rachel, married sometime between October 1790 and January 1791 - about three years before a court dissolved Rachel's first marriage and the couple ``officially'' married. Some questions lack even a suggested answer. What happened to Sen. Huey Long's ``de-duct'' box, which was filled with a million dollars in campaign contributions and disappeared after his assassination in 1935? - Ken Burns, producer of PBS documentary ``The Civil War.'' Why did Secretary of War Edwin Stanton refuse President Lincoln the military escort he'd requested on the day he was assassinated? And why did he dissuade Gen. Ulysses Grant from joining Lincoln at Ford's Theater that night? - Jacques Barzun, Columbia University. Why did the federal government give Virginia the portion of the District of Columbia south of the Potomac River, making the capital's boundary look like ``a sandwich with a large corner bitten off?'' - The late Marcus Cunliffe, George Washington University. And then there's the hamburger. Twenty years ago, when J.C. Furnas tried to determine its inventor, he settled on a creation scenario, circa 1905: a late-night run on bread for a broiled beef patty sandwich forces a restaurant cook to substitute the rolls then used for ham sandwiches; customers praise the innovation for its ease in handling. But where, Furnas asks, was that all-night lunchroom, and who was that cook?

DOC.HEAD: Westerners Moved to Baghdad; Saddam Complains of Medicine Shortage
With PM-Gulf-UN, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has transferred more than 100 Westerners, including at least five Americans, from strategic sites in Kuwait to Baghdad, diplomats report. The U.S. and British diplomats say the hostages were brought to the Mansour Melia Hotel in the Iraqi capital. It wasn't clear if they would be released. President Saddam Hussein appeared on television with hostages and their families on Monday and said three Americans would be allowed to go home. The Swedish Embassy said more than 50 Swedes in Iraq also have been given permission to leave. And the wife of a Canadian hostage said he told her as many as 25 Canadians were about to be released. ``I talked to my husband by phone (Monday) and he said the word was that 15 to 25 of the Canadians were going to be let out,'' Lois Minns said in Edmonton, Alberta. Ralph Minns has been confined to his Baghdad hotel for the last three weeks, she said. In Moscow on Monday, Soviet officials charged that Iraq was dragging its feet on the departure of Soviets from Iraq, failing to allow people to leave as promised. It was the first time Moscow had accused Baghdad of preventing Soviet citizens from leaving Iraq. At least 4,000 of an estimated 8,000 Soviets who were in Iraq when it invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 have left. Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin said Iraq agreed to clear another 1,000 to leavein November, but only 350 have been allowed to go. ``If Iraq does not immediately remove obstacles and allow our citizens to leave, this will complicate the present situation even further and force us to take a tougher attitude,'' he said. Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, met with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the Kremlin on Monday and indicated a ``bureaucratic accident'' had resulted in the delay of the departure of the Soviets, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported. A broadcast on Iraqi television Monday included footage of Saddam meeting with a group of Americans and their relatives, who were told they would be allowed to leave together. ``If you feel that hospitality has come to an end, you can travel to the United States of America, or anywhere else in the world at any time you deem appropriate,'' the report quoted Saddam as saying. The hostages shown on TV were Fred Harrington, 59, of Bellevue, Wash., John Stevenson, 44, of Panama City, Fla. The daughter-in-law of hostage Clyde Jesse, 55, a suburban Chicago businessman who was living in Kuwait, said Jesse has also been promised he can leave Iraq. The U.S. Embassy has said there are more than 900 Americans in Kuwait and Iraq, including 104 held at strategic sites. Saddam has been freeing small numbers of hostages almost daily in response to pleas from visiting dignitaries. U.S. officials say the releases are a ploy to win sympathy and divide the global coalition opposed to his occupation of Kuwait. Tony Benn, leader of a left-wing faction of the British Labor Party, arrived in Baghdad on Monday and said he would try to free British hostages. Saddam has offered to free foreigners beginning Dec. 25 in exchange for U.S. guarantees he will not be attacked. The release period from Dec. 25 to March 25 coincides with the time considered best to launch a military operation since temperatures are lower and there are frequent stretches of calm weather.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Stocks Fall
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against the yen for the second consecutive day today amid worries over the Middle East, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell moderately. The dollar closed at 128.95 yen, up 1.00 yen from Monday's close of 127.95 yen. It opened at 129.10 yen and ranged between 128.55 yen and 129.10 yen. The dollar had climbed 0.82 yen on Monday. Some $8.74 billion changed hands in today's spot trading, up from $6.94 billion the previous day. Currency traders said Persion Gulf tensions helped keep the dollar higher after its overnight rise in New York. ``The yen was sold because of rising oil prices,'' said a dealer with the Industrial Bank of Japan, speaking on condition of anonymity. The U.S. currency is regarded a safe haven in times of international tensions. Worries about a possible war in the gulf also usually weaken the yen because Japan imports about 70 percent of its oil from the Middle East. Brent crude for January delivery was notionally valued at about $33.40 to $33.50 a barrel, about 50 cents above levels seen late Monday in New York. Reports that the U.N. Security Council was likely to approve a resolution authorizing the use of force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait depressed the Tokyo stock market, analysts said. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which gained 362.58 points Monday, lost 139.35, or 0.59 percent, closing at 23,623.51. A total of 250 million shares were traded on the first section, unchanged from Monday's trading volume. ``There was no direction in the market, with many investors taking a wait-and-see position,'' said Takashi Morinaga, an analyst with Okasan Securities. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds slid to 86.45 from Monday's close of 86.56. Their yield rose to 7.390 percent from 7.365 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Respected German Pollster Becoming Major Player in E. Europe Politics
With PM-Poland
DOC.TEXT: Voters who have over the past year cast ballots in Eastern Europe's first free elections in decades were sometimes able to get the results from the evening news, thanks to a German polling firm. The Bonn-based Infas polling institute has made one of the first major injections of technical skill into Eastern Europe in the form of exit polls. The institute, founded in 1958, has done exit polling in elections in former East Germany, Romania, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Poland. In Poland on Sunday, Infas was within a few percentage points of the final result just hours after the polls closed. It is yet another indication of the might a united Germany will have in Eastern Europe, as countries lacking in many of the basic skills of democracy turn to their nearest and most powerful democratic neighbor. Germany is the chief provider of aid to Eastern Europe, and major German companies have through years of cultivating contacts established themselves firmly in the countries of the former Soviet bloc. Freed by Eastern Europe's reforms and prompted by their fledgling media's attempt to cope, the Eastern European polling ventures mark the first time Infas has conducted election polls outside Germany, officials said. Initial exit polls from Infas, which was hired by Poland's state television, projected that Lech Walesa would take 41 percent of the vote, with Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and emigre Stanislaw Tyminski tied at 20.5 percent. Further Infas results released around midnight from the 404 districts it targeted gave Walesa 39.3 percent, Tyminski 23.2 percent and Mazowiecki 19.9 percent. Based on complete, but unofficial, returns released by the Polish news agency PAP on Monday, Walesa won 39.96 percent of the vote, Tyminski 23.10 percent and Mazowiecki 18.08 percent. ``These first projected results are sometimes 2 or 3 percentage points away from the final result, but the second projected result is much closer,'' Reinhart Schneider, one of the project leaders in Infas' election department, said in an interview Monday. Infas has been ``very accurate'' in its forecasts, Schneider said. He was especially proud of results from Romania, the most difficult of the institute's foreign ventures. ``Romania was really a unique situation. It was a revolutionary situation, still,'' he said. But, he added, ``you can see how close the methods come.'' In the May 20 presidential elections, Ion Iliescu of the National Salvation Front received 85.1 percent of the vote, and Radu Campeanu of the National Liberal Party got 10.2 percent, according to final results. Exit poll projections gave 83 percent of the vote to Iliescu and 11 percent to Campeanu, Schneider said. Infas has been approached and paid by the media in the country holding each of the elections, Schneider said. In each case, it hooked up with a partner institute that translated the institute's questions and provided native speakers to do the interviewing. ``This is not very difficult, but you have to have the experience to do this,'' Schneider said. ``These Eastern countries have not yet the experience in doing these things because they have not had democratic elections for years, for decades.''

DOC.HEAD: MCA Seeks to Allay Fears, Head Off Japan-Bashing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Analysts and ...' to fix wording.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TOK4
DOC.TEXT: Industry analysts say MCA Inc. - the entertainment giant that gave the world ``E.T.'' and ``Jaws'' - is so well run that its new Japanese owners will allow creative control to remain in American hands. In the biggest Japanese purchase ever of a U.S. company, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. struck a $6.6 billion deal for MCA on Monday. The Japanese maker of videocasette recorders, televisions and stereos under such brand names as Panasonic, Technics and Quasar got a company that produces hit TV shows such as ``Murder, She Wrote'' and ``Major Dad,'' records artists such as Elton John and Guns N' Roses and owns many of the biggest movies of all time. MCA became the fourth major Hollywood studio to come under foreign control, raising fears that responsiblity for the financing and political content of American entertainment is falling increasingly into non-American hands. In a statement Monday, Matsushita indicated its awareness of American fears of Japanese investment and sought to allay them by promising to leave MCA's management intact and allow the company's direction to be determined at home. Analysts and MCA executives said the public is unlikely to see much of a difference in movie theaters, from CD players or on TV screens. ``They bought it precisely because of management,'' said Jeff Logsdon of Seidler Amdec Securities Inc. ``It doesn't help them to interfere in the creative process.'' ``I don't think Matsushita made a major investment in a company that's doing very well to try to change what it's doing,'' said MCA's movie chief, Tom Pollock. Still, the deal has brought skepticism and criticism. Record producer Quincy Jones said he was worried that the country was selling off its heritage. In Japan, the nationally circulated Asahi Shimbun newspaper reported that Matsushita pushed to close the deal before Dec. 7, the 49th anniversary of the Japanese bombing of Pearl Harbor, to avoid public relations problems. Concerns were expressed in Japanese newspapers of an anti-Japanese backlash in the United States. Backlashes followed Japanese purchases of Columbia Pictures, Rockefeller Plaza in New York and Pebble Beach in California. Skepticism arose at a news conference in Japan on Monday when Matsushita President Akio Tanii was asked if he would object to MCA making a ``Japan-bashing'' film or one critical of Emperor Hirohito's role in World War II. ``Something like that shouldn't emerge,'' said Tanii, looking agitated. ``Filmmakers must create films that are inspirational, that will be enjoyable for everybody. I can't even imagine a case like that.'' To silence criticism that arose during negotiations, Matsushita said it will sell MCA's Curry Co. subsidiary, which operates restaurants, hotels and other services in Yosemite National Park. Matsushita will also spin off MCA's WWOR-TV in the New York area into a separate company owned by MCA shareholders. Foreign companies are not allowed to own domestic TV stations. Japan's Sony Corp. bought Columbia Pictures Entertainment last year, Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti bought MGM-UA Communications last month and Rupert Murdoch's Australia-based News Corp. has owned 20th Century Fox since 1985. Like the $5 billion Sony-Columbia deal, the MCA-Matsushita merger blends Hollywood ``software'' - movies, TV shows and recordings - with Japanese hardware in an effort to exploit the huge world demand for both types of product. MCA, which began 65 years ago as a booking agent for jazz bands, has grown to become a colossus of films (Universal Pictures' ``E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial,'' ``Jaws'' and ``Back to the Future''), records (Reba McEntire, Bobby Brown, George Strait) and television. Attendance at its Universal Studios theme parks in Florida and California is exceeded only by Disney's.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Says 13 Percent of Population Disabled
DOC.TEXT: Thirteen percent of Vietnam's nearly 65 million people - about 8.5 million - are disabled as a result of war, accidents or congenital deformities, the official Vietnam News Agency said today. The official figure was reported at a seminar on rehabilitation held in Hanoi on Monday by the Ministry of Labor, War Invalids and Social Affairs, the agency said in its report, monitored in Bangkok. Rehabilitation is part of the health care programs of 35 of 40 provinces and cities in Vietnam, it said. The Vietnamese have fought five wars in the past five decades. Vietnam began withdrawing its troops from Cambodia last year, but guerrillas opposing the pro-Vietnamese Phnom Penh government say thousands of Vietnamese soldiers remain. The problems of the disabled are aggravated by the poor health conditions and the scarcity of basic medical care in Vietnam, one of the world's poorest nations.

DOC.HEAD: Defendant Testifies Police Forced Him to Lie
DOC.TEXT: A young man on trial in the Central Park jogger case testified police bullied him into signing a false confession. Later, he jumped from the stand during cross-examination, saying, ``I'm not taking anymore.'' Kharey Wise, 18, said on Monday that police hit him, coached him and deceived him to make him confess to the 1989 attack. Defense attorney Colin Moore showed Wise a statement he signed while in police custody. In the statement, Wise implicates himself in the attack on a runner who was gang raped and beaten almost to death. Wise testified Detective John Hartigan told him to lie. ``Tell him that you were there,'' the defendant quoted Hartigan as saying. ``Put yourself in it.'' ``I said, `If I tell him a lie, can I go home?' He promised me I could.'' The defendant refused to answer certain questions by Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer and balked at her insistent questioning about his truancy in 1985. ``What does this have to do with my case?'' Wise shouted. ``Come on, man!'' He jumped from the witness chair but after repeated warnings from the judge was persuaded to return. The jury was led out of the courtroom when Wise vehemently refused to answer other questions about truancy in 1989. Wise, who was 16 when the attack occurred, and Kevin Richardson, 16, are the second set of teen-agers to be tried on charges of rape and attempted murder in the attack. Three others were convicted Aug. 18. All were sentenced to five to 10 years in prison. Another youth will be tried early next year. The 30-year-old jogger recovered from most of her injuries and has returned to work as an investment banker. She said she still suffers vision and balance problems and lost her sense of smell.

DOC.HEAD: Janet Jackson Wins Eight Billboard Music Awards
DOC.TEXT: Janet Jackson took home eight prizes at the Billboard Music Awards on the strength of her 1989 smash album, ``Rhythm Nation: 1814.'' The 24-year-old sister of Michael Jackson was named the year's No. 1 rhythm and blues artist, R&B albums artist, R&B singles artist and Hot 100 singles artist. ``Rhythm Nation'' was chosen best pop album and best R&B album Monday night. The singer was also named top dance artist and top dance singles artist. The awards are given by Billboard magazine and are based on the artists' record sales. Other winners included M.C. Hammer, for top pop and rap artist, and Sinead O'Connor, for the top-ranking worldwide hit single ``Nothing Compares 2 U.'' Phil Collins won three awards: top adult contemporary artist, adult contemporary single for the song ``Do You Remember'' and worldwide album for ``... But Seriously.'' Miss Jackson, who composed or helped compose seven of the 12 songs on ``Rhythm Nation'' and co-produced the record, said her goal was to ``mix social consciousness with dance music'' and ``affect people in a positive way.'' ``The most rewarding thing for me was to actually meet kids who had dropped out of school, had been hooked on drugs, or had even tried to take their own lives, but were inspired to change through `Rhythm Nation,''' she said. The date in the album title refers to the year Francis Scott Key wrote the national anthem. Miss Jackson said she believed her song ``Rhythm Nation'' could be ``the national anthem for the '90s.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against most major foreign currencies today in early European trading. Gold prices were lower. Dealers said trading was quiet ahead of today's release of the latest U.S. trade balance figures. ``The market is quite uncertain,'' a Milan trader said. ``Trading is very thin and investors are nervous about which way to go.'' In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.00 yen to a closing 128.95 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 128.80 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: -1.4883 German marks, down from 1.4920 -1.2635 Swiss francs, down from 1.2680 -5.0197 French francs, down from 5.0300 -1.6784 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6823 -1,116.50 Italian lire, down from 1,118.75 -1.1615 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1596 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9700, up from $1.9655 late Monday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $384.25 per ounce at midmorning, down from $387.00 bid per ounce late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $384.00, down from $386.50 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.16 to close at a bid $385.19. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.16 a troy ounce, down from Monday's $4.18.

DOC.HEAD: Snow in West; Rain and Record Warmth in Midwest
DOC.TEXT: The eastern half of the nation had unseasonably warm weather today, while the West got snow. Temperatures were in the 70s early today in the upper Mississippi Delta region and in the high 60s in many Midwest cities. Near-record warmth was forecast for areas of the Ohio Valley, mid-Atlantic and Northeast today. Record warmth also was likely in Midwest regions that lay east of a cold front that stretched across the eastern Plains. Snow fell in Wyoming, Washington, Colorado, Oregon, North Dakota, South Dakota and Nebraska. Freezing rain fell in Nebraska and Michigan. Temperatures early today were 7 degrees at Bismarck, N.D., and in the teens in parts of the Rockies. Showers fell across much of the Midwest, Great Lakes region, Ohio Valley and into the Northeast. Rain also fell in the South. The nation's high on Monday was 89 degrees at Alice, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Brazilian State Elections Seen as Setback for President ^By STAN LEHMAN ^Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: President Fernando Collor de Mello suffered a sweeping defeat in gubernatorial runoff elections whose results were widely considered a rejection of his tough anti-inflation policies. The runoffs were held Sunday in 15 of the country's 26 states where none of the candidates obtained an absolute majority in the first round. Collor's allies lost the runoffs in each of five major states contested Sunday: Sao Paulo, Rio Grande do Sul, Minas Gerais, Parana and Espirito Santo, according to results that came in Monday. Results in the other six, more isolated states were expected to trickle in. ``The overall picture is terrible for the president,'' said presidential chief of staff Marcos Coimbra. The results seemed to show a sudden plunge in Collor's political fortunes. His allies had swept to victory in 10 of 11 state governors' races that were determined in the first round of voting, on Oct. 3. Political analysts said the election of opposition governors in the major states would make it difficult for Collor to obtain congressional support for his economic programs, which have frozen wages despite continued severe inflation. Brazil's governors are powerful. Under a 1988 constitution, states get a guaranteed share of federal tax receipts, and governors have a large measure of influence over their states' congressional delegations. One key state, Rio de Janeiro, was won in the first round by populist Leonel Brizola, a strong critic of Collor. In Sao Paulo, Brazil's wealthiest and most populous state, Luiz Antonio Fleury Filho of the moderate Brazilian Democratic Movement Party defeated Paulo Salim Maluf of the conservative Social Democratic Party in the runoff vote. Maluf, a wealthy businessman and former governor, was discreetly backed by Collor. In the important southern farming state of Rio Grande do Sul, victor Alceu de Deus Collares of the leftist Democratic Labor Party said the government should interpret the results ``as a warning of the people's opposition to economic policies that provoke recession, unemployment and bankruptcies.''

DOC.HEAD: Pinochet Still Army Chief, but Political Power Fades
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS age to 75 in 2d graf. Birthday was Nov. 25
DOC.TEXT: Former President Augusto Pinochet still is the army commander, but has been losing political ground to Patricio Aylwin, the elected civilian who succeeded him. Even right-wing politicians who supported the 75-year-old general during his 16{ years of military rule, which ended in March, are saying he should stay out of politics. The annual revision of the armed forces high command this month gave Aylwin the opportunity for a clear demonstration of his political authority. For the first time since the political coup that brought him to power in 1973, the makeup of the high command was not determined by Pinochet alone. Aylwin vetoed the promotions of two generals. Pinochet challenged his right to do so but Aylwin was upheld by the General Comptroller's office, which rules on the legality of government decisions. Pinochet retained command of the army after leaving the presidency, under a clause in the 1980 constitution the military regime wrote, and Aylwin cannot fire him. Before the transfer of power, aides to Aylwin predicted the general would retain great political authority and threaten Chile's newly restored democratic rule. That has not happened.
