Most observers acknowledge Pinochet's power has faded, for several reasons: a financial scandal involving army officers, Aylwin's skillful handling of relations with the military and the disciplined, non-political attitude of the other service commanders. In occasional comments to reporters, Pinochet insists he now is ``totally out of politics,'' but some of his public actions suggest otherwise. Last May, he publicly criticized Aylwin's establishment of a commission to investigate human rights abuses under the military regime. In response, Aylwin summoned the general to the presidential palace and rejected the ``political connotations'' of his remarks. Later, Pinochet caused an international incident by saying the German army was made up in part of ``marijuana smokers, drug addicts, longhairs, hommosexuals and unionists.'' After Aylwin condemned the comments, Pinochet withdrew them and apologized. On Sept. 11, the 17th anniversary of the coup, Pinochet caused a political uproar by saying he would do it again under the same circumstances. Even some old supporters are putting distance between themselves and the general, saying he has has no legitimate political role. ``Gen. Pinochet is no longer a political option in Chile,'' said Sebastian Pinera, a leading right-wing senator. Another senator, who was an ambassador under Pinochet, sided with Aylwin in the dispute over the high command. Pro-goverment politicians who once feared the continued presence of Pinochet as army commander now say they may have been wrong. ``Pinochet is not yet checkmated, but he is nearing the end of his match,'' said Camilio Escalona, a Socialist congressman. Loyalty to Pinochet and support for him are believed to be firm in the army, but only in his military capacity. Aylwin told an interviewer on state television he does not think he will have trouble with the army, and said of Pinochet: ``I understand that he who ruled the country as an absolute master for nearly 17 years now has trouble accommodating to his new role, subordinated to the president of the republic and to the minister of defense.'' The conflict with Aylwin on the high command caught Pinochet in a weakened position. A congressional commission is investigating an army payment to one of his sons of the equivalent of $3 million, apparently for the purchase of a metallurgy plant. Newspapers have reported in recent weeks on an illegal savings and loan organization in which several army officers participated. Many Chileans expect a decisive moment in relations between Pinochet and the civilian government in February, when the commission investigating human rights abuses issues its final report. Trials are expected to result, many of them involving military officers. Before leaving office, Pinochet said repeatedly he would not accept trials of military men on human rights issues.

DOC.HEAD: State Abandons Plan To Evict 73-Year-Old Squatter
DOC.TEXT: State officials who fought for three decades to throw a woman off a strip of beachfront property slated to become a state park have decided she doesn't have to leave after all. Doris Gagnon was to be evicted Friday from her rundown collection of shacks and trailers overlooking Long Island Sound. But state Attorney General Clarine Nardi Riddle announced Monday that officials have decided to let the 73-year-old cancer-stricken woman stay. Riddle said the decision was made after officials learned that bags of human waste had been removed from the property and other sanitation violations cleaned up. She also said officials don't need the land right away. But Gagnon said health conditions at her home are no better than before, and she accused state officials of letting her stay in the hope that their battle with her will end when she dies. ``I won't give them the satisfaction of dying,'' she added. Gagnon, who originally owned a house on the property, refused to sell it to the state in the 1960s. The government seized it through eminent domain proceedings and awarded her $15,000 that she refused to take. She began squatting on the property after the government demolished her house 19 years ago. State officials made no effort to evict her until two years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Advocates Decry Subway Begging Ban
DOC.TEXT: Advocates for the homeless denounced a Supreme Court decision to keep intact a ban on subway begging. ``What this decision does is gives police the authority to arbitrarily harass homeless and poor people,'' said Doug Lasdon, an attorney from the Legal Action Center for the Homeless. Without comment, the Supreme Court Monday declined to review the case Lasdon's group had asked it to hear. The group argued the ban infringes on free-speech rights. Transit officials praised the high court's refusal to review the ban, saying it will help restore order underground. ``Nobody likes to push around poor people,'' said Jared Lebow, a spokesman for the Transit Authority, which runs the nation's largest subway system with 3.5 million daily riders. ``But we also recognize that our obligation is to people who use the system to get to and from work.'' The ban was imposed in October 1989. The objective was to crack down on vagrancy in subways, where many of the city's estimated 80,000 homeless people go to stay warm, sleep and beg for small change. No fine is imposed. Beggars are merely removed or directed to a service agency for help.

DOC.HEAD: Road Closed After Truck Carrying Explosives Crashes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to CORRECT to 30,000 pounds sted 50,000 tons. ADDS that road expected to reopen later today.
DOC.TEXT: A tanker truck carrying 30,000 pounds of mining explosives rolled over and spilled most of its cargo, forcing the closing of a 15-mile stretch of highway, officials said. West Virginia 39 was expected to reopen later today after workers cleared it of the ammonium nitrate, Nicholas County chief deputy Bobby Gordon said. The accident occurred about 40 miles east of Charleston. The driver, Earl W. Harmon, 24, was in satisfactory condition today at Charleston Area Medical Center.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say No Evidence of Violent Conspiracy in Strike
DOC.TEXT: Police say they have no evidence that either New York Daily News management or its unions have conspired to commit violent acts during the monthlong strike against the newspaper. Daily News Publisher James Hoge told a joint state Senate and Assembly labor panel hearing in New York City on Monday that the newspaper's nine striking unions are responsible for a series of violent incidents. ``Clearly, violence and intimidation are longstanding and premeditated tools of these unions to lawlessly enforce their will,'' he said. Union officials accused Daily News management of precipitating attacks on strikers. But police officials testified there was no evidence to support the allegations of either side. ``We haven't been able at this point to put together some type of conspiracy,'' said Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli. ``We don't see a conspiracy at all here as of now.'' Chief of Department Robert Johnston said 107 people had been arrested in connection with the strike as of Friday, 75 of whom were union members. Seventeen were non-strikers and 15 were people whose involvement was not immediately clear, he said. Meanwhile, Daily News officials reported the newspaper expects to lose $30 million to $35 million during the last quarter of 190, bringing its losses for the year to $80 million to $90 million. The Daily News lost $115 million between 1979 and 1989, said John T. Sloan, the newspaper's vice president for human resources. The newspaper's financial problems continued Monday when another big company decided to pull its advertising. Sloan said Alexander's department store joined Macy's and A & S department stores in dropping its ads. The Daily News has managed to publish continuously since the strike began Oct. 25, but Sloan said its circulation has fallen from 1.09 million before the strike to 508,000 as of Nov. 16.

DOC.HEAD: List of Israeli Clashes in Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Following is a list of recent incidents involving Israeli forces in Lebanon: Oct. 21 - Israeli soldiers and allied Lebanese militiamen pursued and attacked a Lebanese guerrilla squad spotted inside Israel's buffer zone in south Lebanon. The militiamen caught up with them outside the zone and killed four of them, the army said. Oct. 24 - Israeli jets bombed a guerrilla position near Rachadiya in south Lebanon from which Katyusha rockets were fired into Israel and the buffer zone, the army said. On the same day, it said, Israeli troops swept north of the buffer zone and killed two guerrillas in a raid on a base of the Lebanese Shiite Moslem militia Hezbollah, or Party of God, at the village of Hunah, 15 miles north of the border. Nov. 9 - Israeli tanks, paratroopers and infantry attacked three Hezbollah bases west of Jezzine. The raid came a day after Israel said it would protect the Christians of Jezzine, which is outside the Israeli-controlled zone. No casualties were reported. Nov. 20 - An Israeli officer and four Palestinians were killed when a patrol ambushed a guerrilla squad near Ain Atta, north of the buffer zone in Lebanon. Police in Lebanon said the squad was from the Palestine Popular Struggle Front, a Libyan-backed PLO faction. Nov. 24 - An Israeli navy vessel killed five armed guerrillas in a dinghy off the Lebanese coast as they headed to a raid on Israel, the army said. A Syrian-backed PLO faction, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, said it sent the dinghy. Nov. 25 - A Lebanese woman strapped with explosives blew herself up as she approached an Israeli army patrol near the Beaufort Crusader castle in south Lebanon, the army said. It said two Israeli soldiers were slightly wounded. A Lebanese faction, the Syrian Socialist Nationalist Party, said the woman was one of its members. Nov. 27 - Five Israeli soldiers and at least two Palestinian guerrillas were killed in a clash near Shebaa, on the edge of the eastern sector of the buffer zone, the army said. It said the guerrilas belonged to the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a PLO faction led by George Habash.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Appeals for Help to Defeat `Third Force'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Walesa appealing for help from Mazowiecki allies, Tyminski praising imposition of martial law, new quotes, edits to trim. No pickup. Stanislaw Tyminski is pronounced stan-ihsh-LAWV tih-MIHN-skee.
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa said today that an emigre's strong presidential bid was a ``cold shower'' for Solidarity and appealed to former rivals for help to defeat what he called this dangerous ``third force.'' The outsider, businessman Stanislaw Tyminski, shocked reporters at a news conference by praising Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's 1981 decision to impose martial law to crush Solidarity. He said the country then was under ``unusual danger'' from within. Meanwhile, main national newspapers mourned the fall of the East bloc's first non-Communist government after it resigned Monday night. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki's government was a ``good and right'' cause, one said. Walesa, who will face Tyminski in a runoff Dec. 9, met the press in a packed conference room in Gdansk and extended an olive branch to supporters of Mazowiecki, his vanquished rival within Solidarity. ``We are doomed to be together. ... We should pull this common Polish wagon together,'' Walesa said. ``We have to complete the Polish reforms. This is what the prime minister was (only) saying, and I am trying to actually carry out.'' Walesa polled 40 percent of the electorate in Poland's first democratic presidential elections Sunday. Tyminski got 23 percent and Mazowiecki 18. Walesa said he had warned that Solidarity was losing support from the masses. ``Those people who were with Mazowiecki, who really worked so hard, did not want to understand,'' he said. ``This cold shower will wake us all up and we will think seriously about reforms in Poland.'' Now, he said, ``A third force is possible and capable of overthrowing us all.'' Lame duck President Jaruzelski formally asked Mazowiecki to carry on a caretaker government until the next president names a prime minister, and Mazowiecki agreed to stay on. Walesa told reporters he would like ``the smallest changes possible'' in personnel until parliamentary elections in the spring. Walesa said he would telephone Mazowiecki and appeal for ``not multiplying the tension.'' Tyminski, who lived 21 years in Canada and Peru running a string of computer and communications companies, returned to his homeland in September and launched a bid for president. At a packed news conference in Warsaw, he attacked sacred cows of Polish political life, including praising Jaruzelski and damning Mazowiecki for his economic policies and for alleged cooperation with Communist authorities as a journalist in the early 1950s. Of Jaruzelski's martial-law decision, he said: ``I hope that this country understands now how much has been done for it by President Wojciech Jaruzelski, because at that moment (in 1981) the country was in unusual danger ... from within, because the hand that did the injury for so many years was always our own.'' ``They are very irresponsible,'' he said, referring to the shock economic reform program instituted in January to almost universal praise from the world financial community. ``Even if nothing had been done, there would not be destruction on such a scale.'' A radical economic restructuring plan, backed by both Walesa and Mazowiecki, has caused real wages in Poland to plummet 35 percent. Unemployment climbed from almost zero at the start of 1990 to more than 1 million today. Mazowiecki in his resignation statement Monday night said he had been brought down by lack of public patience for the sacrifices required to improve the economy. ``Poland's painful but necessary program of getting out of economic catastrophe can only be realized with the understanding of the majority of the nation,'' he said. ``Society made its choice.'' The taciturn, lawyerly prime minister, who took office in August 1989 after decades as a writer in the Catholic opposition, won international acclaim for his historic role in the democratization of his nation. ``It happens that good and right causes lose,'' said Adam Michnik, editor of the pro-Mazowiecki paper Gazeta Wyborcza, Poland's largest. ``Rational argument lost out in a dispute with aggressive rhetoric and faith in a miracle.'' Walesa and Mazowiecki had been allies in the underground Solidarity movement but have headed rival wings of the organization since shortly after the prime minister took office. Walesa contended reforms had to be speeded up to avert social unrest while Mazowiecki, the longtime adviser Walesa had picked to be prime minister, stuck by an independent policy of measured, reasoned change. Mazowiecki's election committee seemed to throw its support to Walesa in a grudging way. In a statement, it described Tyminski's possible election as an unallowable ``tragedy'' for Poland and said supporters should do ``whatever serves the interests of the country.''

DOC.HEAD: Existing HomeSales Down 4.7 Percent, Realtors Report
DOC.TEXT: Existing home sales fell 4.7 percent in October to their lowest level in nearly six years, a real estate trade group said today. The National Association of Realtors said house resales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.02 million, compared to 3.17 million in September. It was the lowest sales rate since February 1985 when it dropped to 2.95 million. Reports of persistent budget deficit woes, general economic sluggishness nationwide and the threat of war against Iraq have created psychological barriers that are blocking home purchases, according to Harley E. Rouda, NAR president. Mortgage interest rates, which had been blamed for weak sales in previous months, have remained relatively stable, Rouda noted. He said the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. reported the average rate for a 30-year, conventional fixed-rate mortgage ranged between 10.08 percent and 10.17 percent during October. Rouda said the current rates are in marked contrast to the last home-buying slump in 1982, when rates ranged between 16.0 percent and 18.0 percent. And, he added, despite tight credit restrictions for commercial development projects, mortgage funds remain plentiful for home buyers. At the same time, the Realtors said the median price of an existing home was $92,800 in October, down 1.7 percent from September. The median means half of the homes cost more, half less. Rouda said the monthly decline and a ``marginal'' 0.4 percent increase over October 1989 means that sellers are adjusting their prices to fit a buyer's market. Month-to-month sales declines were recorded in each of the regions while all but the West posted lower median prices. In the Northeast, the resale pace was 470,000 units, 9.6 percent below the September rate. The median price was $136,200, down 0.7 percent from the previous month. Sales in the West totaled 490,000 in October, down 5.8 percent from the previous month. The median price there was $140,600, 4.4 percent higher than in September. In the Midwest, sales were off 5.7 percent, to an annual rate of 820,000 units, while the median price fell 2.8 percent to $72,100. Sales in the South totaled 1.23 million, down 2.4 percent from September. The median price dropped 2.9 percent, to $83,400. The Realtors said sales of existing homes are expected to total 3.33 million units this year, down 4.1 percent from 1989's 3.44 million total.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Bluntly Warns Saddam That Time is Running Out
With PM-Gulf-UN, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Gorbachev, Shevardnadze meeting Saudi foreign minister, Gorbachev dispatching envoys to Iran, Cuba. Pickup 11th graf pvs, `Gorbachev appeared...'
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has issued his sharpest warning yet to Saddam Hussein, saying Iraq will soon face grave consequences if it doesn't withdraw from Kit and release all hostages. Gorbachev summoned Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to the Kremlin on Monday to deliver a stern message to Saddam that no one takes seriously Baghdad's claim that Kuwait is Iraqi territory, and that time is running out. Unless Iraq obeys U.N. resolutions demanding its withdrawal, Gorbachev said it faces ``the worst'' consequences, the official Tass news agency reported. Gorbachev also told Aziz that Iraq must keep its promises to allow the departure of all Soviet contract workers who want to go home. Another Soviet official on Monday accused Iraq of reneging on an agreement to let about 1,000 Soviets leave this month. It was the first time Moscow had charged that Baghdad was keeping Soviet citizens against their will. Iraq was until recently a close ally of Moscow, and the Soviets supplied Baghdad with a wide array of armaments. Gorbachev accused Saddam of failing to conform to accepted standards of morality and of turning the release of foreigners into a kind of bargaining, Tass reported. Aziz reportedly responded that the delayed evacuation of Soviets was a ``bureaucratic accident.'' On Monday, the United States finally won Soviet support for a U.N. resolution authorizing the use of military force against Iraq. Foreign ministers are expected to meet in New York on Thursday to take it up. The Soviet Union has attemped to explore all possible diplomatic avenues before endorsing the use of force to push Iraq from Kuwait. Gorbachev and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze met today with Saudi Foreign Minister Prince Saud al-Faisal. No details were reported. In addition, Gorbachev is sending envoys to discuss the crisis with Iran and Cuba. He dispatched Deputy Foreign Minister Vladimir Petrovsky to Tehran, and another foreign ministry official, Georgy Mamedov, was to leave later today for Havana. Cuba is a member of the Security Council. Gorbachev appeared before the Supreme Soviet parliament on Monday and forcefully warned Saddam that the unity of nations allied against Iraqi aggression cannot be broken. Answering questions from legislators about the possibility of hostilities in the gulf, Gorbachev said the crisis was a test of the new post-Cold War cooperation. ``Our position remains based on principles and it includes the following: Aggression is inadmissible. It should be punished, and the pre-aggression state should be restored,'' Gorbachev said in a booming voice. He said Saddam's aggression could not be allowed to prevail ``because we are just moving away from the Cold War, when everything was decided from a position of force.'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin said Iraq had agreed to allow 1,000 Soviets, mostly contract workers, to leave during November, but only about 350 were permitted to do so. About 8,000 Soviets, including several hundred military advisers, were in Iraq and Kuwait at the time of the Aug. 2 invasion. About 3,000 left shortly after the invasion and about 1,000 more left during September and October. ``If Iraq does not immediately remove obstacles and allow our citizens to leave, this will complicate the present situation even further and force us to take a tougher attitude,'' Churkin said. To his knowledge, Churkin said, no Soviets are being used as human shields at potential military targets.

DOC.HEAD: Bridge's Collapse in Seattle Storm Puts Second Span in Danger
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with westbound lanes of new bridge re-opened this morning, Picks up 9th graf pvs, `The weekend ...'
DOC.TEXT: An old floating bridge that collapsed during heavy weekend rains tore support cables from an adjacent span as it gave way, threatening the main link between Seattle and its eastern suburbs, officials say. The 50-year-old Lake Washington bridge, which had been closed for repairs, went down Sunday when its pontoons were swamped following a storm that devastated the state and dumped 3{ inches of rain on Seattle. At least one person was missing and believed dead because of the storm, and more than 2,600 people were driven from their homes by floodwaters. As the Lake Washington bridge toppled, it snapped a dozen support cables on the adjacent Interstate 90 bridge. Even as engineers decided to re-open the three westbound lanes of that bridge this morning, they said high winds could cause it to sway or even collapse. ``If a storm comes, it could damage the new bridge,'' said Ron Kinoshita, a state engineer. ``All that wind velocity could break the bridge.'' The National Weather Service said a storm late Wednesday or Thursday could bring winds of 40 mph. Ron Anderson, district administrator for the state Department of Transportation, said winds of 20 mph or more could pose problems. ``We don't want anyone on the bridge if it's in danger of breaking up,'' Anderson said. The year-old I-90 bridge, over which as many as 110,000 cars a day pass, was closed Monday, causing rush-hour gridlock that delayed commuters into and out of downtown for nearly an hour. With the 1{-mile-long I-90 bridge out, motorists were left with the choice of driving around the lake, a trip of 20 miles, or taking the four-lane Evergreen Point bridge, which is normally jammed. This morning, calm weather allowed commuters from the eastern suburbs to come into Seattle on the I-90 bridge's westbound lanes. The eastbound lanes remained closed as a platform for repair and inspection. Officials said they could close the bridge again within minutes if wind picked up. The weekend rainstorms caused 20 rivers to flood. Damage was estimated at $100 million. Scot Alan Scott, 28, of Duvall, was presumed drowned after he was swept into the Snoqualmie River near Seattle on Sunday when he got out of his stalled car, police said. Firefighters rescued his wife and 6-month-old son from the river.

DOC.HEAD: Five Israelis Killed After Firefight With Guerrillas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 16th graf, `The clash ...' to CORRECT distance to 28 miles sted 13. Pickup 17th pvs, `The Israeli navy...
DOC.TEXT: Five Israeli soldiers and at least two Arab guerrillas were killed today in a clash in southern Lebanon, and Israeli warplanes later attacked bases of the terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal. The fighting began shortly after midnight near Shebaa, a village on the eastern edge of Israel's self-proclaimed security zone, after Israeli troops arrived by helicopter to battle a guerrilla unit, security sources in Lebanon said. It was the third clash with Palestinians in the security zone in a week. An Israeli military communique from Jerusalem said the soldiers ``stormed a ring of four guerrillas who were on their way toward Israeli territory.'' It said: ``In an exchange of fire at close range accompanied by the throwing of hand grenades, five soldiers were killed and another was wounded.'' Two of the guerrillas were killed and two fled the area, including one who was wounded, the statement said. The Lebanese sources said eight guerrillas were killed in the fighting, which they said lasted 2{ hours. There were also conflicting accounts of how the Israeli soldiers had died. Israel radio said one guerrilla may have been carrying explosives on his back that blew up when he was shot. Israel's army radio said at least one Israeli soldier died when a grenade blew up in his hands. Yet another report, from a Lebanese source, said the bodies of the guerrillas might have been booby-trapped. The site of the clash ``is a known infiltration route to Israel used by terrorists'' and the guerrillas carried explosives, an Israeli military spokesman said, speaking on condition of anonymity. George Habash's Marxist Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine claimed in a communique from Beirut that it staged the attack, which came exactly a week after Israeli troops intercepted another guerrilla squad in roughly the same area. In that battle, Israeli troops killed four guerrillas of another radical PLO group backed by Libya, the Palestine Popular Struggle Front of Samir Goshe, and lost a lieutenant. Before Habash's claim, four Israeli fighter-bombers fired 12 rockets into a hilltop position of Abu Nidal's faction, the Fatah-Revolutionary Council, near Sidon, provincial capital of southern Lebanon. Palls of black smoke billowed from the stricken base after the three-minute air raid, the 19th Israeli air raid in Lebanon this year. There was no immediate report on casualties. Abu Nidal, whose real name is Sabri al-Banna, split from Yasser Arafat's mainstream guerrilla faction, Fatah, in the early 1970s. Since then, he has topped wanted lists around the world for masterminding scores of bloody terrorist attacks to dramatize the Palestinian cause. The Palestine Liberation Organization has sentenced him to death for killing dozens of aides to Arafat. His Fatah-Revolutionary Council is Libyan funded and has bases in Lebanon. Defense Minister Moshe Arens said both the border attack and the bombing raids were part of Israel's ``constant activity by ground, sea and air ... to ensure the safety of Israelis in the north of the country.'' The clash near Shebaa, 28 miles southeaset of Sidon, came two days after a woman suicide bomber detonated a handbag packed with explosives as she walked past an Israeli infantry patrol in the security zone, injuring two soldiers. The Israeli navy on Saturday sank a rubber dinghy off the southrn Lebanon coast, killing five guerrillas of the pro-Syrian Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command. The escalating violence sharpened fears that southern Lebanon is becoming a flash point that could frustrate Syrian-backed President Elias Hrawi's attempts to assert government authority and end Lebanon's 15{-year-old civil war. Hrawi said over the weekend that he would seek international help to end Israel's occupation of the security zone once the government completes plans to get Moslem and Christian militias out of Beirut. Israel carved out the zone when it pulled out the bulk of its invading army in the summer of 1985, ending a three-year occupation of much of Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Some Employee Health Plans Not Subject to State Insurance Laws
DOC.TEXT: Self-funded employee health care plans, which cover some 9.5 million working Americans, are not subject to state insurance laws and regulations, the Supreme Court ruled today. The court, by a 7-1 vote, said in the case of a seriously injured Pennsylvania teen-age girl that federal regulation of such plans pre-empts any state regulation. Self-funded plans are those in which all benefits are paid directly by an employer, and not purchased through an independent insurance company. In an opinion by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, the court said such health care plans are governed by the federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA). ``In view of Congress' clear intent to exempt from direct state insurance regulation ERISA employee benefit plans, we hold that ERISA pre-empts (Pennsylvania law),'' O'Connor wrote. Justice John Paul Stevens was the sole dissenter. Justice David H. Souter, who joined the court after the case was argued last month, did not participate in the decision. The Illinois-based FMC Corp. has a self-funded plan for its employees and their dependents, and that plan paid for a substantial part of the more than $178,000 in medical expenses incurred by Cynthia Ann Holliday since a January 1987 automobile accident in Indiana County, Pa. Miss Holliday, then 15, suffered permanent injuries when the car in which she was a passenger crashed. Her father, Gerald, is an FMC employee. Holliday sued the car's driver, Robert Lyons, in state court. Under a settlement, Miss Holliday's financial recovery was limited to $49,875.50 plus interest. When FMC sought to recover some of its expenses by claiming the lawsuit settlement funds, Holliday successfully invoked a Pennsylvania law that prohibits such action. FMC then turned to a federal trial judge for help, contending that the federal law, ERISA, was meant to be the sole means of regulating its health care plan and that it therefore pre-empted the prohibitive Pennsylvania law. The trial judge, and the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, ruled against FMC. But today's decision reversed the lower court rulings, saying FMC was right in its contention that the federal law superseded any state regulation. The justices sent the case back to the lower courts, where presumably FMC will be able to recover the money Miss Holliday won in the lawsuit against Lyons. FMC's appeal to the nation's highest court has been supported by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, the Self-Insurance Institute of America and numerous self-funded health and welfare plans. The case is FMC Corp. vs. Holliday, 89-1048.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Watches As Allies Fail To Push Treaty Through Russian Congress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Gorbachev quotes, background on other republics' position. Pickup 8th graf, `Yeltsin said ...'
DOC.TEXT: Allies of Mikhail S. Gorbachev failed today to win quick approval by the Russian republic's congress for the president's proposed treaty to keep the union together. Russian reformers argued the proposal should be discussed thoroughly by the public before lawmakers vote on it. Quick adoption of the union treaty by the largest of the 15 republics would have been a tremendous victory for Gorbachev as he tries to keep the country from splintering. It would have been a defeat for Russia's president, Boris N. Yeltsin, and other republic leaders who are trying to diminish the central government's power. Approval of the union treaty would commit them to remain united with a strong central government headed by President Gorbachev. Gorbachev told legislators he personally lobbied Yeltsin during a break in the session, according to the independent news service Interfax. ``Naturally, Russia's position on this question has great significance, for without Russia, there is no union,'' Gorbachev said. As Gorbachev beamed from an isolated balcony in the Grand Kremlin Palace, his allies in the Congress of Russian Peoples' Deputies tried to force Yeltsin to include adoption of the treaty on the congress' agenda. The congress is much more loyal to Gorbachev and to the central government than te smaller Russian Supreme Soviet legislature, which Yeltsin easily controls. The congress is holding an extraordinary session to discuss Russia's economic woes and consider legalizing private land ownership. Largely through sheer stubbornness, Yeltsin refused to allow hard-line Communists to add approval of the treaty to the agenda. Instead, he called for an ``exchange of opinions'' on the treaty and won approval by a vote of 696 to 199 with 36 abstentions. Despite the failed end-run, Gorbachev insisted that ``in the end, all the republics will sign the union treaty. Even those who shout against it won't be able to do anything. They are all just loudmouths.'' ``You carry out a referendum and everything will be clear,'' Gorbachev told the Russian legislators, according to Interfax. There has been no decision on holding a referendum on the union treaty. Gorbachev has said repeatedly that he believes most citizens want the Soviet Union to remain whole. However, leaders of six of the 15 republics have said they will not sign the new union treaty. They are the Ukraine, Georgia, Armenia, Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia. Yeltsin said earlier this month that Russia would not sign the treaty unless the republic's ``real sovereignty'' could be assured and unless the issue of resource ownership was resolved. The proposed treaty would give republics control over most areas except defense and the monetary system. The central government and the republics would share responsibility for economic development, transportation, energy and the space program. On a more conciliatory note, Yeltsin told lawmakers that continued confrontation between Russia and the national government was ``unacceptable.'' Speaking of his personal differences with Gorbachev, he said ``for such a struggle, we simply don't have any more time.'' Yeltsin said the Russian leadership understood the central government's importance to ``the normal functioning of our and other republics.'' But he insisted ``we cannot agree to anybody's interference with problems we can solve ourselves better than anyone else. We shall do all we can to change this situation.'' ``Responsibility for the worsening of the republic's affairs must be carried by federal bodies and destructive forces in the republic,'' Yeltsin said. He vowed that Russia would use ``only political methods'' to solve its problems and said the army must not be used for any political purpose. Yeltsin said the main task of the congress was to discuss how to feed the Russian people during the winter. He said this task threatened to overshadow all other issues. ``Delays in solving this problem threaten Russia's revival,'' he warned.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Wins Soviet, Chinese Support Resolution; Three Americans Freed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf from end, `The freed' to CORRECT name to Clyde, sted Claude. Stands for PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: The United States has won the backing of the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France for a U.N. resolution threatening to use ``all necessary means'' to drive Iraq from Kuwait if it does not leave by January. Meanwhile, 18 foreigners, including three Americans, arrived in the Jordanian capital today after being freed by Iraqi officials. The Americans were released after their relatives went to Baghdad to plead for their freedom. At the urgent request of Kuwait, the Security Council was meeting today to hear accusations of Iraqi terror, torture, imprisonment and summary executions in the emirate. Some Kuwaiti refugees were to tell the council their stories. But the focus was on Security Council action anticipated later in the week. With Monday's agreement on the use-of-force measure among the five permanent members, the broad coalition the United States has mustered against Saddam Hussein crossed a crucial threshold. There had been speculation the Soviets and Chinese might abstain on the resolution, which the 15-member council is expected to take up on Thursday. Secretary of State James A. Baker III has traveled the globe for weeks seeking support from Security Council members for the use-of-force resolution. Soviet Ambassador Yuli Vorontsov said on Monday he was ``enthusiastic'' about the new measure. The Security Council has already passed 10 resolutions condeming Iraq's Aug. 2 seizure of Kuwait and imposing trade sanctions. This may be the last resolution on the Persian Gulf crisis, Vorontsov said, ``because we all hope that after this, a peaceful settlement will be possible.'' King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, where most of the multinational force is deployed, has appealed to Saddam to ``let reason prevail'' and withdraw unconditionally from Kuwait. ``We do not want to see a tragedy befall Iraq,'' the Saudi monarch said. The remarks, made to a citizens' group in Saudi Arabia over the weekend, were circulated by Saudi media today. Saudi Arabia's foreign minister, Prince Saud Al-Faisal, arrived in Moscow today for talks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the Soviet foreign minister, the official Tass news agency reported. Gorbachev met with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in the Kremlin on Monday after telling lawmakers the alliance against Iraq would not be broken and said aggression ``should be punished.'' Another Soviet official, Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin, accused Iraq of preventing hundreds of Soviet citizens from leaving Iraq. It was the first time Moscow had charged that Baghdad was keeping its citizens against their will. Aziz returned to Baghdad on Monday night and accused the Security Council of pursuing a ``double standard'' by calling for Iraq's pullout from Kuwait without similarly pressuring Israel to leave the occupied territories. Iraq ``will continue to struggle steadfastly to realize peace and justice in the region, and to restore first and foremost the Palestinian Arab people's rights,'' Aziz said on Iraqi radio. Under the draft U.N. resolution, Iraq would have to release all foreign hostages, withdraw its troops and restore Kuwait's government by Jan. 1 or Jan. 15; the Security Council members have not yet fixed a date, and the draft contains both dates as options. ``It is a pause in which we're all making clear that no new measures will be taken against Iraq prior to the end of that period, after which the authorization to use all measures, which is of course, the United Nations language for measures which include the use of force, will become available,'' said British Ambassador David Hannay. The resolution would authorize ``member states cooperating with the government of Kuwait ... to use all necessary means to uphold and implement the Security Council resolutions passed in response to Iraq's invasion and occupation of Kuwait, and to restore international peace and security.'' It cites Chapter 7 of the U.N. Charter, which authorizes the use of military force to counter aggression if sanctions and other steps fail. The only other time military force was sanctioned by the United Nations was in 1950, during the Korean conflict. The foreign ministers of most Security Council members are expected to gather in New York on Thursday to adopt the resolution, with Baker presiding. The resolution is supported by at least six of the non-permanent council members: Canada, Finland, Romania, Ivory Coast, Zaire, Ethiopia. Cuban Ambassador Ricardo Alarcon said his country could not support it. Yemen, the council's only Arab member, is believed likely to abstain or vote against it. Malaysia and Colombia's votes are uncertain. A resolution requires at least nine votes to pass, so long as none of the permanent members vetoes it. Britain and the United States favor a Jan. 1 deadline, but U.S. officials in Washington indicated the resolution and date are negotiable. French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said today that he favors a Jan. 15 deadline. The freed foreigners who arrived in Jordan today are three Americans, 10 Britons and five Germans. The Americans are John Stevenson of Panama City, Fla.; Fred Harrington of Bellevue, Wash.; and Clyde Jesse of Buffalo Grove, Ill. In another development, a Spanish navy corvette, assisting the U.S. cruiser Philippine Sea and a French destroyer, fired warning shots to help stop and Iraqi freighter early today in the Red Sea, Spanish officials said. The Iraqi vessel was allowed to continue on its way after it was inspected by a U.S. Navy boarding party and found to be carrying no goods that violated the United Nations embargo.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Opens Hearings on Administration's Gulf Policy
DOC.NOTE: EDS: TOP 11 grafs new with Nunn, Kennedy comments; editing throughout to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Sam Nunn, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, questioned today whether it is in the vital interest of the United States to liberate Kuwait from Iraqi invaders. The Georgia Democrat said President Bush's decision to send 200,000 more troops to the Persian Gulf signals a fundamental shift in policy that raises a number of serious questions. ``Is it in our vital interest to liberate Kuwait? How long can we sustain more than 400,000 troops? Has President Bush limited his options by creating a use-it-or-lose-it situation?'' Nunn asked at the start of four days of hearings by his panel on Bush's gulf policy. The hearings were prompted by Bush's decision earlier this month to send more troops and build an ``offensive military option'' with a force that will total about 430,000 in the region by January. The decision touched off demands by many members of Congress for closer collaboration with the White House on gulf policy. Nunn indicated his support for a possible United Nations resolution authorizing military force against Iraq unless Saddam Hussein's troops leave Kuwait. The Security Council is expected to act on the measure this week. However, he said, ``this is not a substitute for fully informing the American people.'' Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., a member of the committee, said, ``It is not enough for President Bush to go to the United Nations to get approval for the use of military force in the Persian Gulf. He must also come to Congress.'' James Schlesinger, former secretary of defense and onetime CIA director, was the first witness at the hearings. Nunn had envisioned that Defense SecretaryDick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, would kick off the hearings. However, Cheney and Powell will delay their appearances before the panel until next week, after United Nations Security Council action on a resolution authorizing military force against Iraq unless Saddam Hussein's troops leave Kuwait. The panel's ranking Republican, Sen. John Warner of Virginia, said Cheney had delayed his testimony until next Monday ``to have a report from Secretary of State Baker on the U.N. resolution.'' Secretary James A. Baker III is in New York to press the Security Council to approve the resolution. Baker is to testify Dec. 5 before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Monday that Cheney and Powell ``were not too eager'' to testify while the United Nations was debating the resolution. Powell is scheduled to testify with Cheney on Monday. The absence of the administration's top defense officials - and the lack of a guarantee they would testify at all - fueled speculation about a struggle between Nunn, a possible 1992 Democratic challenger for Bush's job, and the White House. Nunn has been critical of the administration's policy since Bush announced the additional deployment of troops earlier this month. A Republican on the Armed Services Committee, Sen. Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming, called the hearings ill-timed while the administration ``is trying to finish the diplomatic end game.'' The timing of the hearings, he said, ``is what you do when your purpose is more political than policy. Not partisan politics, national politics. The chairman is opening a presidential campaign,'' Wallop said, referring to Nunn. Meanwhile, Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., asked that the House be called back from adjournment to discuss the U.N. resolution, lest war be raging by the time Congress returns in January. Schroeder, a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee, had contended two weeks ago it would be useless for Congress to return in a special session to debate a hypothetical action. ``All of a sudden the time has come,'' she said in a telephone interview. Several congressional leaders, including Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole, asked earlier this month for a special session, but that idea quickly died. Instead, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, called for hearings by several panels.

DOC.HEAD: Snowstorm Hampers Firefighters Battling Jet-Fuel Blaze
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with nine grafs to UPDATE with status of fire today, less threat to other tanks. Picks up 6th graf, `Fire Chief...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DX1
DOC.TEXT: A snowstorm today coated firefighters and their equipment with ice, but officials were confident they had a handle on a blaze feeding on millions of gallons of jet fuel at Stapleton International Airport. ``The flames are not near as intense as they have been. Things are boiling down to a simmer,'' said Fire Department spokesman Mike McNeill. As snow fell, about 60 firefighters sprayed water and foam on the fire burning an 800,000-gallon tank and a 350,000-gallon tank. The fire today did not pose a threat to the eight other storage tanks a half-mile from the airport tower, officials said. The fire, which started Sunday, reduced two 400,000-gallon tanks to smoldering, crumpled hulks. The tank farm had a 12.5-million gallon capacity. McNeill said he expected one of the tanks to burn itself out by mid-afternoon and the other by sometime Wednesday. ``This is a little fire, by comparison to what it was,'' airport spokesman Richard Boulware said today. Temperatures dropped below freezing Monday night, and the sprayed water froze on firefighters' clothing and equipment. Snow from the storm that began shortly before midnight Monday added moisture but also left dangerous layers of ice. The storm also knocked out pumps that firefighters had hoped to use to drain fuel. Fire Chief Richard Gonzales said all firefighters can do is let the fire burn itself out. ``You've got to let it consume itself. You physically can't smother it,'' Gonzales said. The cause of the blaze was under investigation. Temperatures near the fire reached 3,500 degrees, well beyond the melting point of iron and too hot for investigators to inspect control valves where the flames were first spotted. The valves are under several feet of water and foam. ``We don't know what's left down there at all,'' said arson investigator Ted Baldwin. A maintenance man performed routine chores 2{ hours before the blaze was spotted, said George Doughty, Denver aviation director. He also said there was no apparent break-in of the 8-foot chain-link fence capped with barbed wire. United Airlines, which owned the tanks, said it lost 2.6 million gallons of fuel to the fire, including about 400,000 from a 24-inch pipeline, but that all but a few of the airline's flights departed on time Monday. No other airlines' operations were affected Monday. Firefighters by midday Monday had used 15,000 gallons of foam to contain the blaze and had poured about 24 million gallons of water on the fire - approximately one-fourth of Denver's water use on an average fall day. The tanks that were destroyed were built in 1976 and probably won't be replaced. A new airport is scheduled for completion in the mid-1990s. In the interim, Doughty said, fuel will be stored in a pair of million-gallon tanks built in 1985 for a now-defunct airline. City officials said the new airport will feature a safer design. New building codes require control valves to be farther from the tanks so they can be shut off during a fire.

DOC.HEAD: Moldavian Secessionists Elect Parliament, Republic Declares it Void
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers in Moldavia today angrily rejected the election of a parliament by people in eastern Moldavia who want to form a separate republic, the official Tass news agency said. The development was the latest in a series of conflicts nationwide that have struck many of the 15 republics, as they themselves seek greater autonomy from the Kremlin. Some ethnic minorities within republics have declared allegiance to the Kremlin against leaders in their own republics. More than 380,000 voters in the self-proclaimed ``Dniester republic,'' a Russian-speaking area along the Dniester River in eastern Moldavia, chose the new parliament in an election on Sunday, the official news agency said. Leaders in the region, which had declared its sovereignty Sept. 2, said the new government would protect residents, mostly Ukrainians and Russians, from alleged discrimination by majority Moldavians, who speak Romanian. However, Moldavia's Supreme Soviet legislature today voted to declare the Dniester election null and void after the legislature's deputy speaker said the balloting had been rigged, Tass reported. ``In a number of constituencies, voting results were falsified and meetings with candidates, who had not been nominated by worker collectives, were held after the polls,'' said Deputy Speaker Victor Pushkash, Tass reported. The legislature called for self-restraint. Ethnic tensions turned violent last month when Moldavian security troops clashed with Dniester activists in the region, leaving four dead. Another secessionist group, the Gagauz minority in the republic's southern corner, also has declared sovereignty and is negotiating with Moldavian officials.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Examines `Depraved' Iraqi Human Rights Abuse
With PM-Gulf-UN, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with testimony today. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait have killed children in front of their parents and tortured prisoners with electric shocks and by beating the soles of their feet, Kuwait's government-in-exile said today. Kuwaiti U.N. Ambassador Mohammad Abulhasan said ``116 days have passed since the flagrant Iraqi aggression against all international laws and covenants, especially against the laws and values of our Islamic religion.'' ``Individual and mass arrests are unabated ... brutal torture of Kuwaitis continues in Kuwait itself'' and in Iraqi prisons, Abulhasan said. Kuwait introduced a draft resolution before the Security Council asking the United Nations to take custody of all its census and demographic records, which were smuggled out of Kuwait on 25 computer discs after the Aug. 2 invasion. Iraq has been seizing and destroying all citizenship records from Kuwaiti citizens in an attempt to erase their national identity, and has moved more than 100,000 Iraqis into occupied Kuwait to change its demographic character. As the Security Council members began their session, they gazed at enlargements of color photographs placed in the council chamber showing mutilated Kuwaiti citizens. At the urgent request of Kuwait, the Security Council took up the issue today and Wednesday, hearing from six or seven Kuwaiti refugees who escaped their homeland. The Security Council's rules allow non-diplomats to address the body, but U.N. officials with up to 30 years' experience said they could not recall the council ever hearing such testimony. The debate on alleged Iraqi brutality is expected to harden the Security Council's resolve for Thursday, when the five permanent members introduce a resolution that would allow U.S.-allied troops to drive Iraq from Kuwait if Saddam Hussein does not withdraw by January. Abulhasan also plans to show the council members videotape to support his assertions. Iraq has denied Kuwait's accusations of rights abuse since its invasion of Kuwait and no longer replies to individual allegations. Abulhasan's charges could not be independently verified. In a letter to the Security Council, Abulhasan said that ``over the last three weeks, the occupying forces have shown their true colors and revealed themselves as perfidious and depraved.'' He cited eyewitness accounts of the murder of children, including a Palestinian who said he and other drivers were detained in Kuwait. ``Then the street they were in was cleared and all who lived there were interrogated. The soldiers then opened fire on five little Kuwaiti girls who were blindfolded,'' Abulhasan said. In another incident, ``Iraqi soldiers opened fire and killed three Kuwaiti children in front of a supermarket. ``The children, aged 7 to 8 years old, were innocently chanting the national anthem of Kuwait and shouting the name of Sheikh Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the emir, as a group of Iraqi soldiers opened fire and shot them dead in front of their mother, who had a nervous breakdown,'' Abulhasan said. In another instance, army troops arrested three small girls. Ten days later they returned them to their homes, and opened fire on them in full view of their parents, said Abulhasan. Mullahs at mosques who did not cooperate in spreading propaganda for Saddam's ruling Baath Party have been killed or tortured, he said. Torture victims, including Indians, Moroccans, Egyptians and Kuwaitis, report a typical pattern of abuse, said Abulhasan. ``Detainees were continually tortured by havin electric cables attached to sensitive parts of their bodies and were whipped on the soles of the feet until they bled,'' Abulhasan said.

DOC.HEAD: Quadruplets Sign Up for Army Together
LaserPhoto BEJ1
DOC.TEXT: Families of soldiers in China are called ``glorious families,'' making the Song family near Beijing glorious four times over. Its 19-year-old quadruplet sons have all signed up to join the army. ``The government has helped to raise the four of us, so we want to serve the country in the army in return,'' the official China Daily newspaper on Monday quoted one of the four, Song Jianjie, as saying. Their birth captured public interest in 1971, and the government gave a special subsidy to the family to help feed the boys, the newspaper said. The four grew up in Changping County, a rural area outside Beijing. They reported last week for their army physicals. Under Chinese law, all males 18 and over may be drafted, but in practice annual recruitment quotas are filled largely by volunteers. Most are peasants who hope to be eligible for jobs in cities after their three years of service are up.

DOC.HEAD: Man Dies Under Hot Asphalt
DOC.TEXT: A businessman helping an out-of-towner with a stalled car was killed when a runaway dump truck crashed into a parking lot, struck the car and covered him in tons of steaming asphalt. Truck driver Terry Conner, 42, told police he was approaching a busy intersection Monday when an indicator showed a loss of brake pressure. ``His only option was to run into the traffic at the light or turn off into the parking lot,'' Police Officer Steve Tinder said. The truck crashed into a bank parking lot, striking three cars before dumping the asphalt and tipping over. The asphalt engulfed Charles H. Sprankle, general manager of a property management company. Sprankle, 71, was trying to help Miles Schlapik of Miami start a rented Cadillac when the accident occurred. ``He was trying to get my hood up to help,'' Schlapik said. ``I shook his hand and told him he was a fine person.'' Schlapik went across the street to a gasoline station to get a mechanic. Sprankle waited. When Schlapik returned, Sprankle was under more than 3 feet of asphalt. Conner escaped injury, and no charges were filed.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Shakes Dalmatian Coast
DOC.TEXT: A series of earthquakes shook the central Yugoslav Adriatic coast early Tuesday, halting rail traffic and causing slight damage but no injuries, the Tanjug news agency reported. The strongest quake, measuring 4.7 on the Richter scale, struck at 5:38 a.m. local time, the report said. The quake's epicenter was in the Dinara mountains, about 18 miles northeast of the central Adriatic port of Split, Tanjug said. Landslides apparently caused by the quake stopped rail traffic on the main line between Split and central Yugoslavia. Tanjug said the tremors caused cracks in the walls of older houses and panic among residents. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number means that the ground motion is 10 times greater.

DOC.HEAD: Official Suggests Marijuana-Generated Electricity
DOC.TEXT: A top state official claims his idea of burning marijuana to generate electrcity is far from a pipe dream. New South Wales state Minerals and Energy Minister Neil Pickard told Parliament on Tuesday that he had asked the Electricity Commission to examine the possibility of burning confiscated pot crops to generate electricity. ``Marijuana burns at extremely high temperatures and gives off considerable heat energy,'' he said. Pickard's comments were greeted with uproarious laughter, but he said it was a serious proposition. He said burning marijuana would be cheaper than coal and produce about as much energy. The Electricity Commission would look into what modifications would be needed for power stations to handle marijuana as well as coal, Pickard said. He said the state's power stations use an average of 20 million tons of coal a year.

DOC.HEAD: Government's Relief Checks Bounced
DOC.TEXT: Officials in the central Philippines were angry Tuesday after relief checks sent by President Corazon Aquino to help rebuild typhoon-devastated areas bounced. Sen. John Osmena quoted his brother, Cebu Gov. Emilio Osmena, as saying local officials received checks from the government totalling $125,000 to help recover from Typhoon Mike, which struck the country Nov. 13-14. But when officials tried to cash the checks Monday, Cebu government banks said there was no money in the accounts. ``The people of Cebu were very much hurt. ... What they gave us was very little - and even it bounced,'' the senator said. Provincial officials said they were told later that the funds were deposited in Manila banks on Friday and that there had not been enough time to notify branches in Cebu, 350 miles south.

DOC.HEAD: Volcanic Eruption Kills Four in East Java
DOC.TEXT: A river of lava from erupting Mount Kelud killed four people in the east Java town of Blitar, police said Tuesday. Lava had been streaming down the volcano without threatening people. But on Sunday it surged from the mountain and spilled out of the existing flow, hitting houses, bridges and farms in the Blitar region, police said. Blitar is about 550 miles east of Jakarta, the capital of Indonesia. Police said four people were killed and at least 77 families were left homeless. The homeless were being resettled in temporary housing, local officials said. Blitar, about 20 miles south of the 5,679-foot Mount Kelud, was badly damaged by falling dust, gravel and rocks blown over a radius of 31 miles when the volcano erupted in February. At least 24 people were killed and more than 350 houses were damaged during the eruption.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Leader Arrested After Street Fighting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with state of emergency declared. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The government declared a state of emergency today following weeks of violence by opposition forces demanding the resignation of President Hussain Mohammed Ershad. Ershad said in a televised speech that the emergency was being imposed to safeguard the country's internal security in the face of what he called a conspiracy to destroy the nation's economy. The proclamation suspended all civil rights and imposed press censorship. An indefinite curfew was imposed on Dhaka, the capital city of 7 million people, and the government arrested a top opposition leader. The action followed another day of rioting which left one person dead and an estimated 100 injured. Students poured into the streets of the Dhaka University campus, a focus of many anti-government demonstrations, shouting: ``We don't accept the emergency!'' and ``Down with Ershad!'' Sheik Hasina, leader of the Awami League, was taken from her husband's home in Dhaka and was later shifted to the residence of her late father, former President Sheik Mujibur Rahman, her spokesman said. Soon after news of her arrest spread thousands of people took to the street protesting her detention, witnesses said. The turmoil prompted the government to announce the curfew. The opposition has been demanding that Ershad quit and allow an interim government to suprevise presidential elections, claiming a fair vote was impossible under his rule. Ershad has refused to step aside, but has called an election for next year and invited international observers to attend, including former President Jimmy Carter. Ershad, a former army general, seized power in a bloodless coup in 1982. He later retired from the military and stood twice for elections, which diplomats and journalists said were rigged in his favor. A teacher at Dhaka University was shot and killed earlier today in a battle between rival opposition factions in the third day of political violence on the campus. More than 30 students were wounded when dissidents in the student faction of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party attacked a march by students from an umbrella group of opposition parties. The rival student groups clashed with guns, bombs and other lethal weapons, witnesses said. Dr. Shamsul Alam Milon, a teacher at Dhaka Medical Colleges, died of bullet wounds, and doctors said one student was serious wounded. It is difficult to get an exact count of casualties because many wounded students avoid hospitals where they may be arrested on charges of rioting, for which they could be jailed for up to seven years. The rift in the Bangladesh Nationalist Party's student supporters worsened after party leader Khaleda Zia expelled six students for hooliganism and ``anti-party activities'' last week. Campus sources said the dissidents fired on a procession of students, including Mrs. Zia's supporters, who were marching to condemn what they called terrorism on campus. The clash quickly caused trouble in other areas around the university. Milon was the second casualty of this week's campus unrest, following the death Monday of a worker at the student dormitories. Eight people were killed last month by police during anti-government riots. In a separate incident, 30 more students were injured in a pitched battle with police using batons and tear gas. The students were protesting the arrest of Mostafa Mohsin Montu, leader of the student wing of the Awami League. Witnesses said the second incident began when several thousand students pelted a police van with stones as it took the Awami League leader, Montu, from his home. When police responded with tear gas, the mob rampaged through the streets, vandalizing shops and vehicles. Police and paramilitary forces rushed to the area to prevent the riot from spreading. The Bangladesh Nationalist Party and the Awami League are leading the anti-Ershad campaign, but their followers frequently clash with each other and among themselves.

DOC.HEAD: Flash Point Southern Lebanon Problem For Hrawi, Israelis
With AM-Lebanon-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Increased fighting between Israel and guerrillas in southern Lebanon could undermine President Elias Hrawi's effort to disband unruly militias and extend state authority after 15{ years of civil war. Palestinian, leftist and Moslem guerrilla factions apparently are stepping up their attacks on the Israelis and their militia allies. Israel is expected to retaliate by intensifying its military actions in the volatile region. In the past week, Israel has intercepted four guerrilla raids by land and sea. Six Israelis and 19 guerrillas have been killed. The Israeli casualties are the worst since eight soldiers were killed in a car bombing in Israel's self-declared ``security zone'' in southern Lebanon Oct. 19, 1988. The two bombers were also killed. The Israelis retaliated for the latest raid Monday night with air strikes Tuesday on bases used by terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal's guerrillas and the radical Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine. It was the 19th air raid on Lebanese targets this year. Since the Palestinians moved into southern Lebanon in 1970, the region has been in the grip of an endless cycle of violence. Guerrilla attacks provoked Israeli reprisals and at least two Israeli invasions in 1978 and 1982. Thousands of people have been killed. There are about 5,000 hard-core PLO guerrillas in the south, and hundreds more from other factions. The Israelis say they have not detected any major influx of guerrillas following the withdrawal this month of Christian and Moslem militias from Beirut under Hrawi's drive to demilitarize the capital area as part of an Arab League-brokered peace plan. But Shiite Moslem militias say they have evacuated hundreds of fighters and heavy weapons from their Beirut strongholds. The Israelis have voiced alarm at a peace treaty between the Iranian-backed Shiite Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the Syrian-backed Shiite Amal movement. The pact ended a three-year power struggle between the factions, for the time being at least. That accord, brokered by Syria and Iran, called for ``joint operations'' against the Israelis in southern Lebanon. The Israelis believe that signals an intensification of attacks on the security zone by the fundamentalist Hezbollah. The commander of Israel's northern sector, Gen. Yossi Peled, said in an interview with Israel Radio last week: ``It would be natural for Amal and Hezbollah to shift their hostility toward us after they've decided to stop fighting each other.'' Israel carved out the 440-square-mile security zone when it withdrew the bulk of its army in mid-1985 after a three-year occupation of southern Lebanon. The zone, which runs from the Mediterranean coast in the west to the slopes of Mount Hermon in the east, serves as a buffer against guerrilla attacks on northern Israel. It is manned by 1,000 Israelis and 3,000 militiamen of the mainly Christian, Israeli-armed South Lebanon Army. Political sources in Beirut, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the violence in the south could thwart Hrawi's hopes of disarming Lebanon's private armies. Hrawi ``can try to move against militias that challenge state authority, but neither Hrawi nor Syria would try to crush a militia that vows to fight Israel, at least under the slogan of liberating Lebanese territory,'' said a prominent Moslem politician speaking on condition of anonymity. Hrawi would ``either have to get the Lebanese army involved in effective resistance efforts against Israel - very risky because it might provoke another Israeli invasion - or forget about disbanding the militias,'' the politician said. Hrawi, like his predecessors, demands the Israelis abandon the occupied zone in the south. The Syrians, the real power in much of Lebanon, have said they will not leave Lebanon until the Israelis do - and the Israelis have shown no sign of doing that.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Janet Jackson was named the year's No. 1 rhythm and blues artist at the Billboard Music Awards, and her album ``Rhythm Nation: 1814'' was chosen best pop album and best R&B album. The 24-year-old sister of Michael Jackson picked up five other awards Monday night: the year's No. 1 R&B albums artist, R&B singles artist, Hot 100 singles artist, dance artist and dance singles artist. ``The most rewarding thing for me was to actually meet kids who had dropped out of school, had been hooked on drugs, or had even tried to take their own lives, but were inspired to change through `Rhythm Nation,''' Miss Jackson said. The awards are given by Billboard magazine and are based on the artists' record sales. Other winners included M.C. Hammer, for top pop and rap artist, and Sinead O'Connor, for the top-ranking worldwide hit single ``Nothing Compares 2 U.'' Phil Collins won three awards: top adult contemporary artist, adult contemporary single for the song ``Do You Remember'' and worldwide album for ``... But Seriously.'' --- LONDON (AP) - J.M. Coetzee, whose novel ``Age of Iron'' takes the form of a white South African widow's letter to her daughter in America, has won Britain's richest fiction prize. South African actress Janet Suzman picked up the $39,000 Sunday Express Book of the Year award on Coetzee's behalf Monday at a literary luncheon. ``Age of Iron'' is the South African author's first book in four years. Coetzee won acclaim for his earlier novels ``Waiting for the Barbarians'' and ``Life and Times of Michael K.'' The Sunday Express newspaper presents its award annually for ``the most enjoyable and compulsively readable book published in Britain.'' The book's monologues reflect a woman's guilt over apartheid - a ``gathering feeling of walking over black faces'' - and her efforts to be a mother figure to those around her. --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - The Statler Brothers will star in their own weekly variety series on The Nashville Network, the cable station has announced. The one-hour Saturday program will debut in October. Taping will begin March 18 at TNN's complex. In a 25-year career, the quartet has recorded hit records such as ``I'll Go to My Grave Loving You,'' ``Flowers on the Wall'' and ``Elizabeth.'' They have won three Grammy awards and nine awards from the Country Music Association. --- SYDNEY, Australia (AP) - The Duchess of York's sister, Jane Makim, was awarded $234,000 in damages Tuesday by a jury that ruled three newspapers defamed her in 1988. The jurors found that The Daily Telegraph, The Sunday Telegraph and The Australian implied Mrs. Makim had an affair with Argentine polo player Horatio Lanusse and wrongfully attempted or threatened to remove her two children from Australia. Mrs. Makim, the 33-year-old sister of the former Sarah Ferguson, now Britain's Duchess of York, said, ``My reputation has been totally vindicated.'' In addition to the award valued at $234,000 in U.S. currency, Nationwide News, publisher of the three Sydney-based newspapers, must pay interest and Mrs. Makim's legal fees. Mrs. Makim was separated from her rancher husband, Alex Makim, 11 months ago. She wept as she told the jury she was ``embarrassed and humiliated'' by the articles. The publisher's attorney, Ian Callinan, argued she suffered no damage from the stories. --- LIMA, Ohio (AP) - Stacy Arthur, who posed nude for the January centerfold of Playboy magazine, says the photographs have caused problems with her fellow contestants in the Mrs. America Pageant. ``Some of the other girls are very upset about it. I have gotten a lot of flak,'' Ms. Arthur said Monday in an interview with Lima radio station WIMA. ``But the pageant system is not going to stop me from competing. They are going to let me compete. They say it would not hinder my odds (or) my chances of winning,'' said Ms. Arthur, who was crowned Mrs. Ohio June 17. Ms. Arthur, 22, said she was not the first Mrs. America contestant to pose for Playboy. The Mrs. America pageant is being held in the Soviet Union in conjunction with the Mrs. USSR pageant. Winners are to be selected December 4, according to a news release from Playboy, and the pageants are to be televised in the spring. Ms. Arthur and her husband, James, live in Sidney, about 30 miles north of Dayton, and run a ceramics shop there.

DOC.HEAD: Councilman Wants Ticketing of Underage Smokers
DOC.TEXT: The Smoke Police will keep a wary eye on Jacksonville's youth if a city councilman has his way. Councilman Harry Reagan wants to create a special anti-smoking police force to ticket underage smokers and stores that sell them cigarettes. He said the unit would be financed by licensing fees paid by the stores. Police could write tickets for fines ranging from $25 to $500, citing businesses or employees that sell cigarettes to anyone under 18 and citing the minors who buy them. Reagan's proposed ordinance has the backing of the Coalition for a Drug-Free Jacksonville, a group of business and civic leaders opposed to drug abuse. It says tobacco is a ``gateway drug,'' the first used by many teens. Reagan said several other council members also support his plan. One opponent, Councilwoman Sandra Darling, said police shouldn't be in charge of regulating public health. And Randy Valentine, manager of Consolidated Cigarette Service, a vending machine company, said he was worried that the proposal could lead to the ticketing of honest businessmen who accidentally or unknowingly sell to minors. ``I'm just afraid that it will be used in an ugly way to entrap people,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Aviation Officials Can't Explain Why Plane Landed at Wrong Airport
DOC.TEXT: Passengers on a flight down the California coast from San Jose to San Luis Obispo got an unexpected side trip when the pilots accidentally landed at the Santa Maria airport. Federal aviation officials are still trying to figure out why the commuter flight made the wrong turn. The Wings West flight 5148, carrying nine passengers and a crew of two, landed by mistake in clear weather Saturday at Santa Maria, 36 miles away from its intended destination. After landing, the Fairchild Metro twin-engine turbo-prop plane went on to San Luis Obispo. Wings West President John Selvaggio said the company, a subsidiary of American Airlines, is conducting its own investigation and won't say what may have caused the mixup. The pilots, if found to be at fault, could face federal punishment ranging from retesting of skills to license suspension, Federal Aviation Administration spokeswoman Elly Brekke said. Pilots have several ways to keep track of their position. Officials said they use projected flight times in addition to navigational equipment to track their progress. They are also supposed to look out the window.

DOC.HEAD: 3 Americans Among 18 Hostages Freed By Baghdad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from Jesse, wife, MOVE UP Bush administration position on hostages, ADD byline. Pickup 5th, `The five...'
DOC.TEXT: Eighteen foreigners - three Americans, 10 Britons and five Germans - arrived in the Jordanian capital today after being freed by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. The Americans, waving Iraqi and American flags, and the Britons were released after their relatives went to Baghdad to plead for their freedom. John Stevenson of Panama City, Fla.; Fred Harrington of Bellevue, Wash.; and Clyde Jesse of Buffalo Grove, Ill., complained they were ignored by the Bush administration. They said only their relatives helped free them. The Bush administration has refused to negotiate the release of American hostages, saying Iraq should free them all unconditionally. The State Department has urged Americans not to go to Iraq, saying they could become hostages themselves or play into the hands of Iraqi propagandists. ``I believe it is time we started talking,'' said Jesse, whose freedom was secured by his wife, Honey, after she flew to Baghdad on Thanksgiving Day. ``Perhaps it is time we women did the work,'' Mrs. Jesse said, smiling and snuggling close to her husband, who was wearing a neck brace that he refused to comment on. ``We work better where men fail,'' she added. Jesse was among the Westerners rounded by the Iraqis a few days after the takeover of Kuwait, while his wife left the occupied emirate on Sept. 1. Stevenson, a computer specialist who worked in Kuwait for 11 years, was released after his twin sister, Mary Trundy of Brockton, Mass., his brothers, Bill Stevenson of Panama City, Fla., and James Stevenson of Sarasota, Fla., visited Baghdad. Harringon was freed when his son, Vala Fouroohi, flew to Baghdad. The 18 freed foreigners reached Amman aboard two Iraqi Airways flights. The five Germans had been in hiding in Kuwait since Aug. 7, five days after Iraq seized control of the Persian Gulf emirate. The Germans said they could not reach Baghdad in time to join 104 of their countrymen who flew out of the Iraqi capital on Sunday after Saddam ordered the release of all German nationals. The Britons were freed after their wives or daughters flew to Baghdad and met with Saddam, who ordered their release in appreciation of ``the women's visit and the role of women in general.'' The Americans' relatives also met widam. The Americans and the Britons were accompanied by their relatives. The women in the British group carried flowers; the Americans waved the U.S. and Iraqi flags. The Germans expressed concern for Westerners left behind. Hundreds of foreigners have been barred from leaving Iraq and Kuwait, and some are being held at strategic sites in hope of warding off any attack by the U.S.-led multinational force. ``There are a lot of people still hiding in various parts of Kuwait,'' Wruck Uwe, a German commercial photographer. ``The telephone system in Kuwait is still good, and we kept in touch with a lot of others like us.'' According to U.S. State Department figures, more than 900,000 of the estimated 3 million foreigners who were in Kuwait and Iraq on Aug. 2 have left. The remaining 2 million, the vast majority Asian and Arab workers, are expected to try to depart. Some foreigners, mostly women married to Iraqis or Kuwaitis, have elected to stay. Some governments and independent public figures have negotiated the release of their nationals. Saddam has offered to free foreigners in exchange for guarantees he will not be attacked. On Nov. 18, he offered to free all foreigners between Dec. 25 and March 25, apparently seeking to forestall a U.S.-led assault. Western governments and others have said they will not negotiate any releases because they believe Saddam is trying to divide the coalition assembled against him since the occupation of Kuwait. However, former officials from several nations have gone to Baghdad and won the release of their citizens. The missions have drawn criticism, but have resulted in the release of some hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Reconsider Decision Setting Aside North Convictions
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 14-15 to UPDATE with quote from dissenting judge
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court today refused to reconsider its decision setting aside former White House aide Oliver L. North's three felony Iran-Contra convictions. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals denied a petition by independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh that the 12-member court rehear the case decided July 20 by a split three-judge panel. The decision sends the case back to U.S. District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell, who must hold a hearing to determine if the 1987 testimony North gave Congress under a limited grant of immunity from prosecution had unfairly seeped into the trial. Walsh probably will appeal today's decision to the Supreme Court, an action that would delay the lower court hearing if the justices agree to consider the case. Walsh issued a statement today saying: ``We appreciate the extended consideration that was given to our petition for rehearing. We are studying the opinions and in all probability will petition (the Supreme Court) because of the importance of the questions involved.'' In its July 20 decision, the three-judge panel set aside the three convictions pending such a hearing by Gesell. It also reversed outright one of the convictions, ruling that Gesell had given improper jury instructions on two points.
