North was convicted of helping to prepare a false chronology of the Iran-Contra affair for Congress, altering or destroying National Security Council documents and accepting an illegal gratuity - the installation of a security fence outside his home. Gesell placed the retired Marine lieutenant colonel on probation, fined him $150,000 and ordered him to perform 1,200 hours of community service. The appeals court did not indicate how its members voted on whether to rehear the case, though two judges did not participate for undisclosed reasons. Seven votes are needed for the full court to rehear a case already decided by a three-judge panel. In a separate order, the three-judge panel reaffirmed all but one section of its July 20 opinion. The change did not affect the outcome of the 2-1 decision, which drew a dissent at the time from Chief Judge Patricia Wald. The panel withdrew a section of its July 20 opinion stating that Gesell had improperly instructed the jury on how to reach a unanimous verdict on the count involving destruction of documents. The panel admitted that it had misread the trial record and found that Gesell had given a proper instruction on reaching a unanimous verdict on that count. But the panel, again over Wald's dissent, stuck by its earlier decision that Gesell had improperly told the jury to ignore evidence that North thought he was acting with authority of his superiors in the Reagan administration when he altered or destroyed documents. Judge Ruth B. Ginsburg dissented from the full court's refusal to reconsider this question. ``A majority of the panel held that a government official may not be convicted ... of altering, concealing or shredding official documents if he believed, however unreasonably, that his actions were legal,'' Ginsburg wrote of the July decision by Circuit Judges Laurence Silberman and David Sentelle, two appointees of President Reagan. A federal grand jury still is investigating the roles of other Reagan administration officials in the Iran-Contra affair. North has used the July 20 decision as a basis for refusing to testify before that panel. He had been questioned several times by the grand jury before that decision.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Regulator Says DeConcini Offered Deal on Keating's Behalf
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New thruout with additional Gray testimony, editing to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Former banking regulator Edwin J. Gray said today that Sen. Dennis DeConcini offered a deal in a 1987 meeting to have a disputed regulation withdrawn on behalf of Charles Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. Gray, in dramatic testimony before the Senate Ethics Committee, described the April 2, 1987, meeting he had with the DeConcini, an Arizona Democrat, and three other senators. Gray said DeConcini asked him to withdraw a Federal Home Loan Bank Board regulation limiting the ability of state-chartered savings and loans, such as Keating's, to make risky speculative investments. The ex-regulator also said that DeConcini said that, in return, Lincoln would be willing to make more home mortgage loans, the traditional business of savings and loans. ``DeConcini said, `We're very concerned about this direct investment regulation of yours. We're concerned it's unconstitutional. We'd like you to withdraw it until we can find out if it's constitutional. If you can do that, we'll get our friend at Lincoln to make more home loans.''' Gray said he told the senators he would not do that, and the senators went on to other issues, raising concerns about the length of the bank board's examination of Lincoln and its appraisal of Lincoln's assets. None of the so-called Keating Five senators under investigation by the ethics panel were present for Gray's testimony. The committeewas holding its sixth day of hearings into allegations the senators improperly intervened with regulators on behalf of Keating, a major financial contributor to the campaigns of each. Besides DeConcini, senators under scrutiny are Republican John McCain of Arizona, and Democrats John Glenn of Ohio, Alan Cranston of California, and Donald Riegle of Michigan. All but Riegle attended the April 2, 1987, meeting with Gray, and all five attended a meeting with San Francisco-based regulators a week later, after being referred by Gray. Gray said that DeConcini ``was the least passive'' of the four senators in the meeting, but that all asked questions. ``I considered it to be improper,'' Gray said of the session. Gray said DeConcini was the host of the meeting and opened it by saying, ``We're here to talk about our friend from Lincoln Savings.'' No aides were present. Gray said his office had been instructed by DeConcini's office for no staff to be present - a directive DeConcini denies issuing. Gray, who was the Reagan administration's chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board from 1983 to 1987, said he felt intimidated by the meeting with four senators. He stressed that DeConcini used the word ``we'' in making the request. ``I felt awkward and pressured,'' he said. ``The whole setting was an intimidating one under these circumstances because I had never had a meeting like this before.'' But under repeated questioning by the committee's special counsel, Robert S. Bennett, Gray said he never protested to the senators that the meeting was improper. And he said they never threatened him by taking action against legislation he wanted, to strengthen the board's ability to shut down bankrupt thrifts. ``I needed their votes desperately for the legislation we were pushing. It was not my intent to get in a fight with these people when I needed their votes,'' Gray said. Gray also testified that, a month earlier, Riegle was the first senator to raise the issue of Keating's thrift and its opposition to regulations limiting its ability to invest directly in speculative ventures. ``He pulled me aside and said, `You know there are some senators out West who are very unhappy about the bank board's handling of Lincoln and I think you ought to talk to them,''' Gray said. Gray said he protested that Keating had been telling people the two were feuding and that Gray had a ``vendetta'' against him - something he said was untrue. ``I went through how Charles Keating had been making these accusations,'' he said. Keating's Irvine, Calif., institution collapsed and was seized by the federal government in 1989. Its cost to taxpayers, estimated at $2 billion, has made it a symbol of the savings and loan industry debacle. Gray read a 13-page opening statement Monday that recalled how the easing of federal controls in the 1980s fueled the savings and loan crisis. Gray described Lincoln as ``a cash cow,'' able to use federally insured deposits to buy and sell stocks, participate in leveraged buyouts, build and run hotels, operate real estate ventures and engage in other risky, direct equity investments.

DOC.HEAD: `Home Alone' Packs the House
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16th graf, `6. The Rescuers...', to ADD gross revenue.
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: ``Home Alone,'' a comedy about a kid left to fend off burglars, played to packed houses over the five-day Thanksgiving weekend, taking in a whopping $28.7 million for the No. 1 spot at the box office. In second place and off to a faster start than its predecessor is ``Three Men and a Little Lady.'' The first sequel from the Walt Disney Co. took in $19.1 million in its premiere engagement, Exhibitor Relations Co. said Monday. In 1987, ``Three Men and a Baby'' - also starring Ted Danson, Tom Selleck and Steve Guttenberg - took in $13.9 million its first weekend. It went on to make $167.8 million. The action-adventure sequel ``Predator II'' opened in third place with $13.3 million. Actor-director Kevin Costner's Western, ``Dances With Wolves,'' was fourth with $12.7 million. ``Rocky V'' made $11.3 million for fifth place. ``Home Alone,'' produced and written by John Hughes, stars Macaulay Culkin as an 8-year-old accidentally left behind at Christmas when his family leaves for a Paris vacation. The boy uses his wits to fight off burglars. In two weeks, the movie has made $48.3 million. ``Everyone seems to be coming and we're getting a lot of repeat business,'' said Tom Sherak, head of marketing and distribution for 20th Century Fox. ``We look at some of the (box-office) grosses from some of those small cities and wonder where the audiences will come from the next day.'' Here are the top movie ticket sales for Wednesday through Sunday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Home Alone,'' 20th Century Fox, $28.7 million, 1,284 screens, $22,328 per screen, $48.3 million, two weeks. 2. ``Three Men and a Little Lady,'' Disney, $19.1 million, 1,281 screens, $14,910 per screen, $19.1 million, one week. 3. ``Predator II,'' 20th Century Fox, $13.3 million, 1,950 screens, $6,815 per screen, $13.3 million, one week. 4. ``Dances With Wolves,'' Orion, $12.7 million, 1,048 screens, $12,071 per screen, $14.3 million, three weeks. 5. ``Rocky V,'' MGM-UA, $11.3 million, 2,053 screens, $5,508 per screen, $27.3 million, two weeks. 6. ``The Rescuers Down Under,'' Disney, $5.3 million, 1,237 screens, $4,275 per screen, $9.2 million, two weeks. 7. ``Ghost,'' Paramount, $4.6 million, 1,528 screens, $2,991 per screen, $195.4 million, 20 weeks. 8. ``Child's Play 2,'' Universal, $4 million, 1,946 screens, $2,032 per screen, $22.6 million, three weeks. 9. ``Jacob's Ladder,'' Tri-Star, $2.7 million, 1,083 screens, $2,516 per screen, $22.4 million, four weeks. 10.``Quigley Down Under,'' MGM-UA, $1.2 million, 835 screens, $1,83 per screen, $17.3 million, six weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Estimates Iraq Has 450,000 Troops in Kuwait Area
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon said today its latest estimates indicate Iraq has 450,000 troops in the Kuwaiti theater of operations, an increase of 20,000 over last week. Pete Williams, the Pentagon spokesman, said half the troops are inside Kuwait itself. The troops are mainly defensive in nature, but ``have the ability to go on the offensive'' if necessary, he said. According to the Pentagon's most recent estimate, Iraq has 3,600 tanks in the area, up from 3,500 last week; 2,200 armored personnel carriers; and 2,400 pieces of artillery, an increase of 100 pieces. Williams said the latest estimates reflect the ``fine-tuning'' of U.S. figures as well as Iraqi troop movements. ``Iraq continues to move forces around within Iraq and within the Kuwaiti theater of operations,'' he said. Williams said the any Iraqi build-up in the Kuwaiti theater is a further indication that Saddam Hussein has no intention of complying with U.N. resolutions seeking to force his withdrawal from Kuwait. While the Iraqis appear to be moving more people into the Kuwait region, the Defense Department has no evidence that Iraq has moved on its pledge of last week to activate new divisions and call up additional reservists. ``We haven't seen any sign of that yet,'' Williams said. President Bush announced recently that the United States would increase its troop levels in the Persian Gulf by 200,000. Some 230,000 troops are already in the area, mainly in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: State: 85 Percent of Shores Oiled by Exxon Valdez Sufficiently Cleaned
DOC.TEXT: About 85 percent of the rocky shores oiled in the Exxon Valdez disaster have been sufficiently cleaned, Alaska's oil-spill coordinator said as the state released next year's cleanup plan. ``The last 15 percent might come hard, but there's just not all that much left to do,'' Ernie Piper said Monday. The plan repeats the state's contention that Exxon Corp. should complete the cleanup next year. It is intended to clarify which areas the state believes still need treatment. ``Next summer the big, tough decision is going to be made: How much oil to leave behind,'' Piper said. ``It's one of the biggest decisions since statehood.'' The tanker Exxon Valdez spilled nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil in Prince William Sound after it struck a reef on March 24, 1989. A total of 1,285 miles of shore extending into the Gulf of Alaska were coated with oil, and countless birds and sea mammals were killed. The plan includes a summary of conditions at 757 ``shoreline segments,'' based on a fall survey. The state has determined 404 of those segments need no more treatment. Oil remains at many of the 404 sites, mostly under the surface. But the plan says ``the state considers it neither technically possible nor environmentally practical to remove all remaining contamination.'' In a news release, Gov. Steve Cowper said ``the state, Coast Guard and Exxon have made substantial progress throughout the spill area. Many areas are free of oil. However, there are limits to what we can and should do.'' It's somewhat misleading to say the sites have been cleaned, Piper said. What the state is saying is that everything that can be done has been done at the approved sites. ``There's no such thing as a successful oil-spill cleanup,'' he said. ``If you get oil on a beach after a spill, you're not going to get it all cleaned up.'' The shore figures do not include Kodiak Island sites, which could not be listed because of a computer programming problem. But nearly all of the island's shores need no more treatment, Piper said. Exxon spokesman Karsten Rodvik in Anchorage said the company was reviewing the plan and would have no immediate comment. The company will make no decision on next year's cleanup until a new shore survey is completed next spring, he said. The nation's largest oil company has spent more than $2.2 billion on the cleanup and paid more than $240 million in claims to those who suffered damages from the spill.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Major Ahead of Rivals, But Anther Round Needed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines urgent series. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Treasury chief John Major finished ahead of two rivals but fell short of a necessary majority today in the race to succeed Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. A third and final ballot by the 372 Conservative Party members of the House of Commons will be conducted Thursday. Major won 185 votes, two less than the simple majority required for election. Former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine had 131 votes and Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd had 56 votes. Heseltine immediately announced that he would vote for Major on Thursday, and Hurd also conceded that Major would win the race. Major, 47, and Heseltine, 57, had been considered the front-runners heading into the second-round ballot. Mrs. Thatcher, who had withdrawn from the contest last week following the first-round vote and had given her support to Major, remains prime minister at least until Thursday night. Hurd said that the party rules required a third ballot, even though he and Heseltine had conceded that Major would be the winner. A week ago, voting in the same committee room at the House of Commons, legislators forced the downfall of Mrs. Thatcher. She received more votes than Heseltine, 57, but failed to gain the 15 percent margin required for an outright victory. Mrs. Thatcher withdrew from the balloting Thursday after party leaders warned she would lose the second round. Major and Hurd immediately entered the race. Mrs. Thatcher says she will submit her resignation to Queen Elizabeth II soon after her successor is chosen, ending 11{ years in power. Lawmakers faced a dilemma in today's vote: Major, chancellor of the exchequer, has the most support in the Cabinet and possibly the party in Parliament, but polls indicate the flamboyant Heseltine is the most popular with voters and thus the most likely to lead Conservatives to victory in the next election, which must be held by mid-1992. Hurd, 60, hoped to squeeze through on Thursday as the consensus second choice. His supporters argue that, as Britain's spokesman throughout the Persian Gulf crisis, he is the best leader to carry on Mrs. Thatcher's hawkish policy. Mrs. Thatcher, however, supported Major, the son of a circus performer. ``She looks upon him as the true man of the people,'' said a Thatcher aide. Major left school at 16, never went to college, worked as a laborer and was on welfare before becoming a banker. He was elected to Parliament in 1979, when Mrs. Thatcher came to power, and was in the Cabinet four years later as treasury secretary. Mrs. Thatcher appointed him foreign secretary last year, then chancellor. Opinion polls published after Mrs. Thatcher's downfall indicate that the Oxford-educated Heseltine is the public's first choice as prime minister, followed by Major. The polls also suggested that Mrs. Thatcher's departure has restored her party's fortunes. After trailing the opposition Labor Party for six months in polls, the latest soundings suggest the Tories would run well ahead of Labor under Heseltine or Major. But it was close with Hurd. Heseltine, who quit the Thatcher Cabinet in 1986, has portrayed himself as a Thatcher-like character: the only one with the determination to walk out instead of getting dropped; the one with the guts to challenge her. ``I'm perhaps too similar to Mrs. Thatcher,'' he said in a weekend television interview. ``In the end we're people you can trust and who stand up and say what we think and stick to it.'' The leadership contest which brought down Mrs. Thatcher, 65, was precipitated b increasing divisions over her combative stance toward the European Community. But her aides say the root causes were rising inflation and unemployment, compounded by an unpopular new local government tax and a growing army of enemies among sacked Cabinet ministers and never-promoted legislators. Mrs. Thatcher appeared in good spirits at a farewell party Monday night for her staff of 200 at 10 Downing Street. ``Life begins at 65 and I shall be working for the future,'' she told them. ``She doesn't want to go out with a lot of backbiting,'' her press secretary Bernard Ingham said Monday. ``It's a rough old world, and I don't think she would have it any other way.''

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Crying Over Scarce Milk
With AM-Reluctant Donors, Bjt
LaserPhoto MOSB3
DOC.TEXT: A shortage of milk is the latest consumer crisis to strike the capital, which already has endured scarcities this year of such staples as bread, sugar, cigarettes and potatoes. Under the scare headline, ``Even the Children of Moscow Might Be Left Without Milk, If ...,'' Tuesday's editionsof Moskovsky Komsomolets reported that the 18 regions shipping milk to Moscow are sending fewer supplies. Since the beginning of 1990, Moscow has received 100,000 fewer tons of milk, the newspaper said, without reporting the total. As a result, production of processed cheese, cottage cheese and sour cream have been cut. A clerk at a mostly barren supermarket in Moscow's Taganskaya neighborhood confirmed the store was getting less milk, with daily supplies that usually last until about 6 p.m. now running out by noon. Scores of people were seen lining up at dairy stores Tuesday. Russian republic President Boris N. Yeltsin warned Russian legislators Tuesday that food shortages have nearly overshadowed all other issues. ``Delays in solving this problem threaten Russia's revival,'' Yeltsin said. Deputy Moscow Mayor Sergei B. Stankevich said Monday that nine regions in Russia have announced that they were stopping deliveries to the capital, pushing residents fearful of a hungry winter ``to the edge of another crisis.'' Stankevich also blamed the milk crisis on ``shopping sprees and hoarding.'' Last week, several rush-hour shoppers riding Moscow's subway were seen carrying four and five of the light-blue, one-liter milk cartons apiece. Moscow and Leningrad, the Soviet Union's two biggest cities, traditionally have been spared the shortages that have struck other cities in previous years. They no longer are immune, however, as nnterprises in various regions withhold supplies and keep them for local consumption. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, meeting Tuesday with members of the Russian Congress of Peoples' Deputies, sharply rebuked those republics and regions that have refused to supply the cities of Moscow, Sverdlovsk, Irkutsk and others with grain and other agricultural supplies. The Moscow Industrial Association ``Moloko'' - milk in Russian - said that in the past, shortages were eased by supplies of powdered milk. But, with 95 percent of the powdered milk obtained from abroad, that ``luxury'' is no longer affordable, the newspaper said. The authors of the story suggested that Moloko triple the price of a liter of milk to one ruble, about $1.80, to avoid having to use state subsidies. But the general director of Moloko is against it. He told the newspaper that Moscow consumers ``may not understand'' such an increase. Moskovsky Komsomolets said the regions supplying Moscow's milk don't want rubles in payment; they want scarce goods in return for their dairy products. ``But the association `Moloko' is not `Mitsubishi,''' the newspaper added wryly, referring to the Japanese consumer goods conglomerate. Rationing of goods such as vodka, pasta and rice is in effect in many places in the Soviet Union as the economy has worsened. Leningrad will introduce food rationing as of Saturday. Although Moscow already rations sugar and cigarettes and is considering such a program for other goods, city officials do not believe it is a solution, because the ration coupons would not necessarily guarantee supplies. Some officials are proposing a special kind of ``Moscow money'' - for example, 50 rubles per month per resident - which would be backed up with food products, the newspaper Moskovskaya Pravda reported. It did not provide further details on the plan.

DOC.HEAD: New Government Formed As Longtime Prime Minister Steps Down
DOC.TEXT: Goh Chok Tong formed a new government Tuesday and prepared to replace the only prime minister Singapore has ever known. Goh officially takes office Wednesday, and his new government includes a prominent post for his predecdessor, Lee Kuan Yew. Lee had been prime minister since the former British crown colony became a self-governing state in 1959. During 31 years of authoritarian rule, he helped transform the former colonial outpost into a flourishing banking and commercial center. The transition of power to his chosen successor has been in the works for more than two years. The 67-year-old Lee is to be a senior minister without portfolio attached to the prime minister's office, and is to continue as secretary-general of the governing People's Action Party. His eldest son, Lee Hsien Loong, 38, was recently appointed one of two deputy prime ministers. In a ceremony on Tuesday at the Istana, or palace, President Wee Kim Wee appointed Goh prime minister and asked him to form a government. Goh then submitted the names of his Cabinet members to the president. Goh's government is expected to push to amend the constitution to provide for an elected president with an array of executive powers. The post is now appointive and largely ceremonial. Because his party holds 80 of the 81 elected seats in Parliament, the measure is likely to be approved and the constitution amended by mid-January. Lee Kuan Yew suggested the changes in 1984, but he says he is not interested in seeking the revamped presidency. Critics say having an executive head of state will virtually end the country's British style of government, in which Parliament is supreme, particularly if the president and prime minister are at odds. Goh said the stronger presidency is needed as an additional check on Parliament. The Guinness Book of World Records had listed Lee as the longest-serving prime minister. ``I think that Singapore has seen and heard enough of me for 31 years,'' he said last week. When the Cambridge-educated lawyer took charge, this island city state had no natural resources, no industry, bitter racial divisions and potentially unfriendly neighbors. Lee helped forge an identity for his polyglot island of 2.7 million people, uniting an ethnic Chinese majority with sizable Malay and Indian minorities. He demanded discipline to overcome hardships. Obedience, hard work, cleanliness, thrift and the profit motive were applied as the shabby British colonial outpost was transformed. Singapore is now a flourishing banking and commercial center with high-tech industries, a first-class educational system and glitzy shopping centers. Years of firm political leadership and stable economic growth helped attract investment by multinational corporations seeking a doorway to the booming markets of the Far East.

DOC.HEAD: Singapore At-A-Glance
With AM-Singapore
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts about Singapore, which swears in a new prime minister on Wednesday: ---
LEADERSHIP: The outgoing prime minister is Lee Kuan Yew, who has been prime minister for 31 years. He is succeeded by Goh Chok Tong, who was a deputy prime minister. ---

LAND: Singapore, a former British crown colony, is a southeast Asian republic consisting of the main island and 57 smaller islands within its territorial waters. Located 85 miles north of the equator, it is linked to the Malay peninsula by road and railway across a causeway. The total land area is 239.5 square miles. ---

PEOPLE: More than 76 percent of Singapore's 2.7 million people are ethnic Chinese. Malays make up 15 percent and Indians 6 percent. The official languages are English, Mandarin, Malay and Tamil. Malay is the national language and English the language of administration. Literacy is 88 percent. ---

POLITICS: Lee Kuan Yew's People's Action Party took power with independence in 1959 amid strong anti-colonial sentiment and with the help of the Communists, whom the PAP later purged. The PAP has been returned to power in eight consecutive elections and controls 80 of the 81 elected seats in Parliament. Voting is compulsory for citizens 21 or older. ---

ECONOMY: With an average per capita annual income of $10,500, Singapore enjoys one of the highest standards of living in Asia. Gross domestic product increased from $3.6 million in 1957 to $28.5 billion last year. Singapore is a hub for international shipping, airlines, oil refining and financial services. ---

HISTORY: In 1819, Sir Stamford Raffles established a British trading base that soon attracted migrating Chinese peasants. It was occupied by the Japanese for 3{ years in World War II, and became a British crown colony in 1946. It became a self-governing state in 1959. Singapore joined peninsular Malaysia, Sarawak and Sabah in the Federation of Malaysia in 1963, but withdrew in 1965.

DOC.HEAD: The Next British Prime Minister in Brief
With PM-Britain-Politics
DOC.TEXT: John Major Age: 47 Born: March 29, 1943. Educated: Rutlish Grammar School, a state school for bright children, to age 16. Career: Bank executive. Family: Married Norma Johnson, 1970; daughter Elizabeth, 19, and son James, 15. Mrs. Major is the author of a 1987 biography on opera singer Dame Joan Sutherland. Parliament: Unsuccessfully sought election February 1974 and October 1974. Member of Parliament for Huntingdonshire 1979-83, and Huntingdon since 1983. Ministerial career: Undersecretary of state in the Department of Health and Social Security 1985-86; minister of state for social security and the disabled 1986-87. Cabinet career: Chief secretary to the Treasury 1987-89, foreign secretary July-October 1989, chancellor of the exchequer October 1989-present.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court: Even New York State Can't Avoid Paying Taxes
DOC.TEXT: When the taxman calls, everyone must answer - even the state. The state's top court ruled Tuesday that state government is not exempt from a law that requires taxpayers to pay their property tax even while they're appealing the assessment. ``The state must pay its local property taxes when they are due,'' Court of Appeals Judge Vito Titone wrote in the unanimous decision. State officials launched the case on behalf of the Hudson River-Black River Regulating District. In 1987, Fulton County raised the state's tax bill for 380 pieces of property operated by the district in Northampton from $234,000 to $440,000, according to the attorney general's office. State lawyers argued that laws that protect New York state from paying penalties for delinquent taxes and from tax foreclosure also exempted it from paying taxes pending resolution of its appeal of the assessment. But Titone argued that, if anything, the existence of those two specific exemptions indicate lawmakers want the state to be treated like any other taxpayer when it comes to an appeal. ``Indeed, the balance of equities may even tilt more heavily in favor of local government's taxing power when the state is the taxpayer, since the state is generally in a better position than an individual taxpayer to absorb a temporary overpayment pending judicial correction,'' Titone said.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds Advantages in Economic Slump
DOC.TEXT: Goodbye pricey menus, long lines and goat cheese. Hello bistros, broccoli and service with a smile. Today's gloomy economy is having a big impact on dining out - but it's not all bad, according to the 1991 Zagat New York City Restaurant Survey. ``Consumers are demanding, and getting, more for their money now - even on tighter budgets and stricter expense accounts - than they did a few years ago,'' said Tim Zagat, publisher and editor of the pocket-sized guide, which arrives at bookstores this week. Restaurateurs are holding down prices, throwing in more extras - like free appetizers and larger portions - and working harder to keep customers happy, he says. According to Zagat Survey, which publishes the restaurant guide, the number of restaurant closings rose from 38 in 1989 to 54 in 1990. But the number of openings held at 125. The new eateries generally have a casual atmosphere, lower prices and simple food, such as scaled-down bistro, regional American or pasta fare, according to the survey. Hubert's, a fancy Upper East Side restaurant, was among the recent closings. It tried to change with the times, shedding its luxury image and slashing its prices to $100 for a dinner for two. But along the way the establishment ``lost direction,'' according to the guide. Diners ``may be less willing to support certain kinds of marginal or expense account hangouts,'' Zagat said, ``but they're still trying out new places in great numbers and are proving especially supportive of smaller neighborhood places with moderate prices and simpler food.'' A total of 5,500 volunteer diners participated in the 1991 Zagat Survey, which reviewed the decor, food and service at 1,012 restaurants citywide. To accommodate the shift to dollarwise dining, the guide for the first time includes a ``Bang for the Buck'' index of 100 good-value restaurants. ``It costs more to get a full tank of gas than to get a good meal out in New York,'' Zagat said. Still, New York City's high-priced restaurants are the highest by far in the country. According to the survey, the average price for dinner at the city's 20 most expensive restaurants is $67.07. In Washington, the average is $50.23; Los Angeles $48.22; San Francisco $48.08; Baltimore $38.30; Atlanta $37.44; New Orleans $34.64; Seattle $33.95; St. Louis $33.23; and Kansas City $25.23. At the top end of the scale in New York, the survey notes, there are still tremendously successful establishments. The Four Seasons, where dinner averages $64, and Lutece, where dinner averages $71, are rated as the most popular. Bouley, which opened less than two months before the October 1987 stock market crash, was rated as having the best food in the city. The nine-course tasting menu at the flower-filled French restaurant is $65. ``It proves that Cinderella stories are still possible among New York restaurants and that put to the wall, some places are performing at the peak of their game,'' Zagat said.

DOC.HEAD: Spoleto Unveils 1991 Program
DOC.TEXT: The 1991 Spoleto Festival U.S.A. will include an 80th birthday gala for Gian Carlo Menotti and feature the composer conducting one of his own operas. Only last month Menotti was offering to resign as artistic director of the festival he brought to Charleston in 1977. He later agreed to continue under his current contract for two more seasons, and his dispute with the festival's board appears resolved. ``It would be entirely inappropriate to have a birthday party at which the honoree didn't come,'' said Ross Markwardt, the chairman of the Spoleto board. Menotti was in Scotland and did not attend Monday's news conference announcing the schedule. However, Menotti generally has not attended program announcements. Markwardt said the dispute hasn't affected fund raising for the $5.7 million festival. ``We find no evidence the artistic content of this festival has been compromised,'' he said. The festival, which runs from May 23 through June 9 will include three operas, including Menotti directing his ``Maria Golovin.'' ``It is one of his favorite operas and one he thinks has been unfairly neglected,'' said Nigel Redden, festival general manager. A preview on May 23 will be followed by a reception honoring Menotti's birthday. The schedule also includes a birthday concert for Menotti featuring cellist and conductor Mstislav Rostropovich. Menotti turns 80 July 7. Other operas at next year's festival include ``Tales of Hoffmann'' and Monteverdi's ``The Coronation of Poppea.'' The National Ballet of Spain and the Rambert Dance Company from England will lend an international feeling to next year's festival. The dance program includes ``The Festival of Indonesia in Performance.'' The troupe includes dancers and a 20-piece percussion orchestra. Dance premieres at Spoleto include works by the Elizabeth Streb Ringside company and Blondell Cummings. Three young Italian dance companies will make their American debuts. They include Compagnia Efesto, Paco Decina and Sosta Palmizi. Choreographer David Gordon will present a new work, ``The Mysteries and What's So Funny,'' featuring music by Philip Glass. Redden said the visual arts program, an apparent source of the dispute between Menotti and the board, will be announced in January. The festival has budgeted a record $800,000 for visual arts, and at Menotti's direction will be taking risks by trying new forms, Markwardt said. The exhibits are expected to include large works throughout this historic port city, and possibly decorating facades of buildings. The schedule for the jazz and theater offerings will be announced later, Redden said.

DOC.HEAD: Poland To Strengthen Troop Levels On Soviet Border
DOC.TEXT: Poland's defense minister said Tuesday he is worried about the Soviet Union's stability and plans to strengthen Polish troop levels along the two nations' frontier. Defense Minister Piotr Kolodziejczyk said Poland's troop levels have been reduced by 100,000 to 350,000 over the last three years and that he expects a further reduction of another 100,000. He said about 40 percent of its armed forces now are along the German border and 20 percent on the Soviet frontier. Kolodziejczyk said those troops will be redistributed, with one-third along the Soviet border, a third along the German border and the remainder in the Polish interior. He said the troops are being moved because of lessened East-West tensions and because of worries about the Soviet Union's stability. ``Even if the situation in the East (Soviet Union) were stable, the troops would have to be distributed in a different way,'' Kolodziejczyk said. ``But the situation is not stable, which is a source of great concern for the Polish government.'' Kolodziejczyk spoke with reporters after meeting with German Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg. The Soviet Union is expected to have an unusually harsh winter this year. There is serious concern that will touch off famine in a crumbling empire already beset by other problems and cause an exodus of hungry Soviets. There also has been concern about civil unrest. Germany has begun a huge emergency program to help out the Soviet Union during the winter months. The German branch of the Catholic relief organization, Caritas, said Tuesday it will begin sending 30,000 food packages to the Soviet Union this weekend. German television said further aid might be airlifted into the Soviet Union. A high-level team of economic, agricultural and transport officials from Germany, led by Chancellor Helmut Kohl's top foreign policy adviser, traveled to Moscow on Tuesday to talk with Soviet officials about organizing emergency assistance. Kohl has stressed in recent days the importance of helping out the Soviet Union and ensuring that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev can survive the growing economic and political problems facing his nation. After his talks with Stoltenberg, Kolodziejczyk also said Poland is interested in acquiring armaments once owned by East Germany and now in the possession of united Germany's armed forces. Through unification, Stoltenberg's ministry has inherited from the East Germans, among other things, Soviet-made MiG-29 aircraft, rated as among the world's best fighter planes.

DOC.HEAD: NOW calls for troop withdrawal from Saudi Arabia
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: by GRETCHEN COOK= Associated Press Writer= WASHINGTON (AP) - The National Organization for Women called on Tuesday for the immediate withdrawal of U.S. troops from the Persian Gulf, saying the ``oppressive regimes of Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are not worth the sacrifice of American lives.'' The organization, in its first public stand on the Gulf crisis, condemned Saudi Arabia and Kuwait for human rights violations against women and protested the treatment of American servicewomen in the region. ``Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are despotic, clan-run monarchies,'' said NOW President Molly Yard. ``Both ... systematically oppress woman. This is gender apartheid in its purest, most brutal form, and should deeply offend all Americans.'' Yard also objected to the restrictions imposed on military women serving in Saudi Arabia. ``We would be outraged if the administration sent American troops to defend South Africa from invasion, ordering black soldiers to `respect the culture' by bowing their heads in the presence of white racists,'' she said at a press conference on the NOW resolution. NOW complained female soldiers in Saudi Arabia must dress in full fatigues while male soldiers are allowed to sport T-shirts in the desert heat. Military women are not allowed to drive while off-duty or run errands unescorted and must wear knee-length shorts while swimming - even in private pools. Rep. Pat Schroeder, a senior member of the Armed Services Committee, agreed that the U.S. applies double standards toward Saudi Arabia. ``We do not tolerate `cultural differences' as an excuse for racial violence,'' said Schroeder, D-Colo. ``Why do we tolerate it for women? Our young women are being put out there to defend the country and are also being told that in off hours they must comply with apartheid in that country vis-a-vis women.'' Yard stressed that NOW opposes Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, but says economic sanctions should be given more time to work and that a diplomatic solution should be reached through the United Nations. ``Everything President Bush is doing leads to war and we are opposed to that,'' said Yard, adding that the military build-up in the Gulf ``is designed to protect U.S. oil interests.'' NOW plans to picket the Saudi Embassy in Washington next week and will petition the U.N. to condemn the human rights violations by the Saudi government against women.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Unidentified Murder Victim Might Be Missing Heiress
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. attorney's office is considering exhuming the unidentified body of a murder victim to see if it is that of missing candy heiress Helen Brach, a newspaper reported Tuesday. For the past six months, federal agents and Illinois State Police detectives have been trying to gather evidence that might connect the body with Brach's disappearance, according to the Chicago Tribune. Hampering the investigation is the fact that the dead woman found in the woods in Calumet City in 1978 was missing her hands and part of her face, including her teeth, the newspaper said, citing unidentified sources. That has made it impossible to compare Brach's dental records to those of the body. Investigators hope to exhume the body and conduct a series of tests, including comparison of Brach's X-rays with those of the woman, sources told the newspaper Monday. Brach, heiress to the Brach Candy Co. fortune, disappeared after checking out of the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., on Feb. 17, 1977. She was then 65 years old. The new interest in the body stems from a federal investigation here into a number of horse traders suspected of defrauding wealthy individuals who purchased horses, the Tribune said. One theory is that Brach was murdered after she repeatedly complained to authorities that she was defrauded in the purchase of horses, the newspaper said. At the time of her disappearance, her net worth was estimated at $17 million. The value of her estate has increased to more than $50 million. Most of her estate has gone to a charitable trust called the Helen Brach Foundation.

DOC.HEAD: 43 Deer Killed to Keep Runways Clear
DOC.TEXT: Forty-three deer were shot and killed in the past two months in an effort to keep the animals off the runways at Orlando International Airport, authorities say. Three commercial airliners have hit free roaming deer this fall, but there have been no injuries to people or damage to the planes. The airport hired a consultant in early October to trap and move deer because the animals were a hazard when they wandered onto runways from nearby woods. But when a Delta jet struck a deer on takeoff Oct. 7, the consultant was paid $100 a deer to kill the animals. On Oct. 26, a Midway Airlines jet struck a deer while taking off. It completed its flight to Chicago without problems. A Northwest Airlines plane struck a deer Nov. 16, again without major damage. Animal rights activists have protested the killings. Sue Santoro, president of Voices for Animals of Central Florida, said she discussed the problem with airport officials before the Delta accident and met with them Oct. 17 and was assured that no more deer would be shot. Bill Jennings, the airport's director of operations, however, denied that he told her deer wouldn't be shot. ``The safety of the traveling public is of our utmost concern,'' Jennings said Monday. ``I've always tried to get people to understand shooting the deer - lethal means - will remain an option that we have. It's not something we want to do, but we will not abandon that.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Hails Close Partnership Between US, Mexico
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS one graf after 2nd graf prvs with Bush remarks in toast
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today said the United States and Mexico are ``one family,'' united in their goal to break down trade barriers and in their opposition to Iraq's aggression in the Persian Gulf. ``The size and sophistication of U.S.-Mexico trade today only hints at our potential. We can create and share unprecedented prosperity and jobs,'' Bush said in a speech at the Monterrey City Theater, referring to the free trade pact that both governments want to accomplish. Bush, in a later luncheon toast, said the trade agreement that could be concluded as early as 1992 would ``unleash powerful energies in both economies.'' He said: ``No country is more important to the United States than Mexico.'' Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, joining Bush in speaking at the Monterrey City Theater, emphasized that Mexican migrant workers make a positive contribution to the U.S. economy and the United States has a ``moral and juridical obligation'' to respect their human and labor rights. Bush, on the second-day of an overnight visit, also called for resuscitation of the faltering international trade talks known as the Uruguay round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. He said ``the critical moment is at hand'' for the talks, which resume next week and are aimed at easing worldwide trade barriers. Negotiators have stumbled over European reluctance to give up agricultural subsidies. ``We must not let the Uruguay Round fail,'' Bush said. Bush praised Mexico's cooperation in the U.S.-led opposition to Iraq, and its stepped-up oil production that has helped cover the loss of oil from Iraq and Kuwait due to a United Nations-imposed embargo. ``Mexico and the United States stand united in rejecting aggression,'' Bush said. ``The world of global conflict is giving way to a new world order of global cooperation.'' Stating that Mexico has contributed to the U.S. cultural, language and architectural heritage, Bush said, ``Somos una familia; we are one family.'' When he arrived in Monterrey on Monday night, Bush told tens of thousands of people at an outdoor rally that he had come to Mexico, `` with a message of respect, of admiration and hope for a brighter future shared by our two countries.'' `Viva Mexico,'' Bush shouted before he and his wife viewed an elaborate fireworks demonstration from a glassed-in stage on the plaza. Bush's two-day trip focused primarily on the two countries' efforts to negotiate a free trade agreement. This morning the president met with a group of U.S. and Mexican business leaders. Later he met for a second straight day with Salinas before they addressed the Monterrey City Theater audience. Bush's schedule also called for a meeting with another group of Mexican and U.S. businessmen and more bilateral talks on issues such as drugs, the environment and economic matters. Bush today refused to answer reporters' questions at a photo session with Salinas on the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis. The Mexican president, however, said in remarks prepared for his speech that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait provides new opportunity for international cooperation. ``A renewed international community enables us to maintain the hope that international law will prevail over the invasion and over capricious and arbitrary actions,'' he said, repeating Mexico's support for the United Nations sanctions against Iraq. Salinas also made clear that he expects the United States to ensure better treatment of Mexicans who migrate across the border. ``There is always a moral and juridical obligation to strive for a real respect for the human and labor rights of these immigrants and their families, whose work unquestionably makes a positive contribution to the development of the United States economy,'' Salinas said in reference to the concerns in Mexico about racism and violence against Mexicans along the U.S. side of the border. He said, ``every single violation of their physical and moral integrity, on either side of the border, is an affront to the values in which both of our nations believe.'' Bush heralded the goal of reaching a free trade agreement with Mexico even as Salinas sounded a cautionary note, citing Mexican worries about what they see as U.S. protectionist sentiments. Both Salinas and Bush say they want the trade agreement to go forward. But Salinas complained in an El Norte newspaper interview published Monday that ``American products can enter the Mexican market without restriction. But ours are detained at customs, and there are always many restrictions.'' Mexican fruits and vegetables are periodically barred from the United States for not meeting quality standards. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the presidents Monday underscored their commitment to opening up the trading relationship. They ``are interested in pursuing the agreement as fast as possible and attach high priority to its successful conclusion,'' the spokesman said. If Congress approves Bush's request to begin formal negotiations early next year, a free trade pact could be concluded some time in early 1992, administration officials have said. Potential sticking points in negotiations might include Mexico's insistence that its oil industry be kept free of foreign investment. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady told reporters that problem has been eased by Mexico's agreement to allow an Export-Import bank loan for drilling and supplying equipment in Mexican oil production. However, that does not extend to allowing U.S. equity in Mexican oil interests, and the United States at this point will not insist on that, Brady said. Brady and other U.S. officials, briefing reporters on Bush's talks with Salinas, said environmental and Central American topics were covered as well. Environmental Protection Agency Administrator William Reilly said the two countries agreed to a study over the next 18 months of environmental problems along the border, particularly pollution and hazardous waste from industry on the Mexican side of the border. The two presidents ``agreed there is a real need for a breakthrough'' in El Salvador where Marxist rebels continue to battle the government, said Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger. He said Bush and Salinas urged a cease-fire there and agreed to push for a greater role by U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar in achieving that. Bush began his visit to this industrial center by attending a small rodeo and dancing demonstration in Salinas' hometown of Agualeguas. The presidents then flew by helicopter to nearby Monterrey. Their motorcade was showered with a thick rain of confetti thrown from tall buildings. People mobbed Bush when he got out to briefly shake hands, as first lady Barbara Bush stayed in the car.

Three out of four of the nation's top business economists believe the United States has skidded into a recession, in part because of the rapid rise in oil prices following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. ``Recession is here,'' the National Association of Business Economists said Tuesday in a report on its canvass of 51 professional forecasters. The report reflects a sharp jump in pessimism among the economists, who just three months ago still felt the country could avoid an imminent downturn. ``We think that the recession began in the fourth quarter and that the (Persian Gulf) oil-price shock played a major role in ending the expansion,'' Richard D. Rippe, NABE president and chief economist with Dean Witter Reynolds, Inc., told a news conference. ``In our view the economy was on a slow-growth track prior to the invasion of Kuwait'' Aug. 2, Rippe said. ``That slow-growth track has been converted into a mild recession outlook by the oil-price shock that has developed.'' In a survey following the Iraqi invasion, only 45 percent of the forecasters said a recession either had begun or was imminent. Just a year ago, 62 percent of the forecasters predicted the economy would escape a recession through 1992. Two other reports Tuesday provided further gloomy news about the economy: -The Commerce Department reported the U.S. trade deficit jumped 28.9 percent in the July-September quarter, to $29.75 billion, the highest imbalance in a year. Imports rose 5 percent to a record $125.91 billion, as the Persian Gulf crisis drove up the cost of oil. Exports, damped by falling overseas demand for American farm products, fell 0.6 percent to $96.16 billion. -The National Association of Realtors said October sales of existing homes fell 4.7 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.02 million, the lowest rate since February 1985, when it was 2.95 million. Realtors' president Harley E. Rouda said reports of persistent budget deficit woes, economic sluggishness nationwide and the threat of war have created psychological barriers that are blocking home sales. Despite the gloomy news, Rippe, the president of the business economists, said any recession ``should be shallow by historical standards.'' The median estimate of the forecasters is for economic growth to decline 1.0 percent in this quarter and 0.8 percent in the next. While two-thirds of the group believe the downturn will last two quarters or less, 29 percent said it would continue for three quarters. Four percent said it would continue for 12 months. None felt it would last beyond a year. The last recession continued 16 months, from July 1981 to November 1982. Another survey this month of prominent economists, by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, found 80 percent of the 52 participants said a recession would begin before year's end. An additional five percent said it would begin in 1991. Assuming two quarterly declines - the informal definition of a recession - the NABE economists projected the economy will grow 1.0 percent in 1990 and 0.5 percent in 1991. That includes growth of 0.6 percent in the second quarter next year, 2.0 percent in the third and 2.5 percent in the fourth. The economy grew 2.5 percent in 1989 and 4.5 percent in 1988. Rippe said ``one key assumption in our economic outlook'' is the prospect that oil prices will fall and ``diminish the tax on the economy ... and help reduce the rate of inflation.'' Indeed, the panelists projected inflation will drop nearly two percentage points on a fourth-quarter-to-fourth-quarter basis - from 6.4 percent in 1990 to 4.5 percent in 1991. The survey also found the forecasters believe unemployment will rise from 5.5 percent this year to 6.1 percent in 1991. The jobless rate in October was 5.7 percent, up from 5.2 percent in June.

DOC.HEAD: John Major Epitomizes Thatcherite Virtues
With AM-Britain-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: John Major, the youngest and fastest-rising British prime minister of the 20th century, epitomizes the virtues of self-reliance and initiative preached by his predecessor. Major described himself as a Thatcherite but insisted he was his own man. ``I am not running as `Son of Margaret Thatcher.' I am running as myself, with my own priorities and my own program,'' Major said over the weekend. He reaches the highest office in the land 11 years after entering Parliament, without leaving a trail of bruised and resentful enemies. And he came all the way up from poverty without so much as a university education. Former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine mounted the successful challenge to Mrs. Thatcher in the Conservative Party that caused the prime minister to abandon her office. But Mrs. Thatcher endorsed Major to succeed her and in the three-way fight for the party leadership and the prime ministership, it was Major who had the votes to defeat Heseltine and Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd. Softspoken, bespectacled and often referred to as ``the gray man,'' 47-year-old Major has none of the obvious qualities associated with the political high-flyer. But Mrs. Thatcher saw in him a sharp mind, political judgment and the conciliator's talent for negotiation. She saw him as ``a man of the people,'' her aides said, and even his opponents say he's a nice man. He appeals to the right wing of his party with free market economic views, and to the left wing with his sympathetic outlook toward Britain's underprivileged. Even for the new breed of Conservative who broke into the ranks of Oxford and Cambridge-educated Tory privilege, Major has an unusual background. The son of a sometime circus performer and actor, he left school at 16, worked as a laborer and spent eight months on welfare before he started his successful banking career as a clerk at age 18. Tall and deliberate, Major has neat gray hair, clean-cut features and a quiet manner of speech nearly free of the inflections of class and geography that still pigeonhole so many Britons. He sees increased social mobility as ``one of the greatest achievements of the last 10 years,'' and says his goal is ``a genuinely classless society in which people can rise to whatever level that their own abilities and their own good fortune may take them.'' The contribution of blue-collar workers should be respected, he says. ``We will need the practical manual skills of people in the future and we should recognize those for what they are - a very genuine talent.'' Once asked if regretted not having gone to university, he said ``not a bit.'' ``It has been of immense value to me to have been on the other side of the fence and to know what it was like to face a few difficulties, and I don't regret any of that.'' Besides the broad electoral appeal of his background, Major's greatest practical asset is his financial experience as a banker, chief secretary to the Treasury and lately as chancellor of the exchequer during a difficult year for the economy. Major climbed swiftly through Standard and Chartered Bank, where he was an executive for 14 years before entering national politics. His lack of expertise in foreign affairs is regarded as a weakness - he spent only three months as foreign secretary - but he has indicated the veteran Hurd would stay on to head the Foreign Office. Major's stance on the Persian Gulf crisis is unlikely to differ greatly from Mrs. Thatcher's. On Europe, he says he is convinced Britain will be able negotiate an outcome on political and monetary union that will be acceptable to the European Community and to Parliament. Elected to Parliament in 1979, he entered the Cabinet in 1987 as chief secretary to the Treasury. From July to October 1989 he was foreign secretary, and when Nigel Lawson resigned as chancellor of the exchequer in October, Major replaced him as the nation's top treasury official. Major started life in the comfortable suburb of Cheam and went to Rutlish Grammar, a state school for bright children. When he was 11 the family, including two brothers and a sister, moved to the tough south London neighborhood of Brixton following ``an injudicious investment'' by his father. He speaks with affection of his father, who was 66 when John was born and soon began losing his eyesight. ``I used to walk with him a lot so he wouldn't trip over curbs and what have you,'' Major once said. ``He was a wonderful talker. ... I still think he was the finest raconteur I have ever heard. He had such a wealth of experience and a range of interests.'' The family lived in a cramped apartment, cooked on a gas burner on the landing and shared a bathroom in the hall with other tenants. The home was five minutes from the Oval, one of the hallowed sporting grounds of England, where Major acquired a lifelong devotion to the game of cricket. He can no longer play, however. During a posting in Nigeria with the bank his left leg was so badly injured in a car crash that he nearly lost it. ``My leg doesn't permit me to run,'' he said. ``If I bend it I'm likely to go base over apex.'' Major married Norma Johnson in 1970 and they have a daughter Elizabeth, 19, and a son James, 15. Mrs. Major, an opera-lover, is the author of a biography of the singer Joan Sutherland. An expert cook and dressmaker, she likes a quiet family life. ``I am very fulfilled by domesticity and I don't feel ashamed or guilty about that,'' she says. The post of chancellor carries with it the prize of 11 Downing St., the house next door to the prime minister, but it was never home to the Majors. Mrs. Major stayed home in Great Stukeley with the children and her husband came home on weekends.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Pick Major to Succeed Thatcher and Rally the Party
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts first 2 grafs to simplify. Pickup 3rd, `Aides said...'
DOC.TEXT: John Major was elected today as leader of the Conservative Party and will succeed Margaret Thatcher as prime minister. Major, whose candidacy was endorsed by Mrs. Thatcher, fell two votes short of the needed majority, but his opponents conceded defeat and Conservative Party officials declared him elected. Aides said Mrs. Thatcher was ``thrilled.'' Major, 47, her Treasury chief, is the youngest person to be elected prime minister since the 19th century. ``It is a very exciting thing to become leader of the Conservative Party, and particularly exciting, I think, to follow one of the most remarkable leaders the Conservative Party has ever had,'' Major said. He called Mrs. Thatcher ``a very great prime minister indeed.'' ``Our job now I think is quite clear. We are going to unite totally and absolutely, and we're going to win the next general election,'' said Major, who emerged smiling from his residence at 11 Downing St. Major won 185 votes, former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine had 131 votes, and Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd had 56 votes in a secret ballot election among Tory members of Parliament. ``I congratulate John Major and thank him for a first-class campaign, fought without rancor or bitterness, which I believe lays the basis for the unity of our party,'' Heseltine said moments after the vote was announced. Hurd also quickly conceded. He said the party needed to unite, and ``John Major is the right leader for this task.'' Within minutes, Cranley Onslow, chairman of the Conservative Party committee that supervised the election, announced that a third ballot was not required and Major was elected. Mrs. Thatcher left her residence at 10 Downing St. to congratulate Major, who as chancellor of the exchequer is her next-door neighbor at No. 11. Mrs. Thatcher intended to submit her resignation to Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace once a new leader was elected. Major would then be called to be confirmed as prime minister and first lord of the treasury. Major was elected to Parliament in 1979, was appointed foreign secretary and then chancellor of the exchequer last year. He moved up quickly in a five-day campaign for the leadership after Mrs. Thatcher announced Thursday that she would resign rather than continue a leadership fight against Heseltine. By the weekend, opinion polls showed that Major was nearly as highly regarded by the public as was Heseltine, who has been prominent for a decade. Major attracted support from prominent figures on the right wing of the Conservative Party, although his friends insisted Major's own views were more liberal than many supposed. He described himself as conservative on economic issues but liberal on social issues. Major epitomized the self-reliant, hard-working achiever who Mrs. Thatcher encouraged. Born March 29, 1943, he was the son of a circus performer, left school at 16 and was a laborer and at one time a welfare recipient. Major became a banker and Conservative Party activist, and was elected to Parliament in the first Thatcher victory of 1979. He was appointed to a junior ministerial post in 1985, then to the No. 2 position in the Treasury in 1987. He emerged as a possible heir-apparent when Mrs. Thatcher appointed him foreign secretary in July 1989, and then chancellor of the exchequer three months later. He inherits a party and a government that have been torn by controversy over European policy and local taxes, and depressed after months lagging behind the opposition Labor Party in opinion polls. The government has until mid-1992 to call an election. Recent opinion polls, however, suggested that any new leader would greatly enhance Tory popularity, and Major was rated as favorably as Heseltine. Major has indicated he would review the widely hated ``poll tax,'' which replaced the property tax with a flat charge against all adults, no matter how wealthy. He entered the leadership race jointly with Hurd, whose position as foreign secretary appears secure. Tall and deliberate, Major has neat gray hair, clean-cut features and a quiet manner of speech nearly free of the inflections of class and geography that still pigeonhole so many Britons. He sees increased social mobility as ``one of the greatest achievements of the last 10 years,'' and says his goal is ``a genuinely classless society in which people can rise to whatever level that their own abilities and their own good fortune may take them.'' Once asked if regretted not having gone to university, he said ``not a bit.'' ``It has been of immense value to me to have been on the other side of the fence and to know what it was like to face a few difficulties, and I don't regret any of that.'' Major and his wife Norma have a daughter, Elizabeth, 19, and a son, James, 15.

DOC.HEAD: Sales of Existing Homes at Lowest Level in Nearly 6 Years
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fading consumer confidence continued to take its toll on sales of existing homes in October, pushing them down 4.7 percent to their lowest level in nearly six years, a real estate trade group said Tuesday. Reports of persistent federal budget deficits, general economic sluggishness and the threat of a Mideast war have created psychological barriers that are blocking home purchases, according to Harley E. Rouda, president of the National Association of Realtors. As a result, the Realtors said, house resales fell to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.02 million, down from 3.17 million in September and the lowest rate since 2.95 million in February 1985. The Commerce Department will report on new home sales in October next Tuesday. In September, sales slumped 6 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 503,000, the biggest drop in six months. The Realtors said the median price of an existing house also fell in October, down 1.7 percent to $92,800. The median means half of the homes cost more, half less. Rouda said the monthly decline and a ``marginal'' 0.4 percent increase over October 1989 prices mean that sellers are adjusting their prices to fit a buyers' market. At the same time, the Realtors said mortgage interest rates remained relatively stable. Rouda said the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. reported the average rate for a 30-year, conventional fixed-rate mortgage ranged from 10.08 percent to 10.17 percent in October. Rates subsequently fell to an average of 9.93 percent by the end of last week. Each region of the country reported declines in sales and all but the West posted lower median prices. The resale pace in the Northeast was 470,000 units, 9.6 percent below the September rate. The median price was $136,200, down 0.7 percent from the previous month. Sales in the West totaled 490,000 in October, down 5.8 percent from the previous month. The median price there was $140,600, 4.4 percent higher than in September. Sales in the Midwest were off 5.7 percent, to an annual rate of 820,000 units, while the median price fell 2.8 percent to $72,100. In the South, sales totaled 1.23 million, down 2.4 percent from September. The median price dropped 2.9 percent, to $83,400. The Realtors said sales of existing homes are expected to total 3.33 million units this year, down 4.1 percent from 1989's 3.44 million total.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Mexico Bjt
First Ladies Tour Community Center, School
DOC.TEXT: Students serenaded Barbara Bush with a Spanish version of ``America the Beautiful'' during her tour Tuesday of a local school and community center. Mrs. Bush visited a DIF center, one of a network in Mexico under the patronage of first lady Cecilia Occelli de Salinas that includes adult education, handicraft training to make items for home sale, a garden and a food kitchen for the elderly. A children's orchestra began playing ``The Yellow Rose of Texas'' as Mrs. Bush passed through the school. ``Oh, oh, there's my song,'' she exclaimed. ``They're playing my song.'' Mrs. Salinas hosted the event. Also on hand were Diana Negroponte, wife of U.S. Ambassador to Mexico John Dimitri Negroponte; Nickie Bennett, wife of Monterrey's U.S. Consul General John Bennett; Alma Rizzo, wife of Monterrey Mayor Socrates Rizzo, and Cristina Trevino, wife of Nuevo Leon Gov. Jorge Trevino. Mrs. Bush wore a light blue silk suit with thin horizontal white stripes and her trademark pearls while Mrs. Salinas wore a teal and black linen dress. Mrs. Bush was presented with a basket of handicrafts made at the training center by 9-year-old Jesus Eduardo Gonzalez Jimenez, who admitted beforehand that he did not know who she was. At the nearby school she was serenaded by students singing ``America the Beautiful,'' ``Cielito Lindo,'' and ``La Bamba.'' She also was given medals and a heart-shaped pecan arrangment with her picture in the middle.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev: U.N. Measure could lead to `Just Resolution' of Crisis
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
The Soviet Union expressed new support Tuesday for a U.N. resolution that would authorize use of ``all necessary means'' to force Iraq to relinquish Kuwait. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and his foreign minister, Eduard Shevardnadze, held talks with Saudi Arabia's foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal. The official Soviet news agency Tass said both sides agreed that the proposed measure would ``promote a just resolution of the crisis.'' The U.N. Security Coun only by American servicemen overseas. Now, through the efforts of a retired Navy officer who helped ovsee their production, they are on the U.S. market. AM-V-Discs, for Monday AMs, Dec. 3, moved as b0477.
BEIJING - Zhou Lihong, seven months pregnant, shares a tiny room in a company dormitory with two other women. Her husband lives upstairs. The company offered part of a primitive house, but the young couple rejected it. Officials say one-fourth of Beijing's residents lack adequate housing, but while the Zhous wait and hope, suitable apartments are empty. One is in the name of a Chinese woman who followed her American husband to the United States, and rents for the equivalent of $1 a month. It is too valuable to give up and her parents don't want to sublet for fear of attracting attention. AM-Oh Give Me a Home, for Tuesday AMs, Dec. 4, moved as b0475.
UNITED NATIONS - One day in 1979, Bismillah Kamkai was taken from his U.N. Development Program office in Kabul, Afghanistan, under armed guard. He was never heard from again. Belay Melake, an Ethiopian statistician working for a U.N. economic agency in Addis Ababa, disappeared more than 11 years ago. His colleagues believe his government tortured and killed him. U.N. staff members say 10 of their colleagues have been killed and 165 are missing or detained around the world. AM-The UN's MIAs, for Wednesday AMs, Dec. 5, moved as b0476.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Japanese Company Honors Former U.S. Ambassador
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese publishing company has purchased the home of the late Edwin O. Reischauer, former U.S. ambassador to Japan, and intends to create a memorial to him. Kodansha Ltd. said Reischauer's Belmont home probably will be used as a residence for a researcher in Japanese studies. But the library and other portions of the building may be open to the public. Reischauer, who died in September, served as ambassador to Japan from 1961 to 1967. He founded the Institute of Japanese Studies at Harvard, where he spent a long teaching career, and was considered the dean of Japanese studies in the United States. Reischauer had worked for Kodansha, publishing some of his books with the company. Kodansha ``wanted to make the house a memorial by preserving it and especially keeping the study and the room in which the present Japanese emperor and empress stayed during their visit in 1987,'' said Reischauer's widow, Hana.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Vows To Fight For Trade Pact With Mexico
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told Mexican business officials Tuesday that a slowing U.S. economy might prompt resistance to a free-trade deal with Mexico. But he vowed to ``write a new page in North American history,'' even if it meant vetoing protectionist bills. Bush wrapped up a two-day state visit to this northern Mexican industrial city with new agreements on oil investment and on educational exchanges. He joined with Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari in voicing strong support for a pact to end trade barriers between the two nations by 1992, but conceded it could face some trouble in Congress. ``This agreement will unleash powerful energies in both economies,'' Bush said in a toast at a state luncheon. ``We're not on an easy path, but I believe we're on the right one.'' The president also praised Mexico for its strong support of the U.S.-led effort against Iraq in the Persian Gulf and for increasing its production of oil to help offset losses from Iraq and Kuwait. Salinas has also hinted he would send troops to Saudi Arabia to join U.S. forces if the U.N. Security Council approves a use-of-force resolution. However, U.S. officials said that the crisis in the Middle East was not discussed in any detail by the two leaders. Meanwhile, the two presidents appeared to reach an understanding in a U.S.-Mexican disagreement over whether Mexico's vast oil industry should be open to U.S. or other foreign investment. Salinas has insisted the state-run and subsidized oil industry be exempt from the free-trade talks. But Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady told reporters here that the dispute has been eased by Mexico's agreement to allow an Export-Import Bank loan for drilling and supplying equipment in Mexican oil exploration. Under such an arangement, U.S. companies could provide Mexico with expertise in finding oil. The Export-Import Bank is an independent U.S. government agency. Brady said the agreement still will not permit U.S. companies to own direct interests in Mexican oil. But he said the United States at this point will not press for that. Bush held a breakfast meeting with a group of Mexican and American business leaders, then met for the second day with Salinas and aides. Afterwards, the two leaders addressed a theater audience of Monterrey citizens and Bush met with about 100 Mexican business leaders. It was at this session, during a question and answer period, that Bush was asked about protectionism in the United States, which many Mexicans view as a threat to the free-trade agreement. ``As the giant U.S. economy slows down - it may slow down even more - it concerns me that some in our country and some in our Congress might turn inward to what you properly label as a protectionist mode,'' Bush said. Bush said that if U.S. business want to export ``we better not be protectionists.'' ``We're going to have problems with certain elements'' in winning support for the trade pact, which would be similar to the one the United States and Canada signed in 1988, he said. ``It is a concern. It is not an overwhelming concern. I think it is something that can be managed,'' he said. Bush told the business leaders that he had recently vetoed a textile import quota bill that he said was the epitome of protectionism. ``And this president will continue to veto protectionist legislation,'' he added. ``The size and sophistication of U.S.-Mexico trade today only hints at our potential. We can create and share unprecedented prosperity and jobs,'' Bush said earlier in his address to citizens in the Monterrey City Theater. ``I look forward to the day when we will meet to sign our names to a free trade agreement that will write a new page in North American history,'' he added. For his part, Salinas used the speech in the theater to criticize the brutal treatment he said some Mexican workers are receiving as they cross the U.S. border to find jobs in the United States. He said Mexican workers make a positive contribution to the U.S. economy and the United States has a ``moral and juridical obligation'' to respect their human and labor rights. Salinas, a Harvard-educated economist, said the free trade pact would help Mexicans find jobs in their own country instead having to cross the border to find work. Environmental Protection Agency Administrator William Reilly, briefing reporters here, said Mexico and the United States agreed to a study over the next 18 months of environmental problems along the border. He said it would pay special attention to hazardous wastes from industry on the Mexican side of the border. The two presidents ``agreed there is a real need for a breakthrough'' in El Salvador where Marxist rebels continue to battle the government, said Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger. He said Bush and Salinas urged a cease-fire there and agreed to push for a greater role by U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar in achieving that. Bush and Salinas concluded their meeting by announcing a $3-million annual program under which 150 Mexican and American students a year will receive scholarships to pursue post-graduate studies each other's countries. The program, to be based in Mexico City, will be jointly financed by both countries.

DOC.HEAD: New Technique Freezes, Destroys Inoperable Tumors, Radiologist Says
DOC.TEXT: A procedure that freezes cancerous tumors by using ultrasound-guided probes offers hope to people who otherwise would be certain to die of liver malignancies, a radiologist said Tuesday. Of 30 patients who underwent the treatment, six are free of disease, said Dr. Gary Onik of Presbyterian Hospital in Pittsburgh. The technique, called cryosurgery, has the ability to destroy tumors next to major blood vessels without destroying normal tissues nearby, Onik reported at the 76th Scientific Assembly and Annual Meeting of the Radiological Society of North America. It offers hope to patients whose cancer is caught before it involves the entire liver, he said, noting that radiation and chemotherapy are ineffective treatments for liver cancer. ``Everybody we worked on by definition couldn't be helped any other way,'' Onik said. The patients who are now disease-free after undergoing the procedure have survived an average of 29 months, with the longest survival five years, he said. Survival for the other patients has averaged 22 months, and two of the patients whose cancer has come back are still alive, he said. That is considerably longer than the projected survival of six months to nine months after diagnosis among comparable liver cancer patients who don't have cryosurgery, Onik said. He and his colleagues also are testing ultrasound-guided cryosurgery for prostate cancer, and among seven patients who have undergone it so far, no complications have resulted, Onik said. A cancer specialist lauded Onik's work. ``I think he's making an important contribution,'' said Dr. Andrew Gage, deputy director of the Roswell Park Cancer Institute in Buffalo, N.Y. Not only does Onik's technique offer hope to patients whose lives otherwise probably would be lost, it also pioneers a method in which doctors can watch the effects of surgery as they go, Gage said in a telephone interview Tuesday. The technique involves making an incision into the patient's abdomen and using ultrasound to find the cancerous lesions in the liver. A surgeon then inserts a probe into a lesion and freezes the lesion with liquid nitrogen. ``You can watch the freezing envelop the tumor,'' Onik said. ``You can show what you've done.'' Most malignant liver tumors develop from cancers that migrate from the colon, Onik said, adding that the phenomenon strikes about 50,000 Americans a year. While colon cancer is relatively easy to remove, liver cancer tends to be more scattered through the organ and more problematic, he said. Gage said conventional surgery still would be the preferred treatment for most liver cancer patients. Cryosurgery might be better for about one person in 50, specifically, patients with too many lesions to remove with a scalpel but not so many that they involve the whole liver, he said. Liver transplants are not an option in cancer patients because they require taking drugs to suppress the immune system and prevent rejection of the donated organ. Anti-rejection drugs promote cancer growth, causing tumors to ``pop up everywhere,'' Onik said. Ultrasound is a radar-like technique in which high frequency sound waves are sent into the body to form an image.
