He said his work with ultrasound and cryosurgery follows success with similar techniques in Japan and China.

DOC.HEAD: Karpov, Kasparov Draw 14th Game
DOC.TEXT: Anatoly Karpov on Tuesday accepted chess champion Garry Kasparov's offer of a draw in the 14th game of the World Chess Championship. The game left them deadlocked with seven points each. The 15th game is scheduled for Wednesday. The Soviet rivals adjourned the game Monday night after five hours of play, with Kasparov sealing his 41st move, Qc2. Both had three pawns, a rook, a queen and king left. Without resuming play Tuesday, Karpov accepted Kasparov's offer of a draw, which the champion had made Monday night. The first player to gain 12{ points, in a maximum of 24 games, wins the championship and $1.7 million of a $3 million purse. In the event of a tie, Kasparov retains the title. The two grandmasters were tied at six after the first 12 games in New York, 10 of which were draws, between Oct. 8 and Nov. 7. The second phase of the championship began Saturday in Lyon with the 13th game, another draw.

DOC.HEAD: A Melancholy Israel Buries Its Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBs 4 grafs for last 3 grafs, beginning ``Cohen was ...'' to say Cohen was only wounded Israeli, give names of all the dead Israelis.
DOC.TEXT: A pall hung over Israel on Tuesday as it buried three of its five soldiers killed in a clash with Palestinian guerrillas in southern Lebanon. Radio stations played sad songs, and Maj. Gen. Yossi Peled, commander of the sector where the deaths occurred, said: ``Today we paid in a big way, heavily.'' The shock over the latest deaths was compounded by the fact that only two days earlier, four Israelis were shot and killed by an infiltrator on the Egyptian border. In a commentary in the daily Maariv, Shmuel Schnitzer wrote: ``We have to learn to live with the feeling that death lurks everywhere.'' The border violence also includes two army deaths on the Jordan River this month. ``I don't recall a month where we have paid such a price,'' said an army officer, who spoke on condition of anonymity. In fact, the army has suffered much higher casualties during Israel's 42 years of statehood. But the latest deaths caught the Israeli public off guard - preoccupied by the 3-year-old Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories and the influx of Soviet Jews. On Tuesday, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Cabinet was in special session to debate the $37.5 billion state budget for 1991. At issue was how to cover the costs of absorbing hundreds of thousands of immigrants while maintaining a strong military posture. No decision was reached. The army also faces a struggle to retain public confidence. It has been wracked for months by a bitter race for the post of chief of staff. And in the midst of the news of the deaths in Lebanon, it emerged that a senior general had resigned in anger, complaining that the army was ill-prepared for war. As head of training and planning, Maj. Gen. Moshe Bar-Kochba was in charge of studying the lessons of past military setbacks. In a letter broadcast by Israel radio, he claimed no one was paying attention to his findings. All this, plus the undercurrent of worry that the Persian Gulf crisis could drag Israel into war, has created an atmosphere of foreboding. Bar-Kochba's letter ``came at a very bad moment,'' army spokesman Brig. Gen. Nachman Shai told Israel television. ``I don't think he intended it to be this way but that's how it came out.'' At the hospital where his 20-year-old son Haim was recovering from injuries suffered in the Lebanon clash, Pinchas Cohen, 50, told reporters: ``It's too bad that our generation didn't solve our security problems for our children, who are now fated to sacrifice their lives. ``But we don't have much choice and we cannot allow this to break us.'' Cohen was the only Israeli wounded in the clash, which occurred during the night but was not announced to Israelis until late morning after the families of the dead had been notified. Those buried Tuesday were Staff Sgt. Roi Domb, Sgt. Amnon Kadmon and Sgt. Gad Meinfeld. Maj. Yuval Veinstein and Staff Sgt. Guy Tal were to be buried Wednesday. In a eulogy at the funeral for Meinfeld, his commander said the guerrillas were headed to northern Israel to commit ``killing and murder.'' ``The terrorists' mission was foiled,'' Peled said. ``The settlements of the north are safe. The price is unbearable.''

DOC.HEAD: Dinkins Has Bulletproof Raincoat
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins said Tuesday he has added bulletproof duds to his wardrobe. He confirmed that he had been fitted for an armored raincoat and a vest that he could wear under his shirt. He said he had been measured about six months ago, but hasn't worn the protective garments. ``It's more comfortable without them,'' he said. Dinkins said there had been no particular threat to prompt the extra protection, which he called a ``routine precaution the Police Department takes.'' He said previous mayors also had bulletproof clothing.

DOC.HEAD: Nuclear Inspectors Find All Normal at Iraqi Plants
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two inspectors who visited Iraq's nuclear plants last week found no evidence that Baghdad is developing atomic weapons for its arsenal, the International Atomic Energy Agency said Tuesday. A brief statement by the United Nations agency said ``no change had taken place in the status of nuclear material under safeguards'' at the four sites since the last routine inspection in April. In Washington, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said: ``We would welcome that Iraq has decided to permit this inspection.'' While the inspectors found no diversion of nuclear material, Williams said the inspection ``doesn't tell what happens in the future.'' He also repeated the U.S. position that Iraq is continuing with its program to manufacture nuclear weapons. The agency inspects nuclear facilities and fissionable materials in various countries every six months under the Non-Proliferation Treaty that prohibits the spread of nuclear technology for non-peaceful use. The statement said inspectors in April also accounted for all nuclear materials registered by Iraq with the agency, indicating none had been diverted to develop weapons as Iraq's army prepares for possible war against the multinational forces in Saudi Arabia. President Bush last week told U.S. troops in the region their mission to push Iraq's Saddam Hussein out of occupied Kuwait was marked by ``a real sense of urgency'' because of Baghdad's headway in acquiring nuclear arms. He said it was not clear just how fast Iraq could have such weapons ready for use. But a Nigerian and a Soviet inspector toured Iraq's two research reactors, a storage and a fuel-producing plant Nov. 19-22 at Baghdad's invitation, agency spokesman Hans-Friedrich Meyer said. The inspectors were accompanied by Iraqi officials as permitted under the Non-Proliferation Treaty, he said. Both inspectors were experienced and had led verification groups into Iraq before, Meyer said. He declined to reveal their names. Although the statement did not say specifically, they apparently checked on a 27-pound mass of highly-enriched uranium that Iraq salvaged from its Osirak nuclear reactor, which was destroyed by an Israeli air attack in 1981. Some analysts in Israel, which closely tracks Iraq's arms program, believe Baghdad could be two to five years away from producing its own atomic warheads for missiles or nuclear bombs to be dropped from jets. But other experts say a 10-year development phase is now needed because of the international trade embargo imposed on Iraq after it invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and later annexed the oil-rich emirate. Israel claims Iraq is using the two reactors for its weapons program with the help of 150 pounds of enriched uranium from France, which sold the reactors to Iraq in 1976 for electricity production. Israel brought the nuclear program to a halt when it bombed the Osirak facility but claims development restarted in 1987. Baghdad has repeatedly denied the allegations. The Iraqi invitation to the agency inspectors appeared aimed at removing one justification for an invasion of Iraq by the multinational force in Saudi Arabia. The force has been deployed since Baghdad invaded Kuwait. Some Western officials have claimed the Middle East can never be safe, regardless of Kuwait's status, as long as President Saddam Hussein of Iraq could threaten to use nuclear weapons. The agency has suspended all technical cooperation with Iraq in line with U.N. sanctions following the invasion. But Meyer said the inspection was not considered technical assistance.

DOC.HEAD: Technicians Suspected Hubble Trouble, but Word Never Trickled Up
DOC.TEXT: Technicians suspected a problem in the manufacture of the Hubble Space Telescope's main mirror but never told anyone and the $1.5 billion instrument was launched with a blurred view of the universe, investigators said Tuesday. The manufacturer, Perkin-Elmer, did not assign its best people to the telescope construction and ``there was a surprising lack of participation by optical experts with experience in the manufacture of large telescopes,'' the investigators' final report added. NASA released the study by a six-member panel headed by Dr. Lew Allen, director of the space agency's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif. One flaw the panel found echoed a finding of the investigators of the 1986 Challenger space shuttle accident. The Hubble report said the management structure at Perkin-Elmer raised ``a strong block'' against communication between people doing hands-on work and higher-level experts. In the aftermath of the Challenger disaster, a lack of communication between engineers and upper management was cited as a contributing cause. The telescope, launched last April from the space shuttle Discovery, cannot be focused properly because its 94.5-inch-diameter primary mirror is too flat in the center. The investigators determined quickly, and reiterated in their final report, that an optical test used in the manufacturing process was not set up correctly and ``thus, the surface was polished into the wrong shape.'' The report said there were ``clear indications of the problem from auxiliary optical tests made at the time'' but that ``both indicators of error were discounted at the time as being themselves flawed.'' It said the distortions in the mirror were seen during tests but that the manufacturer believed the test was not reliable ``when in fact, it was quite accurate enough to detect the gross error, and indeed did so.'' Perkin-Elmer design scientists, as well as management for both the company and for NASA, failed to follow the fabrication process ``with reasonable diligence'' and were unaware of the flaws, the report said. It did not single out any individuals. Efforts to reach company officials for comment on the report were not immediately successful. The firm, which was a leading manufacturer of telescopes used in space by the military, assigned its most capable optical scientists to producing a small demonstration mirror and the design of both the Hubble mirror and the test apparatus, the report said. But the fabrication of the mirror was the responsibility of the Optical Operations Division, which operated in a closed-door environment and used neither the optical design scientists or available skills outside of the division. ``During the testimony, it was indicated that some technical personnel in the Optical Operations Division were deeply concerned at the time that the discrepant optical data might indicate a flaw,'' the report said. ``There are no indications that these concerns were formally expressed outside this division.'' In the grinding of the Hubble mirror, as in all large telescope mirrors, a device known as a reflective null corrector is used to measure the accuracy of the polishing process. The corrector had been preserved exactly as it was during the manufacture of the mirror and the board found its lens was incorrectly spaced. The amount of the error would account exactly for the blurred images recorded by two cameras on the Hubble. NASA plans to put corrective lenses on the cameras during an astronaut visit scheduled for early in 1993 and experts believe that will solve the problem. Even without the corrections, the Hubble has returned some spectacular pictures from space, many with better resolution than ever seen by ground-based cameras.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Seeks Alliance with Defeated Foe's Backers
LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa appealed Tuesday to supporters of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki to help him stop a ``dangerous'' outsider from becoming Poland's president. One of Walesa's sharpest critics agreed. ``Today (Walesa) is the only candidate worth cosidering,'' wrote Editor Adam Michnik, a veteran Solidarity activist and perhaps Walesa's most determined political foe. ``A victory by Walesa would involve high risk for Poland. But a victory by (Stanislaw) Tyminski would bring the absolute certainty of extreme degradation,'' Michnik said in a front-page editorial in Gazeta Wyborza, the country's largest newspaper. The election success Sunday of the wealthy emigre businessman Tyminski denied Walesa an absolute majority triumph and eliminated Mazowiecki from the Dec. 9 presidential runoff. The East bloc's first non-Communist prime minister then announced late Monday he would resign along with his 15-month-old government. Tyminski, who had only just returned from a 21-year sojourn in Peru and Canada, mounted a free-spending campaign characterized by sharp attacks on the government and promises of quick economic improvement. At a news conference in Warsaw, the dark-horse candidate praised Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's 1981 imposition of martial law to crush Solidarity. He said the country at the time was under ``unusual danger'' from within. Walesa asked Mazowiecki backers during a news conference at Solidarity headquarters in Gdansk to help him defeat Tyminski. ``We are doomed to be together,'' the Solidarity chairman said. ``We should pull this common Polish wagon together.'' ``You cannot put Poland into hands that have not been checked, lacking any background,'' he said. ``What is happening now is dangerous.'' Walesa polled 40 percent of the electorate Sunday compared to 23 percent for Tyminski and 18 for Mazowiecki. Walesa said he had warned the prime minister that the movement was losing the support of the masses. ``Those people who were with Mazowiecki, who really worked so hard, did not want to understand,'' he said. ``This cold shower will wake us all up and we will think seriously about reforms in Poland.'' Jaruzelski, the lame duck president, formally asked Mazowiecki on Tuesday to head a caretaker government until the next president nominates a prime minister. Walesa told a news conference that he would maintain the Mazowiecki economic program, but with ``certain corrections.'' Walesa said he planned to telephone Mazowiecki and appeal for ``not multiplying the tension.'' There was no confirmation from Mazowiecki's office, but aides to Walesa in Gdansk said talks were being carried out with ``the highest officials'' in Warsaw. Tyminski at his news conference attacked sacred cows of Polish political life. He praised Jaruzelski and criticized Mazowiecki for his economic policies and for alleged cooperation with Communist authories as a journalist in the early 1950s. Of Jaruzelski's martial-law decision, he said: ``I hope that this country understands now how much has been done for it by President Wojciech Jaruzelski, because at that moment (in 1981) the country was in unusual danger ... from within, because the hand that did the injury for so many years was always our own.'' ``They are very irresponsible,'' Tyminski said referring to the government's shock economic reform program instituted in January to almost universal praise from the world financial community. ``Even if nothing had been done, there would not be destruction on such a scale.'' Mazowiecki said in his resignation statement Monday night that he had been brought down by lack of public patience for the sacrifices required to improve the economy. ``Society made its choice,'' said the taciturn prime minister, who took office in August 1989 after decades as a writer in the Catholic opposition. Meanwhile, Zdzislaw Najder - a historian and former head of the Polish section of Radio Free Europe - told the state PAP news agency that he ``could not exclude'' being named prime minister and forming a government under Walesa. Najder heads Walesa's national Citizens Committee movement. ``I know that there are people of greater authority and experience. ... My trump is a considerable familiarity with the world at large,'' PAP quoted Najder as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Sees Moderate Food Prices, Big Farm Incomes
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department projected on Tuesday that consumer food prices will climb more slowly in 1991 and that farmers will see near-record incomes as production increases. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said there are still some trouble spots but ``the situation has changed for the better'' from the financial crunch of the mid-1980s. ``The overall economic health of this industry is infinitely improved over what is was five years ago,'' Yeutter told the department's annual outlook conference. James R. Donald, chairman of the department's World Agricultural Outlook Board, said the 1991 forecast calls for an average food price increase of 2 percent to 5 percent, compared with almost 6 percent this year. ``Projected record meat supplies, higher dairy product output and the likelihood of bigger citrus crops this season will moderate food price rises,'' he said. Donald also said food marketing costs will rise more slowly if overall inflation eases to around 4.5 percent instead of this year's 5.5 to 6 percent. Donald said farmers will expand 1991 plantings of several crops to take advantage of more flexibility under new farm program provisions. Globally, he said, commodity production ``will increase substantially'' in 1990-91 and that production of livestock products ``will reach a new record as red meat recovers and poultry supplies continue to increase.'' Some U.S. products will face rising competition from other countries, particularly for wheat. And U.S. meat export increases probably will slow as Japan cuts back on imports. ``The big news next year will be grains, and plenty of it,'' Donald said. ``For the last three years, the world has been consuming more grain than it produced, working down stocks. ``But production shot ahead this year. While grain consumption is rising by another 2 percent ... production is up 5 percent to a new record.'' Donald said the outlook for 1991 ``points to a year of near-record incomes for U.S. farmers'' as cash receipts rise with larger sales and higher prices for a few commodities. Meanwhile, farmers will see production expenses increase, partly because of higher prices for energy-related items. But even with those higher expenses, Donald said 1991 cash income of farmers will be in the range of $55 billion to $60 billion, slightly less than this year's record high of $59 billion. Net cash income is simply the difference between gross cash income in a calendar year and cash expenses. In another way of accounting, 1991 net farm income may be in the range of $44 billion to $49 billion, compared with this year's record of $49 billion. That takes into account a number of factors, including changes in inventory values and other adjustments. A year ago, looking at 1990, the department's forecasters predicted food prices would rise 3 to 5 percent. Hard freezes in late December helped boost fruit and vegetable prices much faster than had been anticipated. The year-ago prediction for net cash income of farmers was in the range of $52 billion to $57 billion. Net farm income at that time was forecast in 1990 at $46 billion to $49 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Businessman: Newspapers Key to Students' Civic Participation
DOC.TEXT: Believing that reading newspapers and getting involved in government are keys to a free society, a businessman Tuesday initiated a scholarship program that encourages high school students to do both. ``The idea is to get everybody involved,'' said Carlos Roca, owner of Main Line Foto Inc. ``By bringing in the newspaper we can make sure that they understand what's going on, and that's the first part of the whole process.'' Roca's Pennsylvania-based company, which distributes film and other supplies to newspapers, is starting the Citizenship Education Scholarship Program at three San Antonio high schools. The program will start with current events classes, using newspapers as a primary resource. Roca hopes the program for minorities, disadvantaged youths and new Americans will spread to other schools and cities. A newspaper is ``an educational tool, just like your school book,'' Roca said. ``But this one is going to last the rest of your life.'' ``Ben Franklin said it: a free press will keep this country free,'' Roca said. ``But it's only a free press if people read it. I come from a newspaper family so I know how important it is to read a newspaper.'' Roca, 28, who is of Puerto Rican descent, said he learned from his family's newspaper background the importance of newspapers in a democracy. ``Nowadays, one of the problems we're having is kids don't read newspapers. And unless they do, we're all in big trouble, because that is what keeps this country free,'' Roca said. His father, Gaspar Roca, is president and publisher of El Vocero de Puerto Rico, the largest Hispanic daily in the United States. Following the classroom instruction, students will travel to Washington for a week of seminars and meetings organized by the Close Up Foundation, a non-profit, non-partisan education group. ``I'm just a normal student. To have something like this, I feel I'm going to be a part of the big picture,'' said scholarship recipient Barry Huff, a 17-year-old senior at East Central High School. Jennifer Berry, 16, a junior at East Central, said she's eager to learn how government in Washington works. ``I'm very happy that I got a scholarship, because otherwise I wouldn't be able to go,'' she said. On Tuesday, Roca presented $1,600 to East Central. He also is awarding the same amount to Sam Houston and Sidney Lanier high schools. Each school is allowed to divide the money among as many students as it likes. East Central picked three students. The other schools had not yet decided how many students would receive the scholarship. The San Antonio Independent School District, in turn, is honoring Roca with a ``Friend of Education'' award. The students will raise some of the more than $600 each will need for the trip. And some of the program money in San Antonio will be generated by a percentage of Main Line Foto sales to the San Antonio Express-News. ``It's a great program, and I think it's a healthy one,'' said Express-News Publisher W. Lawrence Walker Jr., who invited the students to visit the newspaper before their trip in February. Roca said he decided to give out the first scholarships in San Antonio after meeting Rep. Albert Bustamante, D-Texas, and learning about the area. Roca said he selected the Close Up Foundation because of its reputation for allowing students to interact with government officials. More than 25,000 students take part in Close Up each year. Main Line Foto is a full line professional stockhouse dealer of film, paper and chemicals. The company, which Carlos Roca founded in 1983 while in college at Villanova University, supplies about 900 newspapers nationwide. His company is one of the top 500 Hispanic-owned businesses in the nation.

DOC.HEAD: Major's Policies in Brief
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at the views of John Major, elected as leader of the Conservative Party on Tuesday. He will succeed Margaret Thatcher as prime minister. ---
ON THE GULF: ``There will be no difference in policy,'' Major said. `` ... There is absolute unity that what has happened there is unforgivable and that it has to be reversed.'' ---

ON THE ECONOMY: In the mold of Margaret Thatcher, Major is a rigorous free-marketeer who will follow her policies of selling nationalized industries and holding down government spending. As chancellor of the exchequer, he had kept interest rates high as part of the government's program to combat inflation, currently 10.9 percent. He has said he would make some tax cuts in lower brackets. ---

ON EUROPE: Major will show more enthusiasm for European monetary union than Mrs. Thatcher did, but remains cautious. He drafted a plan for a so-called ``parallel currency'' that would be used in addition to the 12 national currencies. As chancellor, he took the pound into Europe's exchange rate mechanism on Oct. 8. ---

LOCAL TAXES: Major has pledged to review the unpopular per-capita ``poll tax,'' which has become a major political liability for the Conservative Party, but has ruled out its abolition. ``There is no consensus on what the change may be,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mubarak's Party Virtually Unopposed in Boycotted Elections
DOC.TEXT: President Hosni Mubarak's National Democratic Party is virtually unopposed in Thursday's parliamentary elections because of a boycott by major opposition groups. The 454-seat People's Assembly already has gained a reputation as a rubber-stamp parliament for Mubarak's policies because of the wide majorities his National Democratic Party has held in the three parliaments since he became president in 1981. This combines with opposition party charges of vote-rigging to hold down the number of people voting. Analysts expect even fewer voters this time in light of the boycott and the absence of campaign issues. ``We asked for constitutional changes time after time. The political leadership never answered our demands,'' said Ibrahim Farag of the New Wafd Party, one of those boycotting the election. ``We do not accept that we become an ornament for fake democracy,'' he said. With only token opposition, the National Democrats have not had to defend Egypt's deployment of 20,000 troops in Saudi Arabia following Iraqi's invasion of Kuwait. Instead, National Democrats have wound up debating pocketbook issues: the economy, unemployment, commodity shortages and inflation. Their main campaign asset has been the 62-year-old president, who is apparently enjoying increased popularity because of his unflinching opposition to Iraq's seizure of Kuwait. The National Democrats fielded 444 candidates, one for each elective seat in the chamber. Under the constitution, Mubarak appointees take 10 seats. Mubarak suspended the outgoing parliament Sept. 26 because of a ruling by the Supreme Constitutional Court that the 1987 elections were unconstitutional. The president later decreed that parliamentary candidates must run as individuals even if they are party members. The decree invalidated a party-ticket system struck down by the court. Egypt has nine opposition groups, including the banned but government-tolerated Moslem Brotherhood. Boycotting the elections are the Moslem Brotherhood, the New Wafd Party, the Socialist Labor Party and the Liberal Party. In the disbanded parliament, the Brotherhood and its Socialist and Liberal allies held about 60 seats, and the New Wafd had 35. The National Unionist Progressive Party and the Moslem fundamentalist Umma Party are taking part in the elections. They held no seats in the old assembly. Three new parties are campaigning: the Egyptian Greens Party, the Young Egypt Party and the Democratic Unionists Party. With only 101 candidates, the opposition parties pose no problemfor the National Democrats, who include nine Cabinet ministers and have the state-run news media at their disposal. More than 2,000 candidates campaigned without party ties. But the government press said more than half are Mubarak loyalists. ``We expected that parties that said they would boycott would run through independent candidates,'' said Rifaat el-Saeed of the National Unionist Progressive Party. ``There are at least 68 Moslem Brotherhood members campaigning (as independents) under the slogan `Give Us Your Vote So We Can Mend the World with Religion,' as well as a large number of Wafdists and 23 Liberals,'' el-Saeed said. Maamoun el-Hodeiby, the Moslem Brotherhood's secretary-general, denied that more than two members of his group campaigned. Farag said 30 Wafdists ran as independents and were expelled from the party. El-Saeed said his party is participating because to boycott is to give up. ``We feel that boycotting is like admitting it is impossible to bring about change through democracy and parliament,'' he said. A key demand of opposition forces is that voters be required to produce identification. Now a voter gives his name and casts his ballot after his name is checked off a list. ``My father died in 1975,'' said el-Saeed. ``Every year since then when I go to vote, I see on the list that a check has been made opposite his name showing that he's voted.''

DOC.HEAD: Decline Expected to be 4 Percent
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The value of U.S. agricultural exports is expected to drop 4 percent this fiscal year to $38.5 billion, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. The value of those exports rose to a nine-year high of more than $40.1 billion in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30. The volume of shipments also will drop 6 percent to around 139.5 million metric tons, about 154 million short tons, as sales of corn and other coarse grains decline, the department's Economic Research Service said. Although the decline in 1991 had been expected by the agency for some time, it was the first official forecast to include specific values and quantities. ``Lower world grain trade is expected following larger harvests by traditional grain importers, and the U.S. share of world grain trade is expected to fall following increased competitor production,'' the report said. Also, the report said, larger 1990-91 world wheat output has brought sharply lower wheat prices. Corn exports will drop largely because of a one-third cutback in the Soviet Union's corn import needs. However, higher prices are forecast for soybeans and soybean meal, which will offset declines in the volume of shipments, the report said. U.S. agricultural imports were projected to drop slightly to $22 billion in 1990-91 from a record $22.5 billion last year.

DOC.HEAD: Court Hears Case of College Forced to Compensate Fat Student It Kicked Out
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court was asked Tuesday to free a Rhode Island college from having to pay nearly $44,000 to a nursing student because it kicked her out for being too fat. Outside, the debate centered on alleged discrimination against fat people. But inside, the court heard 60 minutes of technical, legalistic arguments pitting Salve Regina College in Newport, R.I., against Sharon L. Russell, now a nurse in St. Petersburg, Fla. What the justices must decide by July is whether a federal appeals court correctly deferred to a federal trial judge's interpretation of Rhode Island common law. A ruling that such deference was warranted will mean Ms. Russell's victory is upheld. But Steven Snow, a Providence, R.I., lawyer representing the college, argued Tuesday that the appeals court should have rendered its own interpretation of state common law rather than defer to the trial judge. His contention drew numerous probing questions, especially from Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, John Paul Stevens and Byron R. White. At one point, O'Connor noted that most federal appeals courts have shown trial judges the same deference when considering state law issues that land in federal court. Edward T. Hogan, the East Providence, R.I., lawyer for Ms. Russell, argued that forcing appeals courts to engage in the type of review Snow suggested would result in ``a waste of time.'' Ms. Russell, who has become a champion in the fight against size discrimination, weighed over 300 pounds when dismissed from Salve Regina in 1985. She had entered the co-ed Catholic school three years previously and received excellent grades through her freshman and sophomore years. But after beginning her nursing studies, Ms. Russell was told by faculty members her weight concerned them. After being dismissed, Ms. Russell transferred to another school and obtained her nursing degree. She also sued the college, and a federal jury awarded her $44,000 on a breach-of-contract claim. Now a pediatric nurse at All Children's Hospital in St. Petersburg, Ms. Russell did not attend the court hearing. The facts of her legal case barely were mentioned Tuesday. Snow, the school's lawyer, was about five minutes into those facts when Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist told him there wasn't much point to continuing. Taking the chief justice's cue, Snow quickly delved into the sole legal point being studied by the court. But in those five minutes, Snow managed to state that Ms. Russell's ``size did become a problem during the clinical training'' and that her ``severe eating disorder'' had resulted in ``morbid obesity.'' Outside the court building, Ms. Russell's lawyer told reporters his client hoped to win the case and have her victory be seen as ``supportive'' of the rights of other fat people. ``They were wrong in pressing the issue of her weight,'' Hogan said. ``She's just as big as she ever was'' and is functioning well as a nurse, he said. Actually, Ms. Russell now weighs about 285 pounds. She recently was the keynote speaker at a convention of the 3,000-member National Association to Advance Fat Acceptance. The case is Salve Regina College vs. Russell, 89-1629.

DOC.HEAD: Cruiser Diverts German Ship Sailing to Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A German-flagged ship loaded with two heavy boxes that could not be opened was diverted from its destination by a guided missile cruiser patrolling the Red Sea, the Pentagon said Tuesday. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said the USS Biddle intercepted the Premier in the northern part of the Red Sea last Thursday. As a result of the U.N. sanctions, U.S. and allied ships have been patrolling both the Red Sea and the Arabian Sea to prevent goods from entering and leaving Iraq. On board the Premier, U.S. officials found two sealed boxes and a manifest that had been altered. The ship was not allowed to proceed to its port of destination. ``Things just didn't square up,'' Williams said. He said officials did not know what was inside the boxes. Williams said he could not say where the ship was headed or where it was diverted to. In the past, there have been allegations that Jordan had allowed goods bound for Iraq to enter through the port of Aquaba, which is on the Red Sea. Jordan has denied the allegations. In another incident, Williams said the USS Thomas C. Hart, a Navy frigate, along with a French and a Spanish ship, intercepted the Khawala Bint Al Zawra, an Iraqi-flagged cargo ship in the Red Sea Monday night. The ship was allowed to proceed after a boarding party determined it held nothing bound for Iraq. The ship had a crew of 33 plus 97 other passengers, who were mostly crew members from other ships that had been diverted, Williams said.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Proposes, Then Backs Off Citywide Curfew for Juveniles
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with mayor delaying decision to ask for a curfew. No pickup; ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Richard Arrington backed a citywide curfew for youths under age 17, then decided to delay presenting it to City Council. Arrington had said he would make the proposal Tuesday, but he told the council more research was needed. He said he plans to submit the proposal, and other measures to halt an increase in youth violence, in two weeks. The curfew would be similar to one that went into effect recently in Atlanta. Like that curfew, the Birmingham proposal is being attacked by civil libertarians as an infringement of young people's constitutional rights. In addition to the curfew, a task force formed by Arrington proposed stiff new laws against guns and drug possession, with parents liable for children who become repeat offenders. Arrington, who is black, called on Birmingham's black majority to support the curfew and crackdown. ``In the past, these measures have not been supported by blacks because they believe they are racist,'' he said. He added that ``a disproportionate amount of young people involved in crimes are black. But the victims are also black, and somehow we've got to get that across. We need to support these tough measures.'' Neil Bradley, associate director of the Southeastern regional office of the American Civil Liberties Union, said the proposed curfew would be unconstitutional and would be challenged in court if enacted. The task force was formed in the wake of the fatal shooting of an 11-year-old girl by a 14-year-old boy outside a public school.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Navy Gathers Largest Force Since WWII
DOC.TEXT: The United States hasn't had as many ships in one region in the last 45 years. But to face Iraq and Saddam Hussein, the aircraft carriers America, Roosevelt and Ranger and their estimated 240 aircraft are set to join the Kennedy, the Saratoga and the Midway ringing the Arabian peninsula. And the battleship Missouri is to join the USS Wisconsin already in the gulf. The United States is busy bringing together ``the most naval forces that we've had in any one location since World War II,'' according to Rear Adm. Daniel P. March, commander of the Seventh Fleet's Battle Force. But March, 51, does not anticipate serious problems coordinating all the various vessels in the Persian Gulf region, including those from many other allied nations. ``From a command and control standpoint ... a lot of forces do make things a little bit more complex but we're used to joint operations,'' he said. March pointed out that three carrier groups and two battleship groups exercised in the Pacific last year in what then was the largest naval deployment since the 1940s. The admiral spoke to reporters from his base aboard the Midway, the Navy's oldest and smallest carrier. Boatswain John Smith called it a ``Volkswagen' in comparison to the ``Cadillac' it just relieved - the USS Independence. Because the Midway is shorter and lighter, March acknowledged the ship can't carry as many bombs, missiles, shells, fuel or supplies. But he and other officers said the United States' only foreign-based carrier fosters a special esprit de corps. ``Midway attracts a kind of a unique breed,'' noted Lt. Dave Myer, 37, of Orlando, Fla. ``We never go home. We don't go back to the States. So we're out here operating all the time. And I like that.'' March described the air wing's responsibility: ``The mission is to put aircraft over the beach in support of the objectives, in support of troops in the field, in support of interdiction, in support of targets.'' The commodore of the carrier's destroyer squadron said Iraq is keeping a low profile in the area. ``We check out about a hundred ships a day coming in or going out of the gulf,'' said Capt. J.W. Parker. ``We haven't had occasion to board any. It sort of indicates that the Iraqis have changed their procedures a little bit.'' After the multinational force boarded vessels to enforce the U.N. sanctions against trade with Iraq following the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Parker speculates that Baghdad decided against challenging the naval blockade - at least on the gulf side of the Arabian peninsula. ``There are no Iraqi ships coming,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Posts First Win of the Season
With AM-Nielsens-List
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: ABC won the network ratings race Tuesday for the first time in the 10-week-old fall season with a big boost from Monday night football and a Stephen King horror story. ``Stephen King's `It' Part 2'' finished second in A.C. Nielsen Co. rankings, followed by ABC's NFL Monday night showdown between the Los Angeles Raiders and the Miami Dolphins. The most watched show on television was CBS' weekly news magazine ``60 Minutes,'' featuring an interview with ``Born on the Fourth of July'' and ``Platoon'' film director Oliver Stone. ABC finished first in overall network ratings with a 13.4 average. NBC was second with 11.8 and CBS third with 11.3. Last week's figures marked the widest margin between first and second place since all four World Series games were broadcast in prime time last month. Each ratings point represents 931,000 households. In another first, NBC's ``The Cosby Show'' earned the lowest ratings of its 7-year history with a Thanksgiving night repeat that plummeted the longstanding hit series to 39th place. Cosby's fall also provided Fox Broadcasting Co.'s ``The Simpsons'' with its first ratings victory since the animated family's highly publicized move to Thursdays at 8 p.m. An original episode of the bickering cartoon clan tied for 37th place, edging past ``Cosby'' by three-tenths of a rating point. ABC scored high with ``America's Funniest People,'' a spin-off of its successful ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' with fourth and fifth place finishes, respectively. CBS' perennial favorite ``Murder, She Wrote'' landed in the No. 6 slot, followed by its Emmy-winning comedy series ``Murphy Brown'' and the wisecracking interior decorators of ``Designing Women.'' NBC's ``The Golden Girls'' placed ninth. ``Empty Nest,'' also on NBC, finished 10th. In the network news wars, ABC and Peter Jennings held onto their longstanding first place status with a 10.2 average. CBS and Dan Rather were second with 9.6 and Tom Brokaw and NBC finished last with 8.8. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 22.5; ``Stephen King's `It' Part 2,'' ABC, 20.6; ``NFL Monday Night Football,'' ABC, 18.2; ``America's Funniest People,'' ABC, 18.1; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 17.9; ``Murder, She Wrote,'' CBS, 17.8; ``Murphy Brown,'' CBS, 17.7; ``Designing Women,'' CBS, 17.6; ``Golden Girls,'' NBC, 17.5; and ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, 17.4.

DOC.HEAD: Rail Strike Spreads; Workers Agree to Meet With Management
DOC.TEXT: A strike that has paralyzed rail traffic in eastern Germany spread to freight lines and more passenger trains Tuesday, but workers agreed to talk with management and resume international service. The Union of German Rail Workers, seeking higher pay and guarantees against layoffs, has staged the first major work stoppages since the two Germanys unified on Oct. 3. The three-day strike also has severely disrupted rail traffic with neighboring Poland and Czechoslovakia. The union said it would seek exploratory talks Wednesday with the Reichsbahn, the name of the rail system of former East Germany. Negotiations could begin immediately to end the strike if the union believed management was prepared to meet workers' terms, said Rudi Schaefer, head of the union. Earlier, workers had said no talks would be held until management offered an acceptable compromise. Claudia Ruttmann, spokeswoman for the Reichsbahn in Berlin, said officials were prepared to discuss workers' demands for higher pay and guarantees against layoffs. The walkouts began in Berlin on Sunday evening and spread throughout all of eastern Germany, forcing international passenger trains to halt in Czechoslovakia and delaying thousands of passengers. In Germany, the strike first affected inter-city trains. It spread Tuesday to freight and passenger trains in the Berlin area. About 260,000 Reichsbahn employees voted to strike after negotiations broke down last week. Strike leaders fear up to 68,000 workers in the former East Germany will be laid off as the railroad and the economy undergo capitalist restructuring. Similar cutbacks are predicted in other industries in the former Communist nation. The rail strikers are demanding protection against massive layoffs and recommend reduction of the work force gradually through attrition. Union officials say the eastern workers are aid $675 to $945 a month, about $675 less than their counterparts in former West Germany. The union wants salaries to reach 60 percent of western scales in January, but its primary demand is no mass layoffs. The German ADN news agency said more than 150,000 travelers were delayed on Monday and that train traffic to and from Poland also was suffering long delays. The rail line carried an average of 1.6 million passengers a day in 1989. Meanwhile, members of the Public Service and Transport Union working for NATO forces based in western Germany held a second day of warning strikes to force an agreement for new work contracts and layoff provisions. With a reduction of military forces in Europe, up to 23 percent of the approximately 100,000 civilian employees working for U.S., British and other NATO forces are expected to be laid off in the near future, union officials say. Among the strikers' demands are guarantees of retraining and job placement in case of layoffs and adequate severence pay for those who cannot find new jobs. The union said up to 12,000 civilian workers at military installations throughout Germany took part in warning strikes of up to two hours on Tuesday. The union says the the strikes are not intended to interfere with military operations involving deployment of troops to the Middle East. A spokeswoman for the U.S. Air Force European Headquarters at Ramstein Air Base, said the Air Force on Tuesday ``did experience some vehicle traffic delays at Zweibruecken and Bitburg Air Bases.''

DOC.HEAD: ACLU: FBI Spies on Human-Rights Group
DOC.TEXT: The American Civil Liberties Union charged in a lawsuit Tuesday that the FBI illegally kept files on the leader of a group that supports human rights activities around the world. The lawsuit contends the FBI maintained files on J. Roderick MacArthur Foundation and its president, Lance Lindblom, since 1985 and has released only heavily blacked-out copies of 22 pages of material in those files under a Freedom of Information Act request. ``I am outraged that my own country engages in such insidious police state tactics of keeping files on law-abiding organizations and people,'' Lindblom told reporters. The lawsuit was filed in U.S. District Court in Washington, D.C. The ACLU contends the FBI files violate the Constitution's First Amendment freedom of speech rights and the Privacy Act, which restricts the government from keeping such files on ordinary citizens. The ACLU said the FBI material has a chilling effect on Lindblom and the foundation. ``It's chilling because it's this kind of surveillance that created the blacklists in the 1950s, and it's chilling because it forces people to conform,'' said Harvey Grossman, legal director of the Illinois ACLU chapter. Lindblom said the FBI's involvement has affected the foundation's business. ``I think it affects people dealing with us,'' he said. ``And how do you tell your 5- and 6-year-old sons - which I had to do last night - why the FBI is investigating you. That was chilling enough.'' In Washigton, FBI spokesman Carlos Fernandez said the bureau does not comment on pending litigation. The FBI cited ``an exemption under the Privacy Act in order to protect the national defense'' for not providing Lindblom more information, Grossman said. The lawsuit seeks unedited copies of all material in the file, destruction of the file, an admission that the FBI acted unlawfully and monetary damages to be decided by a jury, Grossman said. Grossman said the material the FBI supplied was so heavily edited it was impossible to determine anything about the probe, except for a newspaper column about Lindblom traveling with a South Korean political dissident. Lindblom said he often travels overseas and his foundation helps defend political dissidents on trial in sensitive areas of the world, but ``my action is above board.'' The foundation is based in suburban Niles. It has no connection with the John D. and Catherine MacArthur Foundation, although it was founded by their son, Roderick, and the two groups support some of the same projects, Lindblom said. It has made grants totaling $26 million since its founding in 1976 to other charitable organizations to champion social justice, Lindblom said. He said the foundation has supported such social action documentary films as the 1989 movie, ``Roger and Me,'' about the impact of the closing of General Motors plants on the lives of Michigan residents.

DOC.HEAD: Blackout Darkens Montreal Subway
DOC.TEXT: An explosion and fire in a transformer in Montreal knocked out power in a large part of the downtown area Tuesday, shutting down the whole subway system. Police Constable Jacques Patenaude said the fire broke out about 10:30 a.m. in an underground transformer in the heart of the business district. About 500 office buildings and stores were affected by the outage, he said. By late afternoon, scattered blackouts were still reported in downtown Montreal. Nicole Breton, a spokesman for the Montreal transit commission, said the subway system citywide was stopped and passengers evacuated as a safety measure after communications between the control center and subway operators broke down following the outage. No incidents were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Foley Shares Insights With Freshman Congressmen
DOC.TEXT: House Speaker Thomas S. Foley on Tuesday welcomed freshman Democrats to Congress and advised them to take junkets and miss votes. But not a lot of votes. ``Figure out within the first month, some matter of generally non-consequence on the floor, and sit through a vote. Miss a vote. Miss a couple,'' Foley, a Washington Democrat, advised two dozen incoming lawmakers. ``For heaven sake, do not make the mistake of getting a 100 percent voting record. It is a great sentence of life in prison ... living in uneasy terror'' that the House could hold a sudden vote and ruin that record. He recalled a member who kept a perfect record for years only to have it ruined by a quick, unexpected vote. That member, the speaker said, ``wept on the floor.'' Foley, himself just returned from the Persian Gulf, told the group that ``whenever you get a chance, travel. ``I think it's well worth the government's expense'' for members to see ``the matters on which we legislate,'' he said. Foley addressed the Democratic members at a luncheon on one side of Capitol Hill, while Republicans were meeting with their own at a nearby hotel. The official, bipartisan orientation for new members was scheduled to begin Wednesday. The 102nd Congress will include 18 freshman Republicans and 25 incoming Democrats plus independent socialist Bernie Sanders of Vermont. Overall, barring any election reversals before Jan. 3, the lineup at the swearing-in will be 167 Republicans and 267 Democrats, plus Sanders. Sanders attended the Democratic Party sessions on Tuesday and was applying to organize with the Democrats to obtain his committee assignments. Most of the orientation meetings Tuesday were held in private, except for Foley's address. The topics for the sessions run from the Persian Gulf and the federal budget to the mundane, items like office computers, personnel practices and financial disclosure requirements. Overlaying all of the specifics was a sort of intellectual indoctrination into the culture of the Capitol. Foley, first elected to Congress in 1964, spent much of his time telling tales of how bad it used to be for freshman members. Once, a junior congressman was even declared ``dead'' by a committee chairman and barred from all participation, until colleagues pleaded for a reprieve. In another case, a chairman was confronted by a committee member with an amendment and became annoyed. The chairman asked his top aide who the lawmaker was and how long he'd been on the committee. ``Fourteen years Mr. Chairman,'' was the proverbial reply. Nowadays, Foley said, the chairmen and women know new members' names ``within a matter of days, perhaps a week or so. And nobody's going to declare you dead.''

DOC.HEAD: Official News Agency Reports Death of Chinese Historian
DOC.TEXT: One of China's leading philosophers and historians, Feng Youlan, has died, the official Xinhua News Agency reported Tuesday. He was 95. Xinhua said Feng died Monday of an unspecified illness. Feng, a former Beijing University professor, wrote ``History of Chinese Philosophy,'' a multivolume set of books on the country's political past. In an interview in 1986 with The Associated Press, Feng said China's future does not depend on who succeeds senior leader Deng Xiaoping but on how Communist Party factions settle their differences. He also said the Communist Party would remain the sole political force in China for at least 20 years because economic conditions will not support a multiparty state. ``But there will be factions in the party. Now the party says there are no factions. But everybody knows that's not the truth,'' Feng said. When asked to comment on who would succeed Deng as China's top leader, Feng said personalities are not as important as political methods. ``I don't think there must be one top leader without whom the country will be thrown into confusion,'' he said. ``At present, China is not mature enough for a collective leadership, but it will be in the future.'' Feng attended Columbia University in New York City from 1919-23. He went back in 1982 to receive an honorary doctorate.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Predict 6 Percent Growth in Exports of Goods
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release 7:01 p.m. EST, time set by source. A version of this story moved on financial wires
DOC.TEXT: Growth in world trade is unlikely to be seriously affected by the conflict in the Persian Gulf, according to a report from the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Industrialized countries are now better able to cope with high energy prices than during the last oil shock, according to the report from the secretariat of the 100-nation trade forum. ``Economic activity is less dependent on energy than in the 1970s, the inflation rate is less than half what it was in 1979, and policy-makers have learned the lesson that monetary accommodation of a real price shock has persistent inflationary effects,'' it said. The report, released Wednesday, pointed out that current crude oil prices of $30 to $35 a barrel were lower than the peak of 1981, when crude reached the equivalent of $50 a barrel. ``While the general situation remains highly uncertain, GATT's economists believe that the growth in the volume of world trade in 1990 is unlikely to be seriously affected by the gulf crisis,'' it said. The report estimated the volume of world merchandise exports will expand 6 percent this year, down from a 7 percent increase in 1989. But the report warned that Third World countries, highly indebted nations and Eastern European economies would be hit hardest by the oil price rises. The report also said a successful conclusion next month of the Uruguay Round of trade talks would likely ``create a stronger basis for the world economy in the 1990s.'' It said ``competition is the best path to rising living standards.'' The report made no predictions on what would happen if the complex negotiations collapse. They are now held up over disagreements on the size of cuts in farm subsidies. The report said the value of world merchandise trade in 1989 rose 7.5 percent to a record $3.1 trillion. Exports of manufactured goods outperformed those of farm products, which rose by 4 percent in volume and 5 percent in value. World trade in commercial services like transportation and telecommunications rose an estimated 9 percent to $680 billion. Services now account for nearly one-fifth the total value of world exports. The report said the volume of world trade in the 1980s rose by 50 percent while its dollar value increased by three-quarters.

DOC.HEAD: Massive Model Block City Finally Finds a Home
DOC.TEXT: Marc Kolodner's Lego City, a miniature metropolis constructed with plastic blocks during his hyperactive teen-age years, has been given a permanent home in a museum. The 4-by-8-foot city, complete with a furnished hotel and a functioning drawbridge, took six years to build. It took three years to find it a permanent home. The Baltimore Public Works Museum agreed this summer to display Kolodner's masterpiece after he called the mayor's office for help. The museum opened the exhibit Sunday. Kolodner, 22, used the thousands of Lego pieces his parents gave him to channel his excessive energies in middle school and high school. Lego pieces he received for birthdays, holidays and good grades were added to the city and became an aiport, police station, hospital, homes and even a two-deck cruise ship. ``He was a hyper little kid; he just couldn't sit still,'' said Kolodner's mother, Phyllis. ``I had to find somewhere to channel that energy, so first I put him on the tennis court, and then I gave him Legos.'' Kolodner said about three quarters of the city was constructed according to instructions included with Legos kits. The rest he improvised. He can't estimate the number of blocks used. ``It's a lot of money, that's for sure,'' he said. Like building the city, finding it a home proved to be a tedious task. A first-year graduate student in physics at Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta, Kolodner said his city was too big for his family's apartment. Schools, libraries and hospitals said they couldn't handle its size, either. Lego City was on display more than two years ago at a Baltimore toy store while Kolodner was an undergraduate at Tulane University in New Orleans. But the store returned it after about six months because it took up too much space. The city was stored in giant pieces in his family's apartment until this summer, when Kolodner reconstructed it in the museum.

DOC.HEAD: Sunday Liftoff Planned for Columbia and Oft-Delayed Astro-1 Mission
DOC.TEXT: Shuttle Columbia got a clean bill of health Tuesday and NASA set the launching of its long-postponed astronomy mission for Sunday. Columbia is to carry four major astronomical instruments, including a telescope designed to investigate the content of stars and the history of their formation, in a mission that was originally planned for 1986. ``The shuttle team has worked very hard to get Columbia ready to fly,'' said shuttle Director Robert Crippen. ``With the hydrogen leak resolved, we're ready to end the year with the Astro-1 mission which will extend our knowledge of the universe.'' Columbia and its $150 million payload were scheduled to lift off between 1:28 a.m. and 3:58 a.m. EST Sunday for a 10-day mission. Scientists who have waited years for the flight would prefer to wait a little longer to take advantage of better celestial viewing in mid-December. Certain astronomical targets, such as the brightest visible quasar, will be farther from the sun than they will be during the full moon Sunday. Astronomers prefer dark skies. The Ultraviolet Imaging Telescope, which studies the content and history of stars, takes photographs of its celestial images, explained NASA Mission Scientist Ed Weiler. He said shooting photos into the scattered light of the moon is not preferable, just as no photographer would shoot into the sun by choice. Three other major instruments will also be aboard Columbia. They are the Hopkins Ultraviolet Telescope, which will study quasars, active galactic nuclei and supernova remnants; the Wisconsin Ultraviolet Photo-polarimeter Experiment, which will measure the polarization of ultraviolet light from hot stars, galactic nuclei and quasars; and the Broad Band X-ray Telescope, which will determine the amount of energy in electron volts of X-rays emananting from clusters of galaxies, supernova remnants and stars. The astronomy mission was originally planned for March 6, 1986, but the Challenger explosion Jan. 28 that year grounded all space shuttles. After flights resumed, Astro-1 was rescheduled for launch March 1, 1990. The mission slipped to May 9, then to May 30. Six hours before launch, a liquid hydrogen leak was discovered in Columbia and the launch was scrubbed. Three more launch attempts failed, two of them because of hydrogen leaks and one for a minor problem with the payload, before an Oct. 30 leak check cleared Columbia. By then, workers were busy readying Atlantis for its secret Pentagon mission Nov. 15. NASA held off scheduling a launch for Columbia until Atlantis returned and was thoroughly inspected. Tuesday, after a 5{-hour readiness review, officials gave the go-ahead for the Sunday liftoff. The mission's countdown was set to begin one minute after midnight Wednesday; the astronauts were due to arrive from Houston on Thursday. Columbia will be commanded by astronaut Vance Brand, 59, making his fourth trip into space. The others in the seven-member crew are USAF Col. Guy Gardner, the pilot; mission specialists John Mike Lounge, Jeffrey Hoffman and Robert Parker; and payload specialists Ronald Parise and Samuel Durrance.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk, Mandela Express Hope following Latest Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Clashes in black townships claimed at least 11 lives Tuesday as President F.W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela said peace efforts were threatened but not thwarted. A joint statement by de Klerk and the African National Congress leader indicated they could resolve differences and begin talks to end white-minority rule. ``Having reaffirmed their commitment to and faith in the peaceful negotiating process, they expressed their concern about developments threatening this process,'' said the statement following the two-hour meeting in the South African capital. Mandela said he and de Klerk probably would meet again in the coming months. The statement stressed the importance of close contacts between the two leaders. Mandela refused to give details of the meeting or even say what issues were discussed. Mandela said ``the mood was very cordial'' and the talks were ``productive.'' De Klerk did not speak to journalists. The topics apparently included the growing political violence, charges from both sides of insincerity, and concern that efforts to begin talks on ending apartheid are bogging down. Mandela had been expected to present the ANC's demand for an interim government and multiracial elections for an assembly to draft a new constitution. The government was expected to raise concerns about ANC efforts to mobilize supporters and the growing unrest in the country. Mandela and de Klerk have held several private meetings in recent months to remove obstacles to full-scale negotiations on ending white rule. The negotiations are expected to begin next year, but both sides have expressed concern about growing political disputes that could cause delays. Meanwhile, police said 11 men were shot and stabbed to death in black factional fighting overnight in the township of Katlehong, outside Johannesburg. A police official said the fighting apparently involved rival Zulus and Xhosas. Five other people were killed in scattered violence in other parts of the country, police said. Black violence, mostly between ANC supporters and Zulu followers of the Inkatha movement, has claimed about 800 lives in the Johannesburg area in recent weeks. The two groups are divided by leadership disputes and conflicting views of a future South Africa. The ANC has charged the security forces are involved in a campaign of terror against the opposition and have instigated black factional violence. The government has rejected the charges. The ANC also contends an interim government is needed to ensure all race groups are represented. But de Klerk has rejected the demand, saying his government will remain in power until a new constitution is drafted to share power with blacks. The government on Tuesday reportedly was to press for the ANC and its military wing to suspend mass mobilization campaigns. The government says the ANC campaigns violate an August agreement to suspend the group's armed struggle. Mandela and other ANC leaders say the mobilization efforts are part of peaceful political activities. The ANC has rejected government demands it stop recruiting for its military wing.

DOC.HEAD: Bureau Chief Named for Atlanta
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to ADD date of Bell's retirement.
DOC.TEXT: Henry Ackerman, chief of bureau for The Associated Press in Detroit since 1987, has been named chief of bureau for Georgia and Alabama. The appointment was announced Tuesday by AP President Louis D. Boccardi. In Atlanta, Ackerman succeeds Carl Bell, who is retiring Jan. 1. Ackerman, 48, began his AP career as a vacation-relief broadcast newsman in New York City in 1968 and started full-time service on the news cooperative's World Services Desk in 1972. A year later he was named news editor in Buenos Aires, Argentina. He was appointed chief of bureau in Lima, Peru, in 1975. In 1978 he was named bureau chief in Caracas, Venezuela. He returned to the United States in 1980 as Cleveland correspondent. Two years later he was selected as bureau chief for Louisiana and Mississippi, based in New Orleans. In 1987 Ackerman was appointed chief of bureau for Michigan. A New York City native, he graduated from Davidson College with a bachelor's degree in history in 1964 and then served in the Army, stationed in the Panama Canal Zone and South America, from 1965 to 1967. After his Army service, he earned a master's degree in history from the University of North Carolina and went to Argentina on a Fulbright fellowship.

DOC.HEAD: `Livable' City Copes With Floods, Bridge Sinking
With AM-Storms Rdp
LaserPhoto SE4
DOC.TEXT: Bad news for brochure writers. The city touted by many as among the world's most livable has been living up to an older nickname: Rain City. Seattle already has had its third-wettest month ever, and more rain is expected later this week. The drenching has caused tens of millions of dollars in damage from flooding in western Washington, killed one man and knotted traffic after a 1{-mile-long floating bridge filled with water and sank. Gov. Booth Gardner declared emergencies in all but three western Washington counties. Assessment crews began traipsing through sodden river drainages Tuesday to tote up damage from more flooding over the weekend that ravaged homes and farms along 20 rivers. State officials call the latest round some of the worst flooding in Washington history, with four rivers reaching 100-year flood-stage levels. Seattle in recent years has won numerous accolades for its quality of life. Money magazine this year rated it the second-best place to live in the nation, edged out by Bremerton, across Puget Sound. In 1989, Money rated Seattle first, as did Places Rated Almanac, while Savvy magazine ranked it among the best places to raise children. The region has enjoyed nearly a decade of prosperity, thanks mostly to record commercial aircraft sales by The Boeing Co., which employs about 100,000 people here. Besides steady paychecks, Seattle has become known for good food, good theater, great scenery, an easygoing attitude and darn good coffee - more than 150 vendors sell espresso on city streets. Mayor Norm Rice took a moment Tuesday to acknowledge the city's good fortune in the current catastrophe. ``Seattle itself was hit with extremely heavy rains, but we have so far suffered only minor damage in the form of relatively few flooded streets, wet basements and small mudslides,'' Rice said. ``Compared to many other areas of the state, Seattle has been very, very lucky, so far.'' But Rice noted that hillsides throughout the city are saturated, and more rain or a freeze and thaw in the next few weeks could trigger serious mudslides. Ironically, the city also faces a drrinking water shortage, he said in calling for conservation. ``All that rain and high water have brought tons of silt into the Cedar River, which is the major source of fresh drinking water for much of our region,'' Rice said. ``Right now, the Cedar River looks like chocolate milk.'' The old Lake Washington floating bridge sank Sunday, damaging anchoring cables on the adjacent, year-old Interstate 90 floating bridge, the major east-west route into the city. The state Department of Transportation shut the new bridge for repairs, forcing tens of thousands of commuters to find other ways of getting to work Monday. The new bridge was re-opened Tuesday for inbound traffic, as seven huge tugboats labored to keep the 8,600-foot span in position. Transportation spokesman Bill Southern said crews hustled to install temporary cables and anchors but were worried about 40 mph winds forecast for Wednesday. Tuesday morning traffic actually was smooth, said Vickie Crawford, a State Patrol communications supervisor. Backups were heavy on the Evergreen Point floating bridge, the only other route across the 20-mile-long lake, but not one stalled car or fender-bender was reported on I-90, she said. City businesses reported a lot of late arrivals, but many companies tried to help their employees by offering flexible start times and encouraging carpools and taking the bus. Lisa Bowersock, a US West spokeswoman who commutes by bus from across the lake in Redmond, said the bridge closure may have forced more people out of their cars. ``The biggest traffic jam I've seen was at my park and ride (parking lot) this morning,'' she said. Martin Thompson, National Weather Service forecaster in Seattle, said Seattle-Tacoma International Airport has recorded 10.15 inches of rain this month. The record for the wettest month ever was 12.92 inches, set in January 1953. More rain is on the way, and there's a good chance Sea-Tac will get another inch before Friday, he said. The heavy rains are from the ``Pineapple Express,'' subtropical air laden with moisture from the Hawaiian Islands, Thompson said. That unusual weather system has passed, but more rain is expected from the Gulf of Alaska. Steve Morris, spokesman for the Seattle-King County Convention and Visitors Bureau, said all the soggy news hadn't dampened the tourist trade. ``People understand it's a temporary condition,'' Morris said, adding that from a tourism standpoint, the rains occurred at the slowest time of the year. ``I don't know if we'll ever dispel the notion that it rains sometimes in Seattle,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Killed in Sicilian Shootings
DOC.TEXT: Assailants opened fire inside a game hall and by a nearby butcher shop Tuesday night, killing eight people and wounding seven, police said. State television said the attacks were apparently carried out by a Mafia gang seeking to rub out members of a rival clan. Police said the two attacks occurred about 7 p.m. in the center of this city of 80,000 residents on Sicily's southern coast. Six were killed when the assailants sprayed gunfire inside a game hall crowded with people playing cards and billiards. Two others were gunned down in front of a butcher shop down the street. RAI-TV said investigators suspect the assailants targeted members of the ``Madonia'' crime family. Nearly 100 people have been killed in violence between rival Mafia clans in Gela the past three years, according to news reports. The gangs are fighting for control of extortion rackets, drug trafficking and other illegal activities.

DOC.HEAD: John Major to Become British Prime Minister Succeeding Thatcher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 19 grafs to CORRECT time element 4th graf `Major, the' to Tuesday night sted Thursday, ADDS background on rapid development of leadership challenge. Picks up graf 15 pvs, `Hurd said...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LON1,3,4,14
DOC.TEXT: John Major, endorsed by Margaret Thatcher as the politician closest to her heart, was elected by the Conservative Party Tuesday night to succeed her as prime minister. Major, 47, fell two votes short of winning a majority in voting among the 372 Coservative Party members of Parliament, but his two opponents quickly conceded defeat and the party confirmed Major as the winner. Mrs. Thatcher, ending 11{ years in power, intended to submit her resignation to Queen Elizabeth II on Wednesday morning, and Major would then be called to lead the government. Major, the chancellor of the exchequer, emerged from his official residence at 11 Downing St. Tuesday night smiling and holding hands with his wife, Norma. Inside, Mrs. Thatcher, who came next door from the prime minister's 10 Downing Street residence, embraced Major. ``I am thrilled and delighted that John Major is to succeed me,'' the ``Iron Lady'' said in a statement released by aides. ``It is a very exciting thing to become leader of the Conservative Party, and particularly exciting, I think, to follow one of the most remarkable leaders the Conservative Party has ever had,'' Major said. ``Our job now I think is quite clear. We are going to unite totally and absolutely, and we're going to win the next general election,'' said Major, who will be the youngest British prime minister in this century. Major received 185 votes, two short of a majority. Former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine received 131 and Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd had 56. Hurd and Heseltine conceded within minutes, and party officials declared Major elected. The party had been torn by the sudden and unexpected leadership challenge by Heseltine, who last week stopped Mrs. Thatcher short of victory in the first round of the leadership race. Mrs. Thatcher had not wanted to leave office, but she decided to resign last week after she was unable to put down Heseltine's challenge. She said she resigned to let someone from the Cabinet stand against Heseltine. Major and Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd both joined the race, but before the vote her aides spread the word that she was backing Major. The son of a circus performer and at one time a welfare recipient, Major personifies the values of self-reliance and hard work that Mrs. Thatcher had preached to the nation. His election climaxed a month of British politics-turned-upside down, and the Western world's longest-serving head of government was driven from office by a revolt in party ranks. Heading a government that was trailing the opposition Labor Party in the polls and suffering a losing streak in local Parliamentary elections, Mrs. Thatcher lost control of events after her deputy, Sir Geoffrey Howe, resigned on Nov. 1. Howe, the fourth Cabinet member to resign because of disputes over policy toward the European Community, shocked the House of Commons on Nov. 13 by calling Mrs. Thatcher a threat to Britain's vital interests. The next day, Heseltine announced he would challenge her. Six days later, with Mrs. Thatcher at a 34-nation summit in Paris officially ending the Cold War, Heseltine polled enough votes to deny her re-election as leader. Two days later, she decided to resign after party leaders told her she could not win. Heseltine, 57, said Major's election ``lays the basis for the unity of our party.'' Hurd said the party needed to unite, and ``John Major is the right leader for this task.'' Opposition leaders derided Major's election as ``Thatcherism with a different face.'' The Conservatives' main rivals, the socialist Labor Party, demanded a general election. ``John Major is a Thatcherette - that is how he sought election and that is how he got elected,'' said Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock. ``It means that the policies that brought the poll tax, recession, heavy mortgages and rising unemployment will go on.'' During his five-day campaign, Major had aaid he would review the ``poll tax,'' an unpopular local tax brought in by Mrs. Thatcher, but he gave no other hints of differing with her. While adopting a gentler tone on the contentious issue of Britain's involvement in Europe, he shares her opposition to a single European currency and shares her belief in tight restraint on government spending. However, he insisted over the weekend, ``I am not running as `Son of Thatcher.' I am running as myself, with my own priorities and my own programs.'' Major's victory ended a patient, four-year campaign by Heseltine to promote himself as a future leader of the party. ``Tomorrow always dawns,'' he said, smiling after conceding defeat. Major was elected to Parliament in 1979, was appointed foreign secretary and then chancellor of the exchequer last year. He moved up quickly in the leadership race. By the weekend, opinion polls showed that Major was nearly as highly regarded by the public as was Heseltine, who has been prominent for a decade. Major attracted support from figures on the right wing of the Conservative Party, although his friends insisted Major's own views were more liberal than many supposed. He described himself as conservative on economic issues but liberal on social issues.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Worries Trade Talks Will Fail
DOC.TEXT: Top administration officials expressed concern Tuesday over the prospect that a four-year effort to reform the global trading system could end in failure because of a deadlock over the issue of farm subsidies. The so-called Uruguay Round of talks are scheduled to wind down next week in Brussels with a marathon bargaining session in which trade ministers from 107 nations will attempt to resolve remaining disputes. ``We must not let the Uruguay Round fail,'' President Bush said in a speech in Monterrey, Mexico. However, back in Washington, other administration officials were expressing the belief that unless the European Community retreats from its current position on farm subsidies, the talks could collapse. ``I came back very pessimistic about the outlook, and I'm still pessimistic,'' said Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter. ``It seems to me the position of the European Community is so far from that of, essentially, the rest of the world that I see no way to bridge that gap in the few days that remain.'' Yeutter and U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills recently visited European leaders to urge compromises on agricultural issues confronting Uruguay Round negotiators. The United States is pushing for a 75 percent reduction in trade-distorting internal farm supports and a 90 percent cut in farm export subsidies over 10 years. However, the European Community, seeking to protect millions of small family farms, has only offered to cut internal supports by 30 percent from a 1986 base, a position the United States has termed closer to an actual 15 percent cut from current levels - and completely unacceptable. Japan, which wants to continue protecting its domestic farmers by banning rice imports, is ``the only country that is at all supportive'' of the EC position, Yeutter said. The EC members are Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Britain, Spain and Portugal. They have more than 4{ times as many farmers as the United States in a population about a third larger, and the farmers are a powerful political force. Another administration official, briefing reporters on condition that he not be named, rejected the idea that the deadline for completing the trade negotiations would likely be extended if the farm issue is not settled next week. He said if the European Community does not indicate a willingness to compromise on the farm subsidies, then it is unlikely that a complete trade package can be achieved. He said developing countries would be unwilling to agree to removal of their barriers against foreign investment and trade in services without a promise of expanded markets for their agricultural products. ``It is only through a large package that you can achieve the critical mass needed for an agreement,'' said the senior trade official.
