If the talks fail and everyone goes home without liberalizing global trading rules, it will mean a full-blown reappraisal of U.S. policies, Yeutter told the Agriculture Department's annual outlook conference. ``We'll have to determine how best to protect our own interests,'' Yeutter said. ``In essence, we'll have to determine how to get the most bang for the buck in a more confrontational environment in international trade in agriculture, and perhaps in international trade in all the other spheres of economic activity as well.'' Yeutter said he hoped such a gloomy development does not emerge and that ``we're certainly going to go to Brussels next week with an open mind'' for the final showdown. But he added: ``We're not going to negotiate with ourselves in Brussels next week. We're not going to come back with an agreement that we do not believe is in the best interests of this country. And I'm certainly not going to come back with an agreement that I do not believe is in the best interest of American agriculture.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Jests About Economic Confusion in Soviet Union
With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev emerged from an all-day parliamentary session in a jovial mood Tuesday, and told reporters a joke about the faltering Soviet economy. ``I can't really tell it with ladies present,'' Gorbachev teased journalists in a Kremlin loby after a meeting of the Congress of Peoples' Deputies of the Russian Federation. ``Oh, go ahead,'' said women reporters and lawmakers. Gorbachev grinned and proceeded with a joke about himself, French President Francois Mitterrand and President Bush. ``They say that Mitterrand has 100 lovers. One has AIDS, but he doesn't know which one,'' said Gorbachev. ``Bush has 100 bodyguards. One is a terrorist, but he doesn't know which one. ``Gorbachev has 100 economic advisers. One is smart, but he doesn't know which one,'' the Soviet president said. The joke was warmly received by the Russian Federation lawmakers, some of whom have criticized Gorbachev for his faltering steps toward shifting the Soviet Union from a centrally planned to a market economy.

DOC.HEAD: Weather Blows Hot and Cold; Snow in Colorado, Tornadoes in Missouri
DOC.TEXT: Storms battered portions of the Great Plains and the Rockies on Tuesday while other parts of the nation basked in record warmth. Tornadoes ripped up buildings and downed power lines in Missouri. It looked like winter in Colorado, where more than a foot of snow fell in some places and Denver commuter traffic was slowed to a slushy crawl. It felt like summer in Charleston, W.V., where Christmas shoppers could roll up their sleeves in 84-degree warmth. ``I love it,'' said Becky Vandergriff of Dunbar, W.V., as she looked at Christmas decorations in downtown Charleston. ``The decorations look just as pretty when it's warm.'' Missy Frerichs, a transplanted midwesterner, said the balmy weather ``takes some of the fun out of shopping. ... I just want some snow.'' Colorado was the place for Ms. Frerichs, although parts of North Dakota and Wyoming might have sufficed. A strong weather front brought freezing rain, snow and icy blasts of wind across an area extending from the Great Lakes to the Rockies. The Beaver Creek ski resort in Colorado reported receiving 14 inches of snow overnight. The Colorado State Patrol said roads across the state were snowpacked and icy. The storm followed a weekend of record-breaking temperatures that rose into the 70s in some spots. A tornado tore through a shopping center and at least two apartment buildings in Columbia, Mo., 30 miles north of the capital, Jefferson City. ``We understand that the roof of the shopping center is pretty heavily damaged, plus the roofs and windows of several apartment complexes,'' said Michael Sanford, Columbia's director of emergency management. About 70 miles southwest of Columbia, a similar storm downed trees and power lines and ripped up a boat storage area near the Ozark town of Warsaw. A storm that may have been a tornado struck O'Fallon, Mo., about 30 miles west of St. Louis, downing power lines and trees and damaging some homes and a boat. There were no immediate reports of injuries in any of the Missouri storms. The National Weather Service warned of the possibility of tornadoes from Texas to Indiana, Illinois and Michigan. In Illinois, thunderstorms and possible tornadoes wrecked homes and businesses, toppled trees and knocked out electrical service to thousands of people. The damage Monday night and Tuesday was scattered throughout the state. No injuries were reported. The roof on an apartment complex in Aurora was lifted and a car was overturned in the parking lot of a shopping center in the Chicago suburb of Naperville. In much of Michigan and Indiana, however, the weather talk was about warmth - the record of 66 degrees in Detroit, or the records of 65 degrees in Fort Wayne, Ind., or 65 degrees in Grand Rapids, Mich.

DOC.HEAD: Beijing To Send Top Diplomat To Washington; US Says Policy Unchanged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, bgng ``China's vote, to restore Boucher's first name; picks up 6th graf, ``To date
DOC.TEXT: China's foreign minister will make an official visit to Washington on Friday, the first such encounter here since before China's crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in June 1989. But the State Department said the visit does not signal any change in the U.S. policy of barring high level exchanges with China. The policy does not preclude contacts but does rule out exchanges of a ``formal and ceremonial nature,'' a spokesman said. Foreign Minister Qian Qichen will be in New York on Wednesday and Thursday for the U.N. Security Council deliberations on the Persian Gulf. He will travel to Washington on Friday. On Monay, China announced that a vice minister of trade will visit Washington next month. As a member of the Security Council, China has been the target of a U.S. campaign for support for a resolution authorizing the use of force against Kuwait. It reportedly has agreed to support the proposal, along with the four other permanent Council members. ``China's vote on the U.N. Security Council resolution will be based on its own national interest determination,'' said State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher. ``To date, China has consistently held to the Security Council consensus on the gulf crisis and has voted for every one of the 10 Security Council resolutions on Iraq's continuing aggression.'' Boucher said that since the June 1989 rights crackdown, there have been four meetings between Qian and Secretary of State James A. Baker III. There were two in New York, one in Paris and one three weeks ago in Cairo. ``While Minister Qian is in Washington we intend to explore ways to strengthen cooperation on global and regional issues and seek understandings on ways to achieve improvement in bilateral relations, including further progress in the area of human rights that would permit a gradual return to normal high-level exchanges,'' Boucher said. He said the U.S. approach is consistent with the policies of the European Community, Japan, and other friends and allies. The types of bilateral gatherings which no longer take place, Boucher said, include cabinet level exchanges under the Joint Commission on Commerce and Trade, and the Joint Economic Commission. High-level military exchanges continue to be banned as well. In addition, U.S. companies which invest in China are ineligible for a U.S. government insurance program that protects such investments. Boucher cited China's recent decision to place sedition charges against two dissident journalists as a motivation for ``speaking directly to Chinese officials about our human rights concerns.'' One of the dissidents was the publisher of the now-banned Economic Studies Weekly and the other was the editor. They were charged with plotting to overthrow the government, a crime punishable by death.

DOC.HEAD: Government, Opposition Meet in Effort to End Bulgaria's Stalemate
DOC.TEXT: Bulgaria's government of former Communists began talks with opposition leaders Tuesday on resolving the standoff over how to run this Balkan country of 9 million people, state television said. They met during the nation's worst political and economic crisis and on the second day of a general strike meant to bring down Premier Andrei Lukanov's Socialist government, made up of members of the renamed Communist Party. Petar Beron, chairman of the main opposition alliance, the Union of Democratic Forces, said Tuesday the UDF would urge an end to the strike because of the agreement to talk with the government, the state news agency BTA reported. Beron's group had given the strike lukewarm support earlier. Podkrepa, the opposition labor federation, called the walkout and said in a broadcast statement Tuesday that 790,000 Bulgarians were on strike, including 220,000 in Sofia. Podkrepa spokesman Kiril Vladimirov said large trucks blocked several intersections in downtown Sofia early Tuesday in solidarity with the strikers. Police used tear gas to disperse the truckers and students who also blocked streets with sit-in strikes, he said. But government representative Danail Danailov said the number of strikers had not grown from Monday and actually declined in places. The main union organization did not support the strike, although some of its members took part. In Bulgaria, electricity and many goods are rationed or unavailable, and many people have become impatient with the political infighting. After the walkout began Monday, BTA reported about 500,000 workers - or roughly 11 percent of the work force - were on strike. The government said only one worker out of 100 struck. Leaders of the Socialist Party and the UDF had met late Monday at the suggestion of President Zhelyu Zhelev to try to ease the deadlock. ``These were the most constructive consultations in the last few months,'' UDF deputy chairman Dimitar Ludzhev told radio later. Chavdar Kyuranov, deputy chairman of the Socialist Party, said both sides agreed to set up a group representing the various political parties to work out what he called ``a draft political accord.'' Opposition leaders said the accord should also involve trade unions and should set a timetable for key economic and constitutional reforms. The major obstacle appeared to be an opposition demand that it hold the prime minister's job. It claims a swing in its favor following June elections in which the Socialists gained 211 of 400 seats in Parliament. An opposition representative, speaking Tuesday on condition of anonymity, said Lukanov now seems ready to step down if this could be done ``in a dignified manner.'' The crisis has been complicated by splits within Socialist and opposition ranks. At a seven-hour meeting Tuesday of its leadership and parliamentary bloc of 144 deputies, the UDF failed to agree on a common stand in Parliament. The alliance walked out of Parliament after Lukanov narrowly survived a no-confidence vote Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Electronic Devices to Keep Pigeons Off Cleaned Italian Fountain
DOC.TEXT: Toss a coin in the Trevi Fountain and, if you believe the myth, you'll come back to Rome some day. But if you're a pigeon, you might not want to return to the Baroque monument. A low-voltage electronic field to repel pigeons has been installed at the fountain, following a two-year, $2.8-million scrubbing project, city art officials said Tuesday. The wires don't harm the birds, but emit enough current to discourage them from setting on the fountain. A similar system has been used successfully for several years on Milan's spire-topped cathedral to keep birds' excrement from collecting. According to Rome's superintendency of art and antiquities, restoration of the fountain will be completed in early 1991. Trevi receives its water via the same aqueduct that supplied Roman baths in the days of the emperors, but that water is heavy in calcium, which forms crusty deposits on the monuments. Restorers are now working out a treatment system to reduce the deposits. The fountain, dominated by a giant figure of the sea god Neptune on a winged chariot, has been a backdrop in many films, including ``La Dolce Vita.''

DOC.HEAD: State Department Meets with Families of Hostages
With AM-Gulf-Hearings, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 40 relatives of Americans held hostage in Iraq met with State Department officials Tuesday in sometimes heated discussions about the Bush administration's policies in the Persian Gulf. Daryl Watley, son of hostage Donald Watley, said talks were tense as some family members argued about Bush's decision to send an additional 200,000 troops to the region to provide an ``offensive military option.'' Relatives often ``disagreed with the hotheadedness of the Bush administration's policies'' and the rapid escalation toward war. In the fifth of seven sessions with families nationwide, State Department officials avoided discussing Bush's policies and discouraged family members from visiting Iraq, said Watley, who is from Tomball. For many of the hostages' families, the main topic was whether to go to Baghdad to help free their loved ones following the release Tuesday of three American hostages whose wives had come to visit them. ``They just said that after you leave Amman, Jordan, they can't ensure your safety,'' said Lynda Parker, who still plans to visit her husband, hostage Bobbie Parker. ``My children need their father home,'' said Mrs. Parker, who lives in Vidor. ``I am going with the assumption I will get him. If that's my only chance to get my husband back, I will risk it.'' Freed Americans whose families had pleaded with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein for their release told reporters at the Amman airport that the Bush administration had ignored their plight. ``I was not released with help from my government,'' said John Stevenson of Panama City, Fla. ``It was my family who did it.'' ``It's a very difficult decision for anyone to make,'' said Bill Schaub, OGE Drilling's coordinator for Kuwait, after the meeting ended. Schaub's company has six employees held in Iraq and Kuwait. ``Women want to do anything they can to help their husbands, but it's risky and the husbands don't always want them to come. They're also worried that they may play into the hands of the Iraqis by going,'' he said. Most of the families of hostages taken since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 refused to talk to reporters as they left the meeting, which began Monday. Donnita Cole of Odessa said she plans to visit Iraq next week and was heartened by the release of the Americans on Tuesday. She is the wife of hostage Johnny Cole. ``Fantastic!'' she said. ``I mean, it's the best news since the invention of peanut butter as far as I'm concerned.''

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Refugees Tell Tales of Murder, Torture
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with past denial by the Iraqis of atrocities, RESTORES AP logo. Picks up graf 13 pvs, `Kuwait has...'
DOC.TEXT: Kuwaiti refugees told the U.N. Security Council on Tuesday that Iraqi invaders have turned the conquered emirate into a living hell of murder, torture, rape and pillage. An infant's head crushed under a soldier's boot, a retarded girl gang-raped by soldiers, babies torn from incubators and from their mothers' arms and mass graves for babies were stark images in the testimony delivered by four men and two women. The nearly two-hour session covered atrocities and the destruction of Kuwait's economy and infrastructure. It was a prelude to Thursday's meeting, when the council is expected to authorize the use of military force to liberate Kuwait if Iraq does not withdraw by Jan. 15. At Tuesday's session, the Kuwaiti refugees, including doctors, a nurse, a grandmother and businessmen, appealed to the council not to let their homeland's identity be obliterated. All but one of those testifying, an Indian national, said they dared not use their full names for fear of reprisal against family and friends still in Kuwait. During the presentation to the 15-member council, some in the audience winced at the grisly presentation. Large photographs of the dead, the tortured and dying were displayed in the chamber. Witnesses wept as they spoke of a resistance fighter whose eyes were plucked out and badly beaten prisoners forced to soak their wounds in salt water. ``It is our fervent hope that everything you have heard and seen will further prompt you for action, decisive action, which will contribute to the maintenance of just peace, to be defended without reservation and irrespective of sacrifices to be made,'' Kuwaiti Ambassador Mohammad A. Abulhasan told the council. Witnesses, presenting both eyewitness and hearsay accounts, told of patients disconnected from life-support machines that then were shipped to Iraq, severly handicapped patients turned out into the streets, infants and toddlers forced to give their blood to Iraqi soldiers. One man, who used the name Dr. Essa Ibrahim, said he saw four Kuwaiti doctors shot because their Iraqi soldier patients died. He said another was killed because he refused to shut off an old woman's life-support system. ``Under my supervision, 120 newborn babies were buried in the second week of the invasion,'' he said. ``I myself buried 40 newborns, who had been taken from their incubators by soldiers.'' While there was no immediate comment from Iraq on Tuesday, Iraqi authorities in the past have denied reports of Kuwaiti atrocities, in particular those of babies taken from incubators. The U.N. witnesses also described the systematic looting of their wealthy nation, the dismantling of factories, schools and telecommunications systems and the theft of priceless art objects. Kuwait has submitted a draft resolution condemning Iraq's attempts to alter the demographics of Kuwait by forcing Kuwaitis to flee, destroying identity papers of Kuwaitis and encouraging mass resettlement by Iraqis. The government calls on the U.N. secretary-general to take custody of a copy of the national population register containing the names of all Kuwaiti citizens as of Aug. 1, the day before the invasion. The resolution is expected to be adopted this week. The meeting was delayed when Cuba, Yemen and Malaysia demanded an immediate vote on a Palestine Liberation Organization-backed resolution calling for deployment of U.N. observers to protect Palestinians and for a meeting to help safeguard Palestinians' rights. The United States was considered likely to veto the resolution, but wanted to put the issue off until after a vote on the measure authorizing the use of force to free Kuwait. A date for a meeting and vote on the Israeli-occupied territories has not been set.

DOC.HEAD: President Telephones New Conservative Party Leader
DOC.TEXT: President Bush telephoned John Major, new head of Britain's Conservative Party, to congratulate him on his election to the party leadership, Bush's spokesman said Tuesday night. ``The president said he looked forward to working with Major and to maintaining the special relationship'' with Britain, said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. Bush placed the call from his plane, Air Force One, en route to Washington from a trip to Mexico. Major met Bush at the White House last year on a trip to Washington when he was Britain's foreign secretary. Major will take over the prime minister's job from Margaret Thatcher on Wednesday.

DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said Tuesday after meeting with boxing great Mohammed Ali that a number of Americans held in Iraq would soon be allowed to leave the country. In an interview with The Associated Press, Ali said the number of hostages Saddam promised to free was not specified but that he would remain in Baghdad until they could fly home. He met Tuesday with some of the Americans detained in Baghdad as ``human shields'' in case of attack by multinational troops. Ali, on a mission to Baghdad on behalf of a number of American peace groups, arrived in the Iraqi capital last Wednesday. He met Tuesday with Saddam for about 50 minutes. During the meeting, the president reiterated his stand on the need for a peaceful settlement to the Persian Gulf crisis, which began with Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Ali said he told the Iraqi leader that a release would be ``good for maintaining peace in the area and good for the image of Iraq in the United States.'' Ali, 48, said Saddam gave him a brief review of the history of the area and that he was impressed with its important culture. ``This is the land of the Garden of Eden and the land where Abraham was born. How could it be bombed?'' he said. Ali said he found the president ``a man of conviction.'' The onetime world boxing champion converted to Islam in 1964, and changed his name from Cassius Clay. In Iraq at the invitation of the government, he has been staying in a government guest house and visited holy shrines in the towns of Kerbala and Najaf. He was mobbed by children wanting their picture taken with him wherever he went in Iraq. Ali, who suffers from Parkinson's Disease, marked by slurred speech and shaking limbs, used hand signals to communicate with Jaber Mohammed, who speaks for him.

DOC.HEAD: Synagogue Bombings Shock But Don't Surprise Jewish Community
LaserPhoto HAY1
DOC.TEXT: Jewish leaders reacted angrily Tuesday to two temple firebombings, the latest in a two-week wave of hate crimes. Police said it was too early to tell whether the attacks on Jewish gathering places in the San Francisco area were related. ``It's sick and it's sick people who do this,'' said Dave Karp, mayor of San Leandro and a member of the Beth Sholom temple, which was firebombed Monday. Rabbi Ira Book of Beth Sholom said there was fear among his congregation. Damage from the bomb was limited to a broken window and some scorched floor tiles. ``Most of the reaction, however, was anger that it could happen in this day and age,'' Book said. The firebombing at the temple in San Leandro, about 20 miles east of San Francisco, occurred about a half hour after a firebomb was tossed into the Temple Beth Abraham, about 10 miles away in Oakland. That bomb burned a carpet and damaged a wall. Last week, firebombs were tossed at the Jewish Community Center and Congregation Beth Israel, both in San Francisco. The week before that, police said, three shots were fired at Beth Israel's windows. The synagogue was firebombed in August. The damage in all the attacks was minor and there were no injuries. Police said the temples did not receive threats or warnings and there were no anti-Semitic graffiti or messages. While temple members said they believed the bombings were part of a string of anti-Jewish acts, law enforcement officials said they had not made a definite link. ``It's a little too early to make any determination,'' said Ed Gleba, spokesman for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, which was examining bomb parts recovered from the latest incidents. Karp said police in Oakland, San Francisco and San Leandro were sharing information but had only slim leads. Scott Ury of the Anti-Defamation League, a group that tracks anti-Semitic activities, said he wasn't surprised by the attacks. He said such incidents have reached record levels in the San Francisco Bay area. In 1988, the ADL counted 25 incidents of harassment, assault and attempted firebombings on Jews or their institutions in the San Francisco area. In 1989, the number was 48 - the highest number since the ADL began its count 11 years ago. ``And 1990 is unfortunately already above the 1989 level,'' Ury said. ``This makes 54 incidents, and we have another month to go.'' The City Council in San Leandro doesn't meet until Dec. 17, but Karp was busy Tuesday contacting council members, urging that a special meeting be held to approve the posting of a reward. The Alameda County Board of Supervisors on Tuesday approved a $5,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of those responsible. The ADL has also offered a $2,000 reward. Rabbi Joseph Schonwald of Temple Beth Abraham said the rewards were important to demonstrate ``that the whole community, not just the Jewish community, cares. It sends a message that this won't be tolerated.''

DOC.HEAD: Monarch's Private Audience Makes the Prime Minister
With AM-Britain-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Conservative Party elected John Major as their leader, but only Queen Elizabeth II can make him prime minister. The queen certainly will confirm the treasury chief on Wednesday morning in a private audience at Buckingham Palace. Also Wedesday, outgoing Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher will leave 10 Downing St. for the last time and meet with the queen alone. About 45 minutes after Mrs. Thatcher drives away, Major will be admitted to the same room on the second floor of the palace for a private audience. The room has walls of duck-egg blue and cream silk curtains. There are two paintings of Venetian views by Antonio Canaletto and two portraits by Thomas Gainsborough of King George III - who lost the American colonies - and his consort Queen Charlotte. During Mrs. Thatcher's 11{ years as prime minister, she met the queen most Tuesdays to inform her about government business. ``The new prime minister takes on the post from the moment of the audience,'' said Geoffrey de Deney, clerk of the Privy Council, a body of nearly 400 royal advisers. According to tradition, the new head of government kisses the hands of the monarch - the head of state - and receives the seals of office. ``As the audience is private and confidential we won't know whether there is any kissing of hands or hand and there are no seals of office for a prime minister - there never were,'' de Deney said. It is the title of first lord of the Treasury, not prime minister, that will give Major the right to live at 10 Downing St. Deney said it is a ``firm convention'' that conversation with the monarch at a private audience is never repeated. ``The convention has not always been observed in the memoirs of some former Cabinet ministers,'' he added. As chancellor of the exchequer, Major's official title as Treasury chief in Margaret Thatcher's Cabinet, his official residence has been 11 Downing St. After seeing the queen, Major will move next door to No. 10 to start forming his Cabinet. Mrs. Thatcher will go to her new house in Dulwich, a southeast London suburb. Major's annual salary as prime minister will be $131,700, up from $108,800 he received as treasury chief. He is due for a raise to $142,900 on Jan. 1. Mrs. Thatcher chose to draw the same salary as her fellow Cabinet ministers, forgoing the extra for prime minister. Her salary will now fall to that of a rank-and-file House of Commons member, $52,600 then to $57,000 in January. The governing powers of the British monarchy, in practice, have been assumed by Parliament since the early 19th century, but sovereignty remains with the throne. ``Under the royal powers, Major could appear at the palace to be told by the queen that she had chosen someone else as prime minister,'' said Harold Brooks-Baker, an expert on British royalty and publishing director of Burke's Peerage. ``The result would be the most terrible turmoil. It would be amusing but impractical, although perfectly possible,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Brrr-r-r-ring! Calls Set Record
DOC.TEXT: Americans set a long-distance calling record this week that broke the one set the day after last year's San Francisco earthquake, AT&T said Tuesday. American Telephone and Telegraph has only theories to explain why 148.4 million long-distance calls were made on its lines Monday. On Oct. 18, 1989, the day after the San Francisco earthquake, AT&T handled some 144.7 million long-distance calls, said spokesman Herb Linnen said. On an average day, the company handles 115 million to 120 million calls. ``Traditionally, the Monday after the Thanksgiving weekend is busy, although there has never been one like this,'' Linnen said. ``It was the busiest calling day in the history of AT&T.'' Linnen speculated that people were trying to catch up on business, or perhaps discussing the the possibility of war with Iraq. But then there were a lot of calls to toll-free ``800'' numbers, and that could mean people were doing more Christmas shopping by phone, he said. AT&T handles 70 percent or more of the nation's long-distance calls. There was no similar announcement from the other two major long-distance companies, US Sprint and MCI, and no answer at their Washington offices.

DOC.HEAD: French Officials Say Troops in Chad Facing Strong Rebel Force
DOC.TEXT: Government troops in Chad suffered substantial losses in battles with rebels waging one of the most serious challenges to President Hissene Habre since a 1987 Libyan invasion, French officials said Tuesday. The officials described the 2-week-old desert war in eastern Chad as an internal conflict, contradicting claims by Chad's government that the rebels are mercenaries backed by Libya and Sudan. Libya and Sudan deny involvement. Foreign Ministry spokesman Daniel Bernard said both government and rebels suffered significant casualties. Without giving figures, he said government losses were ``notable.'' Another French authority, speaking on condition of anonymity, talked of the seriousness of the rebel challenge. The source said there appeared no overt Libyan or Sudanese role in the fighting. The daily Le Figaro said 1,270 troops were killed by rebels in one battle. It said rebels led by Habre's former military adviser, Idriss Deby, massacred a column of Chadian troops in bloody weekend fighting. Habre had gone to the front to take personal command of his troops and almost was captured in fighting along the border with Sudan, according to Le Figaro. Chad's information minister, Adoum Moussa Seif, said Tuesday that Habre was in the capital, N'Djamena. He refused comment on reports that the president had gone to the front. Chad's embassy in Paris said Habre was ``in complete control of the political and military situation throughout the country.'' Le Figaro said the rebels trapped a mechanized column of 5,000 troops near Iriba. With loyalist forces bogged down in a minefield, guerrillas of Deby's Patriotic Salvation Movement opened fire with heavy machine guns and anti-tank rockets, killing 1,270 men, Le Figaro said. Surviving government forces fled, Le Figaro quoted the rebels as saying, leaving behind 20 destroyed armored vehicles, 200 light trucks equipped with machine guns, and 12 heavy trucks. Among the captured vehicles were two air-conditioned command cars apparently belonging to Habre, Le Figaro said. The reports could not be independently confirmed, but were the most detailed since renewed fighting in the Chad civil war broke out Nov. 10. Government radio claimed Monday that loyalist troops had retaken the towns of Iriba, Guereda and Adre, but the rebels claimed victories at Iriba and Tine. Chad claims that Libya supports the insurgents. Libya denies it, claiming th problems is among Chadians. Deby, who helped Habre take power in 1982, was accused in April 1989 of involvement in a coup plot and fled to Sudan. Libya, which once occupied the northern half of the country, signed a peace treaty with Chad in 1989, despite an outstanding border dispute. France maintains a force of about 1,000 soldiers in Chad as part of a defense agreement with its former colony. About half the troops are deployed in Abeche, about 150 miles south of the combat zone. Bernard said France has no intentions of entering the conflict. The rebels are based in Sudan's sparsely populated Darfur province in Sudan, over which Sudanese authorities exercise little Control.

DOC.HEAD: Exaggerated Job Woes Among Drug Users Used to Justify Tests, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Claims about accident rates and performance problems used to justify pre-employment drug screening may be exaggerated, say medical researchers who studied thousands of postal workers. The study didn't distinguish between occasional drug users and chronic abusers, who almost certainly would xxhibit problems at higher rates, said a drug-abuse specialist not involved in the study. ``Drug users have been reported to be involved in 200 percent to 300 percent more industrial accidents, to sustain 400 percent more compensable injuries and to use 1,500 percent more sick leave,'' the researchers said. But the study's findings suggest many such estimates used to justify pre-employment drug screening have been exaggerated, the researchers reported in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association. ``We found that those with marijuana-positive urine samples have 55 percent more industrial accidents, 85 percent more injuries and a 78 percent increase in absenteeism,'' the researchers wrote. For those with cocaine-positive urine samples, there was a 145 percent increase in absenteeism and an 85 percent increase in injuries, they said. The researchers cited as examples of exaggerated accidents rates a 1986 manual from the U.S. Office of Personnel Management and articles in the journal Psychiatry Letter and the American Psychologist. Peter Bensinger, a consultant on workplace drug and alcohol abuse, wrote one of the articles. He said he stands by his figures. ``We have clients who had great reductions in absenteeism, accidents with drug testing,'' Bensinger said. Vice President Dan Quayle wrote the American Psychologist article in 1983, when he was a senator. The lead researcher for the AMA journal study was Dr. Craig Zwerling, former medical director at the U.S. Postal Service in Boston and now with the University of Iowa College of Medicine at Iowa City. He and his colleagues performed urine drug tests on almost 5,000 job applicants in Boston for positions of letter carrier, postal clerk, computer-forwarding system clerk and maintenance worker, including skilled technical worker. The study's authors tracked the new hires between 1986 and 1989 to compile data for their report. The marijuana test was sensitive for up to four weeks after use; the test for cocaine was sensitive up to 72 hours after use. Positive tests were confirmed, and only confirmed tests were reported. Of the 2,537 new hires, 2,229, or 87.9 percent, tested negative; 198, or 7.8 percent, were confirmed positive for marijuana; 55, or 2.2 percent, confirmed positive for cocaine; and 55, or 2.2 percent confirmed positive for other ``non-therapeutic'' drugs or multiple drugs, the study found. But nothing in their protocol distinguished the occasional user from the chronic abuser, said an editorial accompanying the study. ``Postal employees in the sample were classified as drug-involved solely on the basis of a single pre-employment urine test,'' said Eric D. Wish of the Center for the Prevention and Control of Substance Abuse at the University of Maryland in College Wish said if the researchers could have differentiated between employees with chronic abuse problems from those who were infrequent users, the observed differences in job performance would have been larger. Regardless, he said, the overall rate of drug abuse was small - 12 percent, two-thirds of which was marijuana use. Such a rate is dwarfed by the 50 percent to 60 percent rates of abuse among people arrested for drug and non-drug crimes, he said. Wish suggested that society may benefit more by investing resources in testing and treating drug abusers coming through the criminal justice system than in finding the comparatively small number of mostly marijuana users in ``the primarily law-abiding employee populations.''

DOC.HEAD: Three NFL Players Fined for Harassing Reporter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with nine grafs to CORRECT that team was ordered to pay a total of $50,000; EDITS to conform. Pick up 8th graf, `We regret ...' Longer version moving on sports as AM-FBN--Olson Report.
DOC.TEXT: Three professional athletes were fined a total of $22,500 Tuesday by the National Football League for taking part in the sexual harassment of a female reporter in their locker room. In addition, the New England Patriots was ordered to pay $25,000 for instructional materials on how to deal responsibly with the news media and $25,000 because they ``never vigorously sought the facts about what had happened,'' NFL commissioner Paul Tagliabue wrote in a letter to Patriots owner Victor Kiam. The Sept. 17 incident involved reporter Lisa Olson of the Boston Herald and Patriots players Zeke Mowatt, Michael Timpson and former Patriot Robert Perryman. Mowatt was fined $12,500 for verbally harassing Olson and exposing himself to her, the NFL said. Timpson and Perryman each were fined $5,000. Timpson was accused of shouting encouragement and Perryman was accused of exposing himself. None of the players was suspended. The fines were levied by Tagliabue after special counsel Phillip Heymann of the Harvard Law School submitted a 60-page report. Tagliabue called the players' actions and statements ``completely uncalled for and improper.'' Kiam, who has been widely criticized for playing down the incident, said the team would abide by Tagliabue's judgment. ``We regret that the incident occurred,'' Kiam added. ``The team and I had previously expressed our apologies and we repeat them once again. The decision has been rendered. Now it's time to get on with playing football.'' The team said the players would have no comment. Perryman, who has since gone to the Dallas Cowboys, denied to investigators any involvement in the incident, the report said. Olson, who now covers the Boston Celtics, said: ``My satisfaction with the investigation and subsequent sanctions is surpassed only by my wish the disgraceful incident had never occurred in the first place.''

DOC.HEAD: Boxing's Muhammed Ali Meets with Saddam, Hostage Release Promised
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to CORRECT Muhammed sted Mohammed, ADDS background on Ali's career. No pickup.
