DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Zap Heartland, Snow in West
DOC.TEXT: Winter-like weather Tuesday replaced mild temperatures enjoyed by much of the nation' heartland for several days. A fast moving cold front pushing high winds and thunderstorms left rapidly falling temperatures, snow and freezing rain in its wake. Strong thunderstorms that developed along and ahead of the front marched across the lower and middle Mississippi Valley. Severe thunderstorms over central Missouri spawned two tornadoes in Columbia and just north of Warsaw. About 20 people suffered minor injuries in O'Fallon, 30 miles west of St. Louis. The thunderstorms produced high winds in Greene County that blew down trees and blew a car off the road. As the damaging storms moved out of Missouri into west central Illinois, they produced high winds in Sterling and downed trees around Barry and Rushville. Strong thunderstorms and locally heavy rain were scattered from central Illinois through central Missouri and northwestern Arkansas into northeastern Texas. Thunderstorms in Oklahoma and Kansas produced hail and damaging high winds. Snow prevailed behind the cold front from eastern Colorado to northern Minnesota. Heavy snow blanketed some of the mountains of Colorado. Elsewhere, showers fell over parts of Florida, Vermont, New York state, Idaho and Montana. Record high temperatures were set in Alpena, Mich., with 61 degrees, Beckley, W.Va., 69, Chattanooga, Tenn., 75, Chicago, Ill., 64, Dayton, Ohio, 69, Detroit, Mich., 66, Flint, Mich., 66, Fort Wayne, Ind., 65, Grand Rapids, Mich., 65, Green Bay, Wis., 63, Lansing, Mich., 65, Lexington, Ky., 73, Louisville, Ky., 73, Milwaukee, Wis., 67, Rockford, Ill., 65, Traverse City, Mich., Youngstown, Ohio, 66, Houghton Lake, Mich., tied 57, and Jackson, Mich., tied 62. The low Tuesday morning in the Lower 48 states was 11 below zero at Williston, N.D.

DOC.HEAD: Two Explorers from French Expedition Safe, Two Others Missing
DOC.TEXT: A Peruvian Air Force search helicopter on Tuesday discovered a Swiss adventurer at the edge of the Apurimac River, a week after a boating accident in the jungled highland region. The French Embassy on Tuesday said a French member of the rafting expedition had found his way back to Cuzco, a mountain city 350 miles southeast of Lima. Two Frenchmen remain missing, the embassy said. Both men were in excellent condition, an Embassy spokesman said. The two were taking part in a 10-man, private expedition when their rubber rafts capsized Nov. 20 in the rain-swollen Apurimac. The accident took place near Curahuasi, 40 miles southwest of Cuzco. The Frenchman told reporters he was lost in the jungle for two days before he came upon a group of peasants who took him to a road, where he caught a truck to Cuzco, he said. The embassy spokesman said searchers hope to find the other two men safe. He speculated they may have walked into the jungle looking for a road or settlement. The embassy has expressed fear the explorers may be captured by leftist guerrillas operating in the region. The Maoist Shining Path has killed at least 12 foreigners the last two years as part of a decade-long insurgency against the government.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Government Approves Additional Taxation
DOC.TEXT: The government on Tuesday approved an increase in taxes proposed by Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai to cover the growing defense and immigrant absorption budgets. The decision came at a special Cabinet session called to debate the $37.5 billion state budget for 1991. The budget for the nine-month fiscal year, which starts in April and ends in December, is expected to allocate $6.2 billion for defense and $6.5 billion for the absorption of Soviet Jews. About 130,000 Soviet immigrants have arrived in the country this year, and an additional 350,000 to 400,000 are expected to come in 1991. On Tuesday, Modai and Defense Minister Moshe Arens agreed after a bitter debate to an additional defense budget of $240 million for military needs linked to the nearly three-year-old Palestinian uprising and the army's continuing state of alert over the Gulf crisis. The Cabinet then voted to accept a new proposal by Modai, setting the value-added tax at 18 percent, compared with the present rate of 16 percent. In addition, it approved a proposal to impose a special five percent hike in income taxes. Modai, speaking on Israel television, said the measures will take effect between Jan. 1 and April 1, 1991. There was no decision on the overall budget, which also has to be approved by the 120-member parliament. However, the government enjoys a Parliament majority. The Histadrut, Israel's largest trade unions' federation, announced Tuesday that it plans to fight against the new measures and said it will stage a countrywide general strike next Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Rock Star Raises $1.3 Million for Brazilian Indian Reserve
DOC.TEXT: Rock star Sting announced Tuesday that his Virgin Forest Foundation had collected $1.3 million toward the creation of the largest Indian reserve in Brazil. Sting told reporters he had come to Brazil to meet with the foundation's leaders and to account for donations raised since the group was founded in March 1989. The foundation is seeking to join five National Parks stretching from the central Amazon state of Mato Grosso to the northern Amazon state of Para to form a 30-million-acre Indian reserve. Sting said the money would also be used for education, health and Indian cultural projects on the reserve. Foundation president Olimpio Serra said the donations had been deposited in a foreign bank account and would be transferred to Brazil's National Indian Foundation when the government authorized the demarcation of the reserve. Serra said $250,000 in donations had been blocked in Brazil's Central Bank since March 16, when President Fernando Collor de Mello froze 80 percent of all money in circulation to curb four-digit annual inflation. The Virgen Forest Foundation was founded after Sting began a world tour in the United States, Japan, Canada and Europe to raise money for the project.

DOC.HEAD: Tories Rally Around after Tense Day of Voting
With AM-Britain-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Conservative lawmakers heard the vote count, roared their approval, then wondered what they had done. More than 100 Tory lawmakers crowded into a committee room at the House of Commons to hear the totals in the leadership race: John Major 185, Michael Heseltine 131, Douglas Hurd 56. Their delighted bellowing reverberated through the ancient wood-paneled corridors of the Palace of Westminster, home of both houses of the British parliament. But wait - nobody won. Major was two votes short of the majority needed. ``We were starting to bang the tables, as we do on occasions like this, but then we held our hands back as we realized what had happened,'' said legislator David Shaw. ``One hundred and eighty-five sounded like an outright victory, but then we remembered the reality of the numbers.'' Then, as they surged out into the corridor to meet waiting reporters, legislators learned that former Defense Secretary Heseltine and Foreign Secretary Hurd had conceded defeat. A week ago, many of these same Tories produced a split vote that toppled Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. It had been a heady two weeks for the backbenchers, as the rank-and-file legislators are known. Most of the time, they vote as they are told by leaders. But in the leadership election, they had a secret ballot and were avidly courted by all three camps. Lawmaker Jeremy Hanley said the wooing could have been more intense. ``I had to pay for my own lunch,'' he said. ``They can't be that keen.'' The result capped a day of buzzing activity in the usually sedate committee corridor, a long walkway leading to dozens of committee rooms where the day-to-day business of Parliament is done. Early voters at Committee Room 12 included Hurd, a part-time writer of fiction, who quipped that the three-way tussle for the leadership ``has given me a plot for my next novel.'' Major flashed an enigmatic smile, and said nothing. Heseltine, voting shortly after lunch time, teased the media by reporting: ``I confirm that at 2:13 p.m. I had three votes, because I have two proxies.'' Mrs. Thatcher cast her vote after making her 698th appearance at Question Time, when she fields queries from lawmakers. She took 7,501 questions in her 11{ years as the head of the government. Whoever the lawmakers supported, they all said afterward that the party would go forward united behind Major. That's exactly as predicted earlier this week by Lord St. John of Fawsley, a former Conservative member of the House of Commons. Tories believe in unity, Lord St. John said. They would support Major, Hurd or Heseltine. ``They'd rally around a broomstick,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Army Says Panama Atrocity Claims Unfounded
DOC.TEXT: Army officials said there was no evidence to support a former senator's allegations that atrocities were committed by U.S. forces whenthey ousted Manuel Noriega from Panama last year. Col. Joseph S. Panvini, director of public affairs for the U.S. Southern Command in Panama, said allegations that U.S. forces paid $6 per body and buried slain noncombatants in mass, unmarked graves was ``absolutely unfounded.'' He said there was no evidence to support other allegations made by former U.S. Sen. Donald Stewart of Alabama. Stewart toured Panama in late August. Stewart said about 100 Panamanians he spoke with told ``story after story'' of innocent citizens, including children and the elderly, being killed and buried in mass graves. He said official figures on casualties appeared to be far short of the actual numbers. ``There has been no attempt on the part of the U.S. government to hide the reporting of Panamanian fatalities as a result of Operation Just Cause,'' Panvini said in a letter responding to the allegations. ``Panvini is saying things contrary to what the people in Panama told me,'' Stewart said in a telephone interview. ``If they don't have anything to cover up, an investigation will reveal that. I would love to know it wasn't true.'' As for Panvini's denial of the $6-per-body claim, Stewart said, ``He may be absolutely correct that they didn't pay $6 a body, but that was what I was told by more than one Panamanian.'' Stewart toured Panama in late August on a trip related to mission work with the United Methodist Church. He said he hopes for a congressional investigation into the claims. Stewart, an Anniston lawyer, won a special election to fill a Senate vacancy in 1978 but lost in the Democratic primary seeking a full term in 1980. After his six-day trip to Panama, he told Methodist church officials that he received ``report after report of those who saw the atrocities.'' Panvini said that since Jan. 11, inquiries concerning casualties of the December 1989 operation have been referred to Panama's Institute of Legal Medicine, similar to a coroner's office. He said that as of Nov. 7, that agency had identified 65 military and 155 civilian remains, with another 50 bodies not yet identified. He said some of the 50 may be among the 75 unsolved reports of missing persons. Prior to Jan. 11, he said, the Southern Command, in conjunction with the agency, estimated there were 202 civilian fatalities. He said it also estimated 315 military fatalities, based on reports from combat units. Stewart said such figures on civilian deaths do not correspond with the accounts given to him by Panamanians. As for mass graves, Panvini said 123 Panamanian nationals were buried in a common grave at Panama City and 18 were buried at Colon. He said the burials and the previously reported exhumations were conducted by Panamanian authorities, not by U.S. personnel. Stewart, however, said Panamanians told him the interments in the common, unmarked graves were paid for by U.S. authorities. Panvini did not immediately return a telephone call concerning that allegation. In his Nov. 21 letter, Panvini said: ``Regarding alleged atrocities by U.S. forces, only 24 reports of alleged misconduct by U.S. troops during Operation Just Cause have been received by U.S. military authorities. All 24 have been investigated.'' As of Aug. 31, he said, the Army review cleared nine and found the remaining 15 ``warranted formal review by the Department of the Army.''

DOC.HEAD: No More `Last' Apperances, Thatcher Tells House
With AM-Britain-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, facing the House of Commons while her colleagues voted for her successor, said that her 698th appearance for Question Time on Tuesday would be her last. ``I don't believe in making a career of positively last appearances,'' said Mrs. Thatcher, who announced last week she would resign after 11{ years in power. She wished her successor well and predicted: ``I am sure he will continue the policies which have been so successful for Britain and he will continue to defeat socialism.'' Neil Kinnock, leader of the opposition Labor Party and her principal antagonist for the last eight years, asked Mrs. Thatcher ``which of the policies that you leave to your successor you now think should be scrapped?'' Mrs. Thatcher replied: ``I am happy that my successor will carry on the excellent policies that have finished with the decline of socialism and brought great prosperity to this country, which have raised Britain's standing in the world and brought about a truly capital-owning democracy.'' She told another questioner that since she became prime minister in 1979, she had appeared 698 times in the House of Commons for Question Time and had fielded 7,498 questions, including his. She answered three more before leaving the chamber and going to a committee room to cast her secret ballot in the Conservative Party's leadership election. Mrs. Thatcher seemed in good spirits but with none of the exuberant fury unleashed five days earlier, when she led a debate hours after deciding to resign. A Labor legislator asked Mrs. Thatcher whether she found it ``nauseating and hypocritical'' to be praised by her colleagues in the party, considering what happened to her last week. ``No I don't find it nauseating. I find it very refreshing,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Former S&L Regulator Says DeConcini Offered Deal for Keating
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 7th graf: ``Keating was,'' to restore dropped digit in figure, making it $1.3 million sted ``$1. million.''
DOC.TEXT: cross-examination

A former top federal regulator testified Tuesday that Sen. Dennis DeConcini improperly offered him a deal on behalf of savings and loan owner Charles H. Keating Jr., and that three other ``Keating Five'' senators acquiesced in the proposal. Edwin J. Gray, a star witness at the Senate Ethics Committee's hearings into the five senators' relationships with Keating, said DeConcini's offer at a 1987 meeting will be ``etched in my mind forever.'' ``I considered it improper,'' he declared. ``The whole setting was an intimidating one.'' He said DeConcini, apparently speaking for the other three senators as well, asked that regulators not apply to Keating's embattled Lincoln Savings and Loan Association a rule limiting risky investments. DeConcini, D-Ariz., referred to Keating during the meeting as ``our friend from Lincoln,'' said Gray, the former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. None of the five senators was present for his testimony. Keating was the chairman of the now-failed Lincoln S&L when the evening meeting took place in DeConcini's office on April 2, 1987. The committee is trying to decide whether the five senators intervened improperly for Keating, a political donor who along with associates contributed $1.3 million to the senators' campaigns and causes. The hearing recessed for the day just after DeConcini's lawyer, James Hamilton, began cross-examination of Gray. His examination followed a contentious cross-examination by Thomas Green, lawyer for Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich. Charles F. C. Ruff, attorney for Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, briefly questioned Gray; John Dowd, representing Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz. declined to cross-examine the witness; and William Taylor, representing Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., awaited his turn. All the senators except Riegle attended the meeting with Gray and all have denied that a deal was offered for Lincoln - which was in deep trouble with Gray's regulators. Gray testified DeConcini asked that the risky-investment rule not be applied to Lincoln and added, ``If you do that, we'll get our friend from Lincoln to make more home loans.'' ``I said we had gone through the administrative processes and I'm not going to do that,'' Gray testified. ``He said they were there for their friend at Lincoln.'' Gray said, ``We did not succumb to that pressure'' and the risky-investment rule was not withdrawn. ``Nothing was speeded up ... nothing was slowed down'' in the Lincoln investigation as a result of the senators' intervention, he said. Gray testified he did not protest to the senators after the alleged deal was offered because he feared they would not back legislation to provide money-raising authority for the hard-pressed Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Fund. Gray was responsible for the fund as chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. Calm under direct examination from special counsel Robert S. Bennett, the witness whose testimony is crucial to the case not only insisted that DeConcini offered the deal, but added: ``Every time he said anything, he said `We.' I assumed he was speaking for'' Cranston, Glenn and McCain. While Riegle was not at that meeting, Gray said the Michigan Democrat was instrumental in organizing it - something that Riegle, the Senate Banking Committee chairman has denied. Gray said that on March 6, 1987, Riegle told him, ``You know there are senators out West who are very unhappy about the bank board's regulation of Lincoln and you ought to talk to them.'' Gray said he resisted, because he thought the matter was simply a continuation of Keating accusations that the chief thrift regulator was out to get Lincoln. Despite that protest, Gray said, Riegle told him, ``I think you'll be getting a call.'' The ex-regulator said he was shocked when he learned that Riegle was at a meeting April 9, 1987, between all five senators and the San Francisco-based regulators who were examining Lincoln. Since Riegle was from Michigan and Lincoln was based in California, Gray said, ``I couldn't figure out for the life of me why he would be there.'' When he later learned from a reporter that shortly before the meeting Keating had hosted a fund-raising dinner for Riegle, Gray said his reaction was, ``You've got to be kidding.'' In his cross-examination, Green read from a news story that characterized Gray as an autocratic executive who was obsessed with personal security and argued constantly with his fellow regulators. Gray attorney Leonard Garment forced an end to that line of questioning by protesting to Chairman Howell Heflin, D-Ala. that Green stop reading from materials not in evidence and accounts with ``lurid'' descriptions. Riegle's lawyer also asked the former regulator why he sent the senator a copy of a transcript of the April 9, 1987 meeting with the San Francisco regulators, a favor that Gray had not extended to the other four senators. Gray said he acted ``as a matter of courtesy to someone who had been friendly and sympathetic to me.'' The five senators have said they had not been aware that a record of the meeting was being kept by one of the regulators. Gray also said of Riegle, ``I bore no malice against this man whatsoever.''

DOC.HEAD: Yazov: Troops May Use Force to Defend Military Installations
DOC.TEXT: Defense Minister Dmitry Yazov on Tuesday said troops may use force to prevent attacks against soldiers defending military installations. He also warned that nuclear weapons must remain under the control of the central government. Yazov's statements in a nationally televised address gave new urgency to tensions in the 15 republics and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's efforts to hold the splintering Soviet Union together. They also appeared to be the toughest official reaction yet to fears that nuclear weapons could fall into nationalist hands. ``Illegal actions in a number of republics ... endanger the defense capacity of the country,'' he said after the evening news. ``In some republics their own army units are being formed. Voices are heard about handing nuclear weapons over to some republics. Decisions are taken requiring relocation of armed forces units, including strategic units,'' Yazov said. ``Attempts are made to defame and dishonor officers and soldiers, (and) members of their families. There are armed assaults against military installations,'' he said. Yazov listed eight points, including one that said nuclear forces must remain under national control and that the president has final authority on deployment of troops. Earlier this year, a Russian republic deputy prime minister called for the vast republic to possess its own nuclear weapons, and some nationalists in the restive southern republics reportedly have tried to storm nuclear weapons facilities. Yazov said commanders of military district around the country have ``directives to take installations and systems under the guard and protection of armed units'' if local officials shut off their water, power or other services. He said soldiers have orders to ``use weapons'' if any serviceman or military installation is attacked. Commanders have orders to prevent acts of vandalism and ``counteract the construction of monuments and other forms of glorifying fascists and their henchmen, (and) eliminate the existing symbols of this sort,'' he said. Hours earlier, Gorbachev used his broad presidential powers to say he would hold local officials personally responsible for any failure to register servicemen or their families on lists for receiving services and goods. ``Refusals to register officers and (non-commissioned officers) and members of their families arriving to the place of service have lately become more frequent,'' Gorbachev said, according to the official news agency Tass. ``It leads to illegal limitations in job placement, medical and other social service,'' he said. He gave officials until Jan. 15 to resolve the problems. The orders revealed a widespread resistance to Red Army presence in the country, nearly all of whose republics have declared some form of sovereignty. However, it was unclear whether the orders would be enforced short of harsher military action. Gorbachev has used his presidential powers to issue several decrees on the economy, but his hands have been tied in a power struggle for economic control with the republics, led mostly by Russia.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Democrats Challenge Bush on Gulf Strategy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with five grafs on Gephardt's position, picks up 2nd graf, now 6th graf: ``The question,'' INSERTS 7th graf: ``Nunn said,'' to bring higher Nunn's support of U.N. resolution; INSERTS 11th graf: ``Neither Foley,'' to note Foley and Mitchell positions unstated
DOC.TEXT: The second-ranking Democrat in the House said Tuesday night he would oppose a resolution authorizing the early use of force to throw Iraq out of Kuwait. Rep. Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., the majority leader of the House, spoke in a telephone interview after some Senate Democrats questioned the need for offensive action right away. The disclosure of Gephardt's position was the first public opposition among party leaders in Congress to the use of force, something the United Nations is expected to endorse soon. Gephardt, who will outline his views further in a speech on Wednesday, said in a telephone interview, ``I think we should stay the course with sanctions.'' ``I would not be in favor of authorizing force at this point. I'm not ruling it out,'' Gephardt said. ``The question is not whether military action is justified. It is,'' said Sen. Sam Nunn, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, which began several days of hearings on the gulf crisis.``The question is whether military action is wise at this time and in our own national interest.'' Nunn said he supported the resolution to come before the U.N. Security Council later this week authorizing member countries to use ``all necessary means'' to restore Kuwait. The hearings were called - after Congress adjourned for the year - in reaction to Bush's decision to send an additional 200,000 troops to the gulf to provide an ``offensive military option.'' With the administration seeking U.N. approval for the use of force in the gulf, some committee members said the president also must make the same request of Congress. House Speaker Thomas Foley, in remarks to newly elected House Democrats, underscored the point. ``I would personally want to have some assurance from the administration that no action would be taken prior to this Congress meeting, or it would be necessary to think seriously about calling in the previous Congress,'' he said. Neither Foley nor his Senate counterpart, Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, has indicated whether he would support a congressional resolution authorizing offensive military action. The opening day of the session also was marked by the conspicuous absence of the administration's top military officials - Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The two will testify Monday morning. Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., said the policy change to underline a U.S. attack capability undermines the nation's attempts to maintain international support for the sanctions ``by declaring, through its own word and those of the imminent U.N. resolution, that our patience was almost spent.'' Kerrey is not a member of the panel but he submitted a statement to the committee. Committee member Edard Kennedy, D-Mass., declared, ``If ever there is a case for giving peace a chance, this is it.'' Yet another panel Democrat, Alan Dixon of Illinois, suggested that the administration's ``priorities are slightly misplaced.'' ``To the best of my knowledge it is the United States Congress that declares war for the United States - not the United Nations,'' Dixon said. Fighting the tide of criticism, Republican John McCain of Arizona declared, ``The issue is not prerogatives, it is patriotism.'' On the question of strategy, Nunn asked, ``Has the president limited our options by creating a `use it or lose it' situation with the deployment of such a large U.S. force to the Persian Gulf?'' John Glenn, D-Ohio, said the administration has yet to make its case for military attack in the gulf, arguing that the nation ``cannot get into a war that is not fully understood and backed by the American people. We need more than sound-bite justification.'' In the place of senior administration officials, the panel heard from former CIA Director James Schlesinger, who testified that the United States believes it will take about a year for international sanctions against Iraq to take full effect. Schlesinger told the panel that that was ``an official estimate.'' The one time CIA director and defense secretary did not indicate the basis for his statement. ``A year, to me, seems to be in the right ballpark,'' Schlesinger said, time enough ``to drain off the cash that is now sustaining the smuggling operations that bring in food.'' ``His society is bleeding and it's going to get worse with the passage of time,'' Schlesinger said. But it may take somewhat longer for those difficulties to lead Saddam to change his mind and withdraw from Kuwait, he said. Meanwhile, at a separate hearing, a Treasury Department official said, ``Iraq's central bank ... and its two primary international banks ... have been effectively cut off from the international financial community, so that Iraqi financial flows have been reduced to a mere trickle of their pre-August levels.'' R. Richard Newcomb, director of the Office of Foreign Assets Control, told the House Banking Committee, ``The ever-tightening economic embargo against Iraq is certain to hamper Iraq's ability to carry out effective military campaigns and will bring home to the Iraqi people the futility of Saddam's aggression against Kuwait.'' Newcomb, in response to questions from panel members, conceded that some goods may be reaching Iraq overland, but he refused to identify countries suspected of breaking the embargo. The hearings come as the United Nations Security Council prepares to vote on a resolution threatening to use ``all necessary means'' to drive Iraq from Kuwait if it does not leave by January. Nunn indicated his support for the resolution but said it ``is not a substitute for fully informing the American people of our own nation's objectives and strategy.'' Kennedy added, ``It is not enough for President Bush to go to the United Nations to get approval for the use of military force in the Persian Gulf. He must also come to Congress.''

DOC.HEAD: New York Mayor Signs Bill Banning Cigarette Vending Machines
DOC.TEXT: A ban on cigarette vending machines in most public places got final approval Tuesday from Mayor David Dinkins, a former smoker who said the ban will help keep smokes out of children's hands. ``Today we have achieved an important pro-child, pro-health law that will save lives,'' Dinkins said. ``Obviously, some children will still be able to buy cigarettes, but many won't.'' The mayor pushed for the ban, saying previously that 32,000 children in New York begin smoking each year and 10,000 will die from complications from the habit. The ban, which takes effect Jan. 31, 1992, allows cigarette vending machines only in taverns, which must keep them at least 25 feet entrances and in view of the operator. Dinkins, who gave up smoking 28 years ago, said he plans to work with state lawmakers to restrict over-the-counter cigarette sales to children and would also like to phase out cigarette advertising in baseball stadiums and on city-owned property. The city already bans smoking in municipal buildings and regulates smoking in work places.

DOC.HEAD: Assad Meets With British Delegation
DOC.TEXT: President Hafez Assad met Tuesday with three British Parliament members in talks expected to accelerate moves to restore diplomatic ties severed four years ago. The Syrian government newspaper Tishrin said earlier this month that Britain should resume relations with Syria if it wanted the 13 Western hostages in Lebanon freed. The official Syrian Arab News Agency reported the Tuesday meeting and said Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa also attended. Sharaa met Monday with the British delegation of Robert Adley and Tim Rathbone of the ruling Conservative Party, and Sir David Steel of the Liberal Democratic Party. During the weekend, Sharaa also met with David Gore-Booth, an undersecretary at the Foreign Office, in the first contact between the two governments since relations with Damascus were cut over alleged Syrian involvement in terrorism. Sources noted that Assad would not have received the delegation unless efforts to restore ties gained ground. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, also said that resumption of relations was unlikely until after the new British government forms. In London, Conservatives late Tuesday elected treasury chief John Major to succeed Margaret Thatcher as prime minister. Mrs. Thatcher, who opposed restoring ties with Syria, ordered relations severed in November 1986. She said her government had evidence Syria was behind a plot to blow up an Israeli jetliner at Heathrow Airport near London in April 1986. Resumption of ties with Britain could give new hope for the release of Western hostages held by pro-Iranian extremists. The captives include six Americans, four Britons, two Germans and an Italian. Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was taken hostage March 16, 1985, and is the longest-held captive. Syria is the main powerbroker in Lebanon, with 40,000 troops based there under an Arab League mandate. It helped free American hostages Robert Polhill and Frank Reed in April and Irishman Brian Keenan in August. U.S.-Syrian ties improved in summer when Damascus sided with the alliance against Saddam Hussein following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Syria committed nearly 20,000 troops to a military buildup in the Persian Gulf. Syria remains on theU.S. State Department's list of countries that sponsor terrorism. But Secretary of State James A. Baker III visited Damascus in September, and President Bush met with Assad in Geneva last week.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Rules in Favor of Universal Suffrage
DOC.TEXT: Switzerland's last bastion of male supremacy was swept away Tuesday by a Supreme Court judgment that a tiny Catholic state must allow women to play an active role in politics. The Federal Tribunal ruled that Appenzell-Rhodes interior state violated Swiss sexual equality laws by refusing to let women participate in its annual legislative assembly. It said that beginning now, women must be allowed to vote at the assembly and all local elections - and hence be eligible for political office in the enclave in northeastern Switzerland. Switzerland is a federation of 23 cantons (states), joined under a federal constitution, with large powers of local control retained by each canton. Swiss women won the vote at federal level two decades ago. The unanimous decision by one female and six male judges followed three separate complaints from Appenzellers of both sexes challenging the exclusion of women. ``It's a huge weight off my mind,'' said one of the complainants, Theres Rohner Sonderegger, after the verdict. The outdoor legislative assembly, known as Landsgemeinde, dates to the Middle Ages. Traditionally attended by men carrying swords to indicate their voting eligibility, the colorful ceremony has the last say in local affairs. Foreign tourists flocked to the mountainous state with a population of just 13,000 last April to witness an overwhelming ``no'' to a proposal for female suffrage.

DOC.HEAD: Houston School Superintendent to Resign With $425,000 Settlement
DOC.TEXT: The city's beleaguered school superintendent resigned Tuesday after district trustees approved a six-figure settlement of her contract, ending contention over her allegedly authoritarian style. Trustees voted 5-4 to pay Houston School Superintendent Joan Raymond $425,000 to buy out her three year contract. Ms. Raymond, who has been superintendent of the nation's fifth-largest school district for four years, will leave the post June 10 and remain as a consultant through Aug. 31. Trustees had been unhappy with what they considered Ms. Raymond's authoritarian management style and had ordered her in June to decentralize the district's power structure and make other changes. Several trustees said she fought the reforms, but they lacked the votes to force her resignation, so Ms. Raymond was put on probation Nov. 16 pending a performance review in March. She had 2{ years remaining on her contract.

DOC.HEAD: Twenty-Eight Students Injured in Bus Accident
DOC.TEXT: A school bus filled with students rear-ended another Tuesday, injuring 28 teen-agers, authorities said. Most of the injuries appeared minor. The buses were taking about 70 students from middle and high schools in Justin to their homes in rural Denton County when the accident occurred on Highway 114, one mile west of Interstate 35W. Roanoke is about 25 miles northwest of Dallas. Most of the injured students walked to ambulances that took them to hospitals, said Eileen Standridge, an assistant superintendent for Northwest Independent School District, which serves several small towns in Denton County. ``There are no critical injuries as far as we know,'' said Ron Hibbs, another assistant superintendent for the district. He said some injuries may be ``fairly serious.'' Both drivers suffered injuries, he said. Les Weaver, a communications operator for the state Department of Public Safety, described the accident this way: A school bus stopped on the highway to let off children. Behind it were two cars and two more school buses. The last bus hit the one in front of it, pushing it into the two cars. The people in the two cars were not injured, nor was anyone injured in the first bus.

DOC.HEAD: Battle Groups to Leave for Middle East After Christmas
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two months after it became the only American warship to have New York as its homeport, the missile cruiser USS Normandy has received orders for deployment to Operation Desert Shield, Navy officials said Tuesday. The Normandy, one of the Navy's newest Aegis-type cruisers, will sail ``shortly after Christmas'' as part of an eight-ship battle group headed by the aircraft carrier USS America, the Navy said. The Pentagon earlier this mnth announced that the America, the USS Ranger and the nuclear-powered USS Theodore Roosevelt would be sent to the Gulf region to reinforce three other U.S. carriers in the buildup for possible war against Iraq. The America and the Theodore Roosevelt, the Navy's newest carrier on active duty, are based at Norfolk, Va., the Ranger at San Diego. Their accompanying escort ships are drawn from those and other bases on the East and West coasts. The Navy announced in Norfolk on Tuesday that the America and Theodore Roosevelt battle groups would depart about the same time for the Middle East, but gave no specific date. The Desert Shield deployment is the first for the Normandy. It was commissioned a year ago, the 14th of the Navy's planned 28 Aegis-type cruisers. The billion-dollar warship is equipped with a computer-linked radar and weapons ``battle management'' system designed to defend carrier groups from long-range threats and provide support for U.S. warships, aircraft and amphibious forces in operations against hostile targets. The 9,600-ton Normandy arrived Oct. 5 at Naval Station New York, the first of six warships planned to port at the new naval facility on Staten Island. The USS America battle group will also include the USS Nitro, an ammunition ship stationed at Earle, N.J., an ordnance supply base in New York's outer harbor. The Nitro carries a full range of ammunition including bombs and missiles for naval aircraft, fuel and other supplies to replenish ships at sea.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Shakes Australia
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake hit 30 miles west of Tennant Creek in the Northern Territory on Wednesday, the Australian Seismological Center said. No serious damage or injuries were reported. Kevin McCue, chief of the center's earthquake seismological group, said the quake struck on the far western side of the fault scarp produced during the January 1988 earthquake at Tennant Creek which caused serious property damage. Tennant Creek Police Sgt. Mark Delaney said the quake, which measured five on the open-ended Richter scale, was the strongest temblor since then. ``This one lasted about 10 seconds and certainly rattled the shelves, but we've had no reports of anything being damaged or anyone being hurt,'' he said. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph.

DOC.HEAD: Second of Peter MacDonald Trials Starting
DOC.TEXT: Suspended Navajo Chairman Peter MacDonald and his son returned to tribal court Tuesday for a second corruption trial, this one focusing on the tribe's purchase of a ranch. MacDonald is charged with bribery, fraud, conspiracy and 10 counts of ethics violations. He could face four years in jail if convicted. His son, Peter ``Rocky'' MacDonald Jr., is charged with one count of conspiracy and could face six months in jail. They were convicted Oct. 17 on separate charges of bribery, ethics violations and conspiracy. They were sentenced to jail, but were released to help with their appeals. The current trial stems from the tribe's February 1987 purchase of the 491,000-acre Big Boquillas Ranch in northern Arizona. The tribe paid $33.4 million to Tracy Oil and Gas Co., which had bought the property for $26.25 million earlier that day. The prosecution's criminal complaint alleges that MacDonald, a Scottsdale real estate broker and K. Tom Tracy, president of Tracy Oil, allegedly agreed to split the $7.2 million profit three ways. Tribal District Court Judge Robert Yazzie ruled Tuesday before jury selection began that he will not permit defense testimony that the case is political.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting to correct coding error.
Jets Attack Guerrillas After 5 Israeli Soldiers Die in Lebanon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 20 grafs to UPDATE with guerrilla death toll, details. CORRECTS second reference of town to Shabaa sted Shebaa. Picks up 20th graf pvs, `The statement...'
DOC.TEXT: Israel sent warplanes to blast guerrilla bases Tuesday after five Israeli soldiers died fighting Palestinian guerrillas in southern Lebanon. Police said at least 13 Palestinian guerrillas were killed. Lebanese authorities said eight guerrillas were killed in the ground action and five died in the air raid on guerrillas of Abu Nidal's Fatah-Revolutionary Council near Sidon. It was the Jewish state's highest death toll in the region since 1988, when eight soldiers were killed by a car bomb. The clash was the third in a week between Palestinians and Israelis in southern Lebanon - a surge of violence that could threaten efforts to end Lebanon's civil war. Three of the Israelis were buried Tuesday in their homeland. Maj. Gen. Yossi Peled, commander of the sector where they died, said in a eulogy: ``The terrorists' mission was foiled. The settlements of the north are safe. The price is unbearable.'' Shortly after the Israeli air raid, reporters based in southern Lebanon said they saw four Israeli gunboats cruise past the border town of Naquora, apparently heading toward Sidon. Several helicopter hovered overhead, the witnesses said, but there was no immediate report of naval bombardments. An estimated 5,000 Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas are based in refugee camps near Sidon. Police said four Israeli fighter-bombers fired 12 rockets into a hilltop position occupied by Fatah-Revolutionary Council fighters in Shahabil, near Sidon. At least two guerrillas were killed and three wounded in the three-minute raid by F-15 and F-16 jets, police reported. They said three other guerrillas were killed in a base of the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine in nearby Baysour village. The group's press office in Beirut confirmed the deaths. It was Israel's 19th air raid on Lebanon this year. By police count, 20 people were killed and 62 were wounded in the previous strikes. The ground action between Israeli troops and a guerrilla band occurred in the foothills of Mount Hermon, about 28 miles southeast of Sidon. Security sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the battle broke out shortly after midnight near Shabaa, a Sunni Moslem village on the Israeli security zone's eastern flank. Police said the battle raged for 2{ hours after an Israeli observation post spotted the guerrllas and called in helicopters with reinforcements. ``By daybreak, the bodies of eight guerrillas were littering the battleground,'' a police spokesman said. He spoke on condition of anonymity. He said the Israelis were killed when they tried to examine the bodies of four of the dead guerrillas. ``A big explosion happened. The bodies must have been booby-trapped,'' he said. An Israeli military communique from Jerusalem, however, said the soldiers ``stormed a ring of four guerrillas who were on their way toward Israeli territory.'' It said: ``In an exchange of fire at close range accompanied by the throwing of hand grenades, five soldiers were killed and another was wounded.'' There were other reports in Israel saying the soldiers were killed by a booby trap or when one soldier pulled the pin of a grenade but was shot before he could throw it. In Beirut, George Habash's Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine claimed it staged the Shabaa attack to mark the start of the fourth year of the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The anniversary is more than a week away. The statement said the attack was staged with guerrillas of the Libyan Revolutionary Committees. A week ago, another Palestinian group claimed responsibility for an attack in concert with the Libyan Committees. An Israeli officer died in that battle, which occurred just outside the security zone. Sources close to the PLO said Libya has recruited about 300 Lebanese and Palestinians in a Libyan-financed guerrilla faction called the Libyan Revolutionary Committees. The sources spoke on condition of anonymity. On Sunday, a woman detonated a handbag packed with explosives as she walked past an Israeli patrol in the security zone. She died, and Israel said two soldiers were wounded. Responsibility for the attack was claimed by the Syrian Social Nationalist Party. The Israeli navy on Saturday sank a rubber dinghy off south Lebanon, killing five guerrillas of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command. The security zone, patrolled by about 1,000 Israeli troops and 3,000 Israeli-affiliated militiamen, has been controlled by Israel since its 1982 invasion of Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico City Airport Fire Injures 20
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with fire out, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A fire broke out Tuesday night at a disused control tower in Mexico City's international airport and damaged a boarding area building, causing panic among passengers and slightly injuring about 20 people, officials said. Fire department duty officer Roberto Mosqueda said it took firefighters nearly an hour to bring the blaze under control. He said in a telephone interview, ``Part of the old control tower burned and Boarding Hall D, which is below, but we don't have many details.'' Red Cross dispatcher Gabriela Vega Pulido said 13 ambulances were sent. She said by telephone that most of the victims were treated for smoke inhalation and that the one person hospitalized was not in serious condition. Fire department dispatcher Catalina Guzman said a fire engine and a water tank-truck were sent to the airport.

DOC.HEAD: New York's Highest Court Rules Senate Leader Must Stand Trial
DOC.TEXT: The state Senate minority leader must stand trial on charges of using public funds to pay four people who performed no work, New York's highest court ruled Tuesday. The state Court of Appeals said in a 6-1 decision that Manfred Ohrenstein did not have to stand trial on other charges of illegally using public funds to pay political campaign workers. Those charges had been dismissed by a lower court and made up the bulk of a 564-count indictment against Ohrenstein, a Manhattan Democrat, and three associates. The Court of Appeals, the state's highest, said that while it did not condone using taxpayer dollars to finance campaign work, the practice was not illegal. The court ordered Ohrenstein to stand trial on so-called no-show charges of hiring and paying four people who did no work. The dismissed charges were considered the central issue in the case against Ohrenstein because they went to the heart of the Legislature's operations, where government work and re-election politics are carefully blended. The indictment stems from Ohrenstein's failed attempt to wrest control of the state Senate from Republicans in 1986. Some of the employees cited in the dismissed charges were full-time legislative staffers assigned to work on campaigns. Other workers were hired for the campaign season, paid with taxpayer dollars and fired after Election Day. Ohrenstein, 65, was indicted in 1987 with Democratic Sen. Howard Babbush, top Ohrenstein aide Frank Sanzillo and former Democratic senatorial candidate Joseph Montalto. The Court of Appeals ruling left them facing trial for their roles in the alleged no-show hirings. Ohrenstein's lawyer, Jack Hoffinger, predicted that it would be difficult for prosecutors to prove the four employees did no work or that Ohrenstein knew if they did no work. ``The so-called no-shows were put in to dress up the indictment,'' Hoffinger said. ``This is not a victory for the prosecution. If you think it is, ask the prosecution.'' Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau, who had asked the Court of Appeals to reinstate all the charges, said in a statement that he would pursue the no-show charges ``as promptly as possible.'' It was not immediately clear when a trial would begin. Ohrenstein faces a maximum of seven years in prison for each of about 50 charges remaining, Morgenthau spokesman Gerald McKelvey said. Ohrenstein, a senator since 1961, and Babbush would also lose their Senate seats if convicted of the felonies. Two weeks after Ohrenstein revealed that he was under investigation, the state Legislature passed a resolution authorizing legislative staffers to engage in political activity as long as they had some official legislative duties and performed them. Democratic and Republican leaders in the state Legislature had united behind Ohrenstein and had asked the court to drop the charges. Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat, called Tuesday's decision ``well reasoned.'' Ohrenstein again failed to take control of the state Senate this year and lost a seat to the Republicans.

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Extinguish Storage Tank Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The two ...' to CLARIFY that four tanks caught fire.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotoDX2
DOC.TEXT: A huge jet fuel fire that burned unchecked for two days near Stapleton International Airport was extinguished Tuesday with help from a team of specialists flown in from Texas. Mounting an all-out assault, firefighters put out the blazes in two storage tanks about 2:30 p.m., 53 hours after the fire began, said Fire Department spokesman Mike McNeil. ``Everybody is relieved. It's been a long ordeal,'' McNeil said. ``There were a lot of smiles on a lot of faces.'' A five-man team from Williams, Boots & Coots of Port Neches, Texas, donned fireproof suits and sealed broken valves on an 800,000-gallon tank that was one-third to one-half full of jet fuel and a 350,000-gallon tank that had only a fraction of fuel left. The two tanks had been on fire since Monday. They were ignited by a pair of 400,000-gallon tanks that burned themselves out Monday. The four tanks, containing more than 2 million gallons of jet fuel, were part of a fuel storage farm for Stapleton airport that includes 12 tanks holding a total of about 5 million gallons of fuel. The storage area is about one-half mile north of the Stapleton terminal. Several water and foam sprays were trained on the two still-burning tanks to cool them down so the team could move close enough to spray the leaking valves with potassium bicarbonate. McNeil said the blasts of foam and water worked better than expected - they extinguished the flames. Denver fire officials had planned to let the fire burn itself out, but they changed their strategy Tuesday after a meeting with Williams, Boots & Coots executives. Continental Airlines, which owns four tanks at the fuel storage area, had flown in the company officials Monday night. ``We have $3.8 million worth of product on-site,'' said Continental spokesman Jim Monaghan. The fire diminished markedly in intensity after the 400,000-gallon tanks finally burned themselves out Monday, leaving smoldering, crumpled metal shells. All four storage tanks destroyed in the fire belong to United Airlines. The airline experienced a severe fuel shortage Sunday that caused it to delay and reschedule flights, but resolved the problem Monday by employing tanker trucks and flying in fuel from outside Denver. A snowstorm that dusted Denver with up to 2 inches of snow dropped temperatures below freezing and further hampered the efforts of more than 60 firefighters Tuesday morning. The snowstorm temporarily knocked out firefighters' pumps and froze water on their clothing and equipment. Warming tents were set up for the firefighters, who took turns on the fire line. The snow later ended and the sun came out, but temperatures did not rise much above freezing. A broken valve on one of the 400,000-gallon tanks was thought to be what triggered the fire.

DOC.HEAD: Qian Says China Won't Vote for Force Resolution
With AM-Gulf-UN
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Qian Qichen said Wednesday China will not vote for a United Nations resolution authorizing use of force to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait. He refused to say whether China will veto it or abstain. As one of the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council, China has veto power over any resolution. It has voted for all 10 previous resolutions that seek to pressure Iraq to end its nearly 4-month-old occupation of Kuwait, but has expressed great reluctance to see force used. ``It has always been the position of China to call for a peaceful settlement,'' Qian told reporters at the Beijing airport while preparing to leave for the United States to cast China's vote. Qian said reports in the United States that China will support the force resolution have ``no basis.'' Asked if he meant China will not vote for the resolution, Qian said, ``I think so.'' Asked specifically it he planned to veto, he replied, ``I have not said so,'' then added, ``I think you will know after I cast the vote. I will not say anything beforethen.'' He may plan to press Washington for concessions before agreeing to abstain. Qian said he will meet with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Wednesday night before Thursday's U.N. Security Council session. Among concessions he may seek, China wants the United States to allow the World Bank to resume normal lending to China, and to lift remaining sanctions imposed after China's June 1989 army attack on pro-democracy protesters. Qian's visit will be the first official visit by a Chinese minister since then.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet: Iraq to be Given Jan. 15 Deadline by U.N. to Leave Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with eight grafs to UPDATE with China saying it will not vote for U.N. resolution, details, quotes. Picks up 6th pvs `The measure...' with minor editing thereafter to conform
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA3, CSB1
DOC.TEXT: Iraq will have less than seven weeks to withdraw nearly a half-million troops from Kuwait before it faces the prospect of a U.N.-authorized military strike, the Soviet ambassador to the United Nations said Tuesday. Ambassador Yuli M. Vorontsov said the U.N. demand for withdrawal would specify Jan. 15 as the date for the Iraqi forces that overran Kuwait 3{ months ago to leave the emirate. Vorontsov said there was a consensus among the five permanent members of the Security Council on the resolution. But Foreign Minister Qian Qichen said Wednesday at Beijing's airport that China will not vote for a U.N. resolution authorizing use of force to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait. He refused to say whether China will veto it or abstain. Meanwhile, three Americans waving Iraqi and American flags arrived in Jordan after being freed by Iraq's leader, Saddam Hussein. And in Saudi Arabia, where the multitude of U.S. troops are based facing off against Iraq, the first rain of the two-month rainy season fell in the north, filling jeep tracks with puddles and forcing Arab forces allied with the West to bundle up against the unfamiliar dampness. U.S. boxing great Muhammad Ali met for 50 minutes Tuesday with Saddam in Baghdad and was promised that a number of Americans held hostage in Iraq would be freed at an unspecified date. Ali said he wouldn't leave Iraq until he is handed over some hostages held as ``human shields'' against possible attack. As one of the permanent U.N. Security Council members, China has veto power over any resolution. It has voted for all 10 previous resolutions that seek to pressure Iraq to end its occupation of Kuwait, but has expressed great reluctance to see force used. ``It has always been the position of China to call for a peaceful settlement,'' Qian told reporters at the airport while preparing to leave for the United States to cast China's vote. The measure, to authorize ``all necessary means'' to get Iraq out of Kuwait after that date, is to be voted on Thursday. The deadline for an Iraqi withdrawal had been the only sticking point in a draft U.N. Security Council resolution. In a fresh sign that the Baghdad government is bracing for war, the Pentagon said Iraq is rapidly increasing its troop strength in Kuwait and southern Iraq. It said Iraq has 450,000 troops in the region, an increase of 20,000 over last week. The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, meanwhile, questioned whether it is really in the ``vital interest'' of the United States to use military force to liberate Kuwait, which Iraq seized on Aug. 2. Some of the freed Americans, whose families had traveled to Iraq to plead with Saddam for their release, told reporters at the Amman airport that the Bush administration had ignored their plight. ``I was not released with help from my government,'' said John Stevenson of Panama City, Fla. ``It was my family who did it.'' The United States has demanded the unconditional release of all of the hundreds of foreigners held hostage in Iraq, and the State Department has discouraged private hostage-freeing missions. Another freed American, Clyde Jesse of Buffalo Grove, Ill., suggested the United States should negotiate with Saddam. ``I believe it is time we started talking,'' he said. The third freed American was Fred Harrington of Bellevue, Wash. Ten Britons and five Germans were released as well. The women in the British group carried flowers; the Americans waved the U.S. and Iraqi flags. At the United Nations, the stage was set for a Security Council meeting to consider the strongest measure yet against Iraq. The resolution calls on Iraq to release all foreign hostages, withdraw its troops and restore Kuwait's government or face imminent action by U.N.-authorized multinational forces. Western diplomats speaking on condition of anonymity said Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze had settled on Jan. 15 as the deadline for an Iraqi withdrawal. Britain and the United States had favored Jan. 1, but had said the question was open to negotiations. The United States had already secured the backing of the other permanent members of the Security Council for the measure. The permanent members - the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France as well as China - have the power to veto council resolutions. Altogether, nine votes on the 15-member council are need to approve the resolution. It is supported by at least six of the non-permanent council members: Canada, Finland, Romania, Ivory Coast, Zaire and Ethiopia. Yemen, the council's only Arab member, is believed likely to abstain or vote against it. Malaysia and Colombia's votes are uncertain. Colombian foreign minister Luis Jaramillo said Tuesday that Colombia still has not decided how to vote, but would prefer a diplomatic solution. Cuban Ambassador Ricardo Alarcon has said his country could not support the resolution. The Soviet Union sent a high-ranking envoy to Cuba, a longtime client state, for talks on Tuesday in advance of the vote. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev also held talks Tuesday in Moscow with Saudi Arabia's foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, and said both sides agreed the U.N. measure would promote a ``just resolution'' of the gulf crisis. In Washington, the Senate Armed Services Committee opened four days of hearings on President Bush's gulf policy. The hearings were prompted by Bush's decision earlier this month to send more troops and build an ``offensive military option'' with a force that will total about 430,000 in the region by January. The panel's chairman, Sam Nunn, said the buildup raises serious questions. ``Is it in our vital interest to liberate Kuwait? How long can we sustain more than 400,000 troops? Has President Bush limited his options by creating a use-it-or-lose-it situation?'' the Georgia Democrat asked. ``It is not enough for President Bush to go to the United Nations to get approval for the use of military force in the Persian Gulf,'' said Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., a member of the committee. ``He must also come to Congress.'' Pentagon pokesman Pete Williams, outlining new U.S. estimates of Iraqi troop strength, said half of Iraq's estimated 450,000 troops in the theater of operations - southern Iraq and Kuwait - are inside Kuwait itself. The troops are mainly defensive in nature, but ``have the ability to go on the offensive'' if necessary, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Books About Freed Slave, Banking Family Win Book Award Competition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with comment from winners; EDITS to tighten. Pick up 14th graf, `The National ...'
DOC.TEXT: Historical novel ``Middle Passage,'' which chronicles the journey of a freed African slave returning to his homeland, won the 1990 National Book Award competition for fiction Tuesday night. Charles Johnson wrote the book, which takes place in 1830 and tells the story of a terrifying voyage to Africa on a clipper ship. Ron Charnow's ``The House of Morgan: An American Banking Dynasty and the Rise of Modern Finance'' won in the non-fiction category during the 40th anniversary awards dinner at the Plaza Hotel. The competition was marked by the presence of little-known writers from small publishing houses and ``acute dividedness'' among the jurors who chose them. The five fiction works that were up for consideration included three books by immigrant authors - the first novels of Jessica Hagedorn and Ilena Castedo, and the 42-year-old second book of Felipe Alfau, who is 88. Johnson, an English professor at the University of Washington who wrote two other novels and a collection of short fiction, was among two established writers in the fiction category. The other was Joyce Carol Oates. Johnson's novel, published by Atheneum, uses the freed slave's difficult trip as a catalyst for self-discovery and also marks a passage for African-American fiction. The title refers to the crossing of the Atlantic to America from Africa by slave ships. ``In this decade, we will see the emergence of black-author fiction that will help us as a people and as a culture to move from narrow complaint to broad celebration,'' said Johnson, 42. One of the fiction jurors, writer Paul West, said there was ``acute dividedness over nearly everything'' discussed by the five-member panel that chose the nominees. He charged that ``ethnic considerations, ideology and moral self-righteousness'' had prevailed over style and merit. But Sonny Mehta, president of Alfred A. Knopf publishers, said although the list of nominees was obscure, he saw nothing ``sinister'' in the choices. ``It looks as if they were looking around for books that have not had their share of praise,'' Mehta said. In the non-fiction category, the four other finalists were books about teaching, former President Nixon, artist Jackson Pollock and Roosevelt Cabinet member Harold Ickes. Chernow's winner was published by Atlantic Monthly Press-Entrekin Books. The book traces the ups and downs of the most influential family in the history of American banking. It charts the Morgan family's story and the changing relationships between financiers and companies since 1838. ``My motivation for writing the book started with my concern with what was happening in the 1980s,'' said Chernow, 41, of Brooklyn Heights. He said 19th century bankers had ``a very different notion of what business was, it was a gentlemen's club against today's wild carnival of greed.'' The National Books Foundation also honored Saul Bellow, Nobel laureate and the only three-time winner of the National Book Award. The 10 finalists came from among 375 books put forward by 72 publishers. For the first time in years, none came from such prestigious houses as Knopf; Farrar, Straus & Giroux; or Simon & Schuster. Alfau's book, ``Chromos,'' was retrieved from oblivion by Dalkey Archive Press, an Illinois publisher whose list amounts to about 15 titles a year and whose biggest seller has been a novel that sold 6,000 copies. The Spanish-born Alfau had his first novel, ``Locos: A Comedy of Gestures,'' published in 1936. It was rediscovered and reissued last year by Dalkey. When the publisher asked whether Alfau had written anything else, he came up with ``Chromos,'' which he finished in 1948. Castedo's ``Paradise'' was published by Grove Weidenfeld and Hagedorn's ``Dogeaters'' by Pantheon, which has been warring with its parent company, Random House, over Pantheon's tradition of against-the-grain publishing. Atheneum brought out Johnson's ``Middle Passage'' and the Oates book, ``Because It Is Bitter, and Because It Is My Heart,'' came from E.P. Dutton-William Abrahams. The other non-fiction finalists were: ``Small Victories: The Real World of a Teacher, Her Students and Their High School,'' by Samuel G. Freedman. ``Richard Milhous Nixon: The Rise of an American Politician,'' by Roger Morris. ``Jackson Pollock: An American Saga,'' by Steven Naifeh and Gregory White Smith. ``Righteous Pilgrim: The Life and Times of Harold L. Ickes, 1874-1952,'' by T.H. Watkins.

The United States has won the backing of the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France for a U.N. resolution threatening to use ``all necessary means'' to drive Iraq from Kuwait if it does not leave by January. With the agreement Monday among the five permanent Security Council members, the broad coalition the United States has mustered against Saddam Hussein crossed a crucial threshold, authorizing the use of military force. There had been speculation the Soviets and Chinese might abstain on the resolution, which the 15-member council is expected to take up on Thursday. Secretary of State James A. Baker III has traveled the globe for weeks seeking support from Security Council members for the use-of-force resolution. ---= MONTERREY, Mexico (AP) - President Bush, buoyed by a cheering throng and a fireworks welcome, says Mexico and the United States are embarking on ``an era more cooperative and more prosperous'' than ever before. ``I've come to Mexico tonight with a message of respect, of admiration and hope for a brighter future shared by our two countries,'' Bush told tens of thousands packed into Heroes' Plaza outside the Governor's Palace Monday evening. ``Viva Mexico,'' Bush shouted before he and his wife viewed an elaborate fireworks demonstration from a glassed-in stage on the plaza. Bush was in Mexico on a two-day trip focused primarily on the two countries' efforts to negotiate a free trade agreement. ---= LOS ANGELES (AP) - Industry analysts say MCA Inc. - the entertainment giant that gave the world ``E.T.'' and ``Jaws'' - is so well run that its new Japanese owners will allow creative control to remain in American hands. In the biggest Japanese purchase ever of a U.S. company, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. struck a $6.6 billion deal for MCA on Monday. The Japanese maker of videocasette recorders, televisions and stereos under such brand names as Panasonic, Technics and Quasar got a company that produces hit TV shows such as ``Murder, She Wrote'' and ``Major Dad,'' records artists such as Elton John and Guns N' Roses and owns many of the biggest movies of all time. MCA became the fourth major Hollywood studio to come under foreign control, raising fears that responsiblity for the financing and political content of American entertainment is falling increasingly into non-American hands. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Former regulator Edwin Gray says financier Charles H. Keating Jr. waged a campaign to discredit him after he moved to curb risky financial practices at Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. The former Federal Home Loan Bank Board chief told the Senate Ethics Committee Monday that Keating's campaign followed ``years of private threats and public vilification'' aimed at easing federal thrift regulation. Gray was resuming testimony today before committee, which is investigating charges that five senators improperly pressured regulators to ease scrutiny of Lincoln Savings. The Irvine, Calif., institution's $2 billion collapse has been the most spectacular in the thrift industry. ---= LONDON (AP) - Two contenders apparently were neck-and-neck and the third was hoping to force a runoff in today's voting by Conservative Party legislators for Britain's next prime minister. Treasury chief John Major, 47, the chosen favorite of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, and former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine each claimed they were nearing the 187 votes needed for outright victory as party leader. But there were signs that Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd had enough support to deny either a majority of the 372 legislators in the House of Commons, forcing a final ballot on Thursday. In a third ballot, lawmakers vote for first and second choices. If no one wins a majority of the first-choice votes, the third-placed contender is eliminated and his second-choice votes are distributed to determine a winner. ---= SANTIAGO, Chile (AP) - Former President Augusto Pinochet still is the army commander, but has been losing political ground to Patricio Aylwin, the elected civilian who succeeded him. Even right-wing politicians who supported the 74-year-old general during his 16{ years of military rule, which ended in March, are saying he should stay out of politics. The annual revision of the armed forces high command this month gave Aylwin the opportunity for a clear demonstration of his political authority. For the first time since the political coup that brought him to power in 1973, the makeup of the high command was not determined by Pinochet alone. ---= COLDWATER, Mich. (AP) - The chatter resembles that of any beauty salon. Women tease each other about their ages and their graying hair as they sit under hair dryers and flip through timeworn magazines. Posters of the latest hairstyles cover the battered walls, and the pungent odor of the solution used for permanents fills the air. The tools of the beauty trade at the medium-security Florence-Crane Women's Facility are nothing special, but they're of some concern. Scissors, electric razors and chemicals can be dangerous - especially in the hands of convicted criminals. Some of these women are locked up for life. Some can receive no visitors. Inmates say the prison beauty shop serves an essential purpose. In the words of beautician Diane Carter, ``Everyone feels better, even if they've had a bad day.'' She's serving 20 years on drug and escape charges.

DOC.HEAD: Free-thinking Massachussetts Town Devises A New-Age Master Plan
DOC.TEXT: The more things change, the more this tiny town wants to remain the same. That means the kind of place where people live in old school buses or build homes as the spirt moves them. A place where the town building inspector can take a six-month leave of absence to help a peace group build a school in El Salvador. Where volunteers give away bread on Fridays. Where most of the roads are dirt. Where most of the residents like them that way. ``This is a town of rugged individualists who came here because we wanted to be free to be ourselves,'' said Prudence Smith, a member of the five-person town planning board. And so they are, a happy melange of young and old, of machinists and musicians, college professors and farmers, sewage workers and aging hippies. Isolated and poor, with no services to speak of and no intention of adding any, Wendell has always attracted its share of truthseekers. Mormon Hollow, marked by a tiny cemetery on the north side of town, is named for travelers who left a 19th-century religious caravan and settled here. In the 1960s and 1970s, Wendell became a haven for back-to-the-landers and flower children from the University of Massachusetts and the other colleges clustered around Amherst, 30 miles away. ``Not only are some of my best friends hippies, but some of our best selectmen have been hippies,'' said Selectman Ted Lewis, not a hippie himself. But Wendell appeared to be falling victim to its own popularity, with the population more than doubling to 830 in 20 years. The problem facing children of the '60s in the 1990s was how they could all stay in Wendell and still retain the town spirit that attracted them there in the first place. ``For a long time, our poverty and isolation protected us, but no longer,'' Smith said. ``The cost of living, even here, has increased to the point where it is becoming difficult for a lot of people.'' So townsfolk held a seven-hour ``visioning workshop'' in which they wrote down, illustrated and debated things the town could use, such as a tool collective to share such homeowner necessities as mowers, chainsaws, grass clippers and ladders. They drew up lists of ``Places of the Heart,'' or landmarks, they wanted to protect, ranging from the Town Common to a heron rookery. Some changes came quickly. A volunteer committee, called the ``Star Riders,'' was formed to offer others rides into town, the result of a discussion about the lack of public transit. With a $20,000 state grant, residents hired a small, local consulting firm to help draw up a master plan, the centerpiece of which is the proposed ``Wendell Works'' - a town-sponsored commercial organic farm and spinoff cottage industries. In a typically casual way, there is no estimated time of completion. ``People don't have much opportunity to spend money in Wendell,'' said Smith, noting that the town's commercial development is limited to two general stores, an egg farm and an auto salvage yard. The fruit and vegetables produced by the farm could be sold by subscription to residents, who would pay in advance for a share of the crop when it ripened, she said. Wendellites want to expand the operation beyond produce into baked goods, milk deliveries, firewood sales and other farm-related businesses. ``It wouldn't add a lot of property to the tax rolls,'' Smith said. ``But if we had a soy dairy that would just satisfy the town's own needs, it would be a way to recycle Wendell money in Wendell and make it easier for individuals to come up with the cash flow they need to make it here.'' And it would fit Wendell's tradition of doing its own thing. This, after all, is a town that boasts its own troupe of African dancers and drummers, and a centrally located Free Box where residents are encouraged to take what they need and leave what they can spare. Once a month, Town Hall becomes the Full Moon Coffeehouse for performances benefiting causes from tax resistance to a group that opposed state surveillance flights to ferret out marijuana growers. All this doesn't necessarily make an impression on folks who grew up in Wendell. ``There's nothing new with the younger people,'' said Raymond Avery, a 72-year-old native. ``Actually, they have less sense of individuality than the older folks.''

DOC.HEAD: Brad Dourif's Horror-Filled Career
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The 1990s may be a true horror story for actor Brad Dourif, who currently appears in no less than four spooky films. The coincidence of so many chilling movies shines light on the darker side of his career. And here's a guy who cringes at fright films. ``I get real scared,'' he confesses. ``I never watched horror pictures when I was growing up. I have a daughter, Christina, who loves horror films. She brings them home and watches them in our living room. I'm sitting there with pillows over my head, and she's sitting there stonefaced. She just absorbs them somehow without flinching.'' November was kind of a Brad Dourif Film Festival month with the release of ``The Exorcist III,'' ``Stephen King's Graveyard Shift,'' ``Child's Play 2'' and ``Grim Prairie Tales.'' In addition, Dourif was seen playing ``a weasel'' in ``Sonny Boy,'' a drama that came and went in a wink. Not so ``The Exorcist'' and ``Child's Play'' sequels, which landed No. 1 on the box-office list. ``Grim Prairie Tales'' was a bomb. The actor commented on the films during a recent interview. -``Graveyard Shift'': ``It was fun. I went down and shot little scenes for two weeks and then returned in summer and shot one day of a big scene. I was working in two other movies at the same time. I was doing `Chaindance' most of the time. When I got a break, I went to Toronto for a film called `Murder Blues.' ``I met Stephen King once. I was trying to pick out some breakfast cereal and all of a sudden this hand came in and a voice said, `Hi. Steve King. Like your acting.' I shook the hand, looked up and he was gone.'' -``The Exorcist III'': ``I was an extremely nasty guy (he plays the devil). People don't come much nastier than that guy. The fun thing about that character was that he really enjoyed his work. It was the most intelligently written part of the horror genre that I have read. (William Peter) Blatty is a wonderful writer.'' -``Child's Play 2'' (as the voice of Chuckie, the evil doll): ``That is what I call my generic Bad Guy from the North voice. I do it off the top of my head without any effort at all. When I think, `What does a bad guy from the North sound like?' Chuckie comes out.'' -``Grim Prairie Tales'': ``It's sort of a horror film, but I don't play a crazy person.'' He and James Earl Jones sit around a frontier campfire and spin yarns of terror. Why do producers of horror pictures think of Brad Dourif? ``Well, I started my career in `One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest' as a kind of crazy guy,'' the actor said. ``Now we're in an era of horror films. That's a field day for actors who can do crazy people. Of course, they're going to think of me - `Get Brad. He does this kind of thing.''' Dourif, 40, spent his early years in Huntington, W.Va, and two movies had a profound impact on him during his youth. ``I went through a very difficult time when I was young,'' he recalled. ``My father died when I was 3, and I went through a period of adjusting to a stepfather. My way of dealing with it as a child was to kind of escape into a dream world. I had a horrible time in school because I was always staring out the window. ``I saw two films with my grandmother. One of them was `The Red Balloon,' the other was `The Bicycle Thief.' These films really had an impact on me. They dealt with problems I was going through. The problem of adjusting was in `The Red Balloon.' The world was against this kid, but he has something about him, the red balloon. ``Then there was the father-son relationship in `The Bicycle Thief.' I learned I wasn't alone. I connected bigtime with them. That was the moment when I wanted to have something to do with film.'' In 1973, director Milos Forman saw Dourif in the play ``When You Coming Home, Red Ryder?'' in New York and cast him as the tragic Billy Bibbit in ``Cuckoo's Nest.'' That resulted in an Academy Award nomination as supporting actor and a host of offers. Forman cast him as the younger brother in ``Ragtime.'' Other films have included ``Eyes of Laura Mars,'' ``Wise Blood'' ``Heaven's Gate'' and ``Mississippi Burning.'' ``It would be lovely to say that I made a wise choice by choosing to play character parts,'' he commented. ``But let's face it, all the money and all the screen time is in playing leading men. You get the girl, you get more time on the screen and they pay you more. Of course I would prefer that. ``On the other hand, if you show people you can play all kinds of parts, your career is going to last longer.''
