DOC.HEAD: NBC Reporter Dies - But Survives
DOC.TEXT: Three years ago, Jay Barbree, a space reporter who has covered more than 60 manned launches in his 32 years with NBC, went for a run along the beach near his home in Cocoa Beach, Fla. It almost was his last. He collapsed and suffered what doctors call ``sudden cardiac death.'' He had no pulse for five minutes. Only quick action by neighbors and paramedics saved him. Frightening, but a blessing in disguise. Had it not happened, he says, odds are that he wouldn't have learned he needed a coronary bypass operation. A few years later, he could have had a definitely fatal heart attack. ``Me dropping dead on the beach is what saved my life. That's a hell of a thing to say, but that's it,'' said Barbree, who has written a just-published book about his experience, ``The Day I Died.'' Now 56, Barbree, the son of a Georgia farmer, had done his best to avoid such an attack. Aware that the men of his family had a history of heart problems, he had quit smoking 11 years earlier, watched his cholesterol count, avoided high-salt foods, and exercised regularly - all that good stuff. ``The scary thing about it is that there was no warning,'' he said. ``I was always convinced when I was jogging that if I overdid it, I'd have pain in my chest, something that said, `Hey, Jay, slow down.' ``But there's a hormone - I forget its name - that protects you against pain, and you get what's known as a runner's high. It's like a drug. ... You get addicted to it.'' In retrospect, ``I was a big idiot, down there running like mad on the beach. It put a bigger demand on my coronary arteries to deliver blood to the (heart) organ than they could sustain.'' The arteries were partly blocked by plaque, he said. He suffered the attack - a ventricular fibrillation - due to their condition. ``It's like a clogged fuel line,'' he said. ``You can have a perfect engine, but if it can't get fuel, it's going to quit.'' After a period of recuperation, reflection and what is known as a PETscan, an electronic test designed to detect heart disease in its earliest stages, Barbree agreed to coronary bypass surgery. It was done this month last year. He didn't lay about afterwards, though. Although his work was extremely limited and done at home, ``I was back on the air within 30 days,'' said Barbree, who has covered the nation's manned space launches since Alan Shepard's first suborbital shot in 1961. Now, he's back at full power, still covering space matters for NBC News and the NBC radio network. He also occasionally reports for some NBC-owned stations and the network's affiliates. Coming close to final checkout time tends to make a man think differently about things. Barbree is no exception. Now living in a new home 10 minutes from Cape Canaveral, he doesn't jog anymore. But ``I walk briskly now. ... Old Harry Truman was right. You get out there and walk.'' Another change: ``Before I `died,' I was for capital punishment, the death penalty. Now I'm against it. I sort of figure that death is God's business. Now, no matter how brutal a crime a man or woman commits, I simply feel he or she should be locked up forever.'' Another: ``Even though I have a black belt in aikido'' - a Japanese system of self-defense - ``I don't think I can hurt anybody now. But I still have a temper I'm trying to get under control.'' And perhaps the most important: ``I really appreciate my family, my friends, people I'm close to, now. I just feel closer, more concerned for them, than I ever did before.'' --- Elsewhere in television ... LIGHTS, CAMERA, OPENING STATEMENTS: With the planned merger of two cable services devoted to the living law, there's going to be a whole lot more than Judge Wapner on the tube next year. The merged services, In Court and American Courtroom Network, will start life next summer as the Courtroom Television Network. Meanwhile, CBS is considering a half-hour real-court series, ``On Trial,'' and NBC is pondering a daytime series called ``Trialwatch.'' All this is in addition to NBC's ``L.A. Law,'' ``Night Court'' and ``Law and Order,'' ABC's ``Gabriel's Fire,'' and CBS' ``The Trials of Rosie O'Neill.'' But they, of course, are only make-believe.

DOC.HEAD: Shortages May Bring Long, Dark Winter to Bulgaria
DOC.TEXT: The pattern of electricity supply is two hours on, two off, and Sofia is even running out of matches, candles and kerosene. The periodic darkness and prospects of a cold, hard winter are symptomatic of Bulgaria's worst economic and political crisis. The governing Socialists, formerly the Communists, are locked with the opposition in an increasingly hostile debate over how to run the country. Dimitar Sokolov, deputy chairman of the Committee for Power Generation, indicated the electricity supply may be erratic even if Bulgaria's crippled nuclear plant is repaired and brought back into normal service. Oil for heating also is a question mark. Unless Soviet crude oil deliveries are made as expected, ``the whole district heating system would be in danger,'' he said. Sokolov said heating in Sofia is provided exclusively by oil-fired plants, and oil storage facilities depots are only one-third full. Moscow has supplied most of Eastern Europe's oil for years, but the Soviets are missing deliveries because of their own economic problems. Four Soviet 440-megawatt reactors and a 1,000-megawatt reactor at Bulgaria's only nuclear power station, on the Danube River at Kozlodui, provide 30 percent of Bulgaria's electricity. The 1,000-megawatt reactor went down at the end of October for the second time in four months because of a mechanical problem. Another 1,000-megawatt reactor is scheduled to go on stream in mid-January, increasing the country's power supply by 10 percent, but whether it will is uncertain. Hospitals, government offices, other public institutions, industrial enterprises and food shops are exempt from the the power cuts, Sokolov said, but the government has imposed power restrictions on industry. Stores can operate during the daylight hours, but when the power is off they close between 5 p.m. and 6 p.m., the time most workers could do their shopping. Reporters recently happened into a basement restaurant where employees were huddled around a kerosene lamp waiting for the lights to go on. They did, and revealed 15 or 20 other customers waiting in the dark. Premier Andrei Lukanov, one of a group that ousted hard-line Communist leader Todor Zhivkov a year ago, is urging opposition legislators to support his plans for market reform. His critics say Lukanov has exhausted his credit with the public during a year of economic deterioration. They demand the resignation of his government, and are supported by growing numbers of protesters. While they wait for something to be done, daily life becomes more difficult for Bulgaria's 9 million people. ``You have to adapt to the situation as best you can, but people are growing ever more nervous,'' said Valery Lazov, a Sofia taxi driver. ``People these days seem to think only about all the items that won't be available in the shops tomorrow. Breakfast for our third-grade daughter has to be prepared the day before because there is no light in the morning.'' Lazov added, however, that he was better off than many others because he has ``a storage battery to operate the radio, and I have a lamp from the car.'' He said some people he knew didn't even have candles. Matches are at a premium. Elitsa Velichkova, a 16-year old Sofia high school student, said her family was ``very angry because there is no television'' and had ``run out of kerosene for the lamp.'' Sokolov belittled the technical and personnel problems at the Kozlodui nuclear plant, where experts from the International Atomic Energy Agency have been reviewing technical and safety conditions. In a recent letter, Kozlodui employees warned of inadequate safety precautions and lack of expert personnel for the new 1,000-megawatt reactor. Sokolov said of the letter: ``We did have enough personnel by the time the letter arrived, but they had to take exams, and most of them have done so in the meantime.'' Nearly a dozen specialists from the Soviet Union were flown in to help out for several months, he said. An official at the nuclear agency's headquarters in Vienna, speaking anonymously, indicated the small Soviet-made reactors were outdated and practically impossible to modernize. ``It's like trying to build high tech into an old truck,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Jews, Haunted by Babylon, Fear War
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Tawfic Sofer, a retired cloth merchant and caretaker of Baghdad's main synagogue, peered through the makeshift peephole of an iron gate 10 feet high. When ordered by two government officials, from State Security and the Information Ministry, the 65-year-old Iraqi Jew unlocked the gate and swung it open. ``Welcome, welcome,'' he said several times in Arabic, his eyes on the cars parked outside. Satisfied that the officials were alone, except for a foreign reporter, he guided the group to the synagogue. President Saddam Hussein's government sometimes allows visits by Western news media to the synagogue in downtown Baghdad, but requires Iraqi officials to accompany them for ``security reasons'' that are not explained. Reporters are discouraged from visiting the synagogue on the Jewish Sabbath, which runs from sundown Friday to sundown Saturday. Reminders of Saddam are omnipresent in Iraq, and the synagogue is no exception. His portrait is on two calendars that hang on the wall at the entrance. The square, white two-story synagogue was built in 1942 in the middle of a bazaar. Its walls are covered with Scriptures written in Hebrew and there are many shelves of old books. The synagogue's Torah scrolls, the handwritten five books of Moses that form the foundation of the Jewish faith, are on a raised platform, concealed by a black and gold curtain. ``It is a very rich collection,'' said Sofer, a bachelor who gave up his business to tend the synagogue after the last caretaker died two years ago. ``We are fine and we do not want war. We are a very small community, but we are surviving.'' About 600 Jews live in Baghdad, 200 more in the port city of Basra, 100 in the northern city of Mosul and 100 or so in other areas of Iraq, he said. Iraq had a flourishing Jewish community of doctors, lawyers, professors and businessmen with 65 synagogues when Iraq gained political independence from Britain in 1932. Only two synagogues still function. More than 120,000 Iraqi Jews moved to Israel soon after the Jewish state was born in 1948. Sofer said his ancestors and those of most Iraqi Jews came to Baghdad from Babylon centuries ago. More than 2,500 years ago, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon conquered Jerusalem and carried the captive Children of Israel back to the land between the Tigris and the Euphrates rivers. Saddam often is compared with Nebuchadnezzar in the Baghdad of today. Iraqi officials describe the Jews of Babylon as an ancient Fifth Column who helped Persian invaders take the city. According to the oft-told story, which does not appear in the Bible, the Babylonian Jews advised King Cyrus to destroy dams on the Euphrates, thus lowering water levels in moats around the city so his troops could enter. ``We do have problems,'' Sofer said of Baghdad's remaining Jews. He paused, looked at the Iraqi officials and continued: ``Our problems are marriages. We don't have enough young men to marry. We have at least 25 girls ready to marry, but there are not enough eligible men.'' Sofer said Iraqi Jews hav only one shohet, the butcher who slaughters animals and prepares the meat according to ancient Jewish law. ``It is a big problem, but we are trying to solve it,'' Sofer said. ``He has to work overtime. There is no other way. When he is sick, we have a major problem.'' ``We are very lucky'' that two rabbis serve Baghdad, he said. Like all Iraqis interviewed, of whatever faith, Sofer would not say if people live in fear of Saddam. When asked whether he feared persecution if the U.S.-led multinational force in Saudi Arabia attacked in an effort to force Iraq out of Kuwait, he said: ``We pray there is no war.'' ``The people here do not trust us, but we are not bothered. But if there is war, we may face problems.'' Sofer refused to elaborate. Iraq, a predominantly Moslem country, denies any persecution of Jews. ``We have Jewish people studying in university,'' said an Information Ministry official, who cannot be named under government regulations. ``They are also in business.'' He said Jewish businessmen, like their Moslem counterparts, were free to travel outside Iraq. Saddam's government, however, carries on a regular propaganda program to ``expose the Zionist movement's imperialist goals.''

DOC.HEAD: Say Something Nice About Recession
DOC.TEXT: Though you might never guess it from the way they are described, recessions aren't all bad, any more than Michael Milken is totally greedy or completely charitable. Recessions put stocks on sale, making them available to ew buyers. They allow housing prices to drop into the range of folks who have waited for years to fulfill their dream. They tend to bring inflation down. In contrast, expansions generally are praised, though they sometimes lead to inefficient buying and selling practices, deterioration of quality, poor service, inflation, irresponsible borrowing habits and the like. Experience has demonstrated, in fact, that some of the nation's worst economic problems were generated by expansions and corrected by contractions, a dramatic example of which is the nation's nagging imbalance of trade. Year after year during the long expansion of the 1980s Americans imported far more than they exported. The economy was strong, and one consequence of that strength was the ability and desire to own foreign manufactured goods. It cost Americans jobs, and it cost them the ownership of part of their country, since the dollars sent abroad were sent back by foreigners to buy American companies and commercial real estate. Now that problem is being addressed, thanks to the slowdown and the threat of recession. Americans are watching their dollars. They are importing less. And faced with a domestic downturn, domestic businesses have improved exports. Despite sharply higher prices for imported oil, overall imports fell 2.4 percent in September. Meanwhile, exports have been rising. If you exclude oil, the deficit rate has been nearly halved since 1987, when the economy faltered. This corrective ability seldom wins accolades for recessions, just as bad colds that force overactive people to bed are usually damned for the postnasal drip rather than praised for the enforced rest that avoids a worse breakdown. Recessions, it is true, inevitably mean layoffs, plant closings, lowered profits, dividend cuts and lowered tax revenues. They can cause a great deal of pain to a great many people, especially if they persist for a year or more. They seldom do. Since World War II, there have been eight economic recessions, but only two lasted more than a year - from November 1973 through March 1974, and from July 1981 through November 1982. The recession of 1980 lasted a mere seven months, and that of 1957-1958 just nine months. Two lasted 11 months and two persisted for a year. But in each instance they also set the stage for healthier economic expansion, reflected in job creation, new plants, higher profits, better real wages, stronger securities and revenue increases. They rearranged the competitive marketplace, routing out poor products and poorly managed companies, encouraging competition, creativity and improved productivity, and discouraging waste of human resources, money, time and opportunity. To an extent, they routed out frivolous activities and expenditures and re-established more sensible priorities. All recessions hurt, but they also give opportunity - to prudent folks who saved their money to buy a house, or who seek a good investment. And they offer relief to the millions of people whose variable-rate loans had become onerous. A recession will always be viewed as an unwelcome guest or even as the enemy who seeks to do us in. But the real rascal is the excess produced by the preceding expansion. Recessions seek to correct those problems. In that sense, recessions are really the launching pads for the good days to follow.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Wednesday, Nov. 28

DOC.HEAD: The Suburbs: Great for Some Families, But Not for These Urban Advocates
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Quitting the City
DOC.TEXT: The Curatolas owned a fixer-upper with a romantic wraparound porch. They had a jeep-style car with the requisite two kids in back, summer barbecues for friends, and chirping crickets to serenade them at night. It was a suburban dream, and the New York couple hated it. ``We had all these ideals about what we wanted in a home,'' said Gerry Curatola. ``Rolling hills and country roads, lots of acreage. It was very romantic ... but it wasn't reality. The suburbs weren't home.'' Many middle-class families have chosen to move away from Manhattan, where violence is on the rise and everything else often seems in decline. But for the Curatolas, the city was home - crime, dirt, noise and all. ``The most important element of anywhere you live is time together as a family,'' Curatola, a dentist, said recently. ``That's the important priority - not commuting, fixing the house, doing this or doing that.'' Curatola and his wife, Georgia, moved back into the city last spring after fewer than four years in their Westchester County dream house. They couldn't take the ``good life'' any longer. For every leisurely weekend in their backyard, Gerry had at least 10 new 1{-hour commutes notched on his briefcase. For every pleasant morning with her husband, Georgia endured many long, lonely afternoons. ``I think women in particular are very affected by a move like that,'' said Mrs. Curatola, whose young daughter and son provided her some relief. ``I don't play tennis and I don't do clubs.'' Without those suburban mainstays, she said, the isolation sometimes was overwhelming. Her days were taken up in solitary journeys to the market, the dry cleaners, to her 6-year-old daughter's school. On the Upper West Side of Manhattan, where the couple now lives, neighbors meet on the elevator. Standing in line at the bank or at the deli, there's always something to joke about. Central Park is the family's backyard. The Curatolas know the streets are dangerous and that the public schools are a mess. But they also know Fifth Avenue's Christmas lights, the Guggenheim Museum's art and Carnegie Hall's music. There's nothing like Little Italy's pasta or the charm of Greenwich Village on a blustery fall day. The Curatolas want their children to experience the city's wonderful mishmash of ethnicities and eccentricities - the very things the Mitzners miss. Barbara and Marvin Mitzner, both 44, had their child in mind when they moved to the New York suburb of Pound Ridge six years ago. ``We thought the school systems were so excellent. But they aren't what they're pumped up to be,'' said Mrs. Mitzner, whose 5{-year-old daughter is attending private school. ``The local kindergarten was appalling.'' The unsatisfactory schools wouldn't be so bad on their own, Mrs. Mitzner said. But add in the many meals her huband arrives home too late to share, the perpetual home repairs, aloof neighbors, the driving everywhere all the time. ``Pound Ridge is ... a lovely, lovely place. But it isn't all it's cracked up to be, particularly for a couple that has grown up with the excitement of city life,'' said Marvin Mitzner, a partner at the New York law firm of Davidoff & Malido. ``Getting out of the city didn't turn out to be what we thought it might,'' he said, adding that a lot of his friends shared similar feelings. There are no statistics on the number of families abandoning the suburbs. But the Mitzners, who have put their home on the market, are among a group of suburbanites disillusioned by their experience. Demographers predicted two decades ago that the baby boomers would choose either rural or urban lifestyles. This rebellious generation, sociologists theorized, would settle anywhere but in the suburbs where they were raised. The experts were wrong. When working couples started families in the 1980s, many of those who could afford to opted for the suburbs as a practical compromise between city and country living. It's a forumula that hasn't worked for everyone. ``We were making enough money where we wanted to make an investment,'' said Deborah Hassan, who with her husband chose the the New York suburb of Scarsdale, where the median home price is $535,000. ``Within a month after we moved out there, our neighbors put up a fence. It felt so isolated.'' Before the year was out, the Hassans and their 3-year-old daughter were back in Manhattan. ``It's not easy living in the city with a kid,'' said Mrs. Hassan, who works part time at American Express. ``But I have this feeling about the city,'' she said. ``There's always someone in the park for my daughter to play with.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon AMs, Dec. 3
$Adv03
For release Mon AMs, Dec. 3, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Enough is Enough: Young Urban Couples Abandon the New York State of Mind
With AM-Quitting Suburbia
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Glenn Fishman and his wife, Joanne Wallenstein, wanted to stick it out in New York. But the city wore them down. Their car was broken into eight times in 12 months. They were mugged, hassled by homeless beggars, frightened on the subway at night. They didn't want to witness the final urban terror: murder. More than a home, the couple and their two young children finally sought a haven here, in this gabled suburb about 40 minutes from New York by train. ``We feel bad abandoning the city,'' said Fishman, a researcher at Albert Einstein College of Medicine. ``But the problems seem to be growing at such a clip that a lot of people ... are finding it's a good time to make a move.'' Added his wife, Joanne: ``It's sad for the city.'' There is much for the city to mourn. Statistics usually reserved for Harlem and Flatbush are touching ``safe'' neighborhoods. It is more difficult for people to ignore the violence, step over the many beggars in their path. New York's welfare caseload numbers 830,000 - greater than the population of all but America's 10 largest cities. Someone is robbed every six minutes and an average of 366 cars are stolen daily. Among the subway users, about 200,000 jump the turnstiles and ride free each day. ``Violence is reaching people it never reached before,'' said Ellen Kaidanow, 30, an executive recruiter for The Gap Inc. ``It used to be that there were certain parts of Manhattan where you felt relatively safe,'' said Mrs. Kaidanow, who is looking for a suburban home where she and her husband can start a family. ``Now the violence could be anywhere.'' It is this sense of randomness that drives many couples back to the secure, relatively quiet suburban lifestyle they knew as children and, in many cases, swore off as young adults. The U.S. Census Bureau doesn't break down New York metropolitan area migration, but suburban real estate agents say that weary urban couples looking for a change lately have given their slumping market a modest boost. ``Many think the city isn't getting any better and a lot ... think it's going to get worse,'' said Merritt Mitchell, president of the Westchester Multiple Listings Service. ``A lot of young couples are looking to get out.'' But along with the contents of their apartments, many ex-New Yorkers end up bringing a sense of guilt with them to the suburbs, where homes cost between $175,000 and $450,000. Their consciences suggest it would be nobler to stay and fight for the city's future. ``But you have to look at it from a standpoint of self-preservation,'' said Marc Tartell, 36, advertising director at A&W Brands Inc. ``Things felt out of control.'' As the Tartells were packing up a moving van bound for Westchester County in September, someone stole two suitcases stuffed with their children's baby clothes. The theft was a final kick in the pants, a reminder of why the longtime New Yorkers were getting out. ``I like city living. I just don't like living in New York anymore,'' said Barbara Tartell, 31, a vice president at Goldman, Sachs & Co. ``The presence of undesirable people is becoming more obvious.'' Jobless, angry, addicted young people used to hang out near the Tartell's home on the Upper West Side. Their 3-year-old son already was asking about prostitution, crack cocaine and homelessness. Their new two-story, five-bedroom colonial home is altogether different. The kids have a backyard now, trees to swing from, a street made for ``kick the can'' and neighborhood pals ready to play such games. Local taxes are higher, but the public schools in Scarsdale aren't overcrowded and underfunded like those in the city. And the $7,500 kindergarten tuition the Tartells faced in New York was anything but cheap. New suburbanites say they wish their kids could grow up with the city's energy, culture and diversity. But those things mean nothing, parents say, if their children are frightened, stressed-out, constantly on edge. ``It's a fight or flight situation,'' said Charlie Clough, an abstract artist who shares a Greenwich Village townhouse with his wife and their two young sons. ``It's palpable ... these are real bullets going by.'' Clough and his wife, Liz Trovato, started thinking about a move after a sniper opened fire at their 10-year-old son's Little League game. ``There I am, lying on the street with bullets whizzing overhead and my son freaking out,'' said Trovato, a graphic designer. ``It started us wondering whether there isn't a better way to live.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon AMs, Dec. 3

DOC.SECOND: AM-Oh Give Me a Home, Adv04,0805
DOC.NOTE: For Release Tuesday AMs Dec 4 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Muddled Housing System: Too Little or Too Much
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Zhou Lihong, seven months pregnant, has no home of her own and shares a tiny room in a company dormitory with two other wome. Her husband, who works for the same firm, lives upstairs. The company offered part of an old house that had no gas, heat or plumbing, but the young couple rejected it, gambling that a better offer would come. They have no guarantees. While the Zhous wait and hope, suitable apartments are empty. One is in the name of Yan Fields, a Chinese woman who followed her American husband to the United States four years ago, and rents for the equivalent of just $1 a month. It is too valuable to give up and her parents don't want to sublet for fear of attracting attention that might cause them to lose the apartment. Housing problems are most acute in the major cities. Officials said one-fourth of Bee. Government programs have had limited success in improving the situation. In 1988, a few cities began raising rents and selling apartments to tenants to finance construction of more housing, but the reforms have not been applied nationwide. Many local officials blocked them, unwilling to pay the higher rents or lose the power they get from assigning scarce apartments. Housing officials insist the reforms have not been abandoned. They say 30 counties and 19 cities, including parts of Beijing, Shanghai and Canton, are following the new policies on a limited scale. Nearly everyone in China has a roof over his head, but he shares it with many more people than Americans do. The average living area for a Chinese is 81 square feet, according to government figures. In the United States, says the National Association of Homebuilders, the average person has 755 square feet. A Shanghai newspaper wrote about a couple who lived in a single room with an aging father. After four years of marriage, they remained childless and the husband was convinced lack of privacy was the reason. They borrowed an apartment for five months and the wife became pregnant. Employers determine whether a young couple get their own apartment. Companies distribute housing by seniority, and both husband and wife have a chance to be assigned an apartment by their respective employers. A worker who has connections to the company housing official may get a larger apartment than he needs. Rents are so low there is no reason not to obtain as much space as possible. Rents for an average three-room apartment in Beijing range from the equivalent of 34 cents a month to $1.14. Officials say the average Chinese spends less than 1 percent of his income on housing, compared with 15 percent in the United States. In the late 1950s, Chinese spent 6 percent to 10 percent of income on rent and officials want to return to that level by the end of this decade. ``Rent is so low that it takes years to recover'' a new building's cost, said Zhang Yuanduan, director of the Construction Ministry's real estate department. Most new buildings soon begin deteriorating because rent often doesn't even pay the cost of maintenance, and Chinese are being born at the rate of more than 30 a minute, too fast for new construction to keep pace. In outlying parts of Beijing and some companies where the housing reforms are being introduced, rents have risen to the equivalent of $6.30 a month for a three-room apartment. The city built 314 new apartments and offered them for sale at prices much closer to the real cost - an average of $18,250, or 40 times the average annual wage - said Liu Qi, deputy director of Beijing's Housing Reform Office. Buyers snapped up the apartments, borrowing money from relatives abroad or taking out bank loans. Liu said some companies in Beijing were following suit and had sold nearly 4,000 apartments to workers in the past two years, generally at lower prices than the city. Proceeds are used to renovate old housing and build new apartments. A local government in Liaoning, northeastern China, earned enough from selling apartments and raising rents to build 120 new dormitories in less than three years. In the past, it had been able to build only one or two in the same period, said Zhang of the Construction Ministry.

DOC.HEAD: 165 U.N. Workers Missing or Detained, 10 Killed
DOC.TEXT: One day in 1979, Bismillah Kamkai was taken from his U.N. Development Program office in Kabul, Afghanistan, under armed guard. He was never heard from again. Belay Melake, an Ethiopian statistician working for a U.N. economic agency in Addis Ababa, disappeared more than 11 years ago. His colleagues believe his government tortured and killed him. British journalist Alec Collett was abducted south of Beirut in 1985 while on assignment for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, which aids Palestinian refugees. In 1986, his kidnappers claimed to have killed him in retaliation for the U.S. air raid on Libya, but no body was found. U.N. staff members say 10 of their colleagues have been killed, including Kamkai and Melake. Collett is among 165 listed as missing or detained around the world. Ninety-nine of those detained are Arab relief workers held by Israeli authorities in the occupied Gaza Strip or West Bank, according to the U.N. employee union. Much attention has focused on Western hostages in the Middle East, but little has been paid to the scores of detained U.N. employees. Most are low-level employees of relief and development agencies who are citizens of the countries where they work. ``These people are working for the world community and it's surprising that there's not more compassion,'' said Lori Berliner, who for a decade has led a committee of international civil servants pressing for the release of those detained. ``We worry about staff being forgotten.'' Israel accuses the Arab U.N. workers it holds of ``subversive activities,'' said Lowell Flanders, president of the U.N. staff union. But he added, ``They're not terrorists.'' Many were teachers, guards or drivers in Palestinian refugee camps. About 20 governments or organizations have been accused of killing U.N. employees or detaining them illegally. Flanders described Ethiopia as one of the most serious offenders because of reports the government has tortured and killed prisoners. He said he had independent reports that Ghennet Mebrahtu, a widow with two children employed by the World Health Organization in Addis Ababa, had been tortured since her arrest in August. An Ethiopian delegate told a U.N. committee in November that Mrs. Mebrahtu was arrested for activities ``not consistent'' with her U.N. duties and would be tried soon. He did not elaborate. The U.N. staff union insists U.N. workers be afforded due process: open hearings, written charges and the right to legal counsel, as provided for in the 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar has demanded repeatedly that the rights of U.N. staff members be respected. ``At a time when the organization is being called upon to undertake greater responsibilities in various parts of the world, it is totally unacceptable that ... staff members are subjected to arbitrary or unexplained detention, abduction, or even have their lives placed at risk,'' he said recently. U.N. committees and member states also have said the matter is urgent, but the staff union wants action. It has demanded a halt to all U.N. activities, except for humanitarian aid, in any country that illegally detains U.N. workers. U.N. officials and delegates say there is little chance of that. Mahmoud Tarjouman, a Syrian arrested by his government in 1976 before he could begin work for a U.N. economic commission in Lebanon, said the United Nations did not work for his release during nine years of imprisonment. No U.N. official ever contacted his wife, and his salary was stopped after 1{ years, Tarjouman said. He said his support for multiparty democracy may have caused his arrest by President Hafez Assad's government. Tarjouman was neither charged or tried, and returned to the United Nations after his release. He now works as an editor in New York and U.N. officials are considering his request for back pay. U.N. workers accept that their duties involve risk, Flanders said, ``but at the same time, they expect that if they do encounter difficulties, the organization would support them.'' Reasons for detentions are many. Some U.N. workers simply were caught up in unrest. Among the 10 believed slain are Fernando Olivares-Mori and Carmelo Soria Espinosa, seized in the 1970s in Chile under the military regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet. Some may have been victims of attempts to frustrate U.N. activity. In 1987-1989, the communist government of Nicolai Ceausescu refused to let a professor working for the United Nations leave Romania to report on human rights.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wednesday AMs Dec 5

DOC.HEAD: Records Produced For WWII-Era Servicemen Now Available to All
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The recording sessions were held in Quonset huts, on movie sets, in night clubs after hours. Some of the biggest names in show business, from old-timers like Al Jolson to newcomers like Frank Sinatra, performed. But the records, produced in a six-year period during and after World War II, were heard only by American servicemen overseas. Now, through the efforts of a retired Navy officer who helped oversee their production, they are on the U.S. market. Nearly 920 12-inch, 78-rpm records were produced by the Army and Navy from 1943 through 1949 as morale boosters. They were called V-Discs. The records - 8 million copies altogether - were accompanied by 125,000 spring-operated windup phonographs, each with 100 steel needles. ``They were played on ships, in foxholes, in trenches, on airplanes, in hospitals,'' said Edmond P. DiGiannantonio. Digi, as he is known, ran the Navy's part of the program and keeps a well-preserved copy of each record in a closet in his lakeside home here. One serviceman wrote a letter saying he and his buddies were playing a V-Disc as they headed to the D-Day invasion of Normandy, DiGiannantonio said. The program was started after an Army musical branch captain named Bob Vincent suggested to Army officials in Washington that they get popular band leaders like Benny Goodman and Artie Shaw to record for the troops. The colonel, Vincent's superior, said, ``Look, these guys don't want to hear any swing music or any jazz; they want marching music,'' DiGiannantonio recalled. The colonel's reluctance was overcome and ``we went on to include all types of music in all releases,'' said DiGiannantonio. ``From Toscanini to Spike Jones. All the way.'' When the Navy started looking for an officer to run the Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard part of the program, DiGiannantonio was in a hospital in Boston, recovering from wounds he suffered when his ship, the heavy cruiser Vincennes, was sunk off Guadalcanal. He had played violin, piano and saxophone in high school in Boston and at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, held a broadcast engineer's license and had recorded Shaw, Glenn Miller, Goodman and other band leaders when they came to town. So he got the job. Along with each box of 20 or 30 records went copies of a questionnaire asking the servicemen to say what kind of music they wanted. ``White Christmas'' was the most requested piece. About 60 percent wanted jazz or swing, 20 percent or so classical and some country and western or others. Marches didn't make it. Some of the music came from movie film tracks and transcriptions of radio broadcasts, but many were live recordings by artists donating their services. During the early years, they were the only records made. The American Federation of Musicians, at odds with the recording companies over royalties, had banned all recording until the dispute was settled. Union President James Caesar Petrillo waived the ban to permit the recordings for the troops. ``We recorded in night clubs, hotel ballrooms, movie studios, Quonset huts, Army bases, Navy bases, wherever the artists were,'' said DiGiannantonio, now 73. ``In those days when you went on a job you traveled by bus all night. They'd do a session and wind up at one or two in the morning, and then come to a studio and lug all the instruments and record for us.'' The services had tried sending shellac records overseas earlier, but found that most of them were broken before they arrived. The V-discs were recorded on more durable vinylite. When vinylite became scarce because it was critically needed for insulation, they switched to Formvar, a product developed in Canada. Instructions on changing needles were often ignored, so many of the records wore out overseas. Others were left behind when the war ended. DiGiannantonio said that when the V-disc program ended, officials ordered the remaining disks destroyed to prevent commercial use. Nevertheless, the Library of Congress has a nearly complete set. Their quality ``ranges from very good to poor, depending on the source,'' said music librarian Sam Brylawski. ``Remember how heavy those old needles were,'' said Brylawski. ``That would gouge a record like a V-disc. If we got one from someone who really liked their recording a lot, it could very well be beat up.'' DiGiannantonio took good care of his. They have been transferred to cassettes and compact discs, with no adjustment of the original sound. ``Some people said let's enhance it, and do this or this,'' said DiGiannantonio. ``But we said this is the way it was, and we are going to do it that way.'' DiGiannantonio said he has clearance from the Defense Department to market the recordings, and is working with the American Federation of Musicians and Broadcast Music Inc. about payment of royalties. He said much of the profit will go to the musicians' union retirement fund, or to the artists, their families, or their estates. The first installment is a three-cassette set with 37 numbers including Glenn Miller playing ``Chattanooga Choo Choo,'' Jolson singing ``Mammy'' and Connie Boswell crooning ``Good Night, Sweetheart.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - The first V-disk installment is available for $24.95 in cassette or $29.95 in compact disc from V-Disc, P.O. Box 6, Springfield, Va. 22150, toll-free telephone 1-800-323-3808.

DOC.HEAD: Oklahoma Math Maverick Infuriates Establishment
DOC.NOTE: With Laserphoto, AP Graphic
DOC.TEXT: He flunked trigonometry as a boy. Yet John Saxon now presents himself as the savior of math education, delighted to brand the nation's math experts as incompetents. The ``math establishment'' - the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics and top state math officials - is to blame for U.S. teen-agers scoring last in international comparisons of numerical skills, Saxon charges. ``It is only in math education where people who are abject failures are called experts,'' says Saxon, whose back-to-basics math textbooks have been rejected by several states and whose blunt personality leaves even supporters cringing. ``They can point to no success in math education in 30 years and yet they call themselves experts.'' Many in the ``establishment'' do, indeed, oppose many of Saxon's methods - and they don't much like this former test pilot and junior college teacher turned math textbook publisher, either. But interviews with teachers around the country make it clear that this math maverick from Oklahoma has tapped into widespread discontent over math education and is causing educators to rethink how the subject should be taught in U.S. classrooms. Since 1982, Saxon has sold some $20 million worth of his texts to 3,000 schools around the country - from Arizona reservation schools to affluent suburban schools outside Chicago, Minneapolis and metropolitan New York. And he's done it without the customary sales force most school textbook publishers employ. Instead, he's run acerbic ads in education trade journals, offered free texts to schools willing to test them, and encouraged his legions of teacher-supporters to help spread his grass-roots math movement. Saxon's philosophy lies in his fourth grade through high school textbook series that he hopes will banish three decades of ``new math'' and replace it with a ``practice, practice, practice'' regimen of basic skills. Or, as he put it in an interview, ``I beat math into the little buggers.'' Saxon's latest battleground is this affluent Long Island suburb, where parents, believing that the state-mandated math curriculum was leaving their kids ill-equipped for college math, overcame opposition from state curriculum authorities and won permission to become the first in New York state to test Saxon's approach. This fall, Saxon's brand of math began a closely watched, three-year trial in two beginning algebra classes at South Huntington's Walt Whitman High School. But here and elsewhere, it's too early to tell if the Saxon approach will do all it claims: boost test scores, keep students in math longer, and make U.S. students world leaders in math skills. One of the few serious studies, conducted with Pittsburgh students in 1987, found that Saxon yielded no test gains compared with other books. And all students did poorly on problem-solving skills regardless of the texts used. Saxon is hard to categorize. His texts blend rote math drill and constant repetition of lessons previously learned - similar to the Japanese ``kumon'' method that helped make that country a math leader. The Algebra I text, for example, has no chapters, but 132 ``lessons,'' each focusing on a particular skill - graphing inequalities, for example. Students work on 30 or so practice problems. But unlike traditional texts, the vast majority of practice questions deal with previous lessons learned. It's as if students are reviewing for their math finals from the first day of the school year. Unlike many math experts, Saxon frowns on students using hand calculators, especially in elementary grades. And Saxon teachers are expected to act as coaches rather than lecturers, and employ other progressive classroom practices such as cooperative learning. In sum, Saxon seems to offer a new way to teach the ``old math.'' As might be expected, leading math educators haven't taken kindly to being told by this prickly outsider that they've been doing it all wrong for decades. Curriculum officials and some classroom teachers in New York, Minnesota, Texas, California, Idaho and even his home state of Oklahoma insist Saxon is trying to march mathematics education backwards. Saxon may teach students how to compute a square root, they say, but his texts neglect problem-solving skills, ignore key areas like probabilities and statistics, and generally fail to connect classroom math to a changing technological world. ``It appears Saxon wants students to perform quick and accurate calculations. He has a behaviorist point of view: learning through constant repeating. The rest of us believe that you build knowledge through prior understanding,'' said Elizabeth Stage, chairwoman of California's curriculum commission. ``There's no application to anything in real life. Students wind up more like trained monkeys,'' said Nancy Guldberg, a math teacher at Eden Prairie High School in suburban Minneapolis, which has used the Saxon texts for six years but now is almost certain to drop them because students disliked the texts and test scores languished. But Mel Twitchell, who has used Saxon to teach his four math sections at Utah's Provo High School for the last three years, is among many others who swear the texts are making students enjoy math so much that they stick with it through calculus. Twitchell said it's too soon to point to big test gains. But at Provo, only two sections of students now take dumbed-down ``consumer'' math, compared with six sections before Saxon, he said. And calculus enrollment is up, from 38 students before Saxon, to 107 studets. Nine weeks into the Saxon experiment at South Huntington, parents, teachers and students seem to like what they see. Walk into John Cardon's Algebra I class and you'll see a teacher who lectures for just 10 minutes, then lets his 26 students work alone or help each other with long lists of review questions. Cardon's students are uniformly positive, even though the homework load is heavy. ``It's easier,'' said Kerri Ball, a 14-year-old freshman. ``Last year, my grades were in the 70s. Now I'm scoring in the 80s.'' Saxon's first-ever foothold in New York is, in itself, an extraordinary accomplishment in a state where only two or three high school textbooks conform to the unusually rigid high school math curriculum. The New York breakthrough is the more remarkable because it happened in a school district where 95 percent of the students already were passing their state exams. But Cardon said the state-required curriculum had students glossing over many facets of math while neglecting the skills needed to really understand them. ``They made the courses so easy in order to attract more kids. But they wound up learning a little bit about a lot of things, but knowing nothing,'' he said. Buoyed by such grass-roots support, Saxon shows no signs of mellowing as the nation's leading math gadfly. ``My critics will tell you I'm not nice, and I will say they are incompetent,'' he said. One critic, Cathy Seeley, the state director of mathematics in Texas, said Saxon refuses to concede there could be more than one way to teach math. Texas rejected Saxon's texts for state adoption in 1983, 1989 and again last month. ``The `establishment' is anyone who disagrees with Saxon,'' Ms. Seeley said. ``In truth, there have been many unpleasant people who have had good things to offer in education. In this case, it's someone who's saying their way is the only way to do something.'' ``It's the personal and professional demeaning that I find amazing,'' said Stage, the California official. ``What difference does it make if I'm a horse's ass?'' Saxon responds. ``What difference does it make if they like me? I have threatened their raison d'etre. The math experts are a lot more human than I hoped they'd be.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Lee Mitgang has covered education for the AP since 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Du Pont Fiber Workers Come Up Empty On Yearend Payout
With BC-The New Workplace I
DOC.TEXT: Workers in Du Pont Co.'s fibers division, who tied their pay raises to profits under a special incentive plan, had banked on a tidy payout around the holidays. But the bank went bust - and so did the experimental program. Because the division failed to reach its $725 million annual profit goal, the department's 20,000 employees, who had as much as 4 percent of their pay at risk, won't see any extra payouts or bonuses at the end of this year. Du Pont also decided to scrap the innovative three-year plan in its second year after several employees cried foul. Beginning in January, employee wages and raises will be paid in the traditional way. James F. Kearns, who heads the fibers division, said employees weren't ready for a pay-at-risk program. ``It was fine when they were getting more back than they put in, which was the case last year. But when they found out they were not going to get back as much as they invested, it began to come out `No, this is not fair,''' Kearns said. The pay incentive plan was mandatory for non-union employees at the department's 10 nationwide plants. Four of the five plants that have unions also agreed to participate. Here's how the plan worked: Employees this year ``gambled'' as much as 4 percent of their annual pay that the division would reach its $725 million goal. Last year, it was as much as 2 percent on a $670 million goal. An employee with an annual salary of $30,000 this year could have received a one-time payout of as much as $1,200 if the goal was met. His regular salary, however, wasn't touched if the goal wasn't met. Last year, that same employee with the same salary earned an extra $600 since the goal was met, plus a small bonus because the target was exceeded. The Du Pont program was designed to give employees a stake in the department's profits to help improve the fibers business. The theory was that such a plan would make employees feel they owned part of the company, encouraging them to become more efficient and to find cost-saving ways to do their jobs. But the fibers business, which represents nearly a quarter of Du Pont's total profits, has been hurt by a rise in foreign competition and raw materials costs. Through the third quarter of this year, Du Pont's fibers division earned $400 million, about $100 million off from the same time last year. The company predicts that fourth quarter net income will be lower than the $191 million earned in the 1989 quarter and, therefore, well below the $725 million goal. Under the plan, employees also could have received half of what was at risk if the department achieved 80 percent of this year's profit goal, or $580 million. But Kearns, the fibers division head, said it would take a ``heroic effort'' to reach that goal by year's end. When the pay plan was announced in the fall of 1988, chemical industry analysts said it was trend-setting. But in a slumping economy, it's not a popular plan. ``I thought it was a pretty bold move. ... (But) workers want stability in their job and compensation, and from that standpoint it may have been too bold a move,'' said James H. Wilbur, an industry analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co.

DOC.HEAD: Granny Flats: Rent-a-Cottage in the Yard for Granny?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf to fix typo in `can.'
DOC.TEXT: Dilemma: Your grandparents can't keep up their big house and they don't want to move to a retirement home. Solution: A portable, factory-built four-room cottage that fits in the back yard. Developer J. Robert Gillette says the cottages are America's answer to Australia's ``granny flats.'' The cottages, which can be hooked to utilities in the main home, sell for about $50,000 or rent for $600 to $700 a month. The relatives are nearby but not crowding the family. Gillette wants the first cottages to be built on the grounds of senior citizens' complexes. Cottage occupants will have more privacy, and pay less, than residents of the complex itself, but still have easy access to social events, meals and services such as laundry. Trial programs in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Texas and California show that what the American Association of Retired Persons calls the Elder Cottage Housing Opportunity can work. ``It's very cozy,'' Pauline Wessner, 85, said from the ECHO cottage she's lived in for two years near Belvedere, N.J. Wessner's grandson thought of her when the county's Office on Aging announced an ECHO trial program. He had bought the house where she lived for nearly 40 years, and she had moved to an apartment, she said. ``It was too much work for me to mow the grass and everything else.'' ``I live right next door to my grandson now, about 45 feet from his house,'' she said. The county bought the cottage and leases it to her for an amount based on her Social Security income. She has a bedroom, bathroom, parlor and fully equipped kitchen. Probably not more than 100 of the little houses have been set up nationally, said Leah Dobkin of the AARP in Washington. But the AARP has published outlines for developers and local governments of the zoning, parking and other issues the cottages raise. It's better than backing a trailer in, Dobkin said. ``These are specially designed for the elderly, and they meet all housing codes,'' she said. Gillette's cottage plans show ramps for people who don't want to climb stairs, wide doors, bathtub rails, and kitchen sinks minus the usual cabinets underneath that keep wheelchair users at arm's length. Gillette said he'll erect four cottages at the American House Dearborn Heights, Mich., complex by spring. That the cottages are detached is a key for senior citizens like Wessner, who want to live near their families, but not in the same house. ``That wouldn't go,'' Wessner said. ``They have two teen-agers, who like loud music. Grandma's a little too old for that now.'' But the cottage avoids the loneliness of long-distance living. ``My grandson stops in every morning with the newspaper for me. They invite me over, which I appreciate. I go over there on Sunday for coffee and a bun.'' And on holidays, she said, ``We eat together. Unless I'm invited somewhere else.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Nov. 29

DOC.TEXT: MCA Inc., one of America's most precious entertainment gems, will be acquired by Japanese business giant Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. in a $6.6 billion deal that firmly establishes Japan's presence in Hollywood moviemaking. Even at that huge price tag - the largest ever for a Japanese purchase of a U.S. company - the deal announced Monday was mildly disappointing to investors who had been anticipating the purchase since it was first rumored in September. The deal figures out to about $71 per MCA share, and the takeover-starved market had been hoping for something closer to $90. --- MOSCOW (AP) - The Kremlin says it wants to slash foreign aid by 75 percent and defense spending by 10 percent in next year's budget, which for the first time makes a distinction between national and republic revenues. Communist countries including Cuba, Vietnam, Ethiopia, North Korea and Angola likely would be hard hit by the cutback. Deputy Prime Minister Leonid Abalkin also told the lawmakers on Monday that real estate, stocks and currency would be sold in the Soviet Union for the first time next year. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Two airline tickets for the price one of might sound pretty good to anybody about to go on vacation, but analysts warn that the freebies could escalate into a harmful fare war if carriers aren't careful. ``Things like this tend to spread like wildfire,'' said Raymond E. Neidl, an airline analyst with Dillon Read & Co. Inc. ``If they can control the number of seats, with black-out periods, then the damage can be controlled.'' The latest gimmick for filling seats comes as airlines have been hit hard by rising fuel costs brought on by the Persian Gulf crisis and a downturn in the economy that has kept demand for air travel sluggish. --- BERLIN (AP) - Thousands of rail workers in eastern Germany have walked off the job demanding protection from layoffs caused by unification, and the strike disrupted travel in neighboring countries. The strike was the first major walkout since the Germanys united on Oct. 3. It started in Berlin Sunday evening, then spread across eastern Germany Monday, forcing some trans-European express trains to stop in Czechoslovakia. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Supreme Court has refused to shield a whooping cough vaccine manufacturer from a lawsuit that said company negligence caused brain damage in an inoculated infant. The court, without comment, on Monday rejected an appeal by Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories to stop the suit. Michelle Graham was given the vaccine in 1980 when she was a few months old. Soon after, she was diagnosed as suffering from severe brain damage that causes retardation. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Justice Department says that it won $257 million in fiscal 1990 from defense contractors and other companies accused in civil suits of defrauding the government. The amount, announced Monday, has risen substantially since Congress approved amendments to the False Claims Act in 1986 authorizing the government to recover triple damages. The Justice Department collected only $27 million in fiscal 1985 through judgments and settlements of civil fraud cases. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Supreme Court has refused to end an affirmative action program aimed at awarding more public works contracts to businesses run by minorities and women. In its decision on Monday, the court rejected an appeal by companies that said the Tampa, Fla.-area program is unconstitutional because it condones reverse discrimination against white men. The affirmative action program was adopted in 1984 by Hillsborough County,which set a goal of awarding 25 percent of the value of all annual construction contracts to businesses owned by women and minorities. --- DETROIT (AP) - The Big Three automakers said 12,600 employees in Canada will be laid off temporarily on top of the 38,800 U.S. employees being furloughed due to sagging North American sales. Automobile spokesmen said the layoffs were due to slumping sales in Canada and in the United States. Also on Monday, state officials in Kentucky said they were optimistic that Toyota Motor Manufacturing Inc. would announce a major expansion at its factory in Georgetown on Tuesday, but auto industry analysts held different views on what Toyota had in mind. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Whittle Communications says that more than 5,700 schools have signed contracts for its commercially sponsored Channel One news show for teens, and expects to reach its goal of 8,600 schools by next June. Chairman Christopher Whittle said on Monday that all of the service's available commercial time has been either sold or optioned for sale to 13 different advertisers for the January-June period. ---
DOC.HEAD: By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: The stock market overcame a broad early setback to finish slightly higher Monday in another session of light activity. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down about 30 points at its morning low, closed with a 5.94 gain at 2,533.17. Bonds rose moderately. The dollar advanced and gold moved moderately higher. Grain and soybean futures prices fell broadly. Oil prices rose sharply on perceptions that the U.N. Security Council soon would approve a military strike to push Iraqi troops out of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Matsushita Seeking Edge Over Rival Sony With MCA Purchase
With PM-MCA-Matsushita, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The buyer of U.S. entertainment conglomerate MCA Inc. has come a long way since its founder, Konosuke Matsushita, made Japanese home life a bit easier by popularizing the rice cooker. Now Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd. has set its sights on dominating the promised next generation of electronic entertainment - high-definition television - with the help of MCA's rich vault of movies and television shows and studios with which to make more. Matsushita (pronounced mat-SOOS-shtuh) needed MCA to keep up with electronics and entertainment rival Sony Corp. in their dead-heat battle over the video and HDTV fields, analysts say. The MCA buyout is valued at $6.6 billion, compared with the $5 billion Sony paid for Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. last year. Unlike Sony, Matsushita is not a household name outside Japan, although its popular brand names Panasonic, Technics and Quasar are widely known. Matsushita is Japan's largest home electronics manufacturer and third-largest corporation, with 163 consolidated subsidiaries. Fortune magazine ranked Matsushita in 1989 as the 16th biggest corporation in the world. The Osaka-based company reported holdings of more than $10 billion in cash alone last year, and it earned $1.48 billion on sales of $37.8 billion. The influence of legendary founder Konosuke Matsushita, who died last year at age 94, is felt in virtually every Japanese home where an automatic rice cooker takes the drudgery out of preparing the nation's staple food. Matsushita, a man who never went to high school yet became Japan's most famous entrepreneur, popularized the electric appliance in the 1950s in keeping with his corporate philosophy: ``To manufacture items of good quality for daily use in abundant supply, thereby enriching and improving life for everyone.'' That creed in 1932 came less than 15 years after 23-year-old Matsushita left his employer, an electric power company, to capitalize on his own two-way electric socket. Today, the Matsushita empire has spawned nearly 500 related firms in 37 countries. During the 37 years it has operated in the United States, Matsushita has built 12 factories and established seven sales companies and a research facility that employ about 10,000 people. Matsushita's huge size, including its 25,000 affiliated retailers in Japan, has proved a disadvantage in switching from low-growth consumer products, which generate 60 percent of its sales, to more profitable fields. Its inability to produce a new hit product to replace the blockbuster video cassette recorder reflects the company's greater strength in manufacturing than invention. Seeking to overcome its limitations, six years ago Matsushita launched a long-term plan to focus on seven areas of high technology, including computers, semiconductors and communications. This year, the company invested about $3.2 billion in liquid crystal computer monitor technology, computers and semiconductors. It also is trying to develop profitable movie and television cameras for professional use, said Boris Petersik, an electronics analyst at Barclay's de Zoete Wedd Securities Japan. So far, Matsushita has had a hard time cracking Sony's dominance in the professional video market. Sony also has a head start in the market for entertainment ``software,'' or the movies, TV shows and music played in tape recorders, laser-disc players and VCRs. Sony achieved this lead through its purchase of Columbia Pictures last year and its 1987 purchase of CBS Records for $2 billion. The entertainment software market is growing faster than the market for the machines that play it. Most analysts believe that control of entertainment software is the key to staying ahead in the electronics field. The MCA purchase gives Matsushita access to a repository of movies and television programs similar to Sony's Columbia cache to be used with the new HDTV format, which offers dazzlingly detailed images, digital sound and wider, cinema-style screen proportions. ``With that purchase, there's a very good chance they'd get a fair share of the HDTV market. They'll be glad to have something to run on those gadgets,'' Petersik says.

DOC.HEAD: MCA: From Jazz Band Booker to Entertainment Colossus
With PM-MCA-Matsushita, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The story of MCA Inc. reads like a Hollywood fairy tale, about a fledgling company that grew from a tiny jazz promoter into a conglomerate of movie studios, theme parks, a big-name record label and a publishing house. The entertainment colossus now represents a chunk of American pop culture, churning out movie icons ranging from ``E.T.'' to ``Jaws'' and making household names out of musicians like Guns N' Roses and Bobby Brown. But Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd. of Japan, which agreed to purchase MCA on Monday, also bought a company of creative visionaries whose screen business has sometimes faltered, whose movies have been swept up in controversy and whose studios recently were ravaged by fire. MCA lived through economic thick and thin to earn a reputation as a survivor. Today MCA owns Universal Studios, one of America's biggest record labels, a publishing house, theme parks and big piece of Los Angeles real estate. It is known for extremely stable management, notable in a business famous for capricious and unpredictable excecutive changes. The company's transformation was stage-managed over a 65-year history by a Chicago eye doctor, the late Jules Stein, and Lew Wasserman, a one-time movie usher from Cleveland. Wasserman, who to this day is MCA's chairman, and president Sidney J. Sheinberg have run the company for decades. Over the years Universal has produced Academy Award winners such as ``The Sting,'' ``The Deer Hunter '' and ``Out of Africa.'' But ``The Last Temptation of Christ'' stirred up an emotion-charged debate, inciting religious groups to protest what they called its shameful interpretation of biblical history. More recently, the company faced a devastating fire and an uncertain market for its feature films. Early this month an arsonist torched the historic Universal Studios backlot, gutting sets for ``Dick Tracy,'' ``Back to the Future'' and an unfinished Sylvestor Stallone movie. While Universal television has long been a steady moneymaker, the film division has endured ups and downs - its dry spells punctuated by periodic blockbusters like ``E.T.'' ``Jaws,'' ``Back to the Future,'' ``The Sting,'' ``Animal House,'' ``On Golden Pond,'' and ``Twins.'' MCA's storied history has its roots in the jazz business. Stein, a jazz player himself, decided musicians needed an agency to strike them better deals with hotels, ballrooms and speakeasies. In 1923 he founded the Music Corporation of America, and by the 1930s, MCA represented most of the name bands in the swing era. Then Stein set his sights on a bigger talent game: Hollywood. Stein's chief aid, Wasserman, proved a dynamo as head of MCA's Hollywood office, and soon the agency represented a long list of stars, including Joan Crawford, Errol Flynn and Alfred Hitchcock. As the major studios shunned television as an upstart competitor, MCA rushed in with its Revue Productions, grinding out series like ``M Squad'' and ``Wagon Train.'' When Ronald Reagan's film career faded, Wasserman found him work as host of ``General Electric Theater.'' Until 1959, MCA was known principally as The Octopus because of its far-reaching influence as a talent agency. Then the company took a giant step, buying the venerable, faltering Universal Studio. Under Wasserman's guidance, MCA-Universal flourished in the 1970s and 1980s. The company became the biggest supplier of television entertainment. In addition, Universal Studios Tours grew to a major tourist attraction.

DOC.HEAD: MCA Sale Would Leave Only One Major American-Owned Label
With PM-MCA-Matsushita, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Oak Ridge Boys may boast that ``My Baby is American Made,'' but their catalogue and that of most other country music artists belong to foreign investors. The planned buyout of MCA Inc. by Japan's Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. in a $6.6 billion deal would leave Nashville's country music industry with only one major label under an American banner: Warner Bros. The acquisition covers MCA Records and MCA Music, a song publishing company, and some of the biggest names in country music. Reba McEntire, George Strait, Vince Gill, Patty Loveless, The Desert Rose Band, Lionel Cartwright, The Nitty Gritty Dirt Band, Conway Twitty, The Bellamy Brothers and Steve Wariner all record for MCA. Officials at MCA Records Nashville wouldn't comment on the sale or any changes it might bring to their operation, spokeswoman Janet Rickman said. But one industry observer doubts Japanese ownership will change a note. ``Historically, the Nashville divisions have retained their creative autonomy after changes in ownership,'' said Bill Ivey, Director of the Country Music Foundation in Nashville. The foundation, which operates the Country Music Hall of Fame museum, is dedicated to preserving the history of country music. ``Typically, the bigger corporations place more emphasis on the bottom line and paperwork, but leave Nashville divisions alone as far as artistic vision.'' Foreign investors usually bring a healthy infusion of cash-flow for Nashville companies they acquire, Ivey said. ``There are some benefits to country music in locally owned operations, but once a company is owned outside of Nashville it matters little whether that company is based in New York or Tokyo.'' Ed Benson of the Country Music Association observed that MCA's Nashville label has been profitable and probably won't see its routine change much. ``All of the Nashville major labels have been profitable and successful and one more foreign acquisition probably won't even change the players,'' said Benson, who is the trade group's associate executive director. Ivey said the character of the industry is changing. It's getting harder for independent labels to thrive. Opryland Records, an independent Nashville label owned by Opryland USA Inc., recently gave up, Ivey noted. ``If you are trying to operate a traditional record company, signing major acts to multi-album contracts and getting radio play and selling records at retail, it gets real tough to compete,'' said Ivey. ``There's a niche for small labels to market mail order, perhaps. But there is no room at the top of the charts.'' Japanese interests control CBS Records, soon to be renamed Sony. BMG, Capitol-EMI and Mercury-Polydor are owned by Germans, the English and the Dutch, respectively.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Media Nervous About Possible Backlash
With PM-MCA-Matsushita, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Concern over a U.S. backlash of anti-Japanese sentiment surfaced Tuesday in local media comment on Matsushita Electric Industrial Co.'s proposed blockbuster buyout of entertainment giant MCA Inc. Some newspapers and television broadcasters also forecast intensifying competition over popular television shows, movies and other broadcast ``software.'' The nationally-circulated Asahi Shimbun reported that Matsushita had been eager to finalize the deal before Dec. 7, the 49th anniversary of the Japanese bombing of Pearl Harbor, to avoid exacerbating U.S. public opinion. Matsushita's purchase of MCA in a $6.6 billion deal is the largest Japanese buyout of an American concern after Sony's $5 billion purchase of Columbia Pictures Entertainment last year. The Japan Broadcasting Corp. (NHK), Japan's authoritative, quasi-public television network, gave the deal prominent early morning air play. The broadcast featured on-the-street interviews with New York pedestrians, whose opinions ranged from approval of the purchase to anxiety about the faltering power of American companies. The Asahi Shimbun played up foreign reaction in a small story about the Monday news conference in Osaka where the purchase was announced. The story focused on a reporter's question about possible censorship by MCA's new owners of films critical of Japan. Similar questions were raised last year in response to the Columbia Pictures purchase. ``I am confident that such works will not be produced because this purchase itself aims to deepen the cooperation between the U.S. and Japan,'' Matsushita President Akio Tanii was quoted as replying. An analysis article in the newspaper said Matsushita paid a high price, probably to avoid a backlash in American public opinion. But another major daily, the Mainichi Shimbun, carried a story from Washington D.C. saying American sentiment was calm, in contrast to reaction to Sony-Columbia transaction. An analysis in the Yomiuri Shimbun, the nation's top-selling daily, said the purchase underlined the inseparable relationship in the audiovisual business between the machinery of broadcasting, from cameras to television sets, and what the machines broadcast. Media reports predicted the purchase will fuel competition in the audiovisual market, which is rapidly expanding due to the popularity of rental videos and advent of satellite services. Japanese businesses have their eyes on Hollywood, at the same time that the U.S. film industry is seeking financing, Yomiuri reported. Japanese trading and computer firms, meanwhile, have begun making their own forays into film-making, Yomiuri said. The quality of films that MCA produces in the future will ultimately be key to determining public reception of the deal, according to the Yomiuri article. ``Matsushita has failed if people begin to say MCA films have changed because of the purchase,'' an unidentified film distributor was reported as saying. The Asahi Shimbun quoted unidentified sources in business circles as predicting the deal will be the final major overseas corporate takeover for Japanese companies, given the downward trend in the nation's economy.

DOC.HEAD: Guinness to Buy 67.5 Percent of Germany's Asbach
DOC.TEXT: Guinness PLC said Tuesday it has reached an agreement with Asbach and Co. stockholders to acquire 67.5 percent of the German brandy maker's shares. United Distillers, the Guinness division making the purchase, declined to disclose the price. Guinness, which has been expanding its European interests, last week announced it was buying Spain's largest brewer, La Cruz del Campo, for about $1 billion. The family-owned Asbach, which is based in Rudesheim on the Rhine river, produces, markets and sells Asbach Uralt brandy, the leading German premium brandy. Asbach is the largest spirits brand in the German market. The company also distributes Furst Bismarck Doppelkorn, a premium grain spirit which is the leading domestic Doppelkorn. Asbach had sales of 468 million German marks, or $314 million, in 1989 and net assets of 99 million marks, or $66.4 million. A profit figure was not available, Guinness said. Tony Greener, managing director of United Distillers, said Asbach will ``significantly strengthen United Distillers' position and broaden its premiumbranded portfolio in the important German market.'' United Distillers will work with Asbach to further develop its business in the future, Greener said.
