DOC.HEAD: Company Seeks Restitution from Ex-Chairman
DOC.TEXT: The former chairman of Ashland Oil Inc. is negotiating to repay expenses the company incurred from his scheme to sell confidential documents to the National Iranian Oil Co. ``We do anticipate there will be an agreement,'' John C. Elam, a lawyer for Ashland, said Monday. The former chairman, Orin E. Atkins, faces sentencing Friday in Manhattan federal court for his role in the scheme. A settlement on restitution is expected to be announced at the sentencing. A call to Atkin's attorney, James Moss, was not returned. Ashland, based in Ashland, Ky., first made its request for restitution from Atkins in an Oct. 9 letter to U.S. District Judge Charles S. Haight, who presides over Atkins' case. ``Mr. Atkins, a lawyer, held the very highest position at Ashland Oil Inc. prior to his resignation,'' Elam wrote. ``We submit that an individual who has held such a unique position also has the highest degree of responsibility and, therefore, has the duty to make restitution.'' The company did not give a specific amount, asking Haight to set a ``just and proper'' figure, but did outline the expenditures it accumulated and the payments made to Atkins during the scheme. According to the letter written by Elam, Ashland spent $1.47 million on an internal investigation of Atkins' acts and related attorneys fees. Additionally, Elam said that since October 1981, Ashland has paid Atkins more than $2.5 million in consulting fees and other discretionary corporate benefits and more than half a million dollars in pension benefits. Atkins, 66, of North Palm Beach, Fla., pleaded guilty in September 1989 to conspiracy and wire fraud and agreed to cooperate with the government. He faces a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison and a $500,000 fine when sentenced by U.S. District Judge Charles S. Haight. Atkins admitted that after he resigned as chairman in 1981 but remained as a paid Ashland consultant, he obtained confidential documents involving the company's decision not to pay National Iranian for $283 million in crude oil purchased in 1979. Atkins and others involved in the scheme offered to sell the documents to the Iranian company for use in a possible lawsuit against Ashland over its nonpayment. While the Iranians never bought the documents, they later sued Ashland and last year obtained a $325 million settlement, which with interest was worth more than $500 million. As part of his cooperation with prosecutors, Atkins testified earlier this year at the trial of an attorney, Charles Barnett, who was accused of participating in the scheme to sell the Ashland documents to the Iranian company. Barnett, of Palm Beach, Fla., was acquitted of all charges. A third defendant, oil broker Roy Furmark, pleaded guilty to a role in the conspiracy. Furmark, who was involved in the Iran-Contra deal, is scheduled to be sentenced in federal court next week.

DOC.HEAD: Navistar Buys More Of Mexican Truck Maker
DOC.TEXT: An agreement to supply engines for Mexico's largest heavy truck builder adds stability to Navistar International Corp.'s engine manufacturing schedule but is no guarantee against layoffs, a spokesman said. Workforce adjustments depend on a number of variables, including domestic demand for diesel engines, said Navistar spokesman William H. Greenhill. ``This is an engine that primarily goes in our medium trucks,'' he said, referring to the deal with DINA Camiones that was announced Monday. ``The domestic market has been sort of soft for both medium and heavy trucks,'' Greenhill said. Navistar said it agreed to supply DINA with as many as 5,000 diesel engines annually and more than tripled its stake in DINA to 17 percent. Chicago-based Navistar, North America's largest manufacturer of medium and heavy trucks, did not disclose financial terms of the agreement. Navistar previously owned 5 percent of DINA, a private corporation created in 1989 as the Mexican government denationalized key segments of the automotive industry. Under the agreement, Navistar's DT 466 family of mid-range diesel engines will become the standard power source for DINA medium trucks beginning next spring. The engine supply agreement is expected to add 3,000 to 5,000 engines annually to the 50,000 engines produced annually in Melrose Park, a Chicago suburb. ``This obviously solidifies the situation out there,'' Greenhill said. Navistar has blamed soft demand for its poor financial performance in the past year. The company lost $18 million in its fiscal first quarter and had earnings declines of more than 75 percent in the second and third quarters. Navistar will announce fiscal fourth-quarter results in early December. Michael Bowyer, a Duff & Phelps Inc. securities analyst who follows Navistar, called the company's increased investment in Mexico ``a good idea.'' Mexican demand for medium and heavy trucks combined has risen from 6,500 vehicles in 1988 to a projected 15,000 in 1990 and is expected to surpass 20,000 next year, according to Navistar. ``Mexico is presently industrializing its economy, and with an industrialized society there will be a good demand for trucks,'' Bowyer said. But he cautioned that industrialization is typically a slow process that's subject to many roadblocks. For 1990 through October, DINA's share of the combined medium and heavy truck market in Mexico was nearly 50 percent, Navistar said.

DOC.HEAD: Mazda, Nissan to Offer Driver and Passenger Air Bags
DOC.TEXT: Front-seat air bags will be a standard fixture for Mazda Motor Corp. vehicles by 1994 and in all Nissan Motor Co. Nissan and Infiniti cars by 1993, the automakers say. ``Mazda has made a commitment to the safety of our customers,'' Mazda spokesman Fred Aikins said Monday. ``We recognize the value of air bags as a supplement to the three-point seat belt.'' Nissan said the company will offer driver-side air bags in most of its U.S. passenger cars by 1992. Mazda will make driver- and passenger-side air bags standard on some U.S. models beginning in the 1992 model year, the automaker said. Currently, the company provides a driver's side air bag on U.S. models of the RX-7 and the sporty MX-5 Miata. The automaker also said it is studying the feasibility of adding air bags to its trucks and multipurpose passenger vehicles. The only Mazda plant in the United States is in Flat Rock. The plant makes the 626 4-door sedan, MX-6 coupe and Ford Motor Co.'s Probe model. The air bags, estimated to be in about 300,000 cars marked for sale in the United States, will be installed in vehicles made in Japan and in Flat Rock, Aikins said. Nissan offered optional driver-side air bags in Pulsar NX models starting in January 1989. They were standard equipment on Infiniti Q45 and M30 models introduced in the fall of 1989 and on 1991 300 ZX models introduced this fall. The company said it would start offering passenger-side air bags at the start of the 1992 model year and expand their availability to all Infiniti models and nearly all Nissan models by 1994. The only U.S. Nissan plant is in Smyrna, Tenn. It makes the Sentra and a pickup truck. Chrysler Corp. made driver-side air bags standard starting with its 1990 models, General Motors Corp. makes them standard on about 15 car lines and Ford Motor Co. puts driver-side air bags on its major lines, or about 1 million cars. By 1993, air bags or passive restraint belts will be required for front-seat passengers as well as drivers, under federal law.

DOC.HEAD: Third-Quarter Trade Deficit Swells to $29.75 Billion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade deficit swelled to $29.75 billion in the July-September quarter, the highest imbalance in a year, as the Persian Gulf crisis drove up the cost of foreign oil against a drop in demand for American farm products, the government said today. The Commerce Department said that the trade gap in the third quarter was a sharp 28.9 percent higher than the $23.10 billion imbalance in the April-June period. The second quarter deficit had been the lowest in more than six years. The turnaround occurred because imports shot up 5 percent to an all-time high of $125.91 billion while U.S. exports edged down 0.6 percent to $96.16 billion, reflecting the drop in demand for American farm products. The deficit is the difference between imports and exports. The July-September imbalance was the largest quarterly deficit since a $29.80 billion deficit in the same period last year. Since that time, the deficit had been on a steadily declining path as a boom in U.S. export sales helped to narrow America's huge trade deficit and give the economy one of its few bright spots. However, since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, economists had been forecasting that a higher foreign oil bill would translate into a rising trade deficit, adding one more negative factor to an economy already flirting with a recession. The figures in today's report on merchandise trade calculated on a balance of payments basis confirmed trends already noted in the department's monthly merchandise trade reports. The monthly report showed the third quarter deficit rose to $28.27 billion. The small disparity between the two reports reflects the fact that the balance of payments report excludes military sales by the U.S. government and makes other minor adjustments to the monthly figures. The higher July-September deficit reflected a $6.1 billion increase in imports. Petroleum imports were up $3.5 billion to $15.7 billion, reflecting a rise in both price and volume. Non-petroleum imports were up as well, climbing $2.5 billion to $110.2 billion as auto imports from Mexico and Canada rose. The small drop in exports left them close to their all-time high of $96.76 billion set in the April-June period. The biggest weakness came in a 6 percent drop in farm exports, which declined to $9.7 billion, reflecting lower sales, particularly in Eastern Europe, of American corn, wheat and soybeans. The average price of wheat decreased 12 percent while corn prices fell by 1 percent. The average price of cotton and soybeans was each up 1 percent. A drop in U.S. exports of aircraft also contributed to the weakness in exports. The largest increase in the deficit was with members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, a rise of $2.5 billion to $6.9 billion. The trade balance with Western Europe, which had been in surplus in the second quarter, dropped back into a deficit of $0.6 billion. As usual, the largest deficit was with Japan, a $9.7 billion deficit, which was still $0.7 billion below the second quarter imbalance and the lowest deficit with Japan since the first quarter of 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Asia's Growth Regions Expected To Weather U.S. Economic Storm
DOC.TEXT: Asia's so-called ``Little Dragons'' - Taiwan, Hong Kong, South Korea and Singapore - enjoyed explosive growth in the '80s thanks largely to soaring exports to a thriving American market. But the Persian Gulf crisis and a looming U.S. recession have the region worried because both factors are likely to shave economic growth next year, analysts say. Still, unlike the deep U.S. recession of the early 1980s, analysts predict those nations should fare better this time around because they managed to diversify their export markets. ``The U.S. recession surely will be a big blow to Taiwan's economy. But we are not as vulnerable this time,'' said Wei Chi-ling, an international trade professor at National Taiwan University. So far, slackening demand from the United States was cited as a major factor behind Hong Kong's decision to halve its projected economic growth rate for this year to 2.5 percent. The United States is the British colony's second largest trading partner after neighboring China. Softening U.S. demand also is cited for slower growth in Singapore, Taiwan, and South Korea. However, all three countries have predicted growth rates of 6 percent to 8 percent for this year and 1991. Although the United States remains among the largest export markets for much of the region, many Asian countries have managed to reduce their dependence on U.S. consumer demand for their textiles, electronics and other goods. For example, 33 percent of Taiwan's exports were to the United States last year, compared to nearly 50 percent in 1985. In Hong Kong, trade with other countries in the region grew eightfold between 1979 and 1989. Japan, the economic powerhouse of Asia, also has been picking up the slack in demand created by the sluggish U.S. economy. ``The Japanese economy is now playing a so-called absorber (role) for the Asian neighboring nations ... although they are still dependent on the U.S. market to a great extent,'' said Nobuyuki Ueda, senior economist at the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan. Bangkok Bank researcher Nimit Notapantawart agreed, saying the diversification strategy may bring only limited benefits. He notes that many Southeast Asian countries manufacture similar products and will face fierce competition. Also, diversifying markets, analysts say, cannot erase more fundamental problems faced by some Asian economies. Among them, a crisis of confidence in Hong Kong before it reverts to Chinese sovereignty in 1997, and the labor unrest and spiralling wages in South Korea. Elsewhere in Asia, Japan's economy is expected to lose some steam, with most analysts predicting growth of between 4 percent and 5 percent next year after four years of roughly 5 percent annual growth. A severe labor shortage, the Gulf crisis, and tighter money policies designed to fight inflation are more to blame for Japan's slowdown than lagging exports to the United States, experts say. ``Japan's growth is more heavily dependent on domestic demand, so even if export demand goes down, there will not be much impact,'' said Seiji Shinpo, head of the overseas research department at the government's Economic Planning Agency. China also might ride out a U.S. recession without major disruption, analysts say. Although the United States is China's third largest trading partner after Japan and Hong Kong, the generally low price of Chinese manufactured exports could keep the country insulated from a recession across the Pacific, said Thomas Chan, a college lecturer specializing in the Chinese economy. China's low wages also are drawing investment from Southeast Asia. The Asian nation likely to feel the worst economic blow in the coming year is the Philippines, where the government recently cut 1990 economic growth projections by nearly half to 3.5 percent. Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait sent thousands of Philippine workers home jobless. The loss of their foreign exchange remittances also depressed the value of the Philippine peso, and higher oil prices triggered a nationwide strike.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Energy Regulators Given More Power to Set Electricity Rates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 3 new grafs, removing word ``potentially'' from lead and subbing 3rd graf to note court agreed to do what FERC requested. Also CORRECTS citation at end, from ``Arcadi'' to ``Arcadia.'' Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today gave federal energy regulators more power to set electricity rates for 49 million homes nationwide. By an 8-0 vote, the justices overturned a ruling that barred the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission from slashing rate hikes to customers in 15 Ohio communities. The court, agreeing to do what FERC requested, sent the case back to a lower court for further study to determine whether the FERC orders are ``just and reasonable.'' At issue in today's ruling is the authority shared by FERC and the Security and Exchange Commission over public utilities and their subsidiaries. The court said a provision of the Federal Power Act governing overlapping authority between FERC and other agencies does not bar the energy regulators from seeking to control rates in the Ohio case. FERC said it is trying to prevent public utilities from passing on to consumers allegedly inflated costs of buying coal and possibly other goods and services from the companies' subsidiaries. The Bush administration supported an appeal by the Ohio communities. The dispute stems from rate hikes first proposed by Ohio Power Co. in 1982. The utility asked FERC to approve higher rates to cover the company's cost of buying coal from its subsidiary, the Southern Ohio Coal Co. The commission concluded that Ohio Power from 1982-86 paid its subsidiary between 25 percent and 33 percent more for coal than the prevailing market prices. FERC ordered the utility to refund $13.4 million to its wholesale customers for that period. But a U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here, which has authority over such actions by federal regulators, overturned the commission's decision last year. The appeals court interpreted the 1935 Federal Power Act to give the SEC primary authority to regulate sales contracts between holding companies and their subsidiaries. Justice Antonin Scalia, writing for the Supreme Court today, said the appeals court was mistaken. Scalia said the case now must go back to the appeals court for further study of the FERC orders. In urging high court review of the case, the Justice Department said effective regulation of utilities serving 49 million households nationwide could be at stake. Justice David H. Souter did not take part in the case. The Ohio communities that challenged the appeals court ruling - most tiny villages - are Arcadia, Bloomdale, Carey, Cygnet, Deshler, Greenwich, Ohio City, Plymouth, Republic, Shiloh, Sycamore, Wharton, Bryan, St. Clairsville and Wapakoneta. The case is Arcadia vs. Ohio Power Co., 89-1283.

DOC.HEAD: Suharto Warns Of Oil Glut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Suharto uses only one name.
DOC.TEXT: President Suharto has warned the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries of a possible oil glut if the Persian Gulf crisis ends, Mines and Energy Minster Ginanjar Kartasasmita said Tuesday. Suharto called on OPEC to reapply the quota system to control production when the situation has returned to normal in the Gulf, Kartasasmita told reporters after a meeting with the president. ``We hope and everyone hopes that the Gulf crisis will be over as soon as possible and we must be ready to cope with the difficulty in putting things in order again as it is not easy to cut output after enjoying large production,'' Kartasasmita said. He said currently, without Iraq and Kuwait, OPEC produces 22.6 million barrels of oil per day exceeding its self imposed quota of 22.5 million barrels per day set last July. Iraq and Kuwait produced about 4 million barrels per day before the Gulf crisis that began with the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The global community immediately boycotted oil from Iraq and Kuwait, and some OPEC nations began producing more than their quotas of crude oil to make up for the shortfall. Analysts have said producing nations will be reluctant to cut back on the oil they pump once Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude is put back in the marketplace, particularly since prices are likely to be depressed at that point. Kartasasmita predicted the production may rise further to reach 23 million barrels per day as demand for OPEC oil will rise from 22.5 million barrels in the third quarter to an estimated 23 million or 23.5 million barrels per day in the fourth quarter of this year. Indonesia currently produces about 1.3 million barrels of crude oil per day and exports about 780,000 barrels. Kartasasmita said the country will raise its output to 1.4 million barrels per day next month.

DOC.HEAD: EC Asks Procter & Gamble To Suspend Cooperation Deal With Finaf SpA
DOC.TEXT: The European Community Commission asked Procter & Gamble Co. of the United States and Italy's Finaf SpA on Tuesday to suspend a plan to cooperate on making diapers and other personal hygienic products. The companies said in September they plan to create joint ventures in Italy, Spain and Portugal for their paper products businesses, notably diapers and sanitary napkins. Also, Procter said it would buy all of Finaf's activities in Britain. The Commission asked the companies to hold off until it is satisfied ``there is no breach'' of EC fair competition rules. A Commission official said the accord could create or strengthen dominant positions by the two companies and received a complaint about the planned venture from Peau Douce SA, a French diaper maker. Peau Douce argued Procter's deal with Finaf would violate competition rules and asked for interim measures to stop the agreement from taking effect. The EC treaty bans undertakings that prevent, restrict or distort fair copetition in the 12-nation trade bloc. Procter & Gamble, which is based in Cincinnati, Ohio, and Finaf have been in touch with the Commission since before they announced plans for their linkup. David Veitch, a spokesman at Procter & Gamble's European headquarters here, said, ``It has always been our intention not to implement this agreement until the competent authorities have been heard.'' The EC Commission official said discussions with the two companies were continuing and if these ``go satisfactorily, we can resolve the problem without going further to law.'' Veitch said under the deal with Finaf, the two companies were ``to merge their paper product business'' in Italy, Spain and Portugal. Procter & Gamble, the maker of Pampers, is a leading diaper producer. But Veitch said the company ``was a relatively small player in Europe'' in sanitary napkins and other personal hygiene paper goods. ``The purpose of the agreement (with Finaf) was to accelerate our entry'' into those products in Europe, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Little Changed; Adjusting To Soviet News
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were narrowly mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade as the marets adjusted to indications there may be no large U.S. grain sales to the Soviet Union in the coming year. A top Soviet grain-buying official said Monday after meeting with U.S. Agriculture Department officials that he expects a U.S. offer of food export credits in six months, but that the Soviets will have filled their food needs from other sources by then. Grain and soybean futures prices fell broadly Monday after Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter reaffirmed the Bush administration's position that any export credits or subsidized grain sales to the Soviet Unions would be contingent on Soviet emigration reforms. Yeutter said today that the Soviet Union has not formally requested food aid from the United States. In early trading, wheat futures were \ cent lower to } cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.43\ a bushel; corn was } cent to 1{ cents lower with December at $2.18 a bushel; oats were { cent lower across the board with December at $1.04 a bushel; and soybeans were 1 cent lower to 2 cents higher with January at $5.76\ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after the Agriculture Department on Monday issued a monthly report that showed unexpectedly large supplies of frozen pork bellies. Live cattle were unchanged to .38 cent lower with December at 79.37 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent to .50 cent lower with January at 87.72 cents a pound; live hogs were .17 cent to .50 cent lower with December at 51.85 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were .35 cent to 1.45 cents lower with February at 68.10 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Hyundai's Auto Exports to U.S. Hits One Million Mark
DOC.TEXT: Hyundai Motor Co. marked a milestone Tuesday when its auto exports to the United States surpassed the 1 million mark, the biggest South Korean automaker said. The company said it has now exported 1,000,021 cars to the United States since it entered the market in February 1986. The exports to the U.S. account for two-thirds of Hyundi's global auto exports of 1.5 million cars during the past four years and 10 months. Hyundai entered the American market in 1986 with subcompact Pony sedans. Hyundai's annual auto exports worldwide peaked at 408,000 in 1988 but declined to 209,000 last year with a loss of price competitiveness and due to sluggish demands in some foreign markets. Hyundai expects its global auto exports to rise to 230,000 cars this year because of a pickup in sales in Europe, including East-bloc countries which are emrging as new markets for Korea.

DOC.HEAD: Globe-Girdling Group Banks on Women
DOC.TEXT: For Gail Edwards, getting down to business means roving the central Maine countryside with her four young children in search of wild herbs and flowers to blend into natural teas and tonics. Annual sales of her home-made potions amounted to a mere $200 last year. But this spring Edwards expects to sell $20,000 worth of products thanks to a $5,000 loan secured with the help of Women's World Banking. The non-profit group has helped at least 250,000 women worldwide get started in business over the past decade through counseling or by securing loans. ``It brought my business from essentially a dream into a thriving business,'' said the 41-year-old Edwards, a single mother who had little hope of getting a bank loan before Women's World Banking's Maine affiliate took up her cause. Although it pales in size to other global lending institutions, the New York-based group has had a profound economic - and political - impact in clearing the way for many businesswomen. In Thailand, the group helped 100 women start a dairy cooperative by helping them get loans totaling $1 million. And the group's affiliate in India has grown into an active savings and loan program for about 60,000 women - many of them from the lowly regarded untouchable caste. Thanks to negotiations by the group, the governments of Japan and Kenya have stricken regulations that required women to have their loans guaranteed by their husbands or fathers. ``In most countries of Latin America and Asia, the cultural barrier has been broken,'' said group president Nancy Barry. Ironically, the United States is the final frontier for the global organization, she said. Focusing on developing countries since its inception 10 years ago, the group's five U.S. affiliates thus far only have the power to help women draw up business plans, write loan applications and suggest alternate funding routes. But before the end of the year, at least one branch - the Akron, Ohio, affiliate - expects to start guaranteeing bank loans like its overseas counterparts. It's a significant step. Despite notions of the United States as progressive in women's rights, old ways sometimes die hard in the nation's predominantly male lending industry. ``Credit isn't without bias, which is different than discrimination,'' said Barbara Lange, executive director of Women's Entrepreneurial Growth Organization (WEGO), the Akron branch. ``A part of the lending process has to do with the comfort level of the banking officer.'' For example, when physical therapist Claudia Miller set out last year to get a loan to start her own practice in Akron, the single woman had no idea her marital status would become a liability. But the bank's loan officer essentially ignored the financial case she'd built and instead insisted on checking out the income level of her part-time partner's husband. Miller, 42, decided to seek an alternative method of funding. Working with WEGO - not yet set up to guarantee loans - Miller developed a cohesive business plan that led to a creative alternative. Instead of outright buying the $75,000 high-tech business equipment her practice required, Miller agreed to lease it with an option to buy later on. Such creativity is repeated throughout the 40 countries in which Women's World Banking has branches. In the case of Edwards, the potion purveyor, Women's World Banking helped her write a business plan that convinced a local economic development agency to loan her $5,334. She spent the money on newspaper advertisements, a 12-page mail-order catalog and spiffy packaging. Her business plan already has shown positive results. Edwards said she was working 16-hour days to meet the surge in requests for her wild-gathered potions of comfrey, colts foot and other medicinal herbs. And this fall, the West Athens, Maine, woman was able to achieve a nearly 20-fold jump in sales from the previous year - a windfall since her only other source of income was food stamps and $80 a month in child support. With her new-found income, Edwards, who left Hoboken, N.J., 20 years ago, hopes to turn an outside shed into a new drying area for her herbs. Barry, the Women's World Banking president, said women generally are good loan risks because they ``tend to be very practical and have their feet on the ground,'' know how to ``juggle a lot of balls at a time,'' and are ``balanced with a sense of the possible.'' ``All of those skills are precisely what it takes to make a small business work,'' explained Barry, 41, a former World Bank employee who pioneered that group's projects in small business development in 1975. Barry, a Harvard MBA graduate, spends her weeks girdling the globe to make sure things are running smoothly. During a recent workday, ten floors above the screeching congestion of midtown Manhattan, Barry filled her corner office with smoke from her freshly lit Marlboro - taken from a 10-cigarette pack she pocketed from a airplane from Tokyo the night earlier. She noted that her November itinerary called for stops in no less than seven countries. ``I actually got to sleep in my own bed last night - it was kind of exciting,'' she said, as she prepared to leave Malaysia in two days.

DOC.HEAD: U.N.: East Europeans Likely Face Hardest Winter Since WWII
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Embargoed for release at 6 p.m. EST; time Set by source. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union and its former allies are likely to face the hardest winter since World War II as recession, compounded by rising oil prices, continues to deepen, U.N. economists said Tuesday. The economists drew a grim picture of increasing food shortages in the Soviet Union, Bulgaria and Romania, soaring unemployment rates throughout the region and double-digit inflation. These threats could stall the whole reform process of moving from a command to a market economy. ``The consequences of such a failure are incalculable and would not only be economic,'' they warned in a 147-page report, which also pointed to ``increasing signs of social unrest in the East.'' ``One certain effect would be to raise enormous pressures for emigration from the East to the West,'' said the survey, compiled by experts of the U.N. Economic Commission for Europe. It noted that new Soviet legislation would soon allow unrestricted travel abroad. ``There seems to be little ground for contradicting the view that the people of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union are facing their hardest winter since the end of the second World War,'' it said. The survey also said slower economic growth in Western Europe and fears that the United States could slide into recession may have an impact on financial and technical support for the East. Moscow's former Eastern European allies depend on the Soviet Union for about 80 percent of their oil. Transmission breakdowns have already reduced Soviet exports by more than a fifth, the survey noted. Starting Jan. 1, 1991, payment for Soviet oil will have to be in convertible currency and at world market prices. Under the region's Comecon trading system, to be dissolved on that date, Moscow's partners have paid the equivalent of about $7.50 per barrel in transferable rubles. This compared with an average $18 paid on world markets before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. If Eastern Europe has to buy oil at $35 or even $40 a barrel, then the ``price shock is much larger'' than the ones faced by the West in the 1970s, the survey said. The Comecon trading system, based on bilateral agreements, has already effectively collapsed, the survey said. ``During the course of this year, a chaotic mixture of barter deals, clearing agreements and hard-currency transactions have emerged,'' it added. To avoid accumulation of rubles, the survey said, Moscow's partners have resorted to avariety of trade restrictions that led to retaliations and a ``virtual trade war.''

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Stepping Up Probe of Reported Ford Seat Belt Failures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT date to 1984, sted 1948. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Federal engineers are stepping up an investigation of reported seat belt failures in 1984 and 1985 Ford Mustang automobiles, the government reported today. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said it had upgraded the probe from a preliminary evaluation - an examination of paperwork - to an engineering analysis, in which engineers will study the possibly defective parts. Agency spokesman Tim Hurd said there had been 21 complaints of plastic components in the seat belt buckles breaking so the belt could not be latched. An estimated 273,500 of the vehicles are on the road. The agency also announced it was similarly upgrading its investigation of reported cracks in the floors of Ward 54 school buses, manufactured from 1983 to 1990 by the American Transportation Co. Hurd said such cracks had been reported in 11 fleets totaling 103 buses. The agency discontinued an investigation of reported rollover propensities of Ford Bronco II automobiles manufactured between 1984 and 1989, saying it found no unreasonable risk.

DOC.HEAD: North American Trade Bloc Envisioned in Trade Talks, But Opposition Remains
DOC.TEXT: One giant economy stretching from above the snowy Arctic Circle to below the sun-baked Yucatan Peninsula - that's the dream of promoters of a North American trade bloc. The United States, Canada and Mexico need to form a common market to counter emerging free-trade zones in Europe and Asia, say these boosters, who count President Bush among their numbers. Also, supporters say, it only makes sense for the United States to ease trade restrictions with its southern neighbor and third-largest trading partner, Mexico, since it did so with its No. 1 partner, Canada, two years ago. Following a U.S.-Mexico agreement, a North American free-trade zone could be created by a companion pact between Canada and Mexico, an idea already backed by Canadian officials. That could mean products made in any one of the three nations could be freely sold in the other two - creating a vast consumer market of more than 360 million people. Bush endorsed a North American common market in his presidential campaign two years ago. He was in Mexico on Monday and Tuesday for talks with President Carlos Salinas de Gortari on establishing a U.S.-Mexico free-trade pact, the next step in creating such a trading zone. Supporters say such an accord would bring a number of benefits to Americans, including cheaper goods made by U.S. companies in Mexico, an expanded market for U.S. products in Mexico, and a counterbalance to the barrier-free Europe planned by the end of 1992, as well as moves by Japan toward forming an Asian trade bloc. ``Given the competition of the Asian countries, and Japan especially, the United States has to have access to cheaper labor in order to be able to compete internationally,'' said Abel Beltran-del-Rio, chief economist for Ciemex-Wefa, an economic consulting firm specializing in Mexico. For Mexicans, a pact should boost the nation's troubled economy by luring U.S. investment in plants and technology. It also should open up the U.S. market to more Mexican products, particularly agricultural goods, boosters say. For both countries, a pact could ease friction over illegal Mexican aliens in the United States. Supporters say there should be less reason for Mexican laborers to migrate to the United States if there are more jobs at home. In addition, Mexican officials want the pact to include provisions making it easier for Mexicans to enter and work in this country. Despite these factors favoring a free-trade pact, don't expect duty-free tequila anytime soon. Detractors, especially organized labor, are expected to fiercely fight any agreement that could result in a weaker bargaining position for U.S. workers and a loss of U.S. factory jobs. ``Who gains from the agreement are U.S. or multinational companies that can take advantage of very, very low wages,'' along with minimal environmental and worker-safety rules in Mexico, said Candice Johnson, a spokeswoman for the AFL-CIO. She said an idea of the outcome of a trade pact can be seen by examining the ``maquiladoras,'' the thriving U.S. assembly plants located just over the Mexican border. There, Mexican workers toil for as little as $2.90 a day under conditions resembling sweatshops of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the union coalition contends. Ms. Johnson said a North American free-trade agreement would be ``a disaster for U.S. workers and ultimately Canadian workers, because everything's going to be made in Mexico.'' Mexican officials and other boosters say any loss of U.S. jobs would be offset by an increase in U.S. exports to its southern neighbor. For each incremental dollar Mexico would receive through the pact, about 15 cents would end up going to the United States through the purchase of U.S. goods, said Edgardo Mendoza Valdes, an official of the Mexican stock brokerage Probursa and a representative of the Mexican financial sector to the trade talks. Under a free-trade agreement, each nation would manufacture what it does best or cheapest, he said. ``There will be losses in some (U.S.) sectors and there will be gains in other sectors, from exporters,'' said Beltran-del-Rio, the economist. He also predicts U.S. exports to the rest of the world would be boosted by the use of Mexican labor, bolstering the U.S. economy. ``I don't see why the United States cannot grow like it used to grow when its cost structure was more competitive in the world.'' But Mexico has its own critics of a free-trade agreement. Among their concerns is the sanctity of Mexico's vast oil reserves, nationalized in 1938 after accusations that U.S. oil companies were exploiting the nation. These critics don't want any free-trade pact to include the right for U.S. oil companies to gain control of Mexican oil fields. Since Salinas took office in December 1988, Mexico has lowered tariffs and joined the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs, which his predecessors strongly opposed. The United States shipped $24.97 billion worth of goods to Mexico in 1989 and imported $27.19 billion in Mexican goods, for a U.S. trade deficit with Mexico of $2.2 billion.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Higher; Pound Rises with Major's Victory
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices ended slightly higher on London's Stock Exchange Tuesday, but well down from session peaks, as some institutional investors began to have second thoughts about the possibility of a cut in British base lending rates. The pending vote on the leadership of the Conservative Party and a dearth of corporate and economic news also limited the gain, dealers said. The market closed before Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major's victory was announced. Foreign currency trading was affected by the announcement, however. The pound rose to $1.9790 after the news from $1.9750 before. It had closed at $1.9655 on Monday. Against the German mark, the British currency rose to 2.9238 marks from 2.9220 marks. It ended at 2.9317 marks on Monday. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 7.6 points, or 0.4 percent, at 2,159.5. The peak was a gain of 14.2 points. The Financial Times 300-share index was up 1.1 points at 1,699.7. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 2.14 points to close at 1,138.76. Volume came to 378.6 million shares, compared with 345.7 million shares Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Offers Cheap Winter Fares to Europe
DOC.TEXT: Pan American World Airways said Tuesday it would offer cheap winter fares to London in hopes of attracting more passengers during the slow winter travel season. The cash-strapped carrier said passengers who buy tickets by Dec. 7 can get a one-way fare of $149 from New York to London, based on a roundtrip purchase, with fares slightly higher from other cities served by Pan Am. Two of Pan Am's competitors on the trans-Atlantic flights, Trans World and British Airways, had no immediate comment on whether they intended to slash any fares in response. Airlines usually move quickly to match cheap fares offered by rival carriers for fear they could otherwise lose passengers in the highly competitive industry. The Pan Am fares, which are non-refundable and available on only a limited number of seats, are good for travel between Jan. 7 and March 21, but the trips must begin by March 14. ``The softening of air traffic demand expected during the first quarter of 1991 due to weakening economic conditions has prompted us to offer winter salfe fares to Europe,'' said John Bloodworth, a Pan Am spokesman. ``We are confident that the fares will stimulate traffic during the traditionally slow winter travel period.'' Pan Am is also offering some sale fares to most of its other 33 destinations in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Theater Company Restructures Financing
DOC.TEXT: The Cineplex Odeon movie theater chain said Tuesday it had reached an agreement with its banks that allows the company to defer principal payments until mid-1992. The preliminary four-year agreement also allows the company to hold on to assets that were to be sold under a previous loan agreement. Cineplex had been committed to selling $160 million (U.S.) in assets by Sept. 30. The company had raised $120 million (U.S.) by selling U.S. theater properties. The new agreement also combines the company's banks in two separate syndicates with three outside banks to form a single bank group. Cineplex Odeon is one of the largest theater operators in North America with 1,700 screens in 415 locations. The company has been struggling recently because of a large debt load amassed in an aggressive expansion by former Chairman Garth Drabinsky. In an effort to turn things around, Cineplex has been peddling assets not connected to its main cinema business. The company has been loaned $100 million (U.S.) by the Claridge Group, controlled by Montreal financier Charles Bronfman, and the U.S. entertainment conglomerate MCA Inc., which was bought Monday by the Japanese electronics firm Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd. The new banking deal requires that this debt be converted to Cineplex stock by May 31, 1991. In addition, MCA and Claridge have agreed to provide the company with a $35 million (U.S.) line of credit. The new banking deal should help the company's restructuring campaign, said Peter Legault, an analyst with the brokerage Thomson Kernaghan.

DOC.HEAD: Yields Fall on 2-Year Notes
DOC.TEXT: Yields on two-year Treasury notes fell in Tuesday's auction to the lowest level in more than 2{ years. The average yield was 7.49 percent, down from 7.84 percent at the last auction on Oct. 30. It was the lowest rate since two-year notes averaged 7.39 percent on March 23, 1988. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 7] percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,979.00. A total of $12.35 billion in notes were sold out of bids totaling $35.24 billion.

DOC.SECOND: BC-The New Workplace I, Adv02-2 Takes,1136
DOC.NOTE: $adv02
For release Sunday, Dec. 2, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: First in a Series. Also moved on general news wires
Part I: More And More Companies Putting Workers In Charge
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Series Logo
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Economists say that if corporate America is to succeed in the midst of recession and increasing global competition, workers must become more productive. In the first of a three-part series examining ``The New Workplace,'' Sharon Cohen looks at how more and more companies, large and small, are turning bored workers into effective bosses, and getting dramatic results. ---

When Ralph Stayer's workers botched sales orders, mislabeled products and even smashed a forklift into a wall, he didn't moan, he didn't groan, he just changed bosses. Stayer put his workers in charge. Yes, the same bored people who made careless, costly errors, he decided, could run his company, make it more profitable and turn it into a bigger, better business. That's precisely what happened at Johnsonville Foods, a family owned sausage company where workers reign supreme. They hire and fire each other, buy equipment, write budgets. They are their own bosses. ``Everyone looks at what we're doing and says, `God, that's knd of flaky, that's kind of goody-goody, warm and fuzzy,''' said Stayer, Johnsonville's chief executive officer and owner. ``It isn't a soft or crazy deal. I'm a real hard-nosed pragmatic guy. . .. Teach people to do for themselves, this way you get a far better performance.'' This run-it-yourself philosophy, in place for eight years at Johnsonville, is spreading across corporate America, from small companies to Fortune 500 heavy-hitters such as IBM, General Mills and Goodyear. The rank and file are taking charge like never before, using brains, not brawn, on the assembly line. Nowadays, steel and auto workers, sausage stuffers, cereal packers, engine makers and others work in teams without bosses, set profit goals, write schedules, develop products, meet customers, design assembly lines, even pore over financial records. ``It's not a social experiment. It makes good business sense,'' said Pat McNulty, who manages a new worker-run General Mills cereal plant in Georgia. ``Nobody knows the job as well as those doing it. If you empower those people to make the decisions, they make good ones.'' The payoff: reduced costs, better quality, greater efficiency. McNulty expects productivity to be 30 percent to 40 percent higher than traditional plants; Johnsonville sales have increased more than 20 percent annually since the changes were made, and productivity has increased 50 percent since 1986. ``It's one of those rare situations where everybody wins,'' said John Zenger, president of a California consulting firm. ``Companies become more competitive. The employees ... learn more skills. The more you have a sense of autonomy, the happier a camper you are.'' ``You feel like you're going to your own business, not like you're going to do something for somebody else,'' said General Mills worker Rhonda Lunsford. Though some companies started this approach long ago, much of the growth has occurred in the past few years. A recent survey of 476 Fortune 1,000 companies found 46 percent had some employees in self-managed work teams, compared with 27 percent three years ago. And more than half say they'll use more teams in the future, said Ed Lawler, a University of Southern California management professor who conducted the survey. The motives: increasing global competition and greater profits. The success of Japanese businesses, and Japan's much-touted management style, has helped to spark changes in this country. ``Companies don't change because they're nice,'' Lawler said. ``They change because they want to make money. ... If it wasn't for Japan Inc., I don't think a lot of this would be happening.'' Though this philosophy won't work everywhere - it's pointless in factories with simple repetitive tasks - changes are occurring in paper mills, oil refineries, chemical plants and elsewhere, usually in non-union settings. Consider: -At Chaparral Steel in Midlothian, Texas, production workers have traveled to Japan, Europe and Canada to evaluate and decide what kind of equipment should be purchased. One lathe operator found a machine for half the $1.5 million budgeted for it. ``He knew more about the machine than anyone else,'' said Dennis Beach, vice president of human resources. ``If you're not going to be responsible, you might as well be a monkey on an assembly line,'' said millwright Mike Glenn. -At Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co.'s hose plant in Mount Pleasant, Iowa, there is no seniority, no time clock, no supervisors - just a manager and teams, with rotating coordinators. ``It's nothing like a factory,'' said worker Danny Pulse. ``You're actually in on everything - from making it to sending it out the door. It's not th same old grind every day. You don't get burned out. You're making your own decisions. You actually get to use your own judgment.'' Workers, too, determine if colleagues deserve raises. ``Sometimes the sparks fly,'' said human resources manager Dave Smith. ``You have to take constructive criticism and not everyone can.'' -At General Mills' plant in Covington, Ga., workers, or ``technicians,'' do their own maintenance, scheduling and clerical jobs, make quality checks, handle disciplinary problems and participate in interviewing and selecting new employees. ``You have to want to take a leadership role,'' said McNulty, the plant manager. ``That's kind of different from the person who wants to come in and be told what to do.'' -At IBM's Rochester, Minn., plant, as in many other places, workers can shut down production lines. One did this year when she spotted a defect on a device built into a computer storage product, saving money and customer inconvenience. Workers there recently won the coveted Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Award. -At the Springfield Remanufacturing Corp., workers in the Missouri-based privately owned company have access to financial records, learn how to read income statements and can start spinoff businesses, sharing profits. If it all seems more democratic, Robert Bies, an associate management professor at Georgetown University, warns, ``The rhetoric is far ahead of the reality.'' ``Many of the companies haven't woken up to the call of competition,'' he added. ``People have to give up authority and they don't like it.'' This approach has drawbacks, too, such as reducing promotion possibilities, eliminating seniority rights and creating new pressures. ``If for the last 10 years, you've been telling people what to do, then they say, `You're not going to do this anymore,' (You think) `What am I going to do?''' said Robert Kelley, management professor at Carnegie Mellon University's Graduate School of Industrial Administration.

DOC.HEAD: SHEBOYGAN, Wis.: Industrial Administration.
DOC.TEXT: At Johnsonville, everything didn't click immediately. ``Do you think we had people doing budgets the first day they walked in? We spent five years at that,'' Stayer said. Workers, dubbed ``members,'' also train one another, decide how much to spend on equipment, cut their hours when necessary and choose which ``associates'' - those hired during busy seasons - become full-time employees. There are no supervisors, just coaches. Initiative is required. One team designed an assembly line. A bookkeeper suggested a mail-order business and shares the profits. ``They feel like they own it, and therefore act like owners,'' said Linda Honold, a former coach who works with Stayer advising other companies. Things weren't always so smooth, said Lori Lehmann, Johnsonville's statistics and hiring coordinator, who recalls how she used to call in sick to avoid work. ``There was no direction, no communication with the supervisors. ... You didn't express ideas,'' she said. ``You'd punch in, do your job, punch out.'' Stayer knew something was wrong, despite strong sales. In the November-December issue of the Harvard Business Review, he describes how workers mislabeled products, sprayed water on them and made other mistakes. ``People didn't care,'' he said. ``They didn't invest much of themselves in their jobs. I had to change to make them be more important so their jobs would be more important.'' This approach, begun in 1982, is flourishing. ``I don't get a lot of pressure from above,'' said worker Michelle Stock. ``I'm not just standing there doing my thing. I'm paying attention. You're thinking about what's going on. You're thinking about the results.'' Johnsonville has no cost-of-living increases or seniority raises. Members receive more money only if they assume more responsibility. Bonuses, tied to the company's performance, amount to 28 percent of pre-tax profits. That's what it's all about. ``They're far more valuable people,'' Stayer said. ``These people have skills that they can take anywhere. That's real morality.''

DOC.HEAD: Phone Co. Stake Valued at $400 Million to $600 Million
DOC.TEXT: The government's 30 percent stake in the phone company ENTel will be offered to investors early next year for $400 million to $600 million, a financial analyst said Tuesday. The stock offering will be the biggest in Argentine history, said Enrique Ruete Aguirre, chief executive officer of the Roberts Group that advised the government on the ENTel sale. Earlier this month, the Empresa Nacional de Telecomunicaciones (ENTel) was broken into two regional companies and privatized. European and U.S. investors agreed to pay a combined down payment of $214 million cash and $380 million in notes for 60 percent of ENTel. They also agreed to retire $5 billion of Argentine foreign debt worth about $750 million on secondary markets. Of the 30 percent to be sold, 5 percent will be offered first to Argentina's 200 rural telephone cooperatives. The remaining stock - and any of the 5 percent unsold - will go on sale in Argentina and New York next April or May, Ruete said. It initially will e offered for over-the-counter trading, Ruete said, before applying to be listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Pepsi's Right to Split From Perrier
DOC.TEXT: PepsiCo Inc. on Tuesday won a court battle to break its business relationship with Source Perrier and take direct control of its soft drink operations in France. The Paris commercial court officially recognized that the franchise bottling relationship between PepsiCo and a unit of Source Perrier SA will expire at the end of this year. The decision clears the way for Pepsi Cola France SA to take direct control of bottling and distributing Pepsi brand beverages in France at the beginning of next year. Officials at Perrier, the maker of the well-known sparking mineral water, had no immediate comment. It was not known whether the court ruling would be appealed. PepsiCo announced a year ago that it intended to end its franchising agreement with Perrier. Stuart Haugen, managing director of Pepsi Cola France, said Pepsi's market share in France had fallen over a decade from 18 percent to 9 percent. Haugen blamed inadequate distribution efforts by Perrier, asserting that Pepsi Cola ``clearly wasn't a priority business for them.'' He said Pepsi Cola accounted for only 1 percent to 2 percent of Perrier's annual revenue. Perrier said the steady decline in Pepsi sales was due to insufficient publicity by the U.S. group and its refusal to launch Diet Pepsi, a low-calorie cola, on the French market. Perrier said Pepsi Cola's announcement that it intended to break off its contract was timed to coincide with a bid by the U.S. company to buy Perrier's soft-drink business outright. Perrier sold its soft-drink assets to Cadbury-Schweppes PLC of Britain in March. In May 1989, Pepsi Cola's arch rival, Coca-Cola Co., agreed to buy its French bottler from its parent, Pernod-Ricard SA, ending a bitter feud between those companies.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Rebound As Soviet-Linked Selling Fades
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices rose Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, rebounding late in the session after selling that was linked to dimming prospects for Soviet purchases. Wheat and corn futures closed slightly lower. Market analysts said the late surge in soybean prices appeared to have been prompted by technical signals because there was no fresh news to spark a rally. The strong finish erased Monday's moderate losses, which had reflected disappointment in the outlook for new Soviet purchases of U.S. agricultural products. Statements made Monday and early Tuesday by U.S. and Soviet officials indicated the Soviet Union may not be a large buyer of U.S. grain in the coming year. Richard Feltes, research director with the commodities brokerage Refco Inc., said the recent volatility in the soybean market suggested prices have bottomed out. ``This is a wild, choppy time and it's difficult to take a stand and be committed for very long, but my long-term view is that we're headed higher,'' he said. At the close, wheat futures were { cent to 3\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.42\ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 2} cents lower with December at $2.18{ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to 2} cents higher with December at $1.07\ a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to 6{ cents higher with January at $5.83 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: More than 40 Jobs Cuts At Two WPP Agencies
DOC.TEXT: Advertising agencies owned by WPP Group PLC, the world's largest ad and marketing services agency group, have decided to cut more than 40 jobs because of the loss of two major accounts, a spokesman said Tuesday. At the same time, a company source said WPP Chairman Martin Sorrell has issued an internal company memo pressing department heads to cut costs when they draw up their budgets next month. The memo follows WPP's warning last week that its annual pre-tax profit wouldn't match analysts forecasts of 110 million pounds, or $217 million. Forty employees are leaving J. Walter Thompson's 490-member London staff due to the loss of the National Westminster Bank account, said a WPP spokesman, who asked not to be identified. The spokesman also confirmed a published report that another WPP agency, Scali McCabe Sloves, is cutting jobs in New York because of the loss of the Volvo car account. He did not say how many jobs were being cut, but The Wall Street Journal said about 35 people were being cut from a staff of 260. Marvin Sloves, who heads the agency, was said to be involved in meetings and was unavailable for comment on the report. The agency recently resigned the Volvo account amid controversy over an advertisement that purported to show a Volvo surviving relatively intact while other cars were crushed by a ``monster'' pickup truck with oversized wheels. It turned out that the Volvo was reinforced with steel and wood while other cars were structurally weakened before the ad was shot. WPP has vaulted to the top of the advertising world in terms of billings in the past five years. It bought the parent of the J. Walter Thompson ad agency and the Hill & Knowlton public relations agency in 1987, and bought the parent of another venerable agency, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, two years later. In addition, it has acquired dozens of smaller marketing services agencies that specialize in areas such as packaging and design. But in the process, the company has accumulated a debt which totaled 325 million British pounds at the end of 1989. As the growth of ad spending has slowed in recent months, some analysts expect that Sorrell will take aggressive action to cut costs, possibly including asset sales.

DOC.HEAD: AAA Says Prices Up This Week
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline prices rose an average 0.7 cent a gallon in the week ended Tuesday and could rise more by the weekend if retailers begin passing a new 5-cent-a-gallon tax to motorists, the American Automobile Association said. The new federal excise tax, part of the the budget package agreed to by President Bush and Congress last month, takes effect this Saturday. The tax will raise the current excise levy to 14 cents a gallon from 9 cents. AAA's Fuel Gauge Report, a weekly nationwide survey conducted for the group by Computer Petroleum Corp. of St. Paul, Minn., showed the average price of self-serve regular unleaded gasoline was $1.366 a gallon, vs. $1.359 a week ago. Self-serve unleaded costs 29.1 cents more a gallon than on Aug. 1, the day before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, which precipitated a Persian Gulf military crisis and a rapid increase in the price of crude oil. AAA, based in Orlando, Fla., said fuel costs were up in New England, the Great Lakes region and the West, but declined slightly in other regions.

DOC.HEAD: Cable Network Locates Productions at Disney-MGM Studios
DOC.TEXT: The Sci-Fi Channel cable television network announced Tuesday that its science fiction, fantasy and horror programming will be produced at Disney-MGM Studios. The network plans to launch its service early next year on cable TV systems with more than 5 million subscribers. Creators of the channel list ``Star Trek'' creator Gene Roddenberry as an adviser and sci-fi author Isaac Asimov as official spokesman. ``The Haunted House'' game show, ``NASA Watch'' and ``The Comic Book Show'' will be among the programs produced at Walt Disney World. Theme-park visitors will be able to view some of the Sci-Fi productions while shooting or in rehearsal through a soundproof glass wall.

Stock prices posted modest gains today after a morning of aimless trading. Analysts said there was little direction for traders. Oil prices dipped briefly in the early afternoon, sending stock prices higher, but then oil recovered and stocks gave back much of their gain. Trading was light but volatile, said Dudley Eppel, a managing director at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. ``It's all over the place. It's really a minute-to-minute game,'' he said. Eppel said there was no economic news to affect the market, and ``not much conviction either way'' prices went. DOC.HEAD: Major Expected to Pursue Softer but Thatcherite Line
DOC.TEXT: As Britain's next prime minister, John Major is expected to pursue kinder, gentler versions of Margaret Thatcher's free-market policies. Major, the nation's top treasury official for the past 13 months, was the financial markets' popular choice. The pound rose strongly Tuesday on word that he defeated two challengers to become the new leader of the Conservative Party. The pound rose to $1.9790 after the news from $1.9750 before. It closed at $1.9655 on Monday. The stock market, which closed for the day before Major's victory was announced, was expected to rise when it reopened Tuesday. ``It's as good a result as we could have hoped for. We have a former chancellor (of the exchequer) leading the country,'' said Derek Scott, chief economist at the London investment firm Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd. Keith Skeoch, chief economist at James Capel and Co., said: ``The financial markets quite rightly see Major as a continuation of Thatcher.'' Major is a regarded as a free-marketeer who is expected to continue the Thatcherite policies of privatization, prudent tax cuts, and tight fiscal spending. ``I intend to build on the policies we have,'' he said when he began his campaign last Thursday. Opponents have accused him of being nothing more than Mrs. Thatcher's ``poodle,'' but supporters insist he is his own man. Mrs. Thatcher said she was thrilled he won. Major is expected to continue current economic policy of high interest rates to fight 10.9 percent inflation, although he is expected to cut the 14 percent base lending rate soon. The aim would be to maintain the Conservative Party's upward momentum in the opinion polls, which showed the Tories surging against the socialist Labor Party during the two-week leadership struggle. Major said Thursday his priorities were uniting the Conservative party and defeating the Labor party in the next general election, which must be called by mid-1992. David Owen, a British economist at the London investment firm Kleinwort Benson Ltd., said: ``The next 18 months or so of U.K. economic policy-making will certainly depend on when they hold the next election. All the Tories want to do is win the next election.'' Major he has pledged to review the highly unpopular per capita community charge or ``poll tax,'' suggesting it might be linked to taxpayers' ability to pay. ``I have become increasingly convinced that we can't leave things as they are,'' Major said about the tax. ``In no sense would I be afraid to make changes in government policy when I think it is wrong.'' He also said he would make the biggest tax cuts at the lower end of the tax brackets. High earners got the biggest breaks under Mrs. Thatcher. He is expected to be slightly more enthusiastic about European monetary union than the hostile Mrs. Thatcher, but still cautious. Major took the pound into Europe's exchange rate mechanism on Oct. 8, a move Mrs. Thatcher fought for years. He also wants Britain to be better represented in Europe discussions. However, he has said he wouldn't agree to a single currency and a single European bank being forced on Britain prematurely. Major, who has served as chancellor for a little more than a year, must deal with an economy that its expected to shrink a quarter to a half percentage point next year after growing 1 percent this year. Major might call an election as early as this coming spring to capitalize on the improved showing in the opinion polls, Owen said. ``He'll want to get a clear mandate from the electorate for the next five years,'' Owen said. ``He was only elected by the Conservative Party, not the electorate.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Japan Won't Comply With Computer Chip Pact, But Progress Made
DOC.TEXT: Japan will fall short of complying with a U.S. trade agreement covering computer chips by the time the pact expires next year, but progress has been made, a trade group said Tuesday in a report to President Bush. ``Overall, the report concludes that the trade agreement has succeeded in containing instances of dumping, and in moving toward a more open market for foreign semiconductors in Japan,'' said Wilf Corrigan, chairman of the Semiconductor Industry Association. Dumping is the sale of products in foreign markets below production costs. ``However, despite the recent progress that has been made, Japan will not have fully complied with the terms of the agreement when it expires next July,'' said Corrigan, who is chairman and chief executive of chip maker LSI Logic Corp. He added in his statement that the trade group believes a new chip pact is needed ``to ensure that the objectives of the 1986 agreement are achieved.'' The Semiconductor Industry Association released the statement with its annual report to Bush on the progress of the chip agreement. In a letter to Bush accompanying the report, SIA president Andrew Procassini said progress was hurt by the fact that Japan ``did not begin its initiatives in earnest until almost three years into the agreement.'' The report discusses two key elements of the 1986 pact: preventing Japanese chip makers from dumping their semiconductors on the U.S. market, and creating an open market for semiconductors in Japan. The report says market-access efforts finally are under way and are making progress. Foreign market share for semiconductors in Japan increased from 8.5 percent when the agreement was signed to 13.3 percent in this year's second quarter, it said. ``U.S. companies are aggressively pursuing opportunities in the Japanese market,'' the trade group said. The safeguards against dumping have encouraged new investment in the United States in two categories of chips that were most severely affected by the practice - dynamic random-access memory chips and erasable programmable read-only memory chips, the SIA said.

DOC.HEAD: No Recession for America's Favorite Sport
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on sports wire
DOC.TEXT: Baseball owners are doing better than ever, increasing their operating profits by 75 percent in 1989 to a record $214.5 million, according to financial figures obtained by The Associated Press. The 26 teams took in a record $1,241,059,000 in 1989, a 23 percent increase from the previous season. Their operating expenses were $1,026,550,000, a 16 percent increase from 1988. That left them with a pre-tax operating profit of $214,509,000, or an average of $8.3 million per team. The previous record profit of $121.6 million was set in 1988 on earnings of $1,007,519,000, baseball's first billion-dollar season. The figures were obtained by the AP from two baseball sources on the condition they not be identified. It was the sixth consecutive season baseball teams increased their operating profits. Because of the accounting practices of the various teams, financial figures for 1990 will not be available until next year. Chuck O'Connor, the head of management's Player Relations Committee, said the figures showed that baseball ``on an overall basis was doing quite well.'' ``The difficulty with it,'' he said Tuesday, ``is that you have to get below the aggregate figures to determine the level of health of the individual parts that make up the game - the 26 clubs. There, there's a different story. You can't look at the overall industry profits and say, `Therefore, my team in Pittsburgh is in great shape' or `My team in Kansas City is in great shape.''' O'Connor said that four clubs lost money in 1989 but that the figure would become nine based on an apportioned share of the tentative $280 million collusion settlement. Baseball has boomed since the mid-1980s. According to figures released by the commissioner's office in the past, the 26 teams lost $66.6 million in 1983 on revenues of $521.6 million, then cut the losses to $41 million in 1984 and $7.1 million in 1985. The teams made $11.5 million in 1986, the season after began shunning free agents. Two arbitrators found the conspiracy depressed player salaries and the profit soared to $103.3 million in 1987. In the four years following the start of the conspiracy, the teams made a total operating profit of $450.9 million. However, as part of the tentative settlement of the collusion cases, owners have agreed to give the Major League Baseball Players Association a payment that would amount to $280 million as of Jan. 2. Interest will be added if the payment is made after that date. One source said that approximately 50 percent of the 1989 revenues came from tickets sales, parking and concessions. Approximately 20 percent came from national radio and television contracts, 20 percent from local broadcasting contracts and the remainder from postseason games, advertising and other baseball-related revenue. Approximately 31.5 percent of the operating revenue was spent on player salaries, the source said.

DOC.HEAD: SBA Head Chides Parker Brothers for Careers Game
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, ``There are, with busines-ownership statistics; INSERTS 4 grafs after 8th graf pv, ``So everyone, with reaction from Washington attorney who first complained to company. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The head of the U.S. Small Business Administration chided Parker Brothers Inc. Tuesday for showing ``insensitivity to modern realities'' in a game that lists ``supermom'' and schoolteacher as key careers for girls. ``Parker Brothers is sending the wrong message to young girls,'' said SBA Administrator Susan Engeleiter. ``Even Barbie dolls come with business suits these days.'' ``Careers for Girls'' is a new board game targeted for girls ages 8-12. Players select from six ``careers'': super mom, schoolteacher, rock star, fashion designer, college graduate and animal doctor. Instructions for the game, packaged in a hot pink box, include ``Show us how you slow dance with your main squeeze,'' ``Describe your dream husband,'' ``Tell us the names of your eight children,'' and ``Burn all your chocolate chip cooies.'' Engeleiter said the game shows an ``insensitivity to modern realities in a society where women are making breakthroughs in almost every profession. ... I'm amazed that as we enter the 1990s, the game doesn't include such careers as business executives, government leaders, astronauts, scientists, or moms without the prefix `super.''' ``There are no leadership or policymaking careers on this Parker Brothers game board. There are no careers requiring physical daring or strength,'' she added, noting that women now own 30 percent of all businesses in the United States and that the SBA projects they will own 36 percent by the turn of the century. Company spokesman Patricia McGovern stressed the game is purely for entertainment and ``is certainly not to communicate that only certain careers are limited to women.'' The game was designed by a woman, art was managed by a woman and the product manager was a woman, she said. ``So everyone that was involved with bringing this game to market is female,'' said McGovern. ``We're really disappointed to hear the objections.'' The first to register a complaint with Parker Brothers about the game was Washington attorney Marna Tucker. ``I called them up and was infuriated about it,'' said Tucker. ``I think that right before the holiday season that Parker Brothers is about to step into something very smelly.'' Tucker said she and a few women's organizations are writing a letter demanding that Parker Brothers either withdraw the game from the market or ``contribute their profits from that to women education groups.'' ``They could do a lot of things with the profits that would be helpful to women, to assist women in breaking down further barriers,'' said Tucker. Actually ``Careers for Girls'' is an update of a 1957 version that listed as professions big business, prospecting, politics, going to sea, expedition to the moon, farming, Hollywood and college. McGovern said the careers were changed in 1971 to include ecology, space, sports, teaching and arts. Career changes were made again in 1979. The game was discontinued in 1984 ``because it had unfortunately lost its mass market appeal,'' said McGovern. ``We decided to reintroduce the game for the 1990s and target it to pre-teen girls because that is a growing niche in the market. Pre-teen girls have returned to playing board games.''
