DOC.HEAD: Dun & Bradstreet Pulls Two Units Off Sales Block
DOC.TEXT: The Dun & Bradstreet Corp. said Tuesday that it is no longer seeking buyers for two of its investment information subsidiaries, Datastream International and Interactive Data. The company cited current conditions in financial markets worldwide for pulling the two companies off the sales block. They generated a combined $155 million in revenue in 1989 and had been put up for sale in March as the company decided to shed some of its non-core businesses. Company spokesman Reid Gearhart declined to say whether there were any bids for the two companies or whether bids were too low. He said Dun & Bradstreet intended to ``continue to manage'' the companies at their current levels. He noted that in the third quarter, the parent company said Datastream had generated higher revenue than a year ago while revenue was down at Interactive Data largely because of the termination of certain services that had been provided under previous owners. Datastream International, based in London, provides investment information principally on international securities. Interactive Data, based in Lexington, Mass., provides securities-related information to the U.S. investment community. The two subsidiaries were among seven that Dun & Bradstreet has put up for sale this year. It has sold three of them while two others remain up for sale. Dun & Bradstreet is a world leader in marketing business information and related service with worldwide operating revenue of $4.3 billion in 1989. Its companies provide the Nielsen television audience ratings, Donnelley Directory listings and Moody's Investors Service credit reports.

DOC.HEAD: Consumers' View of Economy Continues To Sour
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Confidence in the economy has sunk to levels near the depths of the 1982 recession and consumers are paring spending plans entering the Christmas shopping season, a survey released Tuesday said. The Conference Board said its survey of consumer confidence in November found more people expecting higher unemployment and weaker business conditions in the coming months. Fabian Linden, a Conference Board economist, said consumer confidence has dropped to recession levels, ``and is now only marginally above the figure recorded during the lowest point of the 1982 economic downturn.'' The business research organization said its monthly Consumer Confidence Index continued to decline in November, falling to 61.5 from 62.6 in October. The index, which registered 115.1 in November 1989, edged down as the economy has weakened earlier this year, then tumbled after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August. It stood at 101.7 in July and then plunged to 84.7 in August. The survey aso found consumers continued to scale back plans for major expenditures in November, including cars, appliances and vacations. The Conference Board's survey results supported the predictions of economists and retail industry analysts who said consumers would spend less this Christmas because of concerns about the economy and the Middle East. Higher unemployment and higher prices for oil and other energy sources have left Americans with less money to spend on what are called discretionary items -clothing, appliances, furniture and gifts. Some retailers reported their holiday seasons began well, but others found consumers were already cutting back their gift-buying. Sears, Roebuck and Co., the nation's largest retailer, said many shoppers appeared to be looking rather than buying over the Thanksgiving Day weekend, and many appeared reluctant to commit themselves to big purchases. Sears said its sales were somewhat below expectations. Even smaller retailers and stores that sell toys and other merchandise popular this time of the year have been affected. Tonja Little, manager of the Huggable Hut, a stuffed-animal shop in Atlanta, said Tuesday that sales have fallen off sharply compared to last year at the same time. ``People are coming in and looking, but they're not buying,'' she said, adding, ``It has a lot to do with the economy slowing down.'' Sandra Shaber, an economist with the Futures Group in Washington D.C., described the Christmas season as ``off to a slow start.'' She said it was not so much a lack of confidence that has made consumers hesitant, but ``more a reflection of what's happened in the economy directly ... jobs have been lost since the summer and wages have not been keeping up with inflation.'' Elizabeth Armstrong, a retail industry analyst with Prescott, Ball & Turben, characterized Christmas sales so far as ``mixed to somewhat disappointing.'' She said warm weather in many parts of the country was another factor working against consumer spending. The Conference Board survey found that Americans have a dim view of the future. Of those asked, 34.4 percent said there would be fewer jobs available in six months, 9.7 percent said there would be more and 55.9 percent predicted employment would be the same. When asked what business conditions would be like in six months, 11.2 percent said they would be better, 29.5 said they would be worse and 59.3 said they would be the same. The consumer confidence survey was conducted by National Family Opinion Inc. of Toledo, Ohio, which questioned 5,000 households across the country. The Conference Board is a business-supported research group.

DOC.HEAD: Copper Futures Fall Sharply; Supplies Seen Easing
DOC.TEXT: Copper futures prices fell sharply Tuesday on New York's Commodity Exchange amid signs that supply tightness is easing. On other commodity markets, precious metals also fell; oil futures were mixed; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Copper futures settled 2.4 cents to 5.5 cents lower with the contract for delivery in November at $1.123 a pound, the lowest daily settlement for spot copper since June 27. The drop extended a decline from levels near $1.30 a pound just one month ago. Analysts said signs of easing supply tightness in London prompted Tuesday's early selling interest, which in turn triggered profit-taking and new selling by large speculative funds. Bette Raptopoulos, senior metals analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said an expected squeeze in supplies of copper for delivery against the soon-to-expire November contract did not materialize, and also spurred selling. Both she and analyst Fred Demler of PaineWebber Inc. noted that Tuesday's fundamental developments - a slight rise in the stock market and little change in crude oil prices - were bullish for copper. Nevetheless, Raptopoulos said, ``underlying it all are concerns about recession even though that did not surface today.'' Gold and silver futures retreated on the Commodity Exchange in dull trading that reflected a lack of new developments in the Persian Gulf standoff. Gold settled 50 cents to 90 cents lower with December at $385.80 a troy ounce; silver was 4.9 cents to 5.2 cents lower with December at $4.102 a troy ounce. Petroleum futures were little changed on the New York Mercantile Exchange as diplomats debated the timing of a United Nations deadline for Iraq to get out of Kuwait. Light sweet crude oil settled 9 cents lower to 25 cents higher with January at $32.86 a barrel; heating oil was .89 cent lower to .45 cent higher with December at 91.49 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .05 cent to .99 cent higher with December at 84.72 cents a gallon. Soybean futures prices rose on the Chicago Board of Trade, rebounding late in the session after selling interest faded with dimming prospects for Soviet purchases. Wheat and corn futures closed slightly lower. The strong finish in soybeans erased Monday's moderate losses, which had reflected disappointment in the outlook for new Soviet purchases of U.S. agricultural products. Statements made Monday and early Tuesday by U.S. and Soviet officials indicated the Soviet Union may not be a large buyer of U.S. grain in the coming year. Wheat futures settled unchanged to 2} cents lower with December at $2.42\ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 2\ cents lower with December at $2.18\ a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 2} cents higher with December at $1.07\ a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to 5} cents higher with January at $5.82\ a bushel. Cattle futures fell moderately on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting slow retail beef sales, end-of-the-month book-squaring, and selling ahead of first notice day Wednesday for the December live cattle contract. First notice day is the first opportunity for traders to declare their intention to deliver a physical commodity against a futures contract. Pork futures ended mostly higher, supported by lighter-than-expected cash hog sales that may have been due to winter storm conditions in major hog-producing states. Live cattle settled unchanged to .65 cent lower with December at 79.10 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent to .77 cent lower with January at 87.45 cents a pound; live hogs were .30 cent lower to .48 cent higher with December at 52.50 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .28 cent to .75 cent higher with February at 70.15 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls As Pound Dominates Trading, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against most major foreign currencies Tuesday as the British pound, boosted by the election of John Major as the country's next prime minister, dominated the foreign exchange markets. Gold prices slipped lower. The pound surged higher after Major, chancellor of the Exchequer - the British equivalent of the U.S. Treasury - was assured of becoming the next British prime minster. Major, who had the support of outgoing Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, fell just short of winning election as head of the Conservative Party Tuesday. But his challengers withdrew from the race and conceded defeat to Major, effectively giving him the prime minister's job. The pound rose to $1.9775 in New York from $1.96895 late Monday. In London trading before Major's election was assured, the pound rose to $1.9750 from $1.9655 late Monday. Foreign exchange traders had hoped Major would win because they were familiar with his policies and expected little change if he succeeded Mrs. Thatcher. Mike Faust, a currency market annalyst with Money Market Services in Chicago, said sterling's fortune might be short-lived. He said there was speculation among traders that the British government would lower base lending rates to 13.5 percent from their current 14 percent. Currencies are supported by higher interest rates, so a drop in British rates would make that country's investments less attractive and could send the pound lower. Faust said the dollar fell against other currencies amid the belief that the big industrial nations are satisfied with the dollar's low levels. In overseas trading, the dollar was hurt by a widening of the U.S. trade deficit. The Commerce Department said the deficit swelled to $29.75 billion in the July-September quarter, up 28.9 percent from $23.10 billion in the April-June period. Traders believe the U.S. government will be more inclined to keep the dollar lower as a means of narrowing the trade gap. A lower dollar makes imports into the U.S. more expensive, and this country's exports cheaper for overseas buyers. The dollar fell to 128.35 yen in New York from 129.05 yen late Monday. In Tokyo earlier, the dollar rose to 128.95 yen from 127.95 yen at Monday's close, and in London, the U.S. currency fell to 128.30 yen. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.48025 German marks, down from 1.4860; 1.2595 Swiss francs, down from 1.2620; 4.9950 French francs, down from 5.0130; 1,111.25 Italian lire, down from 1,116.125; and 1.16405 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16075. Other late dollar rates in Europe compared with late rates Monday included: 1.4800 German marks, down from 1.4920; 1.2600 Swiss francs, down from 1.2680; 4.9935 French francs, down from 5.0300; 1.6695 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6823; 1,109.75 Italian lire, down from 1,118.75, and 1.1632 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1596. Gold edged down 90 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $385.20 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $385.00, down $1.15. Gold fell earlier in London to a late bid of $384.75 a troy ounce, from $387.00 late Monday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing $384.00 an ounce, from $386.50 late Monday. In Hong Kong, gold fell $1.16 an ounce to $385.19. Silver slipped 4.9 cents on the Commodity Exchange, closing at $4.100 a troy ounce. Silver fell earlier in London to a late bid of $4.12 a troy ounce from $4.18 late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Litton Industry Earnings Drop, Sales Rise
DOC.TEXT: Litton Industries' first-quarter profit dropped 9 percent, due in part to slipping advanced electronics sales, but per-share earnings rose as the firm continued a stock buyback program. Overall sales posted a slight gain to $1.23 billion, from $1.22 billion in the 1990 period, paced by bigger sales in the shipbuilding segment, the company said Tuesday. Earnings for the quarter ended Oct. 31 were $39.6 million, compared with $43.6 million in the first quarter of 1990. Earnings per share were $1.76, up from $1.73. ``During the first quarter we repurchased an additional 1.4 million Litton common shares,'' said Orion L. Hock, chairman and chief executive. ``This continuation of our stock buyback program offset the earnings decline and resulted in a net gain for our earnings per share.'' Litton provides advanced electronic and defense systems, resource exploration services and industrial automation systems in the United States and abroad.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Slip In Response to Mixed Message From Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices were down slightly in uncertain trading Tuesday, as traders awaited action later this week on a United Nations resolution authorizing a military strike against Iraq. ``Clearly the traders yesterday and today are betting that there will be a war and there's some probability of that now,'' said Philip Dodge, oil analyst at Nomura Research Institute. Light sweet crude oil settled down 9 cents a barrel at $32.86 for January delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract had been off as much as 60 cents earlier in the day, partly in response to reports that U.N. diplomats would make Jan. 15 - instead of Jan. 1 - the deadline for Iraqi troop withdrawal from Kuwait. The later deadline would push back the likelihood of war. The U.N. measure, which would authorize ``all necessary means'' to get Iraq out of Kuwait after that deadline, is to be voted on Thursday. Prices had been unchanged at midday when an annual fire drill closed the trading floor for one half hour. The session turned bearish when it reopened. Buyers' enthusiasm also was dampened by news that Indonesia's president Suharto warned the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries of a possible oil glut if the Persian Gulf crisis ends. ``We have a very narrow trading range even with all the news,'' said Brian Tagler, a broker at Lehman Brothers Inc. Contracts for delivery of crude in later months all closed higher. Home heating oil settled .89 cents lower at 91.49 cents a gallon for December delivery contracts. Contracts for later months were mixed, mainly due to seasonal factors. Unleaded gasoline settled up .52 cents at 84.72 cents per gallon on December deliver contracts, with other delivery months mixed. Natural gas futures were off for the day, with January delivery contracts falling 7.8 cents to $2.54 per 1,000 cubic feet. February contracts dropped 4.7 cents to $2.423 per 1,000 cubic feet, with all later delivery months down as well. After the market closed, the leading oil industry group released weekly figures showing that the nation's supply of crude oil remained below 1989 levels. The U.S. stockpile of crude dropped to 337.1 million barrels last week, compared with 341.2 million barrels a week earlier and 344.0 million barrels a year earlier, the American Petroleum Institute reported. The stockpile of distillates, which include home heating oil, were slightly higher at 134.8 million barrels compared with 134.5 million barrels a week earlier but well above 119.6 million barrels a year earlier. The gasoline stockpile was up slightly to 218.3 million barrels from 217.3 million barrels a week earlier, but remained below year-ago inventories of 222.1 million barrels. The nation's refineries ran at 83 percent of capacity, compared with 83.2 percent a week earlier and 86.1 percent a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Administrative Law Judge Rules Against Utility Merger
DOC.TEXT: An administrative law judge recommended rejection Tuesday of the proposed $2.5 billion merger between San Diego Gas & Electric Co. and Southern California Edison, saying the deal would create a monopoly. Officials of both companies immediately said they would challenge the recommendation by George P. Lewnes, an administrative judge for the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. ``The sole conceivable beneficiaries in the long term will be (Edison) and its shareholders,'' Lewnes wrote. ``Meanwhile the market loses an efficient and vigorous competitor, SDG&E, while the surviving corporation gains greater market power and acquires all of the monopolistic anticompetitive advantages attendant thereto.'' The utilities have 30 days to file briefs to the five-member FERC responding to Lewnes' ruling. The commission's decision won't come until next year. ``We're not surprised with the decision and will appeal to the full commission to reverse this result,'' Lee Haney, SDG&E's chief financial officer, said in a statement. ``We believe that the record supports the nearly $1.7 billion in merger benefits an that the antitrust conditions agreed to with the Department of Justice resolve any competitive concerns.'' Administrative law judges for the state Public Utilities Commission have yet to file their recommendations on the proposed merger. The merger must receive approval by both the FERC and the state PUC. The proposed merger was approved by the boards of directors of both companies in November 1988 and by the companies' stockholders in April 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Judge Approves $135 Million for Eastern
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge Tuesday granted Eastern Airlines a lifesaving $135 million infusion to keep it flying through winter and avoid repeated requests for money that have sapped public confidence in the carrier. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland said he approved the emergency request in part because of government statements that chaos could occur if Eastern closes down during the holiday season. Eastern said it sought the money because bad publicity had worsened its financial outlook, spooked potential passengers and made credit-card companies nervous about doing business with the carrier. The emergency cash request from Eastern was far more than it had anticipated asking for only a few weeks ago when the judge permitted the ailing airline to withdraw an immediate $15 million from an escrow fund. At the time, the judge said Eastern could get another $15 million if it met certain cash projections as of Dec. 3. In the latest grant, Lifland went ahead and gave Eastern the $15 million, plus $120 million more. The judge placed $15 million in a contingency fund to be used if creditors demand the airline put up cash deposits before customers do business with it. The money is intended to keep Eastern alive through March, avoiding the need for repeated requests for additional money. ``Under all these circumstances, it seems inappropriate to constantly come back at these short intervals where the adverse publicity will be repeated again and again,'' Lifland said. The judge also chastised the unsecured creditors' committee for creating tension in Eastern's business through comments to the media that their goal is to close and liquidate the carrier. He said the committees had a fiduciary duty to Eastern. Eastern's court-appointed trustee, Martin R. Shugrue Jr., praised the judge for giving Eastern ``a vote of confidence.'' The latest Eastern request for cash fanned the anger of unsecured creditors who have been demanding that the court close down the airline, which has been in financial distress since a crippling strike in March 1989. ``A liquidation of Eastern is inevitable,'' creditor attorney Joel B. Zweibel said in a court filing opposing the cash infusion. ``It should begin now before further funds are wasted and while Christmas holiday travelers have several weeks to rearrange their plans.'' After the judge approved the request, Zweibel said creditors would meet to determine their next move. Shugrue said the airline needed to know that it would have access to a much larger supply of cash so it could make long-term plans. ``We simply cannot run the business on a rolling 15-day time frame,'' he testified at the hearing in Manhattan's federal bankruptcy court. Shugrue said bad publicity from Eastern's previous requests for money caused passengers to shy away from the airline. Moreover, he said, credit card companies were starting to demand that the airline provide millions of dollars up front for charged tickets in case Eastern goes out of business. The unsecured creditors, who are owed about $1 billion by the airline, say Eastern has virtually no chance of becoming a viable airline amid industrywide troubles brought on by higher fuel costs and sluggish demand for air travel. Shugrue has said Eastern stands a good chance of reaching the break-even point early next year through a marketing strategy that offers first-class seats at coach-class prices. But he told the judge Tuesday that Eastern not only needed the $15 million Lifland had agreed to release in early December, but another $120 million to keep Eastern operating through the first quarter of 1991. Eastern spokeswoman Karen Ceramsak said seeking money from the court a little at a time would lead to relentlessly bad publicity hinting that the airline was almost dead, which could become a self-fulfilling prophesy if travelers decide to fly with the competition. So Eastern decided to take a stab at getting operating funds through March at once, Ceremsak said. ``We think it's necessary to restore consumer confidence and build advance bookings,'' she said. ``We sustained significant damage as a result of the liquidation talk.'' At the hearing earlier this month, Shugrue had told the judge that Eastern would need a total of $80 million in a series of payments from the escrow fund through early January. After that, Eastern did not believe it would need to tap any more cash from the fund, and instead hoped to quickly repay the money, he said. But Eastern officials said Tuesday that talk of Eastern's possible liquidation cost it unforeseen cancellations and other problems that could cost $70 million. Miami-based Eastern, one of the industry's oldest and most troubled airlines, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and reorganization March 9, 1989, after unions crippled the airline with a strike. The airline is now smaller than its pre-strike size, staffed with strike replacements and some unionists who returned to work. But the Machinists union remains on strike. Shugrue was appointed trustee last April after creditors lost faith in Eastern's management.

DOC.HEAD: TV Networks Bemoan Latest Foreign Buyout of Hollywood Studio
With AM-Hollywood Goes Foreign Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The big television networks are using the latest foreign buyout of a Hollywood studio to bolster their effort to trash federal rules they say leave them at a disadvantage in the global entertainment market. CBS, ABC and NBC each cited Monday's announcement that Japan's Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. had agreed to buy the American entertainment giant MCA Inc. in a $6.6 billion deal as evidence that foreign-owned companies have a head start on them in marshaling resources for quality programs. The deal comes only three weeks before the Federal Communications Commission's Dec. 14 hearing on the financial interest and syndication rules. The 20-year-old ``fin-syn'' rules prohibit the three major TV networks from having financial interests in shows they don't own and from getting into the lucrative business of selling network programs in the $3 billion syndication market for reruns on local TV stations, cable networks and foreign markets. The rules have effectively barred the networks from bidding for production companies even as foreign companies have swooped in to buy four of the seven biggest U.S. studios, including three in the past 14 months. Laurence A. Tisch, president and chief executive at CBS Inc., said the MCA deal ``accelerates the dizzying pace of consolidation in Hollywood.'' ``This has happened under the financial interest rules that give foreign-owned studios competitive advantages over the three American networks. There is no more eloquent testimony for repeal of these rules than these transactions and the consolidation they have fostered,'' he said. Sony Corp. of Japan bought Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. in September 1989 and Italian-controlled Pathe Communications Corp. recently completed a buyout of MGM-UA Communications Inc. Rupert Murdoch's News Corp., based in Australia, has owned 20th Century Fox Corp. since 1985. There was some indication that policymakers in Washington are hearing the networks' complaints. FCC Chairman Alfred Sikes said the deal ``will almost certainly affect the debate'' and added the commission must consider ``the trend toward vertical integration in the entertainment business ... in concluding what restraints the networks should face, if any, in their efforts to integrate.'' Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee which oversees the FCC and telecommunications policy, said the MCA deal ``is an event of considerable significance'' and said his committee would be interested to see what comes of the FCC examination of the fin-syn rules. Entertainment is one of the few areas in which the U.S. enjoys a trade surplus, the congressman said. ``Our regulatory system should not protect foreign-owned companies at the expense of American enterprise,'' he said. Hollywood studios and producers support the rules because they fear that the networks as ``gatekeepers of the airwaves'' would have too much power if they could also have a stake in programs. ``The three major national networks say whether a show goes on the air or not,'' said Jerry Leider, chairman of the caucus of independent writers, producers and directors. ``It doesn't make a difference whether MCA is owned by a foreign interests or not.'' He said without the fin-syn rules, the networks would soon dominate the production business by demanding concessions on syndication sales from producers trying to get a show on the network. But the networks argue their power over programming has been diluted by the proliferation of alternatives such as independent TV stations and cable TV. Richard Cotton, general counsel for the National Broadcasting Co., said the MCA deal leaves only three major U.S.-owned Hollywood studio companies - Paramount Communications Inc., Walt Disney Co. and Time Warner Inc. ``The great irony in this development is that U.S. regulatory policy is actually contributing to the demise of U.S. competitiveness in the global entertainment sector,'' Cotton said. At Capital Cities-ABC Inc., spokeswoman Julie Hoover said the deal showed the ``anachronism of rules that prevent the three domestic network companies from competing effectively in the global and domestic environment.'' Leider, who was co-chairman of the committee representing the studios and producers in unsuccessful talks with the networks last summer over changes in the fin-syn rules, said he expects the rules will be modified. ``We have an an enlightened FCC that sees the wisdom of safeguards,'' he said. ``I don't think Chairman Sikes has indicated in that statement that the rules will be repealed.''

DOC.HEAD: Chevron Announces Start-Up Of Point Arguello Offshore Oil Project
DOC.TEXT: The $2.2 billion Point Arguello offshore oil facility, which has been dormant since its completion two years ago, will begin pumping crude within a few months, Chevron Corp. announced Tuesday. The San Francisco-based company, the largest of 18 partners in the project, also said it would build a new multi-million dollar underground pipeline to ship oil to refineries in the Los Angeles area. Completion of that project would take at least three, Chevron spokesman Mike Libbey said. The Point Arguello project is about 10 miles off Point Conception, which is about 150 miles northwest of Los Angeles. The consortium wants to ship heavy crude via double-hulled vessels to refineries in the Los Angeles area. However, Santa Barbara County officials on Nov. 12 rejected a proposal by the U.S. Department of Energy to use tankers for interim hauling of 40,000 barrels daily while a pipeline was being built. The consortium then decided to begin producing 20,000 barrels per day and send it to Northern California via the All-American Pipeline, which needs a five-mile connection to a Unocal refinery near Santa Maria, Libbey said. Unocal would use about 10,000 to 15,000 barrels per day, and the remainder will be shipped to refineries in the Bakersfield area or in Contra Costa County near San Francisco, he said. ``The ultimate preferred destination is Los Angeles because that's where the need is ... it's the biggest gasoline market in the world,'' Libbey said. He also said the company preferred to transport the high-sulfer, or sour, crude via pipeline, not tanker, but that the consortium would still push for using ships while the Los Angeles pipeline was being built. An appeal of the Santa Barbara County decision was filed Tuesday with the California Coastal Commission, he said, and a hearing is expected within a few months. Point Arguello is permitted to produce up to 100,000 barrels of heavy crude per day. The project was built in the early 1980s on the assumption that oil prices would be between $40 and $80 per barrel. Earlier this year, when oil prices dropped below $20 per barrel, Chevron officials said the partners would have lost money on every barrel produced, and the company took a $445 million write-down against its fourth-quarter 1989 profits. However, Chevron officials said that bringing in any amount of cash from the Point Arguello project would help defray its costs.
